fields.headline: Trisha Yearwood
fields.standfirst:
Trisha Yearwood
Royal Albert Hall, London ***
fields.trailText:
Trisha Yearwood
Royal Albert Hall, London ***
fields.body:
Amazingly, Trisha Yearwood now has nine albums to her name, which, as she pointed out, can cause a few problems when selecting songs for live performance. Her catalogue is bursting with pop/country/ AOR hits, like the gruesome, schlocky How Do I Live (from the movie Con-Air), and these tend to be the ones that receive the most prominence; but Yearwood is more interesting when she veers away from the lacquered veneer of the mainstream and tackles some earthier material.

The best part of this show was when she was joined onstage by her friend and support act Kim Richey, whose own album Glimmer is due any moment and is well worth an earful. Dispatching her band into the wings, Yearwood duetted with Richey on Those Words We Said and You Won't Matter Any More, both peerless exercises in close-harmony singing with a simple acoustic guitar accompaniment. Stick these two onstage in a club with beer-bottles and sawdust on the floor and you'd have a night to remember.

But mainstream Trisha was what most of the punters had come to hear, and they didn't go home disappointed. She flashed back to 1992 for Walkaway Joe, dutifully dredged up the trite country-rock of XXXs and OOOs, sang The Song Remembers When as if it had a title that made sense, and reserved the glutinously heartrending Bus to St Cloud for her final encore. Thankfully she also slipped in some less obvious material, and some droll between-song patter. There was rather a good Stevie Nicks impersonation, and some self-deprecating stuff about the predominance of tear-jerkers in her set.

Meanwhile, Perfect Love gave guitarist Johnny Garcia scope to whack out some snarly rock'n'roll chords, while Steve Cox waxed Tom Petty-ish at the keyboards. Another of Richey's songs, Believe Me Baby (I Lied), likewise benefited from the band hitting a beefy rock stride. Acoustic guitars were wheeled out for Some Days Are Better Than Others, allowing Yearwood to explore some rootsier terrain. Needless to say, her voice was as impeccable as her shining mane of blond hair. If only Yearwood wasn't so resoundingly successful: then she could afford to be a lot less slick.

Trisha Yearwood plays the Clyde Auditorium, Glasgow (0141-287 7777), tomorrow.

webTitle: Richard Reeves: The way we work

fields.headline: Why we should ditch the 9 to 5
fields.standfirst:
Richard Reeves: The way we work

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Richard Reeves: The way we work
fields.body:
As a workplace question, "How are you?" has only three acceptable answers: "Stressed"; "Oh, you know, really busy";"Frantic, absolutely frantic." Any other answer, especially one that implies you are not running around like a headless chicken, can be taken as a sign of slacking.

Stress and activity are the new white-collar sources of identity. I don't have time to think, therefore I am. And the trouble is that once one person plays the stress card, the pressure to conform is huge. Forget the business struggle: the busyness battle is where it's at. We are engaged in a craziness competition.

Of course, it is not enough to say you are rushed off your feet - you have to be seen to be busy to be believed. Herein lie the roots of the presenteeism culture flowering in many workplaces. It is no good being frantically busy where no one can see you, after all.

The pressure to stick around is not new: Napoleon used to leave a bust in a lighted window so his generals thought he was still working. Now, though, the senior people are the most likely to work long hours and expect others to follow suit.

Robert Kennedy, investigating union-mob ties in the US in 1957, and in particular the role of the Teamsters Union boss Jimmy Hoffa, was heading home one night when he saw lights still on in the Teamsters HQ. Bobby ordered the car to turn around and went back to work. Hoffa, learning of this, ordered the lights left on every night. The exhausted Kennedy didn't get his man (not until 1964, anyway).

The visible busyness craze is particularly absurd given the rise of IT. Not just because laptops, modems and mobiles make it easier to work outside the workplace, but because computers have made it easier than ever to avoid work in the workplace. A person sitting at a desk looking at a screen is "working". Oh really? Chances are they are emailing their mates, booking holiday flights or paying their phone bill. That's why firms are rushing around blocking access to internet sites, monitoring email and devising policies designed to make people use their PCs for work rather than play.

IT can and should support flexible working. And everyone is in favour of flexibility. The problem is that there are two kinds: corporate flexibility and worker flexibility. When firms say they want their staff to work flexibly, outside of "normal" hours (whatever they are now), they mean on top of those hours. Workers want the flexibility to work hours instead of the fixed ones: in a recent survey by the Institute of Directors, just 20% of employees said they wanted a fixed nine-to-five, 50% wanted flexibility between 7.30am and 7.30pm, and the rest wanted to work any time.

Working time is still based on an industrial era in which workers needed to be physically present, slacking was quickly spotted and control of bodies was more important than control of brains. Work is moving back towards a more fluid, pre-industrial pattern, with bursts of productivity followed by more fallow, reflective periods. The eight-hour, five-day week is a straitjacket on this kind of working. It is fine to work in the evening so long as you don't have to clock on at 9am the next day. Control over working hours - and the ability to work at times that make sense to us as individuals - is the key, rather than the number of hours worked. It is time sovereignty we should be fighting for now.

It is difficult for many managers to let go of the need to see their staff to know they are working. But the truth is that different people work better at different times of day and under different circumstances. Would Archimedes have shouted "Eureka!" from behind an office partition? Let's ditch the nine-to-five and the "clocking on" culture, and work according to our own individual patterns. For in work, as in much else, timing is everything.

That Friday feeling

There is now another reason to Thank God it's Friday. Certain merchant banks have discovered that people who are fired on Fridays are more likely to take their own lives than those "let go" on another day. As a result, Friday firings have been banned. The theory is that the routine of a normal weekday - and the fact that recruitment agencies are open - allows victims to feel they are taking control of the situation. Saturday and Sunday just allow the news to fester and sink in, apparently. "It is our idea of being humane," says one director of a major bank that has adopted the policy. So that's the good news. The bad news: today is Wednesday.

Richard Reeves is director of futures at the Industrial Society. You can contact him at rreeves@indsoc.co.uk.

fields.headline: Cinematic Orchestra
fields.standfirst:
Cinematic Orchestra
Ronnie Scott's, London ****
fields.trailText:
Cinematic Orchestra
Ronnie Scott's, London ****
fields.body:
There are upholders of orthodox jazz music who would be bewildered if confronted with Jason Swinscoe's riotous take on jazz. Although the Cinematic Orchestra respects the music, this is far from the jazz that patrons of Ronnie Scott's are used to. Signed to Ninja Tune, home of the quirky and experimental, the Orchestra are extravagantly polystylistic.

Swinscoe, the tactician of the band, records live jazz sessions and then samples, sequences and stretches the sources beyond recognition. What results has a grandiose sweep; and yet, this orchestra is actually only a quintet: Tom Chant (piano/ soprano sax), Phil France (bass), Luke Flowers (drums), Patrick Carpenter (turntable and electronics) and Swinscoe (leader, sequencer, sampler).

Swinscoe fashioned the night's meditative music with ease, conducting the group from behind his sequencer. Slipping between piano and saxophone, Chant established an intimate conversational tone with his sonorous playing. Carpenter cut up ghostly samples of Martin Luther King and other familiar voices into dreamy sci-fi sequences. As Swinscoe turned a deep house groove into a slow throb, the woman next to me gushed that this was "ecstasy music": an accurate description.

Although the concept and playing are clever, only one listen is necessary to take it all in. The Orchestra are concerned more with rhythm and texture than melody, and while the band as a whole were great, there was something about the drummer, Flowers, that really bowled you over. His playing was perfect: each hit was so explosive that he seemed to be shaking the ground the other musicians stood on. For once, the traditional power relationship that relegates the rhythm section to mere accompanists was toppled over.

fields.headline: Net leaves UK plc trailing
fields.standfirst:
New economy, old problems: Blair dream endangered as Germany powers into cyberspace

Money Unlimited
Net news
fields.trailText: Britain is in danger of being left behind in Europe's emergent internet economy, a leading accountancy firm warned yesterday. Germany is powering ahead, according to PricewaterhouseCoopers, unsettling Tony Blair's hopes of making Britain the leading new economy.
fields.body:
Britain is in danger of being left behind in Europe's emergent internet economy, a leading accountancy firm warned yesterday. Germany is powering ahead, according to PricewaterhouseCoopers, unsettling Tony Blair's hopes of making Britain the leading new economy.

In a survey of Europe's biggest internet companies, more than a third of the largest 150 are German. Britain has only 35 in the top rank.

The German market is more mature, with half of the businesses surveyed already in profit compared with little more than a quarter of British net firms. Kevin Ellis, a partner with PwC, said the Germans were bolstered by better access to the web.

The survey findings will pile further political pressure on British Telecom which has been criticised for holding up the introduction of broadband services. Rivals have accused the former monopoly of dragging its feet over the break-up of its local network next year.

The head of one internet company also pointed to the success of the German Neuer Markt as one reason for the gap with Britain.

"The Neuer Markt is largely responsible for the success of e-commerce companies in Germany... It makes it easier to raise money and make acquisitions," said Raphael Fuchs, chief operating officer of europeaninvestor.com, which operates websites for other companies and provides financial information. Frankfurt moved faster than London to set up a specialist market dedicated to hi-tech companies, so Germany had become a natural focus for investors looking to back young companies with high growth potential.

It was not all bad news for Britain. The PwC survey noted clear evidence of better management, leading to lower costs and reduced "cash burn" - the rate at which money is consumed by a start-up business.

The average burn rate is now 20 months before the need to raise new money, an increase of seven months since last December. One company in the survey slowed its burn rate by up to four times.

Mr Ellis said: "I am surprised at how much companies appear to have taken action to improve their burn rates. Forty-two out of 150 are not burning cash any more, which is encouraging. It means that people are moving into the next stage of development."

High risk

The survey ranked 20 of the 150 companies as being at "high risk" of running out of cash within a year unless they act. It does not name the individual stocks because of concern that this could upset the still volatile internet market. "At risk is a combined market capitalisation of €26bn (£16bn), representing more than 10% of the European market," the report said.

PwC also found a difference between consumer businesses - known as B2C - and business to business (B2B) companies. B2C companies are more vulnerable with an average burn rate of 15 months, compared to 23 months for B2B organisations, due to higher marketing costs.

There are also sector distinctions, with software and infrastructure internet companies performing better than content producers and internet service providers.

Rivals doubted PwC's findings. Richard Punt, head of e-business at Deloitte and Touche, said it was difficult to conclude that Germany was the dominant country because the survey was based on market value and ignored factors such as funding types or internet penetration.

Peter Bradshaw, head of internet research at Merrill Lynch, said: "To us the report looks like gross misrepresentation of a few figures."

Mr Ellis concluded that the next six months will see consolidation in the internet sector, with some big success stories but some more big failures. "There still will be some failures because this is a start-up area in a brand new sector, but failures don't necessarily mean it's the end of the sector or a disaster."

fields.headline: Quinteto Piazzolla
fields.standfirst:
Quinteto Piazzolla ****
Barbican Hall, London
fields.trailText:
Quinteto Piazzolla ****
Barbican Hall, London
fields.body:
To think of the Argentine tango is to luxuriate in the musical embodiment of Latin-American sensuality. But for the composer Astor Piazzolla, who died in 1991, the tango was much more than the most familiar badge of Argentine identity. Using techniques learned from his classical training - he studied in Paris with the doyenne of 20th-century neoclassicism, Nadia Boulanger - he created the so-called "new tango" style. His compositions, nearly all of which use the frame of the tango's infectious rhythms and melodic immediacy, are extraordinarily various, complex and expressive.

The Quinteto Piazzolla, formed after the composer's death and comprising his colleagues and some of Argentina's most famous instrumentalists, closed the Barbican's weekend-long Argentine Music and Film Festival. At the centre of the ensemble is the most typical of Argentinian instruments, the bandoneon - a sweet-toned, small-scale accordion - played by Nester Marconi. Surrounding Marconi's beautifully crafted playing was an ensemble of violin, piano, guitar and double bass.

Many of Piazzolla's works featured each player as a soloist in extrovert, concertante passages. Fernando Suarez Paz's virtuosity on violin soared over the rest of the band, alternating fiery intensity with bravura showmanship. Nicolas Ledesma's piano playing was showcased by a solo composed in Piazzolla's most consciously "classical" idiom - a cross between the harmonies of Debussy and the tango's earthy rhythms.

Each individual number contained a cornucopia of ideas, styles and references. The second veered from a conventionally languid tango tune to mock-Baroque harmonic progressions, avant-garde instrumental effects, and a coda of effete, refined trills. Another piece was a dreamscape of cricket and bird calls - characterised by violin yelps, double bass slaps and the clacking of the bandoneon's keys - over the continuous traditional tango bassline.

The most obvious expression of Piazzolla's twin musical allegiances was a piece conceived as a tango and composed as a strict fugue. Piazzolla created a work that is both authentically a tango and an authentic fugue - a deft compositional trick. But he is not afraid, in other numbers, to indulge in the tango's sheer sensuousness. Throughout, the Quinteto Piazzolla revealed the enormous range of Piazzolla's creative universe, and his transformation of the tango into a multifaceted musical form.

fields.headline: Snow Patrol
fields.standfirst:
Snow Patrol
Music Box, Manchester ***
fields.trailText:
Snow Patrol

Music Box, Manchester ***
fields.body:
Hailing from Ireland but now living in Scotland, Snow Patrol began life as the Polar Bears until threatened with a writ by an American band of the same name. Nevertheless, they showed a defiantly cheeky wit by hanging on to the glacial theme with their new moniker, and by calling their first album, Songs for Polar Bears.

That was two years ago, and Snow Patrol have lost none of their icy humour or energy. With his perma-grin and look of frozen astonishment, frontman and ever-ready joker Gary Lightbody opened the set with a confession: "Generally," he says, "we're full of shit."

You'd be wise not to believe him, because what followed was 35 minutes of power-pop that was so fierce, the amps were in perpetual wobble.

Snow Patrol record as a three-piece, but they usually pinch an extra guitarist from Belle and Sebastian. For this show at Manchester's In the City convention, they secured the low-slung services of ex-Black Graper Wags. He wandered about the stage in his inimitably shaggy fashion looking for the odd lost chord, but otherwise fitted in well with the band's thrashy rock.

There was a lot going on here: on top of the shrieking guitars, punishing bass, and relentlessly driving drums, there were wailing sirens, breakbeat scratches and samples, and Lightbody's impassioned vocals. Despite the racket, he veered more towards pop vocals: his were nicely pitched with a light and catchy intonation, and they worked well against the hectic layers of sound when not lost beneath them. That said, he can do a good scream when the mood hits him.

When it all came together - for Chased By, I Don't Know, Black and Blue, and their last single, Starfighter Pilot - the result was awesome: all three guitarists attacked their instruments as if strangling the necks of murderous geese. Meanwhile, over the rhythmic racket, sampled messages such as "You ain't gonna be around for long" added to the feeling that Snow Patrol want to mess with your head.

What's most striking about the band, though, is their versatility: they flit between a thunderous belligerence and the delicate touches of a genuine pop sensibility. Next single Ask Me How I Am is an exquisite pop song, all lush melodies and stalactite riffs. It was given a sleazed-up workout here. Likewise, On Off (from their forthcoming album, When It's All Over We Still Have to Clear Up) was a wonderful whisper of a song, and this time the advice, "No one's perfect", returned us to a more forgiving world.

Snow Patrol are at Qudos, QMU, Glasgow (0141-339 8383), tonight, then tour.

He wandered about the stage in his inimitably shaggy fashion looking for the odd lost chord, but otherwise fitted in well with the band's thrashy rock. There was a lot going on here: on top of the shrieking guitars, punishing bass, and relentlessly driving drums, there were wailing sirens, breakbeat scratches and samples, and Lightbody's impassioned vocals. Despite the racket, he veered more towards pop vocals: his were nicely pitched with a light and catchy intonation, and they worked well against the hectic layers of sound when not lost beneath them. That said, he can do a good scream when the mood hits him. When it all came together - for Chased By, I Don't Know, Black and Blue, and their last single, Starfighter Pilot - the result was awesome: all three guitarists attacked their instruments as if strangling the necks of murderous geese. Meanwhile, over the rhythmic racket, sampled messages such as "You ain't gonna be around for long" added to the feeling that Snow Patrol want to mess with your head. What's most striking about the band, though, is their versatility: they flit between a thunderous belligerence and the delicate touches of a genuine pop sensibility. Next single Ask Me How I Am is an exquisite pop song, all lush melodies and stalactite riffs. It was given a sleazed-up workout here. Likewise, On Off (from their forthcoming album, When It's All Over We Still Have to Clear Up) was a wonderful whisper of a song, and this time the advice, "No one's perfect", returned us to a more forgiving world. Snow Patrol are at Qudos, QMU, Glasgow (0141-339 8383), tonight, then tour.

fields.headline: Cleveland Watkiss
fields.standfirst:
Cleveland Watkiss
Jazz Cafe, London ***
fields.trailText:
Cleveland Watkiss
Jazz Cafe, London ***
fields.body:
Grooving in a silver satin shirt, wearing sunglasses at night, Cleveland Watkiss promises early in his set that "We're gonna come on to you from every kinda direction". It might sound like conventional soul man schmooze, but firing sounds through different musical tangents is Watkiss's forte. A founder member of influential young ensemble the Jazz Warriors with Courtney Pine in 1985, his subsequent incarnations included a move to drum'n'bass MCing in the 1990s, playing dance music festivals and touring his own event, Club 21st Century. In contrast, this show is a more intimate, jazzily laid-back affair, mainly previewing songs from his third album, Victory's Happy Songbook.

Initially, complications with the sound system and the noise of conversation from the venue's bar prove annoyingly distracting. But Watkiss and his current ensemble the Source are assured, adept performers, and by the drawn-out second number, Blessing in Disguise (taken from Watkiss's 1991 album of the same title), they evince an absorbingly spiritual ambience. Watkiss namechecks his players repeatedly during the set; many of them head their own outfits, such as superbly dexterous pianist Alex Wilson, virtuoso trumpet/flugelhorn player Byron Wallen, and the intricate guitarist Ciyo Brown (who also lends some fine backing vocals). When Watkiss declares that these are "some of the baddest musicians in the country", the audience cheer in agreement. Indie music might generally be pigeonholed as rock, but this is a fresh, genuinely free-spirited alternative.

Occasionally, Watkiss's lyrics border on the banal - "I believe in miracles, I believe in dreams" being one nondescript sentiment. But it's the sounds rather than specific words that convey his music's raw emotion and beauty, whether he's presenting older material, such as Green Chimneys (setting vocals to his hero Thelonious Monk's instrumental) or the newer compositions encompassing earthy dub, muscular double bass, funky brass, rich keyboards and lithe percussion. Most of all, Watkiss's voice can sound wondrous: when he holds onto a note, it evolves from soulful croon to human beatbox, rounding off with didgeridoo effects. He freestyles with ease. No doubt as a consequence of his work with Asian breakbeats pioneer Talvin Singh (he collaborated on Singh's Mercury awardwinning album OK in 1999), Watkiss has taken to incorporating complex classical Indian stylings into his rapid-fire scat jazz vocals. It's a thrilling, innovative yet harmonious fusion. Whenever Watkiss adds new directions to his musical journey, he's in his element.

webTitle: Burton leaves a stain on the net

fields.headline: Burton leaves a stain on the net
fields.trailText: Director Tim Burton is to debut a series of animated short films about Stain Boy, his superhero creation, on the internet
fields.body:
Sleepy Hollow director Tim Burton is to debut his latest creation, a series of animated short films about his superhero character Stain Boy, on the internet.

The charcoal-drawn character is an ineffectual but diligent superhero whose only talent seems to be leaving stains wherever he goes. He first appeared in Burton's book, The Melancholy Death of Oyster Boy & Other Stories.

The first 13 five-minute "webisodes" are being produced as part of a licensing deal Burton has signed with Shockwave.com. As well as the stories, fans will also be able to play Stain Boy games, collect trading cards and email postcards from the site.

The deal resembles pacts Shockwave.com has signed with South Park creators Matt Stone and Trey Parker and Twin Peaks director David Lynch to create their own series of animated short films.

fields.headline: Spike Jonze joins Atom films
fields.trailText: Atom Films has announced that Spike Jonze is to become a creative consultant for the online film company
fields.body:
Atom Films announced today that Spike Jonze (pictured) is to become a creative consultant for the online film company. The academy-award winning actor and director, whose last project, Being John Malkovich, was a huge critical and box-office success, will "counsel Atom on creative directions and artistic relations" and "actively take a part in Atom's long-term vision to support independent filmmakers and animators."

His role will primarily involve recruiting new film-makers on short film projects for the company. "I'm excited to be working with a company that helps filmmakers show their work without having to go through traditional distribution channels," said Jonze.

Jonze will also join a team of Atom artists to create three original shorts for the site. A number of his earlier shorts, including Amarillo by Morning and How They Get There will also be available to view on the site.

"We are thrilled to be working with Spike who shares Atom's vision towards empowering artists," said Atom's senior vice president, Heather Redman.

webTitle: Theatre review: Mendes wages war at the Donmar

fields.headline: Sam Mendes wages war at the Donmar
fields.standfirst:
To the Green Fields Beyond
Donmar Warehouse, London ****
fields.trailText:
To the Green Fields Beyond
Donmar Warehouse, London ****
fields.body:
Originally it was going to be Twelfth Night. Instead Sam Mendes marks his theatrical return by directing a new play by Nick Whitby about the first world war. Given the subject, it can hardly fail to move. But the evening, in its precise casting, command of mood and gradual accumulation of suspense, also reminds us why Mendes really is a great director.

The setting is France in 1918. The characters are mainly members of an elite, hand-picked tank-crew who seem to have been blessed by fortune. Now, on the eve of a major battle, they are doubly unnerved. First there is the arrival of a probing American journalist seeking some image that will encapsulate this most hellish of wars. Even more disturbing is the crew's apprehension of certain death: the feeling that the protective spirit has abandoned them. So they seriously debate whether in battle they should nobble their machine and thus ensure their survival.

Up to its last quarter hour, this strikes me as an honest, unglamorous portrait of war. Whitby, whose previous convictions include a South American trilogy, has clearly done his homework. He knows all about Mark IV tanks, about the provision of prostitutes for men on the edge of battle and about the death-fixated "holy friars" who scented carnage. Even more importantly, he understands fear: in a sense, the play is an extension of the eve-of-Agincourt passage from Henry V, where Williams says that though they may see the beginning of the day, "I think we shall never see the end of it".

I don't doubt the accuracy of Whitby's portrait, even down to the presence of Punjab and Caribbean gunners and technicians. His play is also saltily written and emotionally affecting: there's a heart-stopping moment when one of the crew first indicates to the Belgian prostitute that death is inevitable. But, without revealing the climax, it has a touch of what Paul Fussell called "the chivalric mystique of self-sacrifice" which war-poets like Siegfried Sassoon and Wilfred Owen did so much to deflate. Whitby resolves the death-or-life debate theatrically but not intellectually.

The flaws are camouflaged, however, by Mendes's production, by Anthony Ward's afforested design and by the quality of the acting. Dougray Scott as the socialist-mystic chief, Ray Winstone as the ruggedly honest tank-driver, Finbar Lynch as the vehement proponent of survival, Adrian Scarborough as the working-class religious believer and Nitin Ganatra as the Punjabi gunner stand out in a first- rate ensemble. Mendes both brings out each character's singularity and reminds us that war, like theatre, relies on mutual dependence. Rather than take the safe option of reviving a classic, he has also showcased a promising writer who, whatever his faults, clearly understands the disciplines of war.

Until November 25. Box office: 020-7369 1732.

webTitle: Is your office making you ill?

fields.headline: Is your office making you ill?
fields.standfirst:
Is it the air conditioning? The photocopier? The lights? The computers? As new research reveals more dangers in the workplace, Anita Chaudhuri unravels the mystery of sick building syndrome

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Is it the air conditioning? The photocopier? The lights? The computers? As new research reveals more dangers in the workplace, Anita Chaudhuri unravels the mystery of sick building syndrome.
fields.body:
It is either one of the biggest daily hazards of modern working life or a myth concocted by the idle to justify their laziness: it all depends on your perspective. For those who believe in it, sick building syndrome has long been thought to stem from poorly maintained air conditioning systems, toxic photocopiers and dusty offices. Now, in a curious echo of another of our greatest workplace fears, it seems the explanation could lie in a particularly nasty form of computer virus.

According to a team of Swedish scientists, flame-retardant chemicals used in plastic computer casings could be to blame. The researchers conducted experiments which showed how, as computers heated up during the course of the working day, they began to emit into the air an allergenic chemical, triphenyl phosphate. Eighteen leading brands of computer were tested and now the experts are urging manufacturers to "bake off" new computers for 10 days to release the worst of the chemicals before they arrive in office buildings.

The discovery may finally provide the evidence needed to convince those who still need convincing that sick building syndrome has a scientific basis, instead of being a malingerer's charter. The Health and Safety Executive, which monitors office environments, estimates that between a third and a half of all new or re-conditioned buildings are afflicted; the employees at highest risk, according to a recent study by the University of Strathclyde, are clerical workers who wear contact lenses and work at computers in air-conditioned buildings. Airborne bacteria in such offices, which often have low levels of humidity, become electrically charged and settle on computer screens or on contact lenses, or are breathed in.

The travels of bacteria around offices and into workers' nostrils may not be an appetising field of study, but professor Derek Clements-Croome of Reading University has made it his own. The author of Creating the Productive Workplace, Clements-Croome advises companies on how to avoid sick building syndrome. He talks zealously about "the emotional content of space" and is evangelical about improving the quality of air in the workplace.

"It takes just four seconds for a single breath to travel from your nostrils to your blood supply," he says. "But if the air is stuffy or polluted, you can't oxygenate that breath, so you become tired and sluggish."

His research notwithstanding, the most alarming thing about the bacteria with which we share our workspaces is how little we know them. "The biggest problem with these types of airborne chemicals is that we don't yet know the effects of long-term exposure to them," says Professor Vyvyan Howard, a toxicologist at Liverpool University. "They are pernicious because you breathe them in but then the body doesn't get rid of them. They are fat-soluble and persistent - our bodies retain the toxic chemicals. If you're a woman and become pregnant, experiments have shown you pass a dose to your child. In the past 20 years, there's been a 60-fold increase in these compounds in breast milk - and in the last five years the figure has doubled."

Likely effects of exposure can include skin rashes, allergic reactions akin to hay fever, tiredness and flu-like symptoms. So far the only known way to alleviate the effects is really vigorous ventilation - not exactly a speciality of most British offices.

When companies ask Clements-Croome about the ideal office space, he sends them to Japan, to the Kajima building in Tokyo. There they have an atrium filled with birdsong and a scented garden. "There's music, but it's not constant - human beings like contrast and change. From time to time, people walk by and offer trays of refreshments. You don't order from a cafeteria, they just bring you things so you feel cared for.

"The mistake architects make when designing office spaces is that they appeal only to the aesthetic. Office environments need to stimulate all five senses in a harmonious way. That means providing a good amount of natural light, nice smells and no jarring background noise. Touch is often forgotten - we need to be surrounded by natural surfaces such as glass, wood and stone."

That's all very well for moneyed multinationals moving into new premises, but even companies stuck with decrepit buildings can go a long way to creating a healthy environment. "All companies should provide alternative spaces where workers can take breaks," Clements-Croome says. "A coffee break is of no use. Generally, we work in two-hour cycles, then we feel a dip because our brain is asking us to do something else. Rather than be inactive, we need to be stimulated in a different way - by listening to music, meditating, taking exercise or having a massage."

Even the most expensive office technology may contribute to the problem, rather than alleviate it. "As human beings, we have a deep desire to control our environment," Clements-Croome says. "If the windows are locked because of the air conditioning, that will create resentment and depression among workers."

A glimpse of what the future may hold is to be had at Home, a new London-based firm of estate agents. Oak floorboards have replaced depressing carpet tiles; there are TV screens built into corrugated iron, leather armchairs, poodle-hair upholstery and a help-yourself jelly- bean dispenser. The purpose, of course, is to sell houses, but there is more to it than that, according to Rosalyn Dexter, Home's "design and ergonomics consultant". (She avoids the term "feng shui" because firms are increasingly suspicious of it, she says.)

"Our workspaces are constantly subliminally sending messages to us and that has an impact on our health and wellbeing," Dexter says. "You don't want offices to be Zen-like and calm, they need to stimulate creativity and productivity, and design can do that. Artwork, symbolism and colour can help - empty walls are very negative."

The positioning of desks can create subtle hierarchies, she argues - power divisions in open-plan offices that can cause stress among workers if not managed properly. The confrontational opposition of desks so common in contemporary offices is a particularly bad idea. "We all bring emotional stuff to our desks," she says. "We don't need to be dealing with other people's emotions over them."

Yet the best advice may ultimately be the most old-fashioned: plenty of plants (especially spider plants, which help oxidise the air) and plenty of happy photographs. Not that these need to be the traditional gallery of spouse, family or friends. "A great trick is to put pictures up all around your desk of the things you want to buy or achieve through your job," Dexter says. "One chap I worked with in a City firm had large photos of his dream place in the sun. It worked wonders for his sales technique."

webTitle: Theatre review:  Shoot Me in the Heart

fields.headline: Shoot Me in the Heart
fields.standfirst:
Shoot Me in the Heart
Gate, London ***
fields.trailText:
Shoot Me in the Heart
Gate, London ***
fields.body:
What is truly native, Borges once wrote, often dispenses with local colour: quoting Gibbon, he points out there are no camels in the Koran. And one good thing about this version of an Argentinian short story and film, jointly presented by Told by an Idiot and the Gate, is that no attempt is made to be exotically South American: the emphasis, rightly, is on the strangeness of the events.

The production opens a themed season dubbed "Loves work" and deals, humanely, with the unpredictability of passion. Based on a story by Julio Llinas set in a small town in the 1930s, it shows an itinerant bachelor falling headily in love with a young woman who stopped growing at the age of seven. The town is scandalised. The local priest can barely bring himself to perform the marriage rites. Only the girl's mother calmly accepts the situation; she simply warns the groom, with prophetic wisdom, never to take his bride to the circus.

Told by an Idiot, whose work I have hitherto missed, is famed for its devotion to physical theatre. This production, directed by Hayley Carmichael and Paul Hunter, reveals the form's limitations as well as its strengths. You have to go to the press release to discover that the heroine, Carlotta, is seven when she stops growing, 17 when Andrea falls in love with her and 22 when he marries her; since the passage of time is crucial to the plot, it is a failure of story-telling not to make this clear to the audience.

What the eight-strong ensemble does achieve is a sense of rooted universal prejudice against unexpected passion. The red-louvred windows of Naomi Wilkinson's set open up to reveal a hermetic, gossiping community with fixed ideas about love and marriage. Comedy and song are also used to counterpoint the story's tragic destination: the priest lectures the ardent Andrea from St Paul's notional epistle to the Mancunians and the wedding ceremony is accompanied by a touching rendition of Bring Me Sunshine.

Lisa Hammond is remarkable as Carlotta, reminding us that there is no relation between size and physical passion. There is good support from Lesley Vickerage as her self-sacrificing mother, Vincenzo Nicoli as her enthralled lover, and from Annie Fitzmaurice, who at one point skilfully embodies a high-stepping pony. But the refreshing thing is that there is not a sombrero in sight; this haunting tale could be happening in Accrington as much as Argentina.

Until October 14. Box office: 020-7229 0706. Then touring to Newcastle, Manchester, Liverpool, Sheffield and Stratford.

Only the girl's mother calmly accepts the situation; she simply warns the groom, with prophetic wisdom, never to take his bride to the circus. Told by an Idiot, whose work I have hitherto missed, is famed for its devotion to physical theatre. This production, directed by Hayley Carmichael and Paul Hunter, reveals the form's limitations as well as its strengths. You have to go to the press release to discover that the heroine, Carlotta, is seven when she stops growing, 17 when Andrea falls in love with her and 22 when he marries her; since the passage of time is crucial to the plot, it is a failure of story-telling not to make this clear to the audience. What the eight-strong ensemble does achieve is a sense of rooted universal prejudice against unexpected passion. The red-louvred windows of Naomi Wilkinson's set open up to reveal a hermetic, gossiping community with fixed ideas about love and marriage. Comedy and song are also used to counterpoint the story's tragic destination: the priest lectures the ardent Andrea from St Paul's notional epistle to the Mancunians and the wedding ceremony is accompanied by a touching rendition of Bring Me Sunshine. Lisa Hammond is remarkable as Carlotta, reminding us that there is no relation between size and physical passion. There is good support from Lesley Vickerage as her self-sacrificing mother, Vincenzo Nicoli as her enthralled lover, and from Annie Fitzmaurice, who at one point skilfully embodies a high-stepping pony. But the refreshing thing is that there is not a sombrero in sight; this haunting tale could be happening in Accrington as much as Argentina. Until October 14. Box office: 020-7229 0706. Then touring to Newcastle, Manchester, Liverpool, Sheffield and Stratford.

fields.headline: Pity the poor beleaguered bankers
fields.standfirst:
Fear of new regulations forces lenders to act
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: New Labour's credentials with big business are under attack. Top executives in large companies were found by a Mori poll yesterday to be sceptical about government policy. The big banks, while anxious to maintain dialogue with the government, also have their gripes.
fields.body:
New Labour's credentials with big business are under attack. Top executives in large companies were found by a Mori poll yesterday to be sceptical about government policy. The big banks, while anxious to maintain dialogue with the government, also have their gripes.

While bank bashing is not a new a sport, the sector's main lobby group believes this government has knocked them harder than ever.

Tim Sweeney, who as director general of the British Bankers' Association is often the one left to take the flak, will be hoping that the conciliatory tone at this week's Labour conference will feed through to the banks, too.

He believes that one of the deepest blows to the collective reputation of the industry was inflicted by the government's controversial Don Cruickshank-led competition review into banks. The headline-grabbing conclusion of the 18-month review that they overcharged their customers by £3bn-£5bn a year caused the banks great pain.

Mr Sweeney, who would be about to end his tenure at the BBA if he had not agreed to a six-month extension of his contract, believes those statistics caused "immense damage" to the industry's reputation. He insists: "They are nonsense numbers and have tremendous resonance. But it is al most impossible to deal with them in a sound-bite way."

The Cruickshank estimates of over-charging piled the pressure on the banks, rarely popular with consumers, at a time when they were making bumper profits. Yet, at the same time Barclays was closing branches and proposed charges for cash machine withdrawals were causing anger.

Months later the government was asking for their support for a universal bank, tackling two issues in an instant: throwing the post offices a lifeline when social security payments are paid direct into bank accounts after 2003 and finding a way to tackle the problem of providing accounts to people who do not have them.

But this in itself perplexed the banks, which had already committed to providing basic, no-frills accounts for the "financially excluded" by the end of October under a Treasury-backed initiative.

To Mr Sweeney, the situation is simple. If the banks thought the universal bank was a "good commercial proposition" they would be falling over each other to get involved.

Instead, the government, through the Department of Trade and Industry, appears to need to resort to coercion to get them to back the project, about which the banks want further details.

"Some might say this is a tax," Mr Sweeney said. "If it is a good commercial proposition, banks will take it up like everyone. If the government is saying 'we don't care if you like it or not, we want you to pay for it', that's some sort of imposition."

While the situation over the universal bank remains to be resolved, the banks are at pains to make it clear they will remain in dialogue with government.

They continue to face government scrutiny as a result of the now-completed Cruickshank review. The competition commission is conducting an inquiry into small-business banking while the government is to begin canvassing opinion on setting up Paycom, a new regulator for the behind-the-scenes payment mechanisms.

At the same time, the government intends to review the self-regulatory code under which the financial services operate and which was updated last week.

The new version of the code tackles many of the issues for which the industry has been under fire. They are pledging to introduce an eight-week notice period on closure of branches, which will be interpreted as a direct response to the furore surrounding Barclays' closures in April. Mr Sweeney is keen to point out that branch closures are actually a commercial issue for each bank.

The new code also lays down the regime under which banks must notify customers of the charges for withdrawing money from cash machines, another issue which exploded this year. They also say they will make it easier for customers to transfer their accounts to rivals.

These issues which have affected the industry this year have also served to show how financial services firms cannot all be grouped together. "The government is wrong to think of the banking industry as a monolithic whole," he said.

Clearing banks - the mighty four of Lloyds TSB, Barclays, NatWest (Royal Bank of Scotland) and HSBC - are particularly affected by investigations into small-business banking and current accounts, the former building societies - the likes of Abbey National and Halifax - are more concerned about issues such as mortgages and savings. The former building societies could stand to benefit from attempts to make it easier to transfer current accounts. The new internet banks face different problems altogether.

To Mr Sweeney, and whoever succeeds him at the helm of the BBA, it is going to become increasingly difficult to find a common thread which unites the sector.

But the government appears to be having no such problem when its publicity machine swings into action. The banks might not like to admit it, but the fear of fresh government regulation appears to be forcing them to act.

fields.headline: Millwall turn to penitent McGhee
fields.trailText: For a man about as popular among football folk as Salman Rushdie among Muslims, Mark McGhee would seem to be the perfect choice as new manager of Millwall, whose fans' anthem celebrates the fact that no one likes them and they don't care.
fields.body:
For a man about as popular among football folk as Salman Rushdie among Muslims, Mark McGhee would seem to be the perfect choice as new manager of Millwall, whose fans' anthem celebrates the fact that no one likes them and they don't care.

The trouble is, McGhee does care. He cares desperately that Reading fans still hate him for walking out on them to join Leicester; he cares desperately that the football community came close to turning its back on him because he walked out on Leicester to join Wolves; he cares desperately that the fans of Millwall, who announced his appointment yesterday, give him a chance to show that he may be an anti-hero but not quite the Antichrist.

McGhee cares so much that, during 20 months as a pariah after parting company with Wolves, he deliberately wooed the TV lens as much as possible in an attempt to alter the world's perception of him.

"I don't think I got a bad deal," he says. "I think I got exactly what I deserved. The biggest mistake I made was in underestimating the reaction of people when I walked out on Leicester. That is not to say that I regret leaving Leicester but it tarnished my reputation in such a way that Wolves' fans never really accepted me and I've been out of the game since leaving them.

"I was only fulfilling my ambition but I've learned that sometimes you have to think twice and maybe it would have been right for me to have said, no matter how much I want to take what I see as a bigger job, I can't have it. "

There have been many sleepless nights since, he says, and more restless days when he began to wonder whether any club would forgive him. "I don't think people know the real Mark McGhee", he says, "so I am delighted that Millwall have given me this chance. And I have accepted not because I needed the job but because I wanted it."

The mystery is why Millwall felt the need for a new manager at all since they already had two in job-sharers Keith Stevens and Alan McLeary before they were sacked last week. When Ray Harford stepped in as caretaker, his new broom brought a 2-0 win over Ipswich in the Worthington Cup and Saturday's 5-0 win over Oxford. Victory in their two games in hand will take Millwall within a point of the leaders Walsall.

McGhee accepts that it is unique to be taking over a club with their heads so high in the promotion clouds when Reading, Leicester and Wolves only asked him when they were on their knees. He was in pretty much the same position until yesterday, saying: "This is a second chance for me and if I mess it up, I won't get a third."

webTitle: Liverpool in hunt to sign Croatian Biscan

fields.headline: Liverpool in hunt to sign Croatian Biscan
fields.trailText: Gérard Houllier was last night on the verge of a transfer coup after beating Juventus and Barcelona in the race for the Croatian international midfielder Igor Biscan.
fields.body:
Gérard Houllier was last night on the verge of a transfer coup after beating Juventus and Barcelona in the race for the Croatian international midfielder Igor Biscan.

Biscan is expected to arrive at Anfield for £6m on December 15, when the Croatian season shuts down for its winter break.

Barcelona thought they had secured Biscan last week but he rejected them after learning they wanted him as a defender.

Juventus were also interested but were unwilling to match Dinamo Zagreb's valuation of the 22-year-old.

Houllier revealed his interest on Sunday, admitting that he had been tracking the midfielder for two years.

And Liverpool's manager learned last night that he had all but got his man, provided Biscan is granted a work permit.

The Dinamo spokesman Ivan Rotin said: "The transfer to Liverpool is very close to completion. Igor Biscan has said yes and the club has said yes. Igor met the Liverpool people last week in London and everything about contracts is finalised."

A work permit is not expected to be a problem since Biscan is a regular in the national team. He will be Houllier's 19th foreign signing in just over two years at Anfield, initially managing alongside Roy Evans.

fields.headline: Ehiogu rejects £8m Boro move
fields.trailText: The Aston Villa defender Ugo Ehiogu has turned down an £8m move to Middlesbrough. Villa rejected a £7m bid for Ehiogu from Manchester City six weeks ago but, mindful of the fact that the European Commission will decide on October 31 whether to abolish transfer fees, decided to accept the offer Middlesbrough made last week and gave them permission to talk to the player.
fields.body:
The Aston Villa defender Ugo Ehiogu has turned down an £8m move to Middlesbrough. Villa rejected a £7m bid for Ehiogu from Manchester City six weeks ago but, mindful of the fact that the European Commission will decide on October 31 whether to abolish transfer fees, decided to accept the offer Middlesbrough made last week and gave them permission to talk to the player.

Ehiogu, 27, meanwhile, is happy to bide his time. "I am very flattered by Middlesbrough's interest," he said. "But I do not intend to make any major decisions until the situation on transfer fees and contracts is resolved at the end of October." His decision will also disappoint his former club, West Bromwich, who stand to gain 40% of any sell-on fee.

 The 18-year-old Luton Town striker Tresor Kandol could go to prison after failing for the second time to appear before magistrates on a charge of train fare evasion.

webTitle: Champions League preview: PSV Eindhoven v Man Utd

fields.headline: Yorke forgiven but Dutch target is not forgotten
fields.standfirst: United assured of hot reception tonight after row over Van Nistelrooy
fields.trailText: Manchester United assured of a hot reception tonight after the row over Ruud Van Nistelrooy.
fields.body:
On the journey from the airport to their opulent retreat yesterday, Manchester United's team coach bypassed a barbed-wire enclave situated in some of Holland's richest woodland. Sir Alex Ferguson must have winced at the sight.

It was here at PSV's training ground that Ruud van Nistelrooy's £19m transfer to Old Trafford was infamously brought to its knees in April. And it was the fallout, the mudslinging from both camps, which ensures that even with rooftop heaters in the Philips stadium and Dwight Yorke unexpectedly restored to United's team, tonight's subplot has got more than a few people hot under the collar.

Soon after landing Ferguson reiterated his intention to bring Van Nistelrooy to United, provided the Holland striker fully recovers from the cruciate ligament injury suffered in a game of headers five months ago. Whether PSV will offer service with a smile or a snarl remains to be seen.

When United's manager contacted Van Nistelrooy last month and invited the 24-year-old to train with them throughout October the lack of a courtesy call to PSV prompted a spiky response from the Dutch champions.

Harry van Raaij, the club's president, went as far as to query whether Ferguson thought he was "the king of football", so there was no red carpet for United's manager yesterday, just the residue of a red mist. "I've confiscated Ruud's phone to stop United reaching him," volunteered PSV's coach Eric Gerets.

But Gerets has grudgingly accepted that his prize asset is inching towards following Jaap Stam to Old Trafford. "Ruud's doing as well as we could have expected," he said. "Hopefully he will be fit by March or April and still be playing for us next season. But I can't say for certain.

"The one thing he keeps stressing is there is no point him joining a club like United if he is not 100% right. If he is going to go, I personally think he would be better to leave at the end of next season." But, he added, United "may want him sooner than that."

Van Nistelrooy is increasingly optimistic of returning for the late season. He was building up the strength in his legs with a two-hour swimming session yesterday and has imposed his own media ban.

United may err on the side of caution, however, as the financial risk would be too great for a deal to be resurrected before another year. "The boy has had a very serious injury," said Ferguson. "We will have to wait and see how he comes through."

While Van Nistelrooy will be a spectator tonight , Yorke has the chance to work up a head of steam for all the right reasons.

After learning he did not merit a place even on the bench against Chelsea on Saturday, the piqued Trinidad and Tobago international went off in a huff and, to the intense irritation of his manager, was at home in Alderley Edge before kick-off. He was given the Ferguson hairdryer treatment on Sunday morning but is suddenly back in favour.

"Yorke will play alongside Ole Solskjaer," said a prickly Ferguson. "But what may or may not have happened is none of your business. I'm not discussing it."

So Yorke earns a recall despite throwing a tantrum while, just as intriguingly, Raimond van der Gouw will keep his place despite throwing in a goal. One wonders whether Mark Bosnich will ever get the chance to prove his point.

Ferguson made his own point about player fatigue yesterday and, with one eye on Sunday's match at Highbury, plans to rest several players against a side who, along with Yorke, may have benefited from a weekend's rest.

"It shows you the difference in preparation between English sides and teams on the continent," said Ferguson. "They don't have to play the weekend before the Champions League, while we have so many matches to fit in there is no room to manoeuvre. All the English clubs in Europe make the same case every year but nothing is ever done about it.

"We've got a lot of tired players and I will have to rest some rather than risk them getting injuries." Van Nistelrooy would concur with that.

 Teams in the Champions League will earn bigger shares of the estimated £350m pot that last year's competition grossed, according to Uefa. Three-quarters will be passed to the 32 clubs, while a quarter is retained by Uefa for overheads and development programmes.

Manchester United (probable, 4-4-2): Van der Gouw; Irwin, Brown, Johnsen, Silvestre; Beckham, Keane, Butt, Giggs; Solksjaer, Yorke.

PSV Eindhoven (probable, 4-4-2): Waterreus; Van der Weerden, Nikiforov, Hofland, Heintze; Van der Doelen, Van Bommel, Vogel, Bouma; Kezman, Bruggink.

Referee : M Merk (Germany) .

webTitle: The dealmakers - and how they will be rewarded

fields.headline: The dealmakers - and how they will be rewarded
fields.standfirst: Germans want to buy more British utilities
fields.trailText: Bill Alexander, the Thames Water chief executive, stands to make more than £1m from the deal with RWE while his non-executive chairman, Roger Carr, has lined himself up for his second windfall in seven days - he expects to gain £2m from a different deal announced last week.
fields.body:
Bill Alexander, the Thames Water chief executive, stands to make more than £1m from the deal with RWE while his non-executive chairman, Roger Carr, has lined himself up for his second windfall in seven days - he expects to gain £2m from a different deal announced last week.

The two Thames men will be turning on the money taps because the takeover will realise some personal share holdings, share options and employment contracts.

Mr Alexander, who is to stay with the combined company and spearhead its global operations, holds 13,545 shares directly and has another 108,428 in options through long-term incentive schemes.

If these could be exercised at the £12.15 rate offered by RWE, the notional value would be £1.5m, but a more realistic level seems to be around £1.2m.

Mr Carr, who only joined the board in April 1999, will be leaving when the deal is complete and will obtain one year's salary of £100,000.

He will also take £33,412 from the 2,750 shares he holds in Thames. Mr Carr last week announced plans to break up the former conglomerate, Williams, he built up with Sir Nigel Rudd and pocket £2m plus a £180,000 continuing annual fee for acting as non-executive chairman of one of the two remaining former Williams' companies, Chubb.

fields.trailText: New Zealand's Craig Spearman and Chris Harris each hit half-centuries to help their team to a 68-run victory over a Zimbabwe Academy X1 in a limited-overs match in Harare yesterday.
fields.body:
New Zealand's Craig Spearman and Chris Harris each hit half-centuries to help their team to a 68-run victory over a Zimbabwe Academy X1 in a limited-overs match in Harare yesterday.

The tourists scored 282 for eight in their 50 overs with Spearman making 58 off 42 balls and Harris 53 off as many deliveries. The Academy were bowled out for 214 in 48 overs.

New Zealand face Zimbabwe in Harare tomorrow in the first of three one-day internationals.

Nick Knight will have a test on his swollen left knee today to ascertain whether he is fit to join England's one-day squad for the ICC Trophy tournament in Kenya next month.

fields.headline: Redistribution of wealth 'will save lives'
fields.trailText: Thousands of people die prematurely each year as a direct result of government policies in the late 1970s and 1980s that increased unemployment, child poverty and inequality of income and wealth, according to a study published yesterday by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation.
fields.body:
Thousands of people die prematurely each year as a direct result of government policies in the late 1970s and 1980s that increased unemployment, child poverty and inequality of income and wealth, according to a study published yesterday by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation.

Researchers from the universities of Leeds and Bristol identified a surprisingly exact correlation between changes in mortality rates in almost every parliamentary constituency and social factors measuring changes in deprivation. Their ground-breaking report, the first to attempt to link annual death levels to government policy, calculated that a modest redistribution of income and wealth to return inequalities to their 1983 levels would prevent about 7,500 deaths a year among the under-65s.

Eliminating long-term unemployment would prevent another 2,500 premature deaths a year, and achieving the government's target of eradicating child poverty within a generation would save the lives of 1,400 children under 15 each year.

These reductions in premature deaths would be concentrated in the most disadvantaged areas. Indeed a combination of all three policies would eliminate more than half the "excess" deaths in constituencies with above average premature mortality rates.

According to the study: "It is now almost universally accepted that the late 1970s and 1980s were a period of rapid social polarisation. The rich became very much richer and the poor became poorer. Unemployment reached levels not experienced since the 1930s and was highly concentrated in the north and in inner cities... At the extreme, the price of the social change in this period was that some people died younger than they might have done under more equitable circumstances."

The report identified 45 constituencies where 25 or more lives could be saved each year if these poverty reduction policies were successful. They included seats belonging to the following cabinet members: Hull East (John Prescott), Blackburn (Jack Straw), Sheffield Brightside (David Blunkett), Hartlepool (Peter Mandelson), Redcar (Mo Mowlam) and Birmingham Ladywood (Clare Short).

Ms Short's constituency had the record for the highest number of poverty related premature deaths. "On average, in the early 1990s, 275 Birmingham Ladywood constituents died per year at ages less than 65. If the life chances of the people of Birmingham were the same as the national average we would expect only 182 people to die at these ages. There are thus 93 'excess' deaths per year at ages less than 65," the report said.

If the government achieved a modest redistribution of wealth and eliminated child poverty and long-term unemployment, 39 of these deaths could be avoided, the study said.


Inequalities in Life and Death: What if Britain were more equal? Joseph Rowntree Foundation. £13.95.

Useful links:www.jrf.org.uk The Joseph Rowntree Foundation

fields.headline: PSV Eindhoven 3 - 1 Manchester United
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

PSV Eindhoven: 23-Ronald Waterreus; 13-Chris van der Weerden, 21-Yuri Nikiforov, 29-Kevin Hofland, 5-Jan Heintze; 6-Mark van Bommel, 14-Johann Vogel, 17-Bjorn van der Doelen, 22-Wilfred Bouma; 9-Mateja Kezman, 10-Arnold Bruggink.

Manchester United: 17-Raimond Van Der Gouw; 24-Wes Brown, 2-Gary Neville, 27-Mikael Silvestre, 12-Philip Neville; 16-Roy Keane, 18-Paul Scholes, 8-Nicky Butt, 34-Jonathan Greening; 19-Dwight Yorke, 20-Ole Gunnar Solskjaer.

Referee: Markus Merk (Germany)

1 United, playing in blue, kick off with PSV fans screaming their support to ensure Alex Ferguson's men do not settle too quickly.
2 Penalty shocker Solskjaer, through on goal, is brought down by PSV keeper Waterreus, who gets a yellow card for his trouble. Scholes steps up and fires into the top left corner to set up a dream start for United. PSV Eindhoven 0 - 1 Manchester United.
5 PSV fans suddenly quiet until Heintze gets away on the left; he looks up and finds Bouma to the left of the United area, but his header goes straight across the face of goal.
7 United come close to getting a second when Greening on the left finds Solskjaer on the far side of the six-yard box; Solskjaer knocks the ball down for Yorke to drag his shot wide of the far post.
10 United in control unitl they concede a corner to PSV on the left. Bruggink takes but the van der Gouw charges out to clear.
12 PSV comes alive as Kezman shoots from just inside the area - goes wide by a couple of feet.
14 PSV win a free-kick deep on the right after Silvestre checks Kezman in full flow. Bruggink takes but United clear with ease.
16 Heintze again gets away on the left after some sloppy ball control by United, but his cross is no threat for United.
17 GOAL PSV Eindhoven 1 - 1 Manchester United A piercing pass from the PSV half finds Kezman running on to the United area; he beats Silvestre and Brown and then centres, but van Bommel has overrun the ball and cannot make the pass count. United clear, but PSV counter again. Bruggink knocks on a high through ball into the path of Bouma and the flag stays down as he gets away from a dozing Phil Neville, who is trying to tug him down - far corner from 15 yards, crisp and sweet shot.
24 Not surprisingly, the crowd are now in full voice and United have lost most of their early momentum.
25 PSV again try to break down the left and Bruggink is unlucky to be caught offside when chasing a 40-yard pass.
28 United enjoy good possession on the edge of the PSV area as they seek to find a way through, but the Dutch side sit tight and eventually clear.
29 Phil Neville concedes a corner. Bruggink takes and van der Gouw punches clear.
30 Dodgy moment for United as Silvestre struggles to keep up with his man on the edge of the United area, before van der Gouw is forced to come out and clear with his feet.
33 The left flank is proving fertile territory for the home side as a swift exchange of passes sees PSV away again. Bouma crosses from deep with Bruggink and Kezman waiting, but United feet get there first.
35 PSV in full flow now as Bruggink charges into the area, but he is muscled off the ball by three United defenders. PSV play it straight back to Kezman on the right but his cross finds no-one.
36 Kezman goes down in the area under pressure from Brown - play on says the man in black.
38 GOAL PSV Eindhoven 2 - 1 Manchester United Classic counter from PSV. United lose possession deep in the PSV half. Kezman gets away on the left of midfield and drifts inside before sliding a perfectly weighted pass through to van Bommel just outside the area. Van Bommel runs on a couple of yards, pauses, looks up and then slots it through the legs of a splayed van der Gouw with his right foot.
42 United desperately need some width to prevent PSV coming forward and it will be interesting to see how Alex Ferguson approaches the second half.
44 PSV play keep-ball for a couple of minutes as the first half draws to close.
45 One extra minute to play as United look for that equaliser - lots of movement but little substance in the end as Solskjaer is muscled off the ball on the edge of the area. Half-time. Not a great half for United. After a lively start, they had trouble containing PSV on the flanks and completely failed to do themselves justice.

46 No changes in personnel as the second half gets underway.
47 United pass it around interminably deep on the right but fail to find a way through.
48 A golden chance for PSV as United again fall foul of their own intended offside trap. A quick knock-on from a long ball finds Kezman just outside the area, but he drags his shot wide of the far post.
52 Van der Doelen creates havoc on the edge of the United area as he slides the ball through to Kezman on the right side. Kezman turns and shoots wide of the far post.
55 United free-kick just over 20 yards out and to the right. Scholes takes towards Keane coming in at the far post, but everyone misses it.
56 Brown gives away a free-kick 40 yards out; PSV try to work it in from the right, but United clear.
58 Beckham, Giggs and Sheringham start to warm up on the touchline, despite Alex Ferguson's stated intention not to play them if at all possible.
59 Evenly matched so far, which means United are no nearer to finding an equaliser.
63 Van der Doelen the man who is holding up United at the moment as United pressure the PSV goal.
64 GOAL PSV Eindhoven 3 - 1 Manchester United Well, there you go. Another classic counter attack. In no time at all, the ball reaches Kezman deep on the right; he looks up and beats van der Gouw with a firece shot to the far post from the right side of the area.
65 Mr Sitter from PSV. Kezman knocks the ball down inside the United area, Bruggink rides a tackle by Brown and then misses an open goal - shocking.
69 Much dressing and undressing going on the United bench as Alex Ferguson tries to work out what to do next.
70 Booking Paul Scholes. Substitutions Beckham, Giggs and Wallwork on for Scholes, Greening and Silvestre. United pull out the stops in an attempt to save the game.
72 PSV free-kick 30 yards out and to the left. Bruggink takes, van der Gouw gathers easily.
74 Gary Neville finds Solskjaer inside the area, but the Norwegian inexplicably plays it into space for keeper Waterreus.
76 United free-kick, Beckham plays it to Gary Neville who fires it into the pack. No-brainer for PSV.
77 Substitution Lucius on for van der Doelen.
78 Kezman gets away from Wallwork on the left. He centres for Bouma, but Brown pressures well to deny the chance in front of goal.
80 Substitution Rommedahl on for Bouma.
82 Beckham finds Gary Neville running deep with a great ball down the right, but the defender is tackled well for a throw.
83 United corner. Beckham takes to Giggs 30 yards out. Giggs fires it in and PSV clear off the line twice to deny United a second.
84 Booking Keane. Substitution Kolkaa on for Kezman.
86 United free-kick; Beckham takes to the far post and Keane heads over.
87 Butt unlucky when he tries to turn Hofland 25 yards out, but the PSV player tackles well.
88 Substitution Lucius.
89 Substitution Beckham. Yet again his petulance gets the better of him. United players shouting at each other in frustration - all getting very crabby.
90 Three extra minutes to play in a match that Alex Ferguson will be happy to forget. United free-kick 25 yards out. Beckham takes and beats the wall to send Waterreus flying to his left for the save. Full-time. PSV Eindhoven 3 - 1 Manchester United Not a good night at the office for this experimental United side. Roll on matchday four.

fields.headline: Five alive and well
fields.trailText: With a populist horoscope and strong Jupiter influences in the next two years, Channel 5's future looks upbeat. But its raison d'etre shows little of the joy of broadcasting or programme-making, says the Media Medium.
fields.body:
Channel 5 has 5% of total TV viewing and this cheeky three-year-old is small but growing. With a populist horoscope and strong Jupiter influences in the next two years, its future looks upbeat, but its raison d'etre shows little of the joy of broadcasting or programme-making.

By its own definition, it aims to fulfil advertisers' need for "more commercial viewing and less expensive airtime".

Channel 5's incorporation (January 17 1996) shows an ambitious Capricorn with excellent money-making possibilities, especially through a soft-porn Venus-Pluto combination in its cash zone.

Its Spice Girls launch (6pm, March 30 1997) flaunts a bunch of planets in crude, simple-minded Aries. With a nude gameshow and its late-night lust, "Channel Filth" has earned the ire of those who would describe themselves as right-thinking people, courtesy of its mortal enemy, the Daily Mail. Not surprisingly, it is run by Scorpios (the sign of sex, death and secrets): chief executive David Elstein (November 14 1944) and director of programmes Dawn Airey (November 15 1960).

Both Scorpio and Aries relish a fight, and with aggressive Mars rising, Channel 5 has gone for a "challenger brand" approach to self-promotion, deliberately rocking the status quo.

Airey says the channel has "excellence and depth", but she sees its niche, in her own words, as "films, fucking and football", "bosoms, balls and brutality".

So what does this do to the battle between the channels?

The astrology shows an intriguing game is being played out here. Lorraine Heggessey (November 16 1956), the new BBC1 controller, is another Scorpio with a powerful sting, and look at these birth dates: Elstein, November 14; Airey, November 15; Heggessey, November 16. Within a couple of degrees, all three share the same Scorpio sun.

This, and other connections between the horoscopes, especially those involving Mars, indicate Channel 5 has defined successfully the territory over which the BBC and larger channels must fight.

Its strategy indicates the way their war will go. Monica Lewinsky (July 23 1973), that notable political commentator, is to be a Channel 5 presenter during the US election. As a dramatic Leo with a ballsy Mars-Uranus across the Channel 5 horizon, she is a provocative choice. In the ratings war, politics, like everything else, is sucked into the three Fs and three Bs.

Email the Media Medium at: maggie@companyguide.co.uk

fields.headline: Milosevic loses vote
fields.standfirst:
Opposition win 48.22%
Milosevic wins 4023%
fields.trailText:
Escalating Yugoslavia's political crisis, Slobodan Milosevic has defied international calls for him to step down and
called a runoff election against the dour law professor who the opposition claims defeated him.
fields.body:
Escalating Yugoslavia's political crisis, Slobodan Milosevic has defied international calls for him to step down and called a runoff election against the dour law professor who the opposition claims defeated him.

The state election commission announced today that opposition presidential candidate Vojislav Kostunica finished first in the weekend presidential elections but without enough votes to avoid a runoff with Milosevic.

The commission said Kostunica won 48.22 percent of the vote in Sunday's ballot to 40.23 for Milosevic.

"In short, in the presidential elections there will be a second round," TV said. The announcement could escalate the Yugoslav political crisis. The opposition claims Kostunica won outright and has refused to join the runoff, scheduled for 8 October.

Yugoslav opposition leaders had given the commission until tomorrow to release the final election results.

By midday today, the commission had not reconvened after a brief meeting Sunday night, according to Sinisa Nikolic, a commission member from the ranks of the opposition alliance.

But the chairman of the commission, Borivoje Vukicevic, told several dozen foreign observes from "friendly" countries - such as Russia, China and some African countries which had monitored the balloting - that the commission was working "efficiently and in accordance with the law."

More than 40,000 people turned out for a second night yesterday in Belgrade to celebrate what the opposition and much of the international community has said was a stunning victory. The mood was jubilant, with people celebrating what they thought was the final end of Milosevic's 13-year autocratic rule. Opposition supporters also flooded streets in other towns across Serbia, cheering long into the night.

Frustrated by the delay, opposition spokesman Cedomir Jovanovic said Monday that Mr Kostunica's supporters would give the commission two days - until tomorrow - to announce results or they would "proclaim official results no matter what the government thinks."

Mr Jovanovic said it was becoming clear that Milosevic could not accept defeat.

The United States and dozens of European countries issued stern calls for Mr Milosevic to recognise the opposition tally and step down.

The United States has pledged to lift sanctions against Yugoslavia - including blocking international bank loans, an oil embargo and denying visas to Yugoslav officials - once Mr Milosevic accepts defeat.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, today renewed his call for Mr Milosevic, to stand down. Speaking at the Labour party conference in Brighton, he revealed that results from more than half the polling stations in Serbia showed that Mr Kostunica had won "convincingly".
