fields.headline: The Game in Spain
fields.trailText: After the opening three matches in the Primera Liga, it's not big-spending Barcelona or Real Madrid who top the table. It's Celta Vigo.
fields.body:
After the opening three matches in the Primera Liga, it's not big-spending Barcelona or Real Madrid who top the table. It's Celta Vigo.

But Victor Fernandez's unfashionable side deserve their position after maintaining their 100 per cent record with a 1-0 victory at home to Espanyol.

The visitors started the brighter, with Manel's deflected shot producing a brilliant save from Jose Pinto. But it wasn't long before Celta - inspired by their Brazilian signings Doriva, Catanha and Vagner and their Russian playmaker Alexander Mostovoi - started to work over the Espanyol defence.

Catanha, who joined from Malaga during the summer for £7m, should have opening the scoring after 15 minutes, but he tripped over the ball. Five minutes later, however, he made no mistake.

Recent Chelsea target Gustavo Lopez did most of the work, cutting and twisting his way past challenge after challenge before unleashing a powerful shot that the keeper could only parry into the path of Catanha, who slotted home from six-yards.

Celta continued to dominate with Catanha always dangerous and Mostovoi mischievous. However they couldn't add a second - and towards the end Espanyol nearly made them pay, with Pinto and Posse both going close.

Barcelona, who had been thrashed by Athletico Bilbao and Besiktas in their previous two games, returned to winning ways with a comprehensive 3-1 victory over Racing Santander. After some slothful early finishing, Barca finally went ahead in the 32nd minute when Simao caressed in a cross from the right and Kluivert cleverly lofted the ball over Ceballos and into the net.

The Dutch striker then doubled his tally in the 56th minute when De la Pena's pass set up Rivaldo, whose exquisite backheel split the Racing defence and played in Kluivert, who scored from 10 yards.

Five minutes later, Racing pulled one back with a brilliant free-kick from Espina, and the Nou Camp started to sweat. And that unease went into overdrive when Frank de Boer was sent off with four minutes remaining for a second bookable offence. But deep into injury time Santander allowed Marc Overmars to race away and make it 3-1.

Despite the win, the Nou Camp crowd weren't particularly happy, and after 83 minutes they howled like the Autumn wind when Rivaldo was substituted. The Spanish press later claimed their reaction wasn't aimed at the decision, but at the underperforming World Player of the Year. However, Barcelona coach Llorenc Serra Ferrer later denied that was the case. "The whistles and hissing were for me, the fans were unhappy that I was taking Rivaldo off," he said, unconvincingly.

But it will be worth watching developments at the Nou Camp closely over the next few weeks, particularly as second vice-president Angel Fernandez was also highly critical of Rivaldo after Barca lost defeat to Besitkas. Real Madrid, without the injured Raul and Morienties and with Steve McManaman still stuck in the stands, were much too strong for Athletic Bilbao, coasting to a 4-1 victory.

The game was over by half-time, with the over-rated Guti (is he really better than Macca?) heading home after Figo had put in a perfect cross from the right. Roberto Carlos then increased the lead with a 30-yard fizzer of a free-kick.

Two minutes into the second half, Real went 3-0 ahead when another Figo cross - this time from the left - was flapped at by Bilbao goalkeeper Inaki Lafuente. Guti, two yards out, was again the beneficiary of Figo's work. Real's demolition was complete when Pedro Munitis scored after 66th minute, although Athletic pulled back an injury time consolation through Ezquerro.

Elsewhere, Valencia continued their awesome home record with a 3-0 win against Numancia. The visitors had Miguel Soria sent off when the score was still 0-0 at the end of the first half, and eventually Valencia made their numerical superiority count, with goals from Juan Sanchez (2) and Vicente. The win gives them six points from their opening Liga matches, and they seem well placed to challenge the boy boys - as well as Celta Vigo.

fields.headline: Wegg-Prosser to join new Guardian websites
fields.trailText: Benjamin Wegg-Prosser, a former adviser to Peter Mandelson, is joining Guardian Unlimited as publisher of two new internet ventures, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Benjamin Wegg-Prosser, a former adviser to Peter Mandelson, is joining Guardian Unlimited as publisher of two new internet ventures.

The sites, which will launch early next year, will cover politics and the environment as part of the Guardian's continued online expansion into core areas. Each site is to have its own editor and editorial teams, which are expected to be appointed in the coming weeks.

The announcement effectively means that Mr Wegg-Prosser, 26, has ditched plans to bring Slate, the US site owned by Microsoft, to the UK, a project he has been working on for the past nine months.

"After nine months of finalising the licensing with Microsoft, putting a team together and talking to investors, current market conditions mean that we're not able to raise enough funds to bring it to market," said Mr Wegg-Prosser. Slate UK was expected to make its UK debut in the new year, with Microsoft making a small equity investment.

As publisher of the planned Guardian websites, Mr Wegg-Prosser will oversee commercial development and report directly to Simon Waldman, head of GU. "It's a great opportunity to work on an excellent new media project. I can't wait to start," he said.

Before becoming involved in Slate UK, Mr Wegg-Prosser spent a year as communications manager at Pearson and prior to that spent four years as the Department of Trade & Industry as a special adviser to Mr Mandelson.

webTitle: Blair shows he has not lost his nerve

fields.headline: Blair shows he has not lost his nerve
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair used his conference address to stamp his authority on his embattled  administration, write Kevin Maguire and Julian Glover
fields.trailText: Analysis: Tony Blair used his conference address to stamp his authority on his embattled administration, write Kevin Maguire and Julian Glover.
fields.body:
Tony Blair did his best to put pale blue water between Labour and the Tories this afternoon by telling voters they face a clear choice: social commitment from Labour or irresponsible extremism from the opposition. In doing so he delivered a speech which was arguably his most "old Labour" since he took office in 1997.

Though in parts it read like Majorism warmed up and at other points like a leader feigning contrition, there was a passion and an energy to the prime minister's delivery which both reassured and enlivened the conference. Within minutes of the start of his address Mr Blair had proved that he had not lost his nerve.

The prime minister repeatedly highlighted the differences between the two political forces, presenting Labour as the party of mature government and the Conservatives as the party of cuts.

Significantly, he also set out what he called his "irreducible core": a clear, and largely successful, effort to overcome his image as a failing, rootless populist. In a passage which was presented as an unscripted aside (but which gave the appearance of having been rehearsed) the prime minister ran through a shopping list of actions he was not prepared to take but, he said, the Tories would - from "sticking two fingers up" at Europe to attacking asylum seekers and cutting overseas aid.

His own pale blue shirt was left dripping with sweat after the 56-minute address, which earned him a standing ovation lasting 4 minutes and 26 seconds - one second longer than the applause yesterday for chancellor Gordon Brown.

Today's speech was an attempt by Mr Blair to stamp his authority on the party after splits over pensions and petrol and a Downing Street "poison squad" accused of undermining the chancellor. Admitting that the government had "taken a knock", the prime minister accepted responsibility for its fall in the polls. He apologised for the Dome and made it clear that pensioners would get a significant rise, admitting he had "got the message" that this year's 75p rise was a mistake - though he ruled out any linking of future increases to wages.

Mr Blair set out an unashamedly tough policy on law and order, including renewed backing for on-the-spot fines. The idea sparked ridicule when it was first floated and was swiftly dropped.

The old "s" word, socialism, was not used once but Mr Blair employed a new "s" word, solidarity, in a passage that could apply to his feuding ministers as much as the country.

Mr Blair said he believed in "that old principle of solidarity, that by standing shoulder to shoulder you get more out of this life instead of fighting each other as isolated individuals".

The prime minister sketched out Labour's next election manifesto, promising that a commitment to raise again the share of the nation's wealth spent on schools and training would be the first line of a new contract with voters. "Education. Education. Education. Then, now and in the future," he said.

Rattling through a list of core issues concerning voters, he committed himself to action against cancer. "Under plans we publish tomorrow, there will be 1,000 more cancer specialists over the next six years - up nearly a third," he said. "By 2003 for the first time the government will be matching pound for pound charity funding for cancer research." That pledge had echoes of Bill Clinton, who launched his own attack on cancer earlier this year.

There was no escape from the problems over pensions and petrol that have rocked the government in the past two weeks. A humbler Mr Blair vowed to listen but a defiant streak also emerged as the two sides of the politician competed for the support of the electorate. He promised he was listening to the nation's grievances - but set popular concern about tax on some issues against demand for higher spending on others.

"I am listening to people's anger over fuel duties. For hauliers and farmers, to say nothing of ordinary motorists, there is real hardship," he said.

"But I have also had to listen over underfunding in the NHS, over extra investment in schools, over more police on the beat, over public transport.

"I am listening over mortgages, where low interest rates can only be maintained if disciplined public finances are kept.

"I am also listening to pensioners who believe the government should give them a greater share of the country's prosperity... and I will act." But he stressed: "The world is full of competing causes, most of them good."

One of those competing causes is, of course, Mr Blair's bid to win a second term in office and the coming election ran through his words like lettering in a seaside stick of rock. Did he do enough today to win back the electorate's confidence? Not quite, not yet - but the prime minister's speech, like the chancellor's yesterday, certainly made a good case for the Labour fightback.

Tipped for bronze, the prime minister and his chancellor have certainly won silver this week - and if the reaction in the media pen afterwards is to be trusted, they might even be said to have brought home an unexpected gold.

webTitle: Blunkett accused over grammar schools ballot

fields.headline: Blunkett accused over grammar schools ballot
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Campaigners in Kent have dropped plans to press for a ballot on abolishing grammar schools in the county, protesting that the education secretary, David Blunkett, has presented them with a "bureaucratic nightmare".
fields.body:
Campaigners in Kent have dropped plans to press for a ballot on abolishing grammar schools in the county, protesting that the education secretary, David Blunkett, has presented them with a "bureaucratic nightmare".

The Stop the Eleven Plus campaign in Kent, which has 33 of England's 165 grammar schools, more than any other county, accused Mr Blunkett of erecting "too many unfair and undemocratic hurdles for us to jump over".

Last year they suspended their campaign after winning only around 7,000 of the 46,000 petition signatures needed - 20% of eligible parents - to trigger a full ballot in Kent.

Activists complained that under revised guidance issued this autumn, it is even harder to ensure a ballot takes place. Though the Electoral Reform Society now has to approve the wording of the petition, schools are still prevented from distributing petition forms. The forms have to be distributed by campaigners.

Once the ballot is triggered, schools can send out leaflets produced by campaigners - but only if both sides want to put their case. If pro-selection campaigners do not want to send out a leaflet, schools cannot send out just one side of the argument.

Rebecca Matthews, chair of the campaign, said: "Is David Blunkett going to continue to look the other way, wring his hands and say the 11-plus is bad -- but do nothing?

"I want Mr Blunkett to tell us why he has deliberately engineered a situation where a quarter of a million children in Kent continue to have their education blighted by the 11-plus."

The decision will be officially announced at a fringe meeting held by the Campaign for State Education (CASE) at the Labour conference in Brighton, which will be critical of the government's policy on selection.

Lord Hattersley, Labour's former deputy leader, will tell the meeting: "The evidence leaves no room for doubt. Comprehensive education has proved a remarkable success. Yet comprehensive schools are continually denigrated by the prime minister - often in language which suggests that he has no idea how selective schools are organised and run.

"During the 18 years of Tory government we could all console ourselves that once Labour was elected things would get better. But the hard truth is that as far as comprehensive education is concerned that they have got worse. Despite David Blunkett's promise - "no selection by examination or interview" - there is more selection now than there was on the day he became secretary of state for education."

Margaret Tulloch, spokesperson for CASE, said: "Ending selection is too important an issue to be left to the possibility or otherwise of a local campaign being able to collect large numbers of signatures before anything can change."

Anti-selection campaigners in Birmingham are to proceed with their efforts to get 10,000 signatures to ensure a ballot on the future of six grammar schools in the city and two in Sutton Coldfield. Another campaign is afoot in Buckinghamshire, which has 13 grammar schools, though it was unclear last night whether Kent's decision would affect them.

But ministers will be relieved that they will be spared at least one provocative petition on selection, which they feared could harm Labour's image in middle Britain, in the run-up to the general election. Mr Blunkett has said he is not interested in "hunting grammar schools".

A DfEE spokeswoman said the petition forms will be produced by the Electoral Reform Society to prevent any possible fraud. The spokeswoman said the decision to drop the petition was "a matter for the petition organisers themselves. They are free to stop their activities at any time."

webTitle: History just a hop, step and jump away

fields.headline: History just a hop, step and jump away
fields.trailText: Sydney, 2000 Olympics: Despite the controversy of an ill-judged article and the passing of his wife's mother, Jonathan Edwards finally claimed the only championship triple jumping gold that had eluded him - Olympic.
fields.body:
When the Olympics were last held in Australia, in Melbourne in 1956, the winner of the triple jump was Ademar Ferreira da Silva, a Brazilian who moved on to a successful career as a soap-opera actor.

Jonathan Edwards has faced so many trials and tribulations recently that there must have been times when he felt he was living out his own private soap opera. But there was no cliff-hanging finale in last night's closing scenes.

Under the admiring eye of Da Silva a third-round leap of 17.71 metres - the best in the world this year - blew the opposition out of the water and secured for him the honour of becoming Britain's first Olympic triple-jump champion proper.

Timothy Ahearne had won at the London games in 1908 representing Britain but was so outraged at being forced to compete under the union flag that during the medal ceremony he shimmied up the pole, tore it down in protest and replaced it with the tricolour. He now appears in the record books as Irish.

There was no doubt where Edwards' loyalties lay. Draped in the union flag, he took what must be the slowest lap of honour in history. He took so long, constantly stopping to be photographed by British fans in the crowd, that after 15 minutes an official asked him to hurry up. If he was determined to savour the moment after succeeding on his fourth attempt at Olympic gold, then it was perfectly understandable.

At Seoul in 1988, as a 22-year-old, he failed to make the final, being placed 23rd in the qualifying round. Four years later Edwards genuinely felt he could bring home a medal from Barcelona but once again failed to make the final.

Then came the magnificent summer of 1995 which made his a household name. He won at the world championships in Gothenburg with an astonishing leap of 18.29m, the first man to jump more than 60 feet.

First, he was involved in a row with Britain's swimmers when he labelled them party-going medal no-hopers in a website column and was forced to apologise. It deeply affected the devoutly religious Edwards and he contemplated not travelling down to Sydney. But, with the blessing of his wife Alison, he decided to compete, in a last attempt to take the one prize in the sport that had eluded him.

webTitle: Reuters' net broker aims for £4bn float

fields.headline: Reuters' net broker aims for £4bn float
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Reuters, the news and information group, is aiming toward a flotation of its online broking business Instinet in the first half of next year.
fields.body:
Reuters, the news and information group, is aiming toward a flotation of its online broking business Instinet in the first half of next year.

The company is expected to list the business on the technology-oriented US Nasdaq index with a valuation of between £3.5bn and £4.5bn. It is understood Reuters has discussed the flotation with investment bank Credit Suisse First Boston, although insiders said that the green light had not yet been given.

Instinet was identified as a potential candidate for flotation in February by Reuters' chief executive, Peter Job. The tumult that followed for hi-tech stocks meant the project was put on hold.

Instinet has recently been Reuters' star performer and was a crucial driver behind a strong half-year performance by the group, which in July reported a 50% improvement in revenues to £381m.

Mr Job is also considering floating the Greenhouse Fund, Reuters' investment vehicle for internet start-ups.

Greenhouse made £42m from disposals during the half-year and still had £243m of investments in a portfolio of 60 firms. A number of floats in which the fund held a stake have taken place, including Orchestream in Britain and Virage in the US.Greenhouse has been valued at £3bn.

One media analyst said: "Instinet is a very good business with very high margins in the US. They are now looking at launching a lot of new products, including equities in Europe, which should make it all the more attractive.

"But it is a difficult business to value, and doing this would make sense because it would give shareholders a better sense of what it is worth."

Reuters attracted criticism for being slow to appreciate the opportunities presented by the net but has been driving hard to migrate its business online for the past year.

Instinet provides equity and fixed-income brokerage for institutional investors and brokers. The plan is to broaden its product lines and customer base with retail services for both equities and fixed-income products.

At present the US equities business accounts for nearly 80% of Instinet's revenues. Outside the US, revenues grew last year by 39%. Although the online market is booming Instinet's revenues have come under pressure from increasing competition.

Cash from a float would aid further research and development of new technologies as well as providing currency for further acquisitions.

Instinet led a consortium in 1999 that acquired a majority interest in Tradepoint Financial Networks, a UK exchange. The company was named as a potential suitor for the London Stock Exchange.

Both Reuters and CSFB declined to comment on the flotation plans.

fields.headline: On the web
fields.standfirst: Philosophy
fields.trailText: Philosophy
fields.body:
Philosophers' Magazine

***

Aimed at: everyone

Articles from the quarterly magazine are reproduced, alongside a compelling Philosophical Health Check and a few other intriguing games. Features tend to be short and might therefore make good starting-points for class discussion at A-level.

Stanford Encyclopaedia

**

Aimed at: everyone

An impressive, but as yet uncompleted, resource that grows slowly as members of the editorial board approve its content. As you might expect, the bibliographical entries and cross-referencing are unimpeachable.

Greek civilisation

***

Aimed at: children

Produced by a US university, this site is a brief but extensively cross-referenced guide to the lives and thought of Socrates, Plato and Aristotle.

Arts and Letters Daily

***

Aimed at: everyone

Not all the articles collected here tackle philosophical subjects, but those that do are up-to-date and a useful survey of contemporary philosophical debate.

Zeno's Coffeehouse

***

Aimed at: everyone

The proprietor of Zeno's sets regular challenges of the mathematical kind that anyone can enter. The front page also links to an interactive prisoner's dilemma game.

Philosophy at Large

***

Aimed at: teachers

An extraordinary number of annotated links. Many will be more suitable for undergraduates and academics than A-level students, but there is plenty to occupy anyone with an interest; particularly useful are the lists of newsgroups and philosophers' addresses.

Classics Pages

****

Aimed at: everyone

Although this site is intended for classics pupils, it provides an engaging introduction to the lives and thought of some key Greek and Roman thinkers, so it will be invaluable if you want to introduce a class to a particular philosopher before tackling his ideas.

The Atheism Web

****

Aimed at: everyone

An excellent introduction to constructing logical arguments, together with an intriguing list of common fallacies.

The Argument Clinic

***

Aimed at: everyone

Submit an argument to the clinic and have it criticised by staff at the University of Northern Colorado.

Philosophy Comix

****

Aimed at: (in practice) teachers

To know how a Garfield cartoon can convey conversational implications, look here. The cartoons would make a good primary source for lessons.

Blackwell's Resources

****

Aimed at: everyone

An excellent selection of resources from different parts of the web.


Internet Encyclopaedia

****

Aimed at: everyone

A concise, though slightly dry, introduction to key thinkers and concepts.

You can find more philosophy sites at: www.educationunlimited.co.uk/netclass or contact Ros Taylor at ros.taylor@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Balen quits BBC for LNN
fields.trailText: BBC News executive editor Malcolm Balen has quit the corporation to become London News Network's head of news. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
BBC News executive editor Malcolm Balen has quit the corporation to become London News Network's head of news.

He replaces Nick Atkins, who has left to be director of programming at ONdigital.

Mr Balen worked at ITN's Channel 4 News as senior programme editor, before joining the BBC in 1994. He produced the Nine O'Clock News before being promoted to executive editor for the BBC's one, six and nine o'clock bulletins in a reshuffle that was unpopular with staff.

Earlier this year he was sidelined in the restructure led by head of television news Roger Mosey.

webTitle: Protesters riot in Prague as finance summit opens

fields.headline: Protesters riot in Prague as finance summit opens
fields.standfirst:
Audio: 'There are tanks on the bridge'
Graphic: The Prague riot
fields.trailText: Anti-capitalism protesters today marched on the IMF and World Bank summit in Prague, throwing firebombs at police, who responded with tear gas and water cannons.
fields.body:
Anti-capitalism protesters today marched on the IMF and World Bank summit in Prague, throwing firebombs at police, who responded with tear gas and water cannons.

Activists conducted a stand-off on a bridge on the route to the communist-era Congress Center in which the summit was today inaugurated, chanting "Stop the economic terror now" in protest against the two global lending institutions they call a menace to humanity. Official police figures placed their number at around 5,000; journalist sources say it might be double that, or more.

Several policemen were set alight by Molotov cocktails and colleagues hosed them down with a water cannon. Dozens of people are reported to have been hurt.

Earlier this morning, two people suffered head injuries during street fights and demonstrators threw rocks at a McDonald's outlet, cracking the glass door.

The protesters have vowed to halt the meetings, arguing that the Washington-based institutions ignore the needs of the poor, decimating quality of life for millions. Some activists paraded outside the meeting, waving banners saying, "Making love not trade".

Student Hans Jurgen from Bergen, Norway, turned out wearing a green hat festooned with dollar signs - a walking, talking caricature of globalisation's fat cats. "I have children for lunch and I kill people in many countries of the world," Jurgen said.

South African finance minister and conference chair Trevor Manuel said it was a pity the protests had "descended into violence" and queried activists' motives. "I know what they're against but have no sense of what they're for," he said.

World Bank president James Wolfensohn asked conference attendees to recognise the "legitimacy" of the protesters' concerns. "Outside these walls young people are demonstrating against globalisation. I believe deeply that many of them are asking legitimate questions, and I embrace the commitment of a new generation to fight poverty. I share their passion and their question, but I believe we can move forward only if we deal with each other constructively and with mutual respect," he said.

Mr Wolfensohn furthered conceded the IMF and World Bank had a "lot to learn" about improving their efforts to combat poverty.

The annual meeting proceeded as planned inside the building, with speeches from Czech president Vaclav Havel and Mr Manuel.

The new managing director of the IMF, Horst Koehler, talked of the problems of globalisation: "I am aware of the critical debate about globalisation, and many questions raised have to be of concern to all of us. But I also want to be clear: if the IMF did not exist already, this would be the time to invent it. More than ever, globalisation requires cooperation, and it requires institutions which organise that co-operation."

Both Koehler and Mr Wolfensohn called for greater action to lift the living standards of the world's poor, focusing on better education and health care. Mr Koehler called on rich countries to lower their trade barriers on exports of farm goods and other products from poor countries, saying this could mean $100bn (£66bn) annually in extra sales by poor nations.

Mr Wolfensohn said that the processes tying the world more closely together economically cannot be stopped. "We cannot turn globalization back. Our challenge is to make globalization an instrument of opportunity and inclusion - not of fear and insecurity," he said.

The 15,000 delegates were transported at 5am this morning by bus to the conference centre. Czech police had conducted stringent border controls in recent days to ensure the conference took place without impediment, stopping almost 300 people with arrest records from previous anti-capitalism rallies. The authorities also deployed 11,000 police to strengthen security in Prague.

Alice Dvorska, spokeswoman for one of the main activist umbrella groups at Prague, the Initiative Against Economic Globalization, condemned police interference: "We condemn this attempt of the Czech government to prevent people from exercising their democratic rights to freedom of speech, movement and gathering".

fields.headline: Lord Archer charged with perjury
fields.trailText: Lord Archer was today charged with perjury and perverting the course of justice after he allegedly asked a friend to lie for him in court during his 1987 libel case, Scotland Yard said.
fields.body:
Lord Archer was today charged with perjury and perverting the course of justice after he allegedly asked a friend to lie for him in court during his 1987 libel case, Scotland Yard said.

A police spokesman said: "Jeffrey Archer has been charged with two counts of perverting the course of justice, two counts of perjury and one count of using a false instrument."

The 60-year-old former Conservative party deputy chairman and MP could face a jail sentence if he were found guilty of perjury, which carries a maximum prison term of seven years. Attempting to pervert the course of justice can, theoretically, carry a life sentence.

He was bailed to appear next Tuesday at Bow Street magistrates court in central London.

A Conservative party spokesman said: "This is a matter of criminal law. We have no comment to make."

The charges follow claims that he asked former friend Ted Francis to concoct an alibi for him during the libel case against the Daily Star. Lord Archer had been accused of sleeping with prostitute Monica Coghlan.

Coincidentally, the author was due to make his stage debut this evening in his courtroom drama The Accused, playing a doctor standing trial for the murder of his wife. At the end of the drama the audience is left to decide whether he is guilty or not, using electronic keypads.

Lord Archer is expected to appear for just under a month at a Windsor theatre before going on a national tour, ending up in the West End. He was taking part in a dress rehearsal of the play today before the first show, which begins at 8pm.

A spokeswoman for the Theatre Royal said: "The show must go on."

The millionaire peer was questioned by police earlier this year over the perjury allegations, which were first made against him during his campaign to become mayor of London.

He visited a Wimbledon police station this morning in a green BMW with his solicitor to hear the charges, spending an hour and 15 minutes inside.

One photographer was taken into the police station for questioning after Lord Archer left as photographers and journalists scrambled to get access to the disgraced peer.

fields.headline: The mermaid's tale
fields.standfirst: At the age of 39, and with over 30 films to her name, Daryl Hannah wants to be more than a movie star. The reason? All the rubbish she has been in. She tells  Phil Daoust about hack directors, next week's West End debut and the danger that she might be sick all over him
fields.trailText: At the age of 39, and with over 30 films to her name, Daryl Hannah wants to be more than a movie star. The reason? All the rubbish she has been in. She tells Phil Daoust about hack directors, next week's West End debut and the danger that she might be sick all over him
fields.body:
Daryl Hannah is looking fantastic: clear skin, sparkly eyes, glossy hair, not a day over 30, though she's just months away from the big four-oh. She's pale, but then she always has been. Let's just say that she shines . You'd never guess that a couple of hours ago she was throwing up in a theatre toilet.

"It's the second day I've been ill in a fortnight," she says. "All I've eaten today is a banana, and I couldn't even keep that down." She gulps and looks worried. Perhaps I do too, because she leans over and touches me on the elbow. "You won't catch it," she says with exaggerated concern. "I promise I won't kiss you."

Hannah has spent the afternoon rehearsing George Axelrod's 1950s comedy The Seven Year Itch, not just her West End debut but her first ever stage role. With a week to go until previews, rumours are flying. The producer has hinted she may strip off to play the lusted-after girl-next-door, and some imaginative soul has claimed that Hannah is "channeling" the ghost of Marilyn Monroe, who played the same part in Billy Wilder's film version. Not only is the deceased blonde bombshell giving Hannah hints about her acting; she's telling her the winning lottery numbers.

After the frenzy over Nicole Kidman baring all for theatregoers in The Blue Room, followed by Kathleen Turner and Jerry Hall in The Graduate, Hannah knows there's no chance of the critics forgetting to turn up on her first night. "Everyone keeps warning me," she says. " 'In England they're so mean. They're so hard-core. The press is out of control.' Everyone says I shouldn't even bother reading the reviews because they're so horrible."

So is it nerves that are making her ill? There was never any question of her appearing naked, she says: that suggestion was just "a cheap and cheesy way to sell tickets". But she feels exposed all the same. "Being in front of an audience for the first time will be the scariest thing. I just hope I get through it and don't embarrass anybody. I missed a whole section of the script during the run-through today. What if that happens in a week's time? What if I freeze or panic?" She has prescribed herself ginkgo biloba to improve her memory, but says she keeps forgetting to take it.

She doesn't seem paralysed by the danger - more anxious and thrilled, like someone watching a horror movie. But still. With more than 30 films under her belt, why did she want to try her luck on stage? "I'm not sure I did really," she says. She was talked into it by the play's director, Mike Radford, who had just finished bossing her around in Dancing at the Blue Iguana, his recently completed movie about strippers. "I was so honoured that he wanted to work with me so soon afterwards. But I still said no. Then I realised this might be the only time I'll ever have the chance to do something like this."

Does she go to the theatre a lot? "Not that often," she admits.

When Hannah was a teenager, she couldn't even get into the high-school play. Now she's the show's main selling point. The posters have just gone up on Shaftesbury Avenue: there she is in profile, looking unusually buxom in an underwired bra. "Yeah," she says, gesturing towards her breasts. "A much more 1950s shape. I really have a sort of boy's figure." As a kid she was known as Broomstick.

She makes this West End business sound very spur-of-the-moment. But Hannah has being trying to reinvent herself since the early 1990s. Her first big role, in Ridley Scott's 1982 movie Blade Runner, cast her as a homicidal android sex slave and won her a certain cult following; but she really made her name two years later in Splash, Ron Howard's charming updating of the Little Mermaid story, which stuck her in a fish tail opposite Tom Hanks. Oliver Stone put her in Wall Street (1987), his study of capitalist greed, Steve Martin wooed her in the romantic comedy Roxanne (1987), and she even got a chance to act dowdy alongside Dolly Parton in Steel Magnolias (1989). But she was heading for a string of forgettable features and kooky comic eye-candydom. Just the title of her 1993 telemovie tells all you need to know: Attack of the 50ft Woman.

By the early 1990s she was known more for her boyfriends than her career. After a violent argument to which the police were called, she left the rock singer Jackson Browne and began a relationship with John F Kennedy Jr that was to last three years. She would never talk about it, but that didn't stop the speculation about pregnancy, impending marriage and Jacqueline Kennedy's fury/ indifference/delight about her son's actress girlfriend. When a passer-by filmed the couple kissing on their doorstep for an impressive 16 minutes, the footage was broadcast coast to coast.

She's obviously bright, but it wasn't her brain that was used to promote her movies. "I would only do photoshoots, because I was too afraid to talk in person on TV, and they'd always dress me up like some glamourpuss. But that's not really who I am." Sitting in a restaurant booth in her T-shirt and denim jacket, a large fake-fur shoulderbag beside her, she looks more like a midwestern teen. "I don't like to be a ball-breaker, you see. It's in my nature to be a little acquiescent."

With many of her movies, she knew before filming was over that she'd never want to watch them. "I always took the best of what I got offered," she says with a smile, "but most of it was crap."

She doesn't sound bitter about it, but she's not the ranting sort. "I come from Chicago, and people from there tend to be pretty grounded. It's the centre of the country - they aren't as flighty as Los Angelenos or as frenetic as New Yorkers. And I never bought into that whole star thing. I realised early on that success is just a matter of fortitude and luck, and so I never took it personally.

"Maybe if I'd burst on to the scene with some Merchant Ivory film I'd have had a different career," she muses. Instead, what stuck in minds was Splash. Before she arrived at the restaurant, one of the waiters fishtailed his hand from side to side and asked if she would be swimming in.

Another door opened in 1994 when Hannah booked herself into a course in film production at New York University. Her homework, a 12-minute short called The Last Supper, was shown in film festivals around the world. The New York Times described it as one of the best films at Sundance. In Berlin it won the jury award for best short.

"I really did the course to learn about cinematography," she recalls. "I've noticed from working on films that no matter how shitty the movie is, the cinematographer is always an artist. They always try to make something beautiful.

"What I didn't expect was that I'd like directing and writing as well. Writing has always been a real struggle for me, and I've worked with so many hack directors that I didn't think that was a creative position. But on the course I realised that it can be if you take that upon yourself. Every single decision matters, whether it's what colour the paint on the walls is, or what the costumes are, or what angle to look at the scene through. I loved every second of it. I felt very calm and very centred and very much like I knew what I was doing, which I was surprised by. I felt comfortable."

Once the play has finished its run, she'll go back to her wilderness home in the Rockies, a solar-powered affair with a stream in the living room and grounds for her horses and the stray animals she has adopted. There may or may not be room for a man; she doesn't give much away. "The basic tenet of a love relationship is that it's intimate," she insists. "It's between two people - not you, the other person and the world. I've never really felt comfortable discussing it. Plus, as I'm sure every body knows, personal life is always in a state of growth or flux." She giggles. "Say one thing and the next day it may be a different story."

Anyway, she'll find the time to finish off her second movie, a feature-length documentary based on the interviews she did while researching her part in Dancing at the Blue Iguana. She's hoping to submit it to Sundance; there are more projects to follow.

Might she be a better director than the "hacks" she has worked with?

"Definitely. And that's weird, because I'm not a person who brags about things. It's been ingrained into me to be self-deprecating." True to form, she starts to stumble over her words. "But I have a very strange confidence about, er, I guess, my ability or not my ability but I guess more my desire and my, um, my ideas in that area. I just have a feeling that I'll be very good at it."

The bill arrives; Hannah has eaten a whole poppadom and so far it seems inclined to stay down. There's no sign of the taxi that is supposed to be picking her up, and she asks if I'll walk her back to her flat. She's fascinated by Soho's Friday-night bustle, by the crowds drinking outside the pubs, by the bicycle rickshaws. She seems invulnerable as she threads her way through the promenaders. I think of Pris, the android she played in Blade Runner - bright and deadly and larger than life. And then she becomes confused about the route and begins to wobble. "We might have to find a dark alley," she says. "I hope you're not one of those people who throw up just because someone else does."

Tomorrow is Saturday. At least she'll have the weekend off to get rid of whatever's squatting in her stomach.

"Oh no," she says. "Rehearsals in the morning, fittings in the afternoon. I have to go in or we'll never be ready in time."

Oh yes: The Show Must Go On. Her stage debut, and already she knows the golden rule.

 The Seven Year Itch is previewing at the Queen's Theatre, London W1 (020-7494 5040), from next Monday.

webTitle: I'm lost, alone, afraid and despised

fields.headline: I'm lost, alone, afraid and despised
fields.standfirst: The diary of a junior doctor
fields.trailText: Bedside stories: The diary of a junior doctor
fields.body:
I 'm beginning to suspect that I just cannot cope. I know I'm supposed to be having an awful time, I know that it's part of the job and it's not as bad as it used to be (every doctor over the age of 50 is proud to point that out), but this is real, this is me, I'm a real person and eight weeks ago I was a normal person and now I feel lost and alone and afraid and incompetent and out of my depth and despised for it.

The house officer on the next ward got a urinary tract infection last week from under-hydrating herself: what kind of ridiculous job do I have when the best advice your colleagues can offer is to eat whenever you possibly can, because you never know what might happen next, and make sure you watch your urine output? She treated herself with Augmentin (a sledgehammer) and was delighted to find that her patients weren't the only ones reporting mucous diarrhoea as a side effect. Experiences like this can teach us all an important lesson about taking drugs seriously (junkies kindly take note, and stop waking me up at three in the morning to ask for pethidine which you obviously don't need).

God, it's so tough. I get things wrong: I forget to do things, I run through the patients in my head when I'm in the cinema and compulsively phone the ward from my mobile to check I haven't messed anything up and killed anyone (come on, I'm being hysterical, not one of them is really that ill). No matter how many lists and counterlists I write in my little file, I always mess something up - only little things, honestly teeny things, like pursuing a scan report that would arrive by itself in two days anyway, but it makes me feel like an blubbery idiot on the verge of bursting into tears when my consultant asks me for results on the ward round and I just don't know them.

Of course I don't know them, I have to look them up. Nobody knows them, everybody has to look them up. How can I begin to expect you to understand how low I've been feeling when I don't even believe my fellow house officers? I whinge and moan and they all tell me it's the same for everyone, but I just can't believe it.

So have I become moody? Do I snap? No. I have reinvented myself as a slightly hysterical over-friendly ball of energy who dashes from one patient to the next repressing my anxiety and fear, multi-tasking like Shiva on amphetamines with three drug charts six blood forms and five sets of notes spread across my six pairs of hands, and I've been thinking about fitting my white coat (which I still love to pieces) with a few huge auxiliary pockets and a shoulder-mounted tank of nebulised Ventolin to spray onto the endless stream of asthmatics who pile in through casualty.

At least the heating's working now in my crappy hospital room, even if the radiator is burning hot and attached to the only wall long enough to have a bed against it (and I still need to close the door to open the wardrobe and pull out another unironed shirt). Fatigue enhances the effects of the cold and I still need to keep the window open to fumigate the airborne residue left behind by my stinky predecessor. Right now I'm shivering in two jumpers and trying to believe it's not just the caffeine.

The worst of it all was when my research registrar spent three whole days systematically pointing out to me and the consultant how shit I am at my job, before buggering off to some clever conference and leaving me alone on the ward with 30 patients. By my maths (and I've only been a doctor for two months) someone with eight years experience has precisely 52 times as much experience as me. His behaviour is exceedingly uncool.

So, in the military hierarchy of medicine I have resorted to the only form of catharsis available to me, and started taking it out on anyone I can find who is more junior than me. You think I've been bullying nurses? God, you're sick. I mean medical students. But even they seem to know more than me. I give up and take them to see a guy who lost his memory when he lost his liver (booze) and has now started confabulating. He doesn't have a clue what's going on around him but fills in the gaps with some rather imaginative nonsense, with an answer to everything. ("Sound familiar, Michael?" asked my registrar when he first demonstrated the phenomenon.)

The patient refuses to play ball, however, and seems perfectly oriented until I shrug and lead my troops away from the bed. "Oh, and when are we docking, Captain?" he asks. Quite.

webTitle: Dr Ann Robinson answers your health questions

fields.headline: Dear doctor
fields.standfirst: Dr Ann Robinson
fields.trailText: Dr Ann Robinson
fields.body:
Plagued by facial hair

I am 36 years old and since I was 22 I have been growing unnatural facial hair, first on the chin and, after I had children, on the neck and the side of the cheeks. To get rid of it I've tried everything from threading to bleaching to tweezing, but the results, especially for the chin, are not satisfactory. I am now thinking of laser treatment, but I am not sure whether it is completely safe and whether the results will be satisfactory, especially since it is so expensive. Also, could this problem have its root in an hormone imbalance, and, if so, how could I find out?

 Your recent growth of facial hair probably does represent a change in your hormonal balance, which is a common phenomenon after childbirth and as you get older. Losing excess weight can affect hormonal levels and make hair growth less severe. The contraceptive pill Dianette is a good option if you need contraception, can take the pill and want to help acne and excess hair. Laser hair removal requires several treatments, can leave permanent marks and cannot guarantee that the hair won't regrow. Some women I've spoken to have been delighted with the result, others have been rather disappointed. It's not available on the NHS and the best way of tracking own a reliable laser clinic near you is to ask a consulant dermatologist to whom your GP can refer you.

I'm missing a beat

I experience frequent "missed" heartbeats, particularly when feeling tired or ill or just under the weather. I have had an ECG and a chest x-ray, and my GP assures me that these are ectopic beats, and are nothing to worry about. However they can occur up to a dozen times a minute, and feel very alarming. Can you explain what they are, and what causes them.

 Missed heartbeats are actually due to an extra heartbeat followed by a prolonged period of resting by the heart in which it feels as though you've missed a beat! An extra beat every so often may be disconcerting, but is not usually part of a dangerous condition. The ECG can distinguish between the different patterns of extra heartbeats and other disturbances of the rhythm of the heart. The harmless type you have is known as extrasystole and can be exacerbated by stress and caffeine, but gets better when you exercise. If it is causing you concern or discomfort, you could see a cardiologist who may order other tests such as a 24-hour ECG to pick up any other rhythm disturbances that the one-off ECG may have missed.

Itchy nipples

I 've had extremely sore nipples in the last week which have been weeping and itchy. I can't feel any lumps in my breasts but I'm very worried about the problem. I'm 24.

 Two likely causes come to mind; if you've started running or jogging recently, it may be that your nipples may be rubbing against your top and are becoming irritated by the friction. A well-padded sports bra and Vaseline on the nipples sorts that out. The other possibility is that you've changed your soap powder and that soap residues in your clothes are irritating the skin of your nipples. Washing your clothes in a non-biological, hypo-allergenic powder should prevent a recurrence and 1% hydrocortisone cream on the nipples will sooth the irritation. I would see your GP if it doesn't clear up within a week.

fields.bodyText: Plagued by facial hair I am 36 years old and since I was 22 I have been growing unnatural facial hair, first on the chin and, after I had children, on the neck and the side of the cheeks. To get rid of it I've tried everything from threading to bleaching to tweezing, but the results, especially for the chin, are not satisfactory. I am now thinking of laser treatment, but I am not sure whether it is completely safe and whether the results will be satisfactory, especially since it is so expensive. Also, could this problem have its root in an hormone imbalance, and, if so, how could I find out?  Your recent growth of facial hair probably does represent a change in your hormonal balance, which is a common phenomenon after childbirth and as you get older. Losing excess weight can affect hormonal levels and make hair growth less severe. The contraceptive pill Dianette is a good option if you need contraception, can take the pill and want to help acne and excess hair. Laser hair removal requires several treatments, can leave permanent marks and cannot guarantee that the hair won't regrow. Some women I've spoken to have been delighted with the result, others have been rather disappointed. It's not available on the NHS and the best way of tracking own a reliable laser clinic near you is to ask a consulant dermatologist to whom your GP can refer you. I'm missing a beat I experience frequent "missed" heartbeats, particularly when feeling tired or ill or just under the weather. fields.headline: Vice and advice
fields.standfirst: So what you eat in the first few days after conception can seriously affect your baby's long-term health? Thanks for the warning, says  Kate Figes,   but women have to live in the real world
fields.trailText: So what you eat in the first few days after conception can seriously affect your baby's long-term health? Thanks for the warning, says Kate Figes, but women have to live in the real world
fields.body:
Mothers are now programmed to believe that everything they do affects the welfare of their children - for better and for worse. Plenty of chat and the right stimuli as babies will make them more intelligent in later life; cruel words or neglect may land them in therapy or turn them into criminal delinquents. Smoking and alcohol are well known health risk factors for babies. A deficiency in folic acid in the first few weeks of a foetus's life can cause neural damage and even spina bifida... and so on.

Now, a spate of research into the effects of diet on a woman at about the time of conception is ladling on yet more guilt before she even gets to shag the dad. It seems that a woman's health and diet in the hours before and after conception - before she may even realise she's pregnant - appears to have a profound affect on her baby's long-term health.

Research findings from the University of Southampton, released last week, suggest that female rats briefly starved of protein shortly after conception have offspring with a higher rate of defects. Their female offspring are underweight at birth, while the males have high blood pressure, shrunken livers and enlarged kidneys. Research at Queen's University in Belfast, also released last week, suggests that the official advice of four units of alcohol per week for pregnant women may be under-cautious, for the mildest tipple may affect the foetus's nervous system. Research at St Thomas's Hospital in London, released earlier this month, seemed to show that eating too much fat and too little protein can create cardiovascular disease, regardless of how healthily the child lives after birth. Yet more research, from the University of North Carolina, has shown that gum disease can be as harmful to an unborn child as smoking regularly, for women with severe gum disease are seven times more likely to have a premature baby with low birth weight than those without.

Then there is the rather thorny issue of toxins - harmful chemicals in the environment, pesticides, additives and hormones in our food - that build up in a woman's fat tissues over the years and get passed onto the foetus through the placenta and to the baby in breast milk. According to the World Health Organisation, people should ingest a maximum of 10 nanograms of polychlorinated chemicals and dioxins a day. Yet babies in western Europe, at two months old, are taking in on average 170 nanograms a day from their mothers' milk. (Natural birth advocate Michel Odent has devised a detoxifying regime for prospective parents to maximise the health chances of their as yet unconceived child.)

Clearly there is bound to be a link between the diet of a mother and the health and welfare of her unborn child when she is manufacturing another human being. She "eats for two", with the growing foetus hijacking valuable nutrients such as calcium away from the mother to ensure its own healthy development. But how are women to differentiate between what may be significant and irrelevant when they understandably do not want to do anything that may harm their unborn child?

Firstly, the experiments on protein deficiency were carried out on rats and there is no guarantee that we behave in the same way. Secondly, most of this research has been conducted on small samples and is by no means conclusive. Thirdly, and perhaps more importantly, everything we do or consume and perhaps even feel is bound to have some sort of an effect on growing children but if we stop to analyse all this and attempt to control it we drive ourselves mad with self reproach and risk, reverting to the dark old ages of superstition. My grandmother always maintained that my mother was born with a missing ear lobe because a bullet had grazed her own ear when she was pregnant. However, that perverted gene has jumped a generation and affected one of my nieces proving, perhaps, that the cause lay elsewhere.

Living beneath an electricity pylon or near a nuclear power plant may increase the chances of cancer. Walking through busy streets in all likelihood increases respiratory diseases and asthma. Driving a car through rush hour traffic or working in a stressful job must raise a pregnant woman's blood pressure and any form of emotional distress will provoke adrenalin in both mother and baby. But this is modern life - we cannot avoid potential dangers and live enveloped in cotton wool. It won't be long before scientists find a tenuous link between excessive consumption of chocolate biscuits and hair loss or jogging and the shape of a babies nose. Diet in pregnant women is more balanced today than it has ever been. Babies are born fatter and healthier than ever, and more survive until adulthood than ever before in history. We know more about their nutritional needs, but we still indulge them with packets of fat-laden crisps, yoghurt pots heaving with unnecessary sugar and junk food riddled with additives. How can science disentangle genetic factors and the unhealthier ways we live our lives from the effects of a pregnant woman's behaviour on her unborn child? There is no way of knowing how many health problems are genetically programmed and beyond our control or the direct result of diet in pregnancy. This thirst for research into the impact of maternal behaviour on the foetus may equip some women with greater knowledge about how best to safeguard her baby's interests but the net effect is yet more guilt, as well as an uneasy sense that one can control the whole process of reproduction. Yet so much of it is still mysterious and down to chance.

Clearly, any woman longing for a child wants to maximise the health and safety of her unborn child. But the danger is that there is so much that is beyond her control that all she may be left with is an encroaching sense of inadequacy, and what sort of start does that give to mother and child? Mother's matter, a great deal. If this research genuinely empowered them to be better mothers without cranking up all those feelings of guilt and inadequacy then it would be genuinely useful. But we're human too - and fallible. We all need that odd drink to lift the spirits, a bag of chips or a bar of chocolate for occasional comfort, and often pregnant women smoke because life is tense and stressful rather than the calm oasis that medical researchers and natural birth activists maintain it should be. Women do not exist just for the sake of reproduction. They live with the stresses and conundrum of modern life and inevitably they pass some of that on to their children.

fields.headline: First the good news...
fields.standfirst:
A reassuring new government report on the contamination of food by pesticides is not telling the whole story, says John Vidal

Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: A reassuring new government report on the contamination of food by pesticides is not telling the whole story, says John Vidal
fields.body:
You can't see, taste or smell them, but the pesticide residues found in almost all meat, fruit, veg, milk and poultry are consistently one of the public's greatest environmental and health concerns. Now the Ministry of Agriculture has come up with an alternately reassuring and worrying report.

The good news is that Professor Ian Shaw, outgoing chair of the pesticides residues committee, believes that the short-term effects of the minute doses of poisons we consume with many foods are so low as to be of "no concern". His team took 2,300 random samples from shops and suppliers and analysed them for more than 85,000 pesticide/commodity combinations.

Less than 1.6% had residues above the minimum recommended levels, and less than 1% had residues of pesticides banned from the UK. The sampling was deliberately biased towards common foods and fruits that were most likely to be contaminated.

And the worrying news? There's plenty. A few thousand samples from the many hundreds of thousands of tons of food sold every year in Britain may be statistically slight, but 1% of samples translates into a great number of potential poisoning incidents.

To give an indication, official figures from the US - where sensitivity to pesticide residues is far higher and regulatory standards generally tighter - suggest that 74,000 children were involved in pesticide-related poisonings in 1994. Adjusting populations, this could mean that something like 20,000 children in Britain are being poisoned to some degree each year.

Secondly, testing pesticides for their impact on health is inexact and, critics say, flawed. Many of the thousands of pesticides routinely applied to food cannot be easily detected by government laboratories. Few have been tested on humans, and almost nothing is known about potential effects on the immune system. The US National Academy of Sciences has estimated that the data needed to conduct a thorough assessment of the health effects of pesticides is available for only 10% of the ingredients used.

The third and most worrying point is that toxicologists such as Shaw admit they haven't much of a clue about the long-term effects of residues. Many foods are laced with not just one pesticide, but many. How they interact and perhaps accumulate, and the effects they may have on humans, remains a mystery. The Food Standards Agency is setting up a working group to investigate the impact of cumulative exposure.

A further cause for concern is that children are most at risk. They have unique vulnerabilities because their excretory systems are not fully developed and they are not always able to fully remove pesticides from their bodies.

Another area for concern is the globalisation of the food industry. Britain is importing more and more food, often from countries without strictly monitored pesticide regulations and grown by farmers who may be untrained in agri-chemical use. Furthermore, pesticides banned from use in this country may still be legally used overseas.

It is not easy for the consumer. Cooking, washing and peeling food normally minimises the level of pesticide residues on foods, but not all, especially those grown with "systemic" pesticides - those that are absorbed into the plant. Some residues have been shown to concentrate, not diminish, through cooking and processing. Labelling is nonexistent.

Governments, and the increasingly allied chemical and food industries, are reassuring. The risks, they say repeatedly, are minimal, and standards are improving as farmers steadily decrease pesticide use with updated farming systems. Nevertheless, they advise people to wash all food thoroughly and to eat a wide variety of foods to reduce exposure.

Much baby food is now organic, using ingredients grown virtually without pesticides, and millions of adults who can afford it are following the same route with their own diets. Organically grown food can, of course, be contaminated with micro-organisms, and all foods may contain natural carcinogens, but in all cases washing food is considered the best short- and long-term precaution.

fields.headline: Blood simple
fields.standfirst: Devotees of the latest diet craze say you should eat and drink according to your blood type. The theory's great, says  Oliver Burkeman. Shame about the facts
fields.trailText: Devotees of the latest diet craze say you should eat and drink according to your blood type. The theory's great, says Oliver Burkeman. Shame about the facts
fields.body:
It is all Martine McCutcheon's fault. This time last year, the "blood group diet" was emphatically a fringe practice - popular enough on the wilder shores of American food-faddery, perhaps, but strictly non-mainstream here. There wasn't, after all, much medical backing for the central claim of the diet's originator - a bow-tied doctor from Stamford, Connecticut called Peter D'Adamo - that your blood type holds the key to your optimum diet: that eating only those foods suited to your blood would, as D'Adamo hyperbolically put it, "lead you back to the essential truths that live in every cell of your body and link you to your historical, evolutionary ancestry."

But that was before the EastEnders star went public with her enthusiasm for the diet which, she announced, had made her "look and feel totally different". Elizabeth Hurley and Hugh Grant were soon reported to have followed suit, and D'Adamo's book - published in the UK as The Eat Right Diet - has enjoyed sustained success in the bestseller charts since.

In some parts of the world - especially Japan - one's membership of blood group O, A, B or AB has long held a roughly similar status to one's star sign, a piece of information treated as essential by dating agencies and even by some recruiters. But D'Adamo (a naturopathic doctor, as opposed to a medical one) broke new ground in proposing a scientific mechanism to explain why blood type - previously of medical interest mainly for matching the donors and recipients of blood transfusions - could hold the key to nutritional health.

The theory is bewitchingly simple. Each of the four blood types - characterised by the presence or absence of certain molecules, called antigens, on the surface of red blood cells - emerged at different stages of human evolution and so, D'Adamo argues, members of each group should stick to the foods and exercise styles prevalent at that time. Type O emerged 50,000 years ago, when hunting and gathering were dominant, so today's type Os, "the hunters", are best suited to a meat-heavy diet, low in dairy products, and to intense exercise. Type As, "farmers", whose blood group dates from the dawn of agriculture, should be largely vegetarian, while type B, the "nomad", dating from times of mass migration, is suited to most foods except wheat, shellfish, chicken and some pulses. (D'Adamo never really gets to the bottom of AB, the rarest blood group, which he labels "the enigma" and on which he places the fewest dietary restrictions.) In Britain, most of us are hunters: 45% of the population is type 0, 43% type A, 9% type B and just 3% type AB.

Too much of the wrong foods for your blood type, D'Adamo argues, and lectins - a type of protein - in the food will cause clotting reactions in the blood, leading to obesity and numerous illnesses including irritable bowel syndrome and cirrhosis of the liver. But with enough of the right foods, weight loss is pretty much inevitable: "I'd dare to say," D'Adamo writes of the first type Os, "that there wasn't an overweight Cro-Magnon on the planet!"

The popularity of the theory - like any that postulates a genetic, rather than environmental, cause for obesity - is partly due to the fact that it explains why certain diets work for some people and not others, without accusing the failures of being cheats guzzling chocolate when nobody's looking. Unsurprisingly, the theory is proving a hit with food manufacturers too - already, a product line of teas matched to blood groups, entitled Sip Right 4 Your Type, has been launched by the California-based company The Republic of Tea.

But D'Adamo's theories have drawn aggressive fire, not just from rival dieticians - who often have vested interests or who advocate vegetarianism and take exception to his anti-vegetarian recommendations for type Os - but from mainstream medicine as well. Most nutritionists simply refuse to accept the basic mechanism at the heart of the theory.

"It's cobblers," says Professor Tom Sanders, head of the department of nutrition and dietetics at King's College, London. "There's no phsyiological reason to believe that energy balance should be altered by the type of antigens your blood has on it - the idea is laughable. But because most people don't understand science, you can get away with it: it appeals because it's a pseudo-scientific explanation for why some people seem able to maintain their weight and others need only to look at a cream bun to put on weight."

One of the theory's key flaws is that it seems unable to account for the massive rise in obesity in recent decades to today's levels (in Britain, one in five women and one in six men is obese, while a further 45% of men and 33% of women are overweight). Needless to say, what people were eating in the years before this increase began did not resemble D'Adamo's prescriptions.

In any case, critics argue, blood type simply does not have the significance that D'Adamo ascribes to it. First discovered in the early 1900s by the Austrian physician Karl Landsteiner, the ABO system for distinguishing blood cells has since been complemented by a huge number of alternative classifications. While there is evidence that a small number of conditions are correlated to blood type - Type As seem to be at a significantly increased risk of stomach cancer - such examples are far too rare to lend support to D'Adamo's theory.

Tim Gorski MD, a US doctor and contributor to publications advocating a sceptical stance towards alternative therapies, calls D'Adamo's theory "awesome nonsense... people who would scoff at proposal that a car's paint colour determines what sort of gasoline or oil should be used for the vehicle, or that a home's exterior brickwork determines how the furniture inside should be arranged are nevertheless apparently willing to consider this particular delusion." (D'Adamo was unavailable for comment this week, his personal assistant explained, the popularity of the blood type diet meaning his diary was completely full for some time.)

Advocates of the diet do not deny that other factors, both genetic and environmental, have an impact on obesity. The blood type diet is, D'Adamo insists, "not a panacea": it might work for you and it might not, and if it doesn't that doesn't mean the theory is wrong. Whatever the latest weight-loss theory, it seems, having your cake and eating it is still the preferred option for dieticians.

 The easiest way to discover your blood type is to donate blood. Contact the National Blood Service (0345 711711). The Eat Right Diet is published by Century Books, price £6.99.

Most nutritionists simply refuse to accept the basic mechanism at the heart of the theory. "It's cobblers," says Professor Tom Sanders, head of the department of nutrition and dietetics at King's College, London. "There's no phsyiological reason to believe that energy balance should be altered by the type of antigens your blood has on it - the idea is laughable. But because most people don't understand science, you can get away with it: it appeals because it's a pseudo-scientific explanation for why some people seem able to maintain their weight and others need only to look at a cream bun to put on weight." One of the theory's key flaws is that it seems unable to account for the massive rise in obesity in recent decades to today's levels (in Britain, one in five women and one in six men is obese, while a further 45% of men and 33% of women are overweight). Needless to say, what people were eating in the years before this increase began did not resemble D'Adamo's prescriptions. In any case, critics argue, blood type simply does not have the significance that D'Adamo ascribes to it. First discovered in the early 1900s by the Austrian physician Karl Landsteiner, the ABO system for distinguishing blood cells has since been complemented by a huge number of alternative classifications. While there is evidence that a small number of conditions are correlated to blood type - Type As seem to be at a significantly increased risk of stomach cancer - such examples are far too rare to lend support to D'Adamo's theory. Tim Gorski MD, a US doctor and contributor to publications advocating a sceptical stance towards alternative therapies, calls D'Adamo's theory "awesome nonsense... people who would scoff at proposal that a car's paint colour determines what sort of gasoline or oil should be used for the vehicle, or that a home's exterior brickwork determines how the furniture inside should be arranged are nevertheless apparently willing to consider this particular delusion." (D'Adamo was unavailable for comment this week, his personal assistant explained, the popularity of the blood type diet meaning his diary was completely full for some time.) Advocates of the diet do not deny that other factors, both genetic and environmental, have an impact on obesity. The blood type diet is, D'Adamo insists, "not a panacea": it might work for you and it might not, and if it doesn't that doesn't mean the theory is wrong. Whatever the latest weight-loss theory, it seems, having your cake and eating it is still the preferred option for dieticians.  The easiest way to discover your blood type is to donate blood. Contact the National Blood Service (0345 711711). The Eat Right Diet is published by Century Books, price £6.99.

webTitle: Italians stunned as PM quits on chat show

fields.headline: Italians stunned as PM quits on chat show
fields.trailText: Giuliano Amato, the prime minister of Italy, announced last night that he would concede the leadership of the centre-left government to his rival Francesco Rutelli, the mayor of Rome.  Mr Amato told an amazed chatshow audience that he would resign before next year's general election because only the telegenic mayor could stop Silvio Berlusconi's resurgent centre-right opposition.
fields.body:
Giuliano Amato, the prime minister of Italy, announced last night that he would concede the leadership of the centre-left government to his rival Francesco Rutelli, the mayor of Rome. Mr Amato told an amazed chatshow audience that he would resign before next year's general election because only the telegenic mayor could stop Silvio Berlusconi's resurgent centre-right opposition.

Coalition partners had been urging Mr Amato, 61, a competent but dry technocrat, to quit in favour of Mr Rutelli, 45, whose good looks and youth score highly in opinion polls.The prime minister had repeatedly vowed to fight to keep his job but appeared to have cracked as Mr Rutelli's challenge gathered momentum.

Mr Amato said: "If this situation continues there will be division. The duel between Amato and Rutelli is not helping the centre-left. For me, being the king or the kingmaker is the same thing."

He intends to stay in office until just before the election, due by April.

His words transformed the political landscape. Polls show that a centre-left led by Mr Rutelli stands a significantly improved chance of defeating Mr Berlusconi, a media tycoon and former prime minister.

Mr Amato, internationally respected for guiding Italy through a financial and political crisis in 1992, was burdened by his association with Bettino Craxi, a disgraced Socialist prime minister. Since winning power in 1996 the centre-left has lost cohesion as Mr Berlusconi emerged from the shadow of corruption accusations to make an alliance with the far-right Northern League and National Alliance.

Mr Rutelli, a former radical and Green, has a high profile and has has been positioning himself towards the centre. He has rediscovered his Catholic faith and was widely praised for his handling of the Vatican's 2000 jubilee, or holy year; it has attracted millions of pilgrims to a spruced-up Rome.

fields.headline: Digital divide still gaping
fields.trailText: The digital divide is as alive as ever, according to figures released today by the office of national statistics.
fields.body:
The digital divide is as alive as ever, according to figures released today by the office of national statistics.

The survey, conducted in July, shows that 55% of people have still never accessed the net - and that people are far less likely to have done so if they are elderly, female or from a lower social class.

The widest discriminating factor is age. More than half of adults under 54 have accessed the net, but the figure drops to 6% for the over-75s.

The social gap is almost as wide - 66% of individuals from a "professional" household have been online, compared to just 20% of those classed as "unskilled".

Some 52% of men have been online, compared to 39% of women.

The survey also shows widespread scepticism of e-commerce. Of those who had just accessed the net, just 28% had bought goods or services. Most adults were happier looking for information online, using email or just surfing around.

fields.headline: Vivendi hopeful for Seagram merger
fields.trailText: French media group Vivendi has received a boost in the battle to get European Commission clearance for its merger with Canadian rival Seagram, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
French media group Vivendi has received a boost in the battle to get European Commission clearance for its merger with Canadian rival Seagram.

The competition commission has extended the deadline for ruling on the deal from October 2 to October 13, though a spokesperson refused to disclose details of what the companies had offered.

A source close to the negotiations told MediaGuardian that comparisons with the AOL and Time Warner merger, which is also being scrutinised by the commission, are wide of the mark.

"A lot of people are making comparisons between the two mergers," said the source. "But that is pointless. The main problem with AOL and Time Warner is that they are also merging with EMI. Vivendi has no music industry interests of its own, so there are far fewer problems with negotiations."

A Vivendi spokesperson said the company was confident of receiving clearance for the merger by October 13, but refused to give details of the negotiations, except to say that they involved making undertakings rather than concessions. Canada's Competition Bureau approved the deal last month, and Seagram said the US Federal Trade Commission has hinted that it would also give the go-ahead.

A successful merger would see Vivendi merging with its 49%-owned pay-TV arm, Canal Plus, and entertainment and drinks group Seagram, to create a £23bn media giant called Vivendi Universal. The new company would combine Seagram's Universal Music and Universal Pictures subsidiaries with Vivendi's expanding telecoms and internet businesses.

The competition commission can still initiate a four-month, in-depth investigation into the merger if it is not fully satisfied with the undertakings offered by the companies. The commission has set a deadline of October 24 for making a final decision on the AOL/Time Warner merger, with its decision on the Vivendi /eagram link-up likely to be seen as a portent.

Meanwhile, Swiss luxury goods firm Richemont yesterday sold its holding of 17.5m Vivendi shares. The company refused to disclose the buyer in the transaction, which netted the company E1.175bn (£707m).
