webTitle: First World Chaos, Third World Calm

fields.headline: First World Chaos, Third World Calm
fields.standfirst: Kader Asmal, Chair of the World Commission on Dams, talks of former protests against the World Bank and the IMF, and contrasts them to the work of his organisation.
fields.trailText: Winter: World Trade Organization riots in Seattle. Spring: World Bank/International Monetary Fund standoffs in Washington, DC. Then the May Day clashes in London and Berlin. I watch the escalating rhetoric, arrests and police crackdowns from South Africa with a touch of irony. The BBC shows large groups of comfortable, educated protesters violently confronting and challenging the legitimacy of smaller groups of equally well-nourished trade leaders, industrialists, agency heads and finance chiefs, all over the aid or agony global capitalism brings to nations like mine.
fields.body:
Winter: World Trade Organization riots in Seattle. Spring: World Bank/International Monetary Fund standoffs in Washington, DC. Then the May Day clashes in London and Berlin. I watch the escalating rhetoric, arrests and police crackdowns from South Africa with a touch of irony. The BBC shows large groups of comfortable, educated protesters violently confronting and challenging the legitimacy of smaller groups of equally well-nourished trade leaders, industrialists, agency heads and finance chiefs, all over the aid or agony global capitalism brings to nations like mine.

As one who spent three decades exiled by and agitating against a country that did not recognize my vote, I fully support dissent and the freedom to express it. As one who has spent half a decade helping lead that country, I share the frustration when dissent and expression regress from a means into merely an end, smothering the message in the process. But from both perspectives, I wonder: Why not cut out the middle men and take the debate over globalization directly to third world cities like Sri Lanka, Brazil, Egypt, or Vietnam? Why not, to make it interesting, lock both sides indoors, face to face?

I ask these questions not to be churlish, but for three reasons:

First, these relatively poor places are precisely where the debate on "global development" - defined either in terms of McDonald's and Monsanto or agricultural subsidies and debt forgiveness - matters most. Second, their impoverished people - one billion lacking reliable tap water, two billion without electricity - are those for whom both sides claim to speak with authority. Lastly, over the past 18 months, one multinational authority tackled exactly these issues, in exactly these places, on the ground, and with surprisingly productive, nonviolent results. When chaotic protest becomes the norm in Europe and America, such pockets of calm are breaking news.

That 'multinational authority' is the narrow-mandated, tight-staffed and short-lived World Commission on Dams. Born in controversy, it was established in 1998 - by globalization's protagonists and antagonists alike - to assess a critical aspect of international development and investment: which, how, where and why earth's 45,000 large dams have either worked or failed to deliver as expected. To do so, it analyzed seven dammed river basins under a microscope; studied the experience with dams in Russia, China and India; and evaluated trends through a cross- check survey of 150 dams worldwide.

Based on the distilled evidence from this global review, the WCD will make authoritative recommendations and set rigorous criteria and guidelines for the construction, operation, overhaul and even decommission of new and existing dams.

Which all sounds harmless enough. But the process can feel like putting out fire with gasoline. No natural resource, even gold, is more precious to any given country than its water. And no public tool has been more widely and controversially used for parting - and imparting - those water, than dams. Decisions over dams are decisions over sanitation. Crops. Drinking water. Health. Electricity. Flood control. A nation's future.

Dam building is a $42 billion a year industry. In recent decades it has forced 4 million people from their homes each year; or roughly 11,000 per day, 450 every hour, 8 per minute. Not surprisingly, conflicts between governments building dams and people affected by dams have resulted in violence, occupation and alienation; conversely, there have been attacks on governments when dam projects were cancelled. In time of scarcity, dams are even believed by some leaders to have the capacity for triggering wars between nations sharing the same river. Now, in the interest of full disclosure, I chair the Commission. But I agreed to do so only after ensuring that, unlike so many self-perpetuating bureaucracies, our office would shut itself down, lock up and disband after fulfilling its two-year mandate this November.

I back our mandate, but there are tense moments when I take comfort in our limited life span. Like when things grow suddenly testy between one commissioner who has spent his life engineering large dams around the world and another who has devoted her life to stopping one. Or when, starting on December 10, 1998, two hundred pro- and anti-dam forces from Pakistan, India, Bangladesh and Nepal converged upon our first meeting in Colombo, with a real potential to explode. Instead, we sat the protagonists opposite each other and asked them to explain to the Commission, in words of one syllable, their opposing perceptions. First, that dams, if done right, are critical tools for governments to use. Second, that over-centralised planning can devastate nature, cut off water that had been the lifeblood of villages for generations, and flood religious, cultural sites and homes with minimal concern for those affected.

To be sure, there were heated moments. Government officials spoke passionately of growing populations, increasing demands for food, power and drinking water, national development goals and their responsibility to the people.

Affected peoples talked equally passionately of their villages being destroyed, of resettlement in inadequate sites and the impersonal nature of the State when faced with real people living real lives with little food security and real livelihood risks.

For three full days they talked. We listened. We absorbed a clash of perspectives. And we built on common ground, noting and respecting divergences. We made progress if only due to the fact that people felt they finally had the chance to put their case in a neutral arena, and that the Commission had listened to all sides. No crackdowns. No arrests.

But perhaps that was just beginner's luck.

In Sao Paolo, Brazil, on August 11, 1999 we had no sooner banged the gavel than word came that our meeting would quickly be overrun by nearly a thousand people who had been displaced by dams in Brazil. They had not been invited, but were moments away. Should we contact the police? Disband? Instead, we welcomed most of them inside, while the rest queued peacefully, sat listening to the debate and departed as quietly as they had come, their points made, listened to, and documented.

In Cairo, December 8, 1999 we had to grapple with the delicate Middle Eastern politics of trans-boundary waters between Turkey and Syria, Jordan and Israel, and even protests from people directly affected by dams financed in large part by South Africa where I was Minister for water affairs. Again, we left unscathed, having brought both sides closer together.

By Hanoi, February 26, 2000 we wrestled with the delicate Asian dynamic of complex relations between governments and civil society movements, some of whom are persona non grata at home and abroad. Yet once again we found acceptable ways for them to make their views heard and ensure that all sides of the debate are on the table.

No one party was excluded. Ever. For exclusion breeds resistance. We can and do recognise divergence, but above all we must provide a neutral, free and ordered space, where violence is replaced by verbal debate, shouting by listening, chaos by calm.

There is nothing novel to this approach; it is just rarely tried on the scale of a global theater. Also, few other institutions are small, finite or focused enough to attempt this. But it goes beyond a method soothing tensions to a standstill; it seeks to harness the dynamic forces out there, enfranchise them toward a mutually acceptable solution that lets all parties move forward, and turn them into forces for change, rather than merely blind resistance.

Critics, from both sides, have cited the World Commission on Dams as a model for resolving disputes over globalization. That's flattering, but much too early to say. We have merely managed to take the debate off the streets, and clear one small patch of political ground over which the terms and conditions of a key dimension of global capitalism - imparting the wealth of water - can be negotiated.

A parting warning: doing so is never a neat, organized, tidy concerto. More often, the process becomes a messy, loose-knit, exasperating, sprawling cacophony. Like pluralist democracy, it is the absolute worst form of consensus buildingexcept for all the others.

Kader Asmal, South Africa's minister of water affairs and forestry under Nelson Mandela, and now education minister, chairs the World Commission on Dams.

webTitle: Money back guarantee for Dancer in the Dark

fields.headline: Money back guarantee for Dancer in the Dark
fields.trailText: Host of bad reviews for Dancer in the Dark prompts distributor to offer a refund to punters who watch the film and are less than impressed when it goes on wide release on September 29
fields.body:
Punters who go to see Dancer in the Dark this Friday and come away less than impressed will get their money back, reports Ananova today.

FilmFour, which distributes the film in the UK, has taken this extraordinary step because of the host of bad reviews the film received when it was released in the West End last week. It goes on general release across the country this Friday.

FilmFour deputy chief executive Peter Buckingham said in a statement: "If you go see Dancer in the Dark on September 29 and decide, having watched the film to its conclusion, that the experience was not worth the price of your ticket, the cinema manager will refund your money to you."

Dancer in the Dark won a number of awards at Cannes this year, including the best actress gong for its leading lady Björk. Directed by Lars Von Trier, it tells the story of Czech immigrant Selma (Björk) and her son. Working long hours in a factory, Selma's only escape is her love of Hollywood musicals. It was described as "the most sensationally silly film of the year - as well as the most shallow and crudely manipulative" by the Guardian's Peter Bradshaw (see review), while another asked: "How could anyone have admired or been moved by this tedious, banal, incompetent movie?"

webTitle: Transcript: Harriet Lane interviews Anna Nolan (I)

fields.headline: Transcript: Harriet Lane interviews Anna Nolan (I)
fields.trailText: Question: So what have you been doing since getting out?
fields.body:
Question: So what have you been doing since getting out?

Answer: Since I left I've been staying a lot in my flat, lying low. I've seen lots of people going out here there and everywhere and I thought, no. I just wanted to go home, and be at my home, just chill and relax.

Question: Why did you want to do that, rather than go out and celebrate?

Answer: I didn't want to go to those big parties you see [the other contestants] all being filmed and photographed and I thought I've had enough of that, you know, almost drove me mad for 10 weeks. Even though C4 offered security because apparently everyones homes was being bombarded by the media... you know, ours wasn't! No one was bleeding interested! I was like: no I don't want any security, I don't want anybody at all around.

Question: So why are the others behaving so differently?

Answer: I think it's just so tempting, they know they're going to mingle with the stars. it's from one extreme to the other, and fair enough when I was in the house I was dreaming of going to the party and having pints and whatever. it's an extension of the personalities as well, the people who are going out, know what I mean, were the ones, even in the house, who wanted attention

Question: This all begs the question that we were asking when we were watching it, which is, what on earth were you doing in it, cos it just didn't seem at all ..

Answer: Me.

Question: There was a lot of positive identification with you, but at the same time, that made us think, why does she want to be on it?

fields.headline: Transcript: Harriet Lane interviews Anna Nolan (II)
fields.trailText: Question: When you think back, what is your defining moment, what is you clearest memory, that just says Big Brother House to you.
fields.body:
Question: When you think back, what is your defining moment, what is you clearest memory, that just says Big Brother House to you.

Answer: Waiting. Waiting, waiting for a shopping list, waiting for nominations, I was tense, I would say, 6 out of the 9 weeks .On and off, I'd say 70% I found it a strain, waiting for nomina... having to nom... who's going to be evicted and ... the difference of say the first two weeks when we had to make an effort to chat to everybody and all this noise[?] going on, being exhausted because you're like, I have to make polite conversation with somebody, compared to, um, this last 3 days of sheer and utter, oh that I'd never ever experienced anything, the last few days, ever.

Question: You didnt look as if you were having the easiest time communicating with Craig. You all became a bit polarised, and you did look sort of like someone had hit you over the head with a frying pan. You all did, you all had a kind of glazed look at the end.

Answer: Yes, exactly. It was because, I just didn't want to talk to anyone and so I was ... cos I was tense. I was so bored, I'd finished my books, I had nothing, there wasn't even a shopping list to bloody write, we didn't have to look after the garden cos we were going in 3 days, there was nothing nothing nothing. People say well why didn't you ... it's like ... cos there was nothing. And there was bad weather. And also we didn't want to talk to each other because why, why should we talk to each other, all we would talk about was that.

Question: There was nothing left to say?

Answer: Well, in 3 days time one of us is going to win 70,000 pounds. No one ever really, no one talked about that. About winning.

fields.headline: Vodafone's deputy chairman quits
fields.standfirst: Vodafone earmarks £100m for web projects
fields.trailText: Vodafone deputy chairman Dr Klaus Esser has resigned just four months after joining the board, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Dr Klaus Esser has resigned as deputy chairman of UK mobile phone group Vodafone, just four months after joining the board.

Esser was head of German rival Mannesmann before it was snapped up by Vodafone for £108bn earlier this year, following a hard-fought takeover battle.

A Vodafone spokesperson said Esser was brought in to oversee the integration of the two companies and agreed to leave when the job was done.

Chris Gent, chief executive of Vodafone, said: "We greatly appreciate the contribution that Klaus has made to the integration process of Vodafone and Mannesmann and wish him well for the future."

fields.headline: Transcript: Harriet Lane interviews Anna Nolan (III)
fields.trailText: Answer: Yeah. I was so freaked out by the whole thing, and everyone there was talking over the top of them, oh my god, it was like, god, I haven't seen you, oh, are you all getting in with each other, have you all seen the tapes, what's the real feeling going on here, and I just didn't want to say anything to anyone because, it's such a wind down process, the fact that people were leaving, they were gone from the house and then we had to adapt so quickly, you couldn't miss anyone, you adapt so quickly and then the next day you'd always forget about the people who had gone. Everyone knows that we became the most fickle group of people ever, seeing them all there again was like, Jesus.

Question: You'd sort of got your head round the idea that you wouldn't see them again and that was it.

Answer: Oh yeah.

Question: So is there any of them that you're going to stay in touch with?

Answer: Mel. And I'd like to give Darren a bell

Question: Have you seen either of them since you got out?

Answer: Yes. I saw Mel today and we went for lunch a couple of days ago.

Question: So you're getting a bit of sort of attention on the streets and stuff, but it's all benevolent is it?

Answer: Lovely. Men going, Alright my darling? You alright?

Question: They all voted for Craig, people like that.

Answer: Really? Alright I'll give them the fingers the next time they say it.

Question: Was there an element of disappointment that you didnt win?

Answer: No.

Question: You sure? Because that must have been ...

Answer: I wanted to win the day before, I really thought, fuck, I really want to win, I really do, it would be lovely. And then, I didn't, and then ... I knew Craig would win, even from the first week Craig would win. Disappointment? Yeah a bit, but then you're like, what have you won, what's this programme all about, well, has the most interesting person won? has the most intelligent person won? Has the most combination of all? You know. Do I want the mass of the UK and Irish public to like me? I only want the people who I think I would like, to like me. I don't want mass popularity.

Question: What are you planning to do now? What's your game plan?

Answer: What's my game plan? "lot of things in the pipeline," which means not going to say anything or I'll be turned down. I'm going over to do the Late Late Show tomorrow night in Ireland. You have to do that. Possibly the Priory next week. And then, all these offers have come in, newspapers, and I said I don't want any newspapers, just one, that's fine, um ...

Question: Did you particularly want the Observer? Thats what we were told.

Answer: Yeah.

Question: You don't have to say that...

Answer: I said, I said the Observer, Guardian, Telegraph. And I was just like, no tabloids, and then, the Observer was mentioned, I said yes that's great.

Question: Right. So are you going to do TV presenting?

Answer: Yeah, well not TV presenting, there's maybe a couple of documentaries that have come in, that they're interested in me doing, which is nice. Yeah, me infront of a camera. Not being all ... I'm not a personality that would go down well on TV I think. Just ... stuff that I'm interested in.

Question: Right. Are they comedy things or a series or ...

Answer: Um ... I don't know if I should say.

Question: Give me a vague hint

Answer: Kind of I suppose factual look at certain different cultures and life, that sort of thing, and commentary on ... and going away to places and ... etc.

Question: So what about the music stuff, is that something that you've going to pursue?

Answer: I wanted to but there's very little scope, seemingly, for following up the music.

Question: Was this a surprise? Disappointment?

Answer: A wee bit, yeah, a wee bit. Television wise there's very little music coverage on television. It's bizarre, but, and there's a chance of a slot on a radio station, having a little show, where I talk rubbish everyday! That would be great!

Question: Is that in London or ...

Answer: Yeah yeah. Not a mainstream station. I don't want a recording thing.No. I'm not that good, really I'm not.

fields.headline: Vodafone earmarks £100m for web and wireless projects
fields.standfirst: Vodafone deputy chairman quits
fields.trailText: Mobile telecoms giant Vodafone has launched a £100m global fund to invest in wireless and internet ventures writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Mobile telecoms giant Vodafone has launched a £100m global fund to invest in wireless and internet ventures.

Vodafone Ventures is to be managed by a wholly owned Vodafone subsidiary and will target first and second stage private equity investment opportunities of between £2m and £10m.

Leading investment bank Goldman Sachs will advice Vodafone Ventures on its investments and have the option to co-invest in projects.

Vodafone's chief executive, Chris Gent, said: "We view the creation of Vodafone Ventures as providing an important vehicle for investing in an area of great strategic significance for Vodafone."

webTitle: Granada and Carlton shares slip after ITV ad revenue forecast

fields.headline: Granada and Carlton shares slip after ITV ad revenue forecast
fields.trailText: Shares in Granada Media and Carlton continued to slide today, after Merrill Lynch downgraded its ITV advertising revenue forecast for this year . By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Shares in Granada Media and Carlton have continued to slide this afternoon, after a report from investment bank Merrill Lynch cut estimates of Granada profits for 2000 due to ITV's absence from Sky Digital and concerns over its takeover of United News & Media.

Just after 3pm, Granada Media's share price had fallen 8.5% to 506.50p, from an opening price of 550.00p. Carlton, though not singled out by Merrill Lynch, had seen its share price slip 4.9% over fears for ITV's advertising revenue this year.

Merill Lynch estimates Granada Media's profit before tax for 2001 at £256m, down from £321m due to ITV's anticipated poor fourth quarter 2000, as well as "more prudent accounting" of the assets Granada purchased from United.

The bank's media and entertainment team, led by Neil Blackley, has calculated that ITV will lose £62m worth of advertising revenue in 2000, largely due to the continuing absence of the channel from Sky Digital homes.

It forecasts that ITV will earn £1.953bn, downgraded from £2.015bn, in 2000, according to an analyst's briefing note published on Monday (September 25) and leaked to MediaGuardian.co.uk.

Merrill commented that ITV's fourth-quarter advertising revenue performance "seems to be getting weaker by the minute, and October could be down 17%, with November also down, by a lower 3"'. The first half of 2001 is also likely to show "minimal growth off a very strong first half of 2000", according to the Merrill report.

The briefing note estimated the trend towards Sky Digital viewers using the broadcaster's electronic programme guide to navigate to programmes had "resulted in a 45% fall in viewership of ITV in Sky Digital enabled homes".

"ITV is continuing to suffer from badly declining audiences, exacerbated by its lack of presence on digital satellite," the Merrill team concluded. "We believe ITV will have to go on satellite in 2001."

Even assuming ITV joins Sky Digital in the second half of 2001, the Merrill report reduced ITV's ad revenue growth estimate for next year from 4% to 3%. But the team forecast that the extra 2.5 minutes advertising per night ITV will be allowed in primetime from January 1 as part of the News at Ten deal with the Independent Television Commission could potentially add 4%, or £80m, to its annual ad revenue.

webTitle: Collymore to leave Leicester after contract row

fields.headline: Collymore to leave Leicester after contract row
fields.trailText: Stan Collymore's career at Leicester City looks over after the club today agreed to his transfer request. Manager Peter Taylor admitted: "I would be surprised if I played him again."
fields.body:
Stan Collymore's career at Leicester City looks over after the club today agreed to his transfer request. Manager Peter Taylor admitted: "I would be surprised if I played him again."

Rumours emanating out of Filbert Street this morning suggested that Collymore had been sacked and his contract terminated immediately. However, the 29-year-old told Sky this afternoon that this was not the case.

"I faxed a transfer request to the club at the beginning of the week," he said. "If you are not playing you do not seem to be in the first XI plans. But let me state that I don't want to leave Leicester.

"All I want to do, having come back from a broken leg, is to play regular first-team football. My aim is to get back into the England squad and I don't think I am going to do that by coming on for 20 or 30 minutes in a game."

Yet according to reports, Leicester manager Peter Taylor was ready to terminate the contract of the former Liverpool and Aston Villa star - and Collymore initially had the same viewpoint after the pair met on Monday.

But Collymore backtracked from that standpoint after speaking with his advisers and instead asked to go on the transfer list. The striker was unhappy about his lack of first-team starts during Leicester's flying start to the current campaign.

In a press conference this afternoon, Taylor attacked the level of application shown by Collymore, who had demanded a substantial wage increase and a new contract before the start of the season.

And he admitted that Collymore's dismal performance in Sunday's 1-1 draw with Everton at Filbert Street was the last straw.

Taylor said: "Stan would have to change in many ways to ever play for Leicester City again - and I would be surprised if I played him again.

"When he came back initially for pre-season training he was doing well but then nine days before the start of the season his advisers asked for very high wages and a new contract. As a club we were not prepared to meet those and since that day Stan has not been as positive as he was in the early part of pre-season training.

"He had an injury and couldn't get back in the team and his performance against Everton made it obvious when he was on the pitch that he was not happy with that decision.

"I was very disappointed with that. He could have worked a lot harder and I told him the way he played was not the way he should be performing. I said that if he was going to play like that then it would be in the best interests of Leicester City that he was no longer with us.

"When we had that meeting on Monday we agreed that his contract would be terminated but then his advisers told him instead to go on the list. I could not be more disappointed about how things have worked out because we all know how good a player he can be.

"I think Leicester City and myself could not have tried any harder to get him to be the player he is but things like getting fit and having the right sort of desire to succeed have to come from him.

"He has put on a stone since pre-season training."

It now seems that Collymore's career in England could be over as the player has indicated to Taylor that he wants to end his playing days abroad.

Meanwhile, the FA have confirmed that their video advisory panel will meet later this week to review Collymore's clash with Paul Gascoigne during Leicester's 1-1 draw with Everton on Sunday, during which he appeared to stamp on - and later elbow - Gascoigne.

FA spokesman Adrian Bevington said: "We have requested the video which we are then going to distribute to the three members of the 12-man video advisory panel.

"If something is brought to our attention that has been missed by an official we can then call for the video and send it out to the three panel representatives - which we have done in this instance.

"They will be making their recommendations to our chief executive, Adam Crozier, who will decide what action to take, if any is needed."

webTitle: Officers dismissed radar warning of Exocet attack on HMS Sheffield

fields.headline: Officers dismissed radar warning of Exocet attack on HMS Sheffield
fields.standfirst:
Invincible lost 19-minute chance to issue alert during Falklands conflict

'Precious time was passing us by'
fields.trailText: Officers aboard the aircraft carrier Invincible failed to alert other British warships about the first Exocet missile attack during the Falklands conflict although they had 19 minutes warning, it was revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Officers aboard the aircraft carrier Invincible failed to alert other British warships about the first Exocet missile attack during the Falklands conflict although they had 19 minutes warning, it was revealed yesterday.

One missile - fired from an Argentine plane first spotted on radar 180 miles away - hit the destroyer HMS Sheffield, killing 20 men and wounding 24. The Ministry of Defence confirmed yesterday that a series of sightings on HMS Invincible were dismissed by senior officers as "spurious" and that no warning was passed to other ships in the Falklands task force.

HMS Sheffield, only on half-alert and with its own radar not fully operational, got little more than a minute's warning. The attack caused the first mass British casualties of the south Atlantic war in 1982.

Yesterday a former radar operator on the carrier, David Forster, 37, said the officer who decided not to warn the fleet should "admit and explain" his decision: "I want him to apologise."

He said the officer, in the Invincible electronic operations room, dismissed sightings by him and other operators by accusing them of "chasing rabbits". Mr Forster added that he personally felt he had "let 20 men die" by failing to insist that other ships were alerted. "This has been on my mind for the last 18 years.

"I should have stood up and shouted, 'There's something coming in, believe me - alert the fleet.' I'll always punish myself in my conscience for the death of those men. The Sheffield was a sitting duck. It never had a chance to change course, fire its chaff [anti-radar foil] or even its missiles. Remorse and sadness lie heavy on my heart."

The MoD ruled out an inquiry into the conduct of the officer responsible, whose identity has not yet been officially confirmed. "No doubt the officer will still be thinking 'if only'," a spokesman said.

Remorse

"I don't think that blame is the word, given the set of circumstances. But that does not relieve him of a sense of personal and professional regret."

Last night Des Keoghane, organiser of the Falklands Families Association, said, "I have spoken to a parent of one of the Sheffield dead. He has not heard of this before - and neither have I."

Invincible's then captain, Admiral Sir Jeremy Black, who rose to be home fleet commander-in-chief and an aide de camp to the Queen before retiring from the navy in 1992, declined to comment.

The MoD confirmed the incident, on May 4, 1982, after a Guardian investigation into separate accounts from two ex-able seaman radar operators on the Invincible. The operators, now civilians, have not previously disclosed what happened

Inquiries established that the incident was confirmed soon afterwards in the Falklands Deployment Book, a souvenir volume of recollections of Invincible's role in the south Atlantic written by officers. Circulated only to crew members in January 1983, six months after the liberation of the Falklands, it says the radar sightings were classified as "spurious".

A Royal Navy Sea Harrier fighter was asked to check with its airborne radar "but could find nothing", the deployment book says. The Exocet hit the Sheffield 19 minutes after the first sighting by Invincible, according to its timetable of sightings.

This crucial series of radar traces was not known to the eminent historian David Brown, formerly of the Royal Navy historical branch, when he wrote what the navy regards as the nearest thing to an official history of the conflict at sea.

Mr Brown's book, The Royal Navy and the Falklands War, says that before the attack "there were no bogeys [unidentified aircraft assumed to be hostile] on any of the radar screens".

Mr Brown notes that in previous days a series of radar false alarms had led to British warships being put on full action stations. His history says the Sheffield was first warned by another destroyer when the two Argentine Super Etendard attack planes - with top flying speeds of 733mph - were only 25 miles away. Her own radar was jammed because officers were making a satellite phone call to fleet headquarters in Northwood, London. They ended the call and spotted the Etendards on their radar 20 miles away.

False alarms

The planes fired Exocets from 12 miles away. One of them locked on to the Sheffield. It had "little more than a minute's flying time to reach the Sheffield", Mr Brown says. The only warning given to the crew was a Tannoyed shout: "Missile attack - hit the deck".

At the time of the attack the Sheffield's unlucky crew was "only in second degree readiness rather than at full action stations", according to another history of the naval conflict. This was "in order to give the crew a short respite. Electromagnetic interference from [the satellite phone] blanketed her detection gear". The Exocet did not explode, but its friction caused a fuel explosion which swept the destroyer with flames and poisonous smoke.

David Forster, who now lives in Victoria, Australia, said: "In the task force we perfected a drill called Red Alpha which closes a ship down into full action stations and battle readiness in four minutes.

"Men are at their radar displays or manning their guns. Most are at their fire-fighting stations. You could defend yourself against any attack. You could dodge and weave, turning at the last moment to confuse an attacking missile.

"I could have given those men on the Sheffield more than four times four minutes if only I'd stood up and said 'Alert the fleet' after getting those contacts on my screen. I had the time to do it. I should have been strong enough to break the chain of command, even if it meant getting my arse kicked.

"I have carried the shame of that day with me and will do until I die."

The man sitting next to him in Invincible's ops room, Mark Booth, 37, son of a Royal Navy signals operator and now a professional golfer who lives in Buckingham, said his memory fully confirmed Mr Forster's account of the radar contacts.

"They were absolutely crystal clear contacts. I was adamant that they were true contacts. I would have bet my house on them.

Hostile aircraft

"After we reported them, they went on to a universal screen in the ops room with the symbol HA for hostile aircraft, the number of the contact and a line plotting the aircrafts' approach to the task force. A lot of people had that on their screens."

But he did not recall any remark by an officer about "chasing rabbits" and disagreed with Mr Forster on the issue of guilt. "We did exactly what we trained for in reporting the contacts. It was for other people in the ops room to act on that information. It is every ship's job to make the rest of the fleet aware of such things.

"Invincible was closer to those contacts and smaller ships don't have the same radar. Any responsibility is on other people's shoulders, not David's. If he had made a fuss in the ops room, he would simply have been treated as hysterical. I feel no guilt at all and David should not. Although we were only 19 at the time, we were very, well trained. We were very good at our jobs. We had the fast reactions that young people often have on electronic matters."

The MoD spokesman said: "David Forster must not blame himself. The buck stops somewhere. Someone else had to make that decision." The Sheffield incident was the Royal Navy's first encounter with low-flying, Exocet-carrying attack planes. Many positive lessons had been learned from it, especially in warship design.

The destroyer's fire-gutted hulk finally sank six days after the attack. This Argentine success - coming only two days after the British sinking of the cruiser General Belgrano, with more than 300 Argentine deaths - doomed diplomatic negotiations and established the Falklands conflict inescapably as a shooting war.

In May 1983, the next of kin of the Sheffield dead were taken by helicopter to the place where she sank so they could cast wreaths into the sea.


David Forster's story

"As I was the long-distance air surveyor, I operated 1022 radar which covered 258 miles down to 18 miles radius from the ship. I was sitting at my display when a contact appeared at 180 miles. So I waited for the next sweep - and there it was again. I logged it into the computer and reported it as I'd done so many times before.

But this time [an officer] said there was nothing there. The next sweep of my radar came and there it was, now at 160 miles. I reported it again. But the same thing happened. Precious time was passing us by, we did not alert the fleet. We did nothing.

The next sweep of my radar, it was at 130 miles, so I reported it again. This time [the officer] became annoyed and told me 'You're chasing rabbits'. My mate now reported a contact at 120 miles and closing. I changed my display down to watch it closer. The contact was now at 80 miles and closing.

The radar swept again but this time there were two contacts. The second contact was only on our display for two sweeps when it disappeared under radar coverage. This indicated that we were dealing with an Exocet missile designed to skim above the waves. My mate and I reported the double contact and the fact that one had suddenly disappeared. [An officer] told us that we were 'riding a bike'.

Slowly the machines in the ops room began ticking away with the information that Sheffield had been hit. We were shocked with disbelief. An officer came up to us and began handing round sweets.

I should have stood up and shouted, 'There is a fucking contact, there's something coming in, believe me - alert the fleet'. I'll always punish myself in my conscience for not having done that. But you're trained to obey the chain of command regardless. It had been drummed into me."

Mark Booth's story

"I was sitting next to David. We were literally shoulder to shoulder. I knew him very well at the time. He was a very good radar operator.

He nudged me when the first contact came in. We already knew from a contact in Chile that the Argentinian aircraft had launched, so we were expecting something.

David was the very first person to see them. I saw them as clearly as he did. It is quite a disturbing thing to see an enemy aircraft approaching your ship. He was very nervous and could not speak, so I transmitted his message to the air picture supervisor. We definitely said that they were clear contacts.

What he says about the other contacts is correct. The screen giving the identification goes on to everybody's screen in the ops room. There was nothing more David could have done at all."

webTitle: Robin Cook's speech to Labour party conference

fields.headline: Robin Cook's speech to Labour party conference
fields.trailText: Margaret, friends,
fields.body:
Margaret, friends,

You have just heard from the man who has led Croatia away from the narrow politics of ethnic nationalism and put it on the path to modern European democracy.

And now the people of Serbia also have voted to join modern Europe.

With results in this morning from two thirds of the polling stations, the opposition are way ahead by 20 percentage points. In his home town, his own stronghold, Milosevic lost in every polling station. Even the army and the police, the backbone of his power, voted against him.

Last night we saw tens of thousands of Serbs dancing on the streets of Belgrade with delight that he was overthrown.

The only person who does not seem to know he lost is Milosevic himself. We know he was always planning to rig the central count. He had even written a new programme for the election computer and he didn't get it from elpac.

But even Milosevic cannot conceal a defeat on this scale.

Let's give Milosevic a clear message while he is trying to decide who won. Don't rob your people of their vote for change! Accept their verdict and go!

We are on the verge of a new era for the Balkans. One that puts the politics of hate into history.

It would not be happening if this government had not stood up to Milosevic when he attempted the brutal ethnic cleansing of Kosovo. We demonstrated that his fascism of ethnic cleansing belongs to Europe's past. We made it clear that we would not tolerate it returning to Europe's future.

My regret is that the last Tory government wasted years in Bosnia refusing to stand up to ethnic cleansing. If they had shown the same resolve then Milosevic might have gone long before now.

And now that the Tories are in opposition, they still refuse to stand up for human rights.

Every now and again one of the press exposes that I travel more than any other cabinet member. One of them was gracious enough to say that at least as foreign secretary I had an excuse to travel.

What I remember most from my official visits this year is not the capital cities.

It is a camp I saw in Sierra Leone for 2,000 amputees. Every one of them a victim of rebel atrocities. Many of them children.

Most of them had a hand lopped off. Some of them had lost both hands. Wherever I looked, I saw people holding out stumps, pleading for protection.

The Tory defence spokesman has said we should withdraw from our commitment to Sierra Leone. I challenge him to go to that camp and tell those victims of the rebels that the Tories are in favour of abandoning them.

We are in Sierra Leone out of simple human decency. We are there because it is in our interests that democratic government should not be overthrown by terrorism.

We are there because we believe that everyone, whatever their colour, whatever their continent, has the same equal right to freedom that we have.

When you look back over the past parliament, you can be proud of what your government has done around the world.

Proud that across Africa and Asia there are villages with safe water, children with primary schools and mothers with health care, because Labour reversed the Tory aid cuts.

Proud that it was the British ambassador who led the protest at the suppression of Aung San Suu Kyi.

The Burmese military sent 200 riot police to detain one woman. That's how dangerous they find her ideas of freedom and democracy.

Those are our values too. That's why we demand they set free Aung San Suu Kyi.

Proud that it was your government that banned the export, import and production of landmines.

I remember queuing up to hear Lord Justice Scott prising the truth out of the Tory government about their arms sales to Iraq. It gave me a lot of pleasure to hear him say that he had read Labour's annual report on arms exports, and he was "amazed by the difference".

We have produced the fullest, most comprehensive annual report on arms exports of any country in Europe.

We agreed a code of conduct on arms sales with the rest of the EU.

One under which we all apply the same strong standards on human rights.

One which for the first time gives us the right to object if any partner takes up an arms contract we refused.

We have made sure that those who are denied the truth by their own government can hear it through us.

On Thursday, Conference will hear Nelson Mandela, who was encarcerated for almost 30 years by the apartheid regime. Throughout those long years, his only window to the outside world was a radio which could receive the BBC World Service.

Nelson Mandela would approve that your government has reversed the Tory vandalism of the World Service.

Because of Labour's investment, it now reaches 150m people worldwide.

That public diplomacy between peoples is just as important as the official diplomacy between governments.

So that we can do both better, we have made the Foreign Office more representative of all the diversity of modern Britain.

A 50% increase in staff from ethnic communities. A 100% increase in the number of women Ambassadors and heads of post.

The Foreign Office should represent all the people of Britain. And should serve all the people of Britain.

Every year tens of thousands of British Muslims go on the Haj pilgrimage to Mecca. This year Britain was the first western country to provide consular help on the Haj for British citizens.

We have put human rights at the heart of our foreign policy.

Last week's report on our record by Amnesty concluded: "The balance sheet shows a record of real achievement".

But we have to be realistic. If we want to make a difference in the world, we cannot do it alone. We do it by setting the agenda in the unique range of international organisations to which Britain belongs. And that is what we have been doing.

In the G8, where Britain has been in the lead in securing relief for the poorest countries burdened by debt. We are freeing those countries from the debts of their past so that they can afford to educate the children that are their future.

At the UN, where Britain is leading the campaign to expose the illicit trade in diamonds from regions in conflict. The price of diamonds should not come with a cost in human life.

In the Commonwealth, where under Labour Britain is now at one with our partners. In contrast to the Tories who made themselves a minority of one in opposing sanctions against apartheid.

Partnership abroad is essential if we are to succeed at home.

If we want to live in peace then we need to strengthen our alliances.

If we want factories with full order books, then we need to widen our trade agreements.

If we want to protect our national environment then, we need to negotiate global commitments to halt climate change.

That is the way to promote Britain's interests. To work in partnership, to set the agenda. To find common cause with other countries.

It comes easy to Labour to do that. Our movement is built on the principles of partnership, of solidarity, of cooperation.

But that's not the Tory way. I have read their new international policy. It doesn't take long. One of the reasons it doesn't take long is that it does not mention a single one of those international organisations. Nothing on the G8. Nothing on the UN. Nothing on the Commonwealth.

It is the first time in history that a party has tried to produce a foreign policy while trying to avoid working with foreigners. Especially if they're Europeans.

Tory policy on Europe reveals no trace of being influenced by its impact on our 14 partners. But it might have been made up by someone under the influence of 14 pints. Or who had spent too much time reading the Europhobic press.

They have threatened us: - that lollipop ladies will be harmonised; that darts will be banned from British pubs; and that rubber ducks will be banished from British bathtubs. Tell your readers the truth about Europe. Tell them 3m British families depend for their living on exporting to Europe. Tell them five thousand American and Japanese companies have invested in Britain because we are in Europe.

One Tory frontbencher has said we should renegotiate our terms of membership or "pull out if we cannot".

We want a more democratic Europe. We want a new role for national parliaments in European decision-making.

Those are our priorities for a second term. The priorities of a government that knows that Britain's security, prosperity, and democratic values are strengthened by a healthy international community.

I see William Hague has called his new policy "Believing in Britain". What a miserable, shrivelled, shrunken thing is the Tory vision of Britain. A country hostile to its neighbours, frightened of foreigners and bigoted about people who come from other continents.

We believe in Britain. But we believe in all of Britain. We will not accept sneers at overseas doctors who work hard for our hospitals. We enjoy living in a multi-cultural society. We welcome the strength it gives us in our relations around the world.

And that is what we will offer the people at the election. A Britain that is a leading partner in Europe and a force for good in the world.

fields.headline: Lord Borrie to succeed Rodgers as ASA chairman
fields.trailText: Lord Borrie QC has been named as the next chairman of the Advertising Standards Authority, reports Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Lord Borrie QC has been named as the next chairman of the Advertising Standards Authority. He will take over on January 1 from Lord Rodgers of Quarry Bank, who is retiring after six years in the job.

Lord Borrie's appointment was announced by Winston Fletcher, chairman of the Advertising Standards Board of Finance, which funds the ASA from a levy on display advertising.

Mr Fletcher said: " We are fortunate in having secured the services of a man of Gordon Borrie's experience and distinction. He is supremely qualified to lead the Council of the ASA and will give confidence to all who wish to see advertising self-regulation succeed".

As director general of fair trading, Gordon Borrie was in charge of the Office of Fair Trading from 1976 to 1992. He chaired the Labour party's commission on social justice from 1992 to 1994 and was created a life peer in 1995.

Lord Borrie served on the Council of the Consumers' Association and has written on consumer law. He was President of the Institute of Trading Standards from 1992 to 1996 and has been Chairman of the Direct Marketing Authority since 1997.

His appointment runs for four years.

webTitle: News in brief and the latest casting news

fields.headline: News in brief and the latest casting news
fields.trailText: No more storms for Dancer in the Dark's star and director, open your eyes to the plot for Tom Cruise's latest, Gwyneth takes to the skies, and Mel B goes 'oop north'
fields.body:
 Dancer in the Dark's star Björk and director Lars Von Trier have apparently kissed and made up. The two rowed repeatedly during the shooting of the film, but have now put their spats behind them. Björk explained: "In Denmark, I was in a situation similar to Selma's, where I was surrounded by people who did not understand me at all The conflict was not me and Lars it was between my character Selma and Björk." Von Trier added: "The experience with Björk was difficult because it was unpleasant, but once we were filming we had an incredible connection. She was so willing to absorb, to become the character."

 The plot of the new Tom Cruise (pictured) film Vanilla Days has finally been revealed, according to Yahoo News. The film, to be directed by Cameron Crowe, will be an adaptation of the 1997 Spanish romantic thriller Abre los ojos (Open Your Eyes). The plot focuses on a rich womaniser who falls in love with his best friend's girlfriend. The project, which has long been a passion for Cruise, is also set to star Cameron Diaz and Penelope Cruz (who starred in the original Spanish version).

 Variety reports that Gwyneth Paltrow is close to signing on to star in a new romantic comedy called View From The Top. The film, about a small-town woman trying to achieve her goal of becoming a flight attendant, is due to start filming in December under the direction of acclaimed Brazilian film-maker Bruno Barreto.

 Spice Girl Mel B to set to star as a single mum living on a Newcastle housing estate in a forthcoming British short film. The film, called Fish, "was a bit of a contrast to the Spice videos," revealed the singer on the pop group's official website.

fields.headline: Queercompany seeks new ad agency
fields.trailText: Gay and lesbian financial services provider, Queercompany, has split from its ad agency St Luke's and is seeking another agency. By Jade Garrett
fields.body:
Queercompany, the online start-up offering financial products and services to the gay and lesbian market, is shortlisting a number of agencies for its account, following a split with St Luke's.

The company, run by former Air Miles acting managing director, Wanda Goldwag, has been working on its strategy with St Luke's for the last five months but now wants an agency to develop its first ad campaign.

Al Young, creative director of St Luke's, commented: "It is a totally amicable split. We think they are a fabulous organisation and don't doubt their success for a moment, but the reason we've parted company is that after a period of strategic development we had categorically different views over what was the best executional way forward."

Queercompany.com recently secured £3.5m in funding from venture capital firm Smedvig Capital.

fields.headline: Fightback speech from impassioned Blair
fields.standfirst:
Prime minister admits: 'I made people angry' - but defends government's record
Policies and key soundbites
fields.trailText: In the most important speech of his political career, Tony Blair today set out his "second-term vision" to appreciative Labour party delegates.
fields.body:
In the most important speech of his political career, Tony Blair today set out his "second-term vision" to appreciative Labour party delegates.

The prime minister admitted he had "made people angry" over his handling of the fuel crisis, pensions and the Millennium Dome.

In his keynote speech to the Labour party conference in Brighton, Mr Blair conceded that the government had suffered in the opinion polls over these issues.

But he reminded the party faithful that Labour had created 1m jobs, increased public spending and strengthened the economy. He told delegates in Brighton he wanted to set out the big choices facing Britain.

"After the events of two weeks ago, it's no wonder the government has taken a knock," he said. "It happened on my watch and I take responsibility."

In a conciliatory gesture, Mr Blair said: "There are things we have done that have made people angry and we should be open enough to admit it." He said he should have listened to people's "agony" over fuel duty - but added that he was also listening to those who wanted an increase in NHS spending, extra investment in schools, more police on the beat and better public transport.

"I owe you an explanation. Yes, petrol is expensive. But of the 14p rise since the Budget last year, 12p has been in the world oil price, which is why these protests have taken place all over the world. It's true that it's cheaper elsewhere in Europe, but VAT is often higher there, income tax is higher, business taxes are higher.

"All in all, Britain has the lowest overall tax burden of any large industrialised nation in the world except Japan and the USA."

The prime minister admitted that many older people wanted a bigger pension but said he made no apology for helping the worst-off first."Seventy-five pence," he said. "I tell you now, as Gordon [Brown] made crystal clear yesterday, we get the message.

"But I believe that when people reflect on the big fundamentals that determine our future - the economy, jobs, public services - we are doing the right thing and we are on the right track for Britain.

"We rejected returning to the earnings link. For the next two or three years we could afford it; but 10, 15 years down the line, it would have imposed a huge financial burden on a future generation that would have been unfair to them."

For the first time, the prime minister expressed public regret over the Millennium Dome. He said: "Hindsight is a wonderful thing, and if I had my time again I would have listened to those who said governments shouldn't try to run big visitor attractions."

Mr Blair said that he was elected to lead and that he had to make "decisions of destiny" on Britain's behalf. The last government, he said, had locked Britain into a cycle of boom and bust that the Labour party had to draw to a close to create a budget surplus.

"Don't ever let them con this country into boom and bust again," he told delegates to applause.

In a crowd-pleasing attack on the Tory party, the prime minister heaped derision on William Hague, who was always looking for a bandwagon "and then three came at once". "Opportunism always knocks for William Hague," he said, before adding his name to the long list of conference speakers who mocked the Tory leader's alleged drinking habits. "Everything makes sense after 14 pints: John Redwood looks sane. Michael Portillo looks loyal. After 14 pints, even William Hague looks like a prime minister... I don't think so."

The Tories would only take Britain backwards, Mr Blair said. "We are in a fight - and it's a fight I relish. For it is a fight for the future, the heart and soul of our country.

"Their policies may change every five minutes but their prejudices do not."

Mr Blair said though his government should be "proud of our record" the party should be not become complacent. The prime minister received a four-and-a-half-minute standing ovation at the end of his speech.

Policies

 10-year plan for the NHS
 The transformation of secondary education
 Cradle-to-grave poverty strategy
 Harnessing new technology to spread prosperity to all
 Making the streets safe and society strong
 10-year plan for modern transport
 Next steps to full employment

Key soundbites

Education: "Education. Education. Education. Then, now and in the future."

Crime: "It is time for zero tolerance of the yob culture."

The Millennium Dome: "Hindsight is a wonderful thing."

Foreign affairs: "I say to Milosevic - you lost. Go. Your country and the world has suffered enough."

Pensions: "I am listening, I hear and I will act."

Employment: "I want to be the first prime minister in 40 years to stand up and say: 'Britain is back at full employment'."

The NHS: "The Labour party will never abandon what was one of the greatest civilising acts of emancipation this country has ever known."

Asylum: "If people want me to go out and exploit the asylum issue for reasons of race, then vote for the other man, because I won't do it."

Petrol: "I am listening to people's anger over fuel duties. For hauliers and farmers, to say nothing of ordinary motorists, there is real hardship."

New Labour: "One of the things I take most pride and pleasure in is that the Labour party today is more united in its ideas and policies than at any time I can remember."

"I tell you now, as Gordon [Brown] made crystal clear yesterday, we get the message. "But I believe that when people reflect on the big fundamentals that determine our future - the economy, jobs, public services - we are doing the right thing and we are on the right track for Britain. "We rejected returning to the earnings link. For the next two or three years we could afford it; but 10, 15 years down the line, it would have imposed a huge financial burden on a future generation that would have been unfair to them." For the first time, the prime minister expressed public regret over the Millennium Dome. He said: "Hindsight is a wonderful thing, and if I had my time again I would have listened to those who said governments shouldn't try to run big visitor attractions." Mr Blair said that he was elected to lead and that he had to make "decisions of destiny" on Britain's behalf. The last government, he said, had locked Britain into a cycle of boom and bust that the Labour party had to draw to a close to create a budget surplus. "Don't ever let them con this country into boom and bust again," he told delegates to applause. In a crowd-pleasing attack on the Tory party, the prime minister heaped derision on William Hague, who was always looking for a bandwagon "and then three came at once". "Opportunism always knocks for William Hague," he said, before adding his name to the long list of conference speakers who mocked the Tory leader's alleged drinking habits. "Everything makes sense after 14 pints: John Redwood looks sane. Michael Portillo looks loyal. After 14 pints, even William Hague looks like a prime minister... I don't think so." The Tories would only take Britain backwards, Mr Blair said. "We are in a fight - and it's a fight I relish. For it is a fight for the future, the heart and soul of our country. "Their policies may change every five minutes but their prejudices do not." Mr Blair said though his government should be "proud of our record" the party should be not become complacent. The prime minister received a four-and-a-half-minute standing ovation at the end of his speech. Policies  10-year plan for the NHS  The transformation of secondary education  Cradle-to-grave poverty strategy  Harnessing new technology to spread prosperity to all  Making the streets safe and society strong  10-year plan for modern transport  Next steps to full employment Key soundbites Education: "Education. Education. Education. Then, now and in the future." Crime: "It is time for zero tolerance of the yob culture." The Millennium Dome: "Hindsight is a wonderful thing." Foreign affairs: "I say to Milosevic - you lost. Go. Your country and the world has suffered enough." Pensions: "I am listening, I hear and I will act." Employment: "I want to be the first prime minister in 40 years to stand up and say: 'Britain is back at full employment'." The NHS: "The Labour party will never abandon what was one of the greatest civilising acts of emancipation this country has ever known." Asylum: "If people want me to go out and exploit the asylum issue for reasons of race, then vote for the other man, because I won't do it." Petrol: "I am listening to people's anger over fuel duties. For hauliers and farmers, to say nothing of ordinary motorists, there is real hardship." New Labour: "One of the things I take most pride and pleasure in is that the Labour party today is more united in its ideas and policies than at any time I can remember."

webTitle: Cook's conference speech is missed opportunity

fields.headline: Cook serves up a bitter dish
fields.standfirst: The foreign secretary chose to moan and thereby missed his chance to shine, writes Julian Glover
fields.trailText: The foreign secretary chose to moan and thereby missed his chance to shine, writes Julian Glover.
fields.body:
Robin Cook's speech to the Labour conference this morning delivered exactly what Tony Blair wanted: little applause and less interest. As a result, Blair's big conference moment this afternoon is guaranteed to get all the attention.

True, the foreign secretary was speaking in the conference's graveyard spot: at 11am most people in the hall were still recovering from last night's excesses.

And it's true, too, that most of the attention was always going to go to the prime minister. But Cook appeared to do his utmost to avoid making an impact.

While Gordon Brown barnstormed the conference yesterday with a potent cry for government action, and Mo Mowlam the day before offered a quiet apology for New Labour's errors, Robin Cook sedated delegates with a discontented ramble through world affairs.

His speech revolved around a pair of international demons. The first of these twins was "Milosevic", for whom Cook seems to have such a hatred that he never uses his first name. The foreign secretary celebrated Milosevic's defeat in the Yugoslav elections - before any official announcement of the results. Good news, no doubt: though it is doubtful whether dancing on Milosevic's political grave is the best way to persuade him to leave power.

The other demon was the Tory party, and it occupied much of Cook's speech. Either the foreign secretary was short of good news to deliver and needed something to pad out his text, or he has been badly spooked by William Hague's sudden success in the opinion polls.

"What a miserable, shrivelled, shrunken thing is the Tory vision of Britain," he said, accusing the Conservatives of failing to stand up for human rights; abandoning the amputees of Sierra Leone to fresh rebel attacks; "vandalising" the BBC World Service and undermining Britain?s place in Europe.

The speech ended to dutiful applause and a crouching ovation: some in the hall stood, many sat still. The prime minister didn?t bother to attend, and even Cook's wife Gaynor could not be coaxed on to the platform.

The negative tone did not do Cook justice. He could have spoken in detail about Britain's involvement in a range of peacekeeping operations, in Sierra Leone, Kosovo, Bosnia and elsewhere.

The foreign secretary, perhaps the cabinet's biggest pro-European, did little to praise Europe beyond attacking the Daily Mail. Cook also has a reputation as a loyal democratic socialist, but he gave the party none of the ideological encouragement it so craves.

Complaints, then, about a complaining speech. Tony Blair will have to do better.

fields.headline: Welsh poet RS Thomas dies
fields.trailText: The controversial Welsh poet RS Thomas has died at the age of 87.
fields.body:
The controversial Welsh poet RS Thomas has died at the age of 87.

Ronald Stuart Thomas, considered the greatest religious poet of his time, enjoyed a writing career spanning over 50 years and produced more than 20 volumes of poetry.

Born in Cardiff in 1913 to non-Welsh speaking parents, he was ordained as an Anglican priest in 1936 and spent his working life as a clergyman in parishes in rural Wales. He felt that living in the countryside made him a better poet and wrote some of his most acclaimed poetry on his favourite subjects of nature, faith and landscapes.

He was awarded the Queen's Gold Medal for Poetry in 1964 and was nominated for the Nobel Prize for literature in 1996. The publication of his Collected Poems in 1993 was described as the greatest publishing event in Anglo-Welsh poetry since Dylan Thomas's Collected Poems came out in 1952.

Hardly the mild-mannered clergyman, Thomas was a fervent Welsh nationalist and an outspoken advocate of direct action. In the 1960s his poetry expressed the growing nationalist sentiment in Wales at that time, and he caused a huge outcry in the late 1980s when he publicly praised the arsonists who firebombed English-owned holiday homes in Wales. Political to the end, in one of his last interviews with the BBC in July Thomas claimed he had no confidence in the National Assembly of Wales and felt they would not deliver to the people.

Although the majority of his poetry was written in English, Thomas set about learning Welsh at the age of 30 and produced several prose works in the language. His autobiography, published in 1985, was entitled Neb, which is Welsh for Nobody.

The Plaid Cymru leader Ieuan Wyn Jones today described Thomas as one of Wales's greatest literary voices, who helped to "put Wales on the cultural map of the world".

RS Thomas's first wife, Elsi, died in 1991 after 51 years of marriage. He is survived by his son, Gywdion and his second wife, Betty.

fields.headline: ITV's Celebrity fails to find fame
fields.trailText: Celebrity, ITV's Andi Peters-fronted replacement for ill-fated early evening showbizfest OK! TV, failed to overpower BBC2 gameshow The Weakest Link on its debut on Monday .
fields.body:
Celebrity, ITV's Andi Peters-fronted replacement for ill-fated early evening showbizfest OK! TV, failed to overpower BBC2 gameshow The Weakest Link on its debut on Monday .

The daily show - produced by Carlton, which also made OK!TV - drew 2.4m and a 20% share between 5.05pm and 5.30pm, according to unofficial overnights. For the quarter hour from 5.15pm, when Celebrity was up against The Weakest Link, it rated 2.6m (21%), while the latter had 2.9m and 23%.

Overall, The Weakest Link had 3.5m and a 25% share from 5.15pm to 6pm. Last Monday in the Celebrity slot, a You've Been Framed repeat rated 3.2m and a 27% share for ITV.

Also yesterday afternoon, Children's BBC launched a raft of new autumn shows and scored the narrowest of ratings victories over Children's ITV. Between 3.30pm and 5pm, when the two channels' kids' line-ups were head-to-head, CBBC averaged 1.38m (15.8%), while CITV had 1.37m (15.3%).

CBBC opened a new run of pre-school animation Bob the Builder and debuted new factual show Space Detectives and S Club 7 Go Wild.

Yesterday morning BBC1 continued to sweep up daytime ratings and share with Olympic Grandstand, which averaged 3.2m and a whopping 55% (7.55am-1.15pm), as viewers across the land invented Monday morning ailments so they could stay home and watch Jonathan Edwards jump to Olympic gold.

ITV's normally omnipotent morning line-up of Trisha (1m, 18%) and This Morning (1m, 17%) was brushed aside. Last Monday, the two shows drew 1.3m/30% and 1.5m/31%, respectively.

In peaktime last night, BBC1 current affairs flagship Panorama (4.1m, 21%) returned at 10pm with a report on the fuel crisis. It lagged well behind the concluding part of ITV's Martin Clunes drama, Dirty Tricks (8.5m, 38%).

On BBC2 from 9pm, the new run of Louis Theroux's Weird Weekends (2m, 9%) was up against Channel 4 documentary Is It a Boy or a Girl? (2.2m, 9%).

fields.headline: Acquisition boosts London & Edinburgh's profits
fields.trailText: 1pm: London & Edinburgh Publishing's acquisition of the Profile Pursuit Group has boosted first-half profits, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
London & Edinburgh Publishing is to stay on the acquisition trail after its takeover of the Profile Pursuit Group helped boost first-half profits.

The company, which is to change its name to the Profile Media Group following the £21m deal, saw pre-tax profits increase from £0.35m to £1.8m, on turnover of £9.2m - soaring from £2.3m last year.

London & Edinburgh has grown rapidly since its flotation in 1996, having last year bought the Good Ski Guide's title and assets and reaped instant rewards from the February acquisition of PPG.

The US publisher produces books, souvenir brochures and one-off publications for specific audiences.

Deputy chairman David Ellingham said: "We are very much a niche publisher, but we have £5m in the bank and we are a cash-generative business, so we want to make sizeable acquisitions."

Ellingham said the PPG acquisition had gone well, but declined to say whether the company plans further acquisitions in the US.

webTitle: The mag that blew them away

fields.headline: The mag that blew them away
fields.trailText: Never wished that you were an American? Forget global warming and death row. Forget their ignorance of cricket and their love of gridiron. Think double-chocolate muffins and John Cusack; Brandi Chastain and Marion Jones. And now think of their sporting literature.
fields.body:
Never wished that you were an American? Forget global warming and death row. Forget their ignorance of cricket and their love of gridiron. Think double-chocolate muffins and John Cusack; Brandi Chastain and Marion Jones. And now think of their sporting literature.

The country that gave the world women's studies in the 1960s has this year given it Sports Illustrated for Women, a magazine aimed at women who love sport about women who play sport. It is the first magazine of its kind in the US, and it has provoked an astonishing response on the news stand.

Missy Dye, from the publicity department, reports that SIFW (aimed at women between 18-34) has a current circulation of 300,000 and is expected to top 400,000 at the beginning of 2001. "It is above and beyond any expectation of Time Inc [the publishers]. It has blown them away," she said.

The magazine had a long gestation period. A tester copy was printed early in 1997, under the name Sports Illustrated Women's Sport. It flew out of the shops. Then in 1999 four other special issues were published as the editorial was refined and further research was carried out into what the readers wanted. From the evidence of the July/August issue, what women want isn't just dry reports or lectures on how to train. It contains features on college wrestler Patricia Miranda, basketball player Yolanda Griffith and middle-distance runner Marla Runyan. But it also includes articles on skincare, the best surf outfits around, and eating organically - with, eureka, no mention of diets. Plus letters which probably wouldn't make the cut at Just Seventeen: "After batting practice my hand is sore for hours. Is something wrong with my swing?"

Oh, and don't forget the horoscopes. Yes, I know they're nonsense, but they're addictive nonsense. And it was a treat after ploughing through pages of go-gettem editorial to learn that despite being "a wuss at confrontation" I should learn to "come on strong to get what I want". And that I should try rollerskating or line dancing to get in shape. [Take note Ashley Giles, the only piscean in the England Test squad to Pakistan and Sri Lanka.] Anyway, it all seems to go down well with the advertisers. All the big names in sport are there, such as Nike, Reebok, Adidas and Vans. Plus cars (Ford, Suburu and General Motors), chocolate (Kit Kat), Nintendo (Mia Hamm Soccer 64), and, interestingly, the US Army Reserve

It isn't perfect. There are more than a couple of advertising features and pages and pages of advertorial masquerading as features. Plus the permanently upbeat tone might irk British readers (for a taster have a look at the SIFW website).

But it is new and innovative and one step up from anything you'll get over here. Our nearest equivalent is Zest, but that concentrates more on health and beauty rather than sport.

What is there for the active woman over here? Not much. Individual sports federations usually produce a newsletter dedicated to their women's section. Every female cricketer registered with the ECB gets a copy of Wicket Women. But sometimes you feel the need for more than a worthy read. Perhaps sports other than just cricket take your fancy. Perhaps you want glamour and substance. Perhaps you need to feel some glossy pages between your fingers.

It's not as if there's not the demand. A specialist women's football magazine sells more copies in the UK than Wisden Cricket Monthly. And it wasn't just men who tuned in avidly to the Women's 400m final at Sydney yesterday and are reading about it in today's papers. By punching its weight in America, Sports Illustrated for Women shows that there's a market waiting to be tapped on this side of the Atlantic too. The US version will never have a mass readership over here because of its concentration on American sports, but at the moment it is the best we have. And that's a shame.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. To read last week's Women's Page, on why Don Bradman should follow Cathy Freeman's lead, click here

webTitle: BBC news staff to vote on industrial action

fields.headline: Unions ballot BBC news staff on industrial action
fields.trailText: September 26: BBC News staff are threatening to strike just as a new breakfast programme is due to launch, writes Jessica Hodgson
fields.body:
BBC director general Greg Dyke is facing his first brush with the broadcasting unions in what insiders at the BBC say could signal longer term problems.

BBC News is facing unrest on three fronts, with ballots for industrial action at Bush House and Television Centre and further action threatening its new breakfast programme, due to launch next week.

In the dispute over night-working conditions, between 15 and 20 members of broadcasting union Bectu are being balloted this week at Bush House and around 25 at Television Centre . NUJ members are also understood to be balloting for industrial action.

Unions want improved working conditions for staff working on night shifts, an end to compulsory working for staff over the age of 50, a reduction in the working week to 35 hours for night workers and increased pay for staff working between the hours of midnight and 6am.

Meanwhile, staff on the BBC's new breakfast programme have balloted for industrial action after news chiefs introduced new technology, forcing them to cut the post of a news producer.

A BBC News spokeswoman said: "Last week the unions put their proposals to us and we are in discussions to find a solution."

News insiders anticipate further problems as BBC News is expected to begin merging its two separate newsrooms - one for bulletins and another for continuous news.

Last year rival TV channel ITN was brought to the brink of strike action after forcing through a raft of changes to working patterns for staff working on its new news channel.

webTitle: Nick Berry to star in undercover cop series for BBC1

fields.headline: Nick Berry to star in undercover cop series for BBC1
fields.trailText: September 26: BBC1 has announced a new undercover cop drama series to debut next spring, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Nick Berry and Stephen Tompkinson will co-star as undercover detectives in a new BBC1 series made by Berry's indie, Valentine Productions.

In Deep, commissioned as a series of three two-part stories, will deal with the world of undercover cops and the psychological effects on their families.

Berry and Tompkinson will play Liam Ketman and Garth O'Hanlon, who are sent in to handle particularly unpleasant or bizarre crimes in the series, which is already filming in and around London.

The BBC is said to be hoping the duo will have the same kind of ratings force as Martin Shaw and Lewis Collins had in The Professionals.

Liam's wife, Pamela, is played by Lisa Maxwell but there are hints of a romance for Berry with an attractive police psychologist played by Meera Syal, while Garth is a loner.

In Deep is due to go out on BBC1 next spring. The series is being executive produced by BBC head of drama series Mal Young.
