fields.headline: Hardy returns after illness
fields.trailText: Bert Hardy, the former chairman of the Barclay Brothers' newspaper interests, European Press Holdings, has returned to the media after an absence due to illness. By Janine Gibson.
fields.body:
Bert Hardy, the former chairman of the Barclay Brothers' newspaper interests, European Press Holdings, has returned to the media after an absence due to illness.

Mr Hardy, whose media jobs have ranged from deputy chairman of Channel 4 to chief executive of News International and Associated Newspapers, has joined Accord Holdings Ltd as a non-executive director.

He quit the Barclay Brothers' business shortly after winding down the European, when he fell ill, but is understood to be fully recovered.

Accord, which owns two advertising agencies: Conrad Advertising and Conrad UK, specialises in travel advertising, particularly for teletext services.

Mr Hardy is understood to have joined the company as it is planning to develop and acquire web publishing businesses that complement its existing base.

Accord chairman Bob Walton, also formerly of Associated Newspapers and the Evening Standard, is believed to have built up a substantial war chest to fund acquisitions. Announcements are expected in the next month.

fields.headline: All the media stories from today's papers
fields.trailText:
THE INDEPENDENT

Rupert Murdoch is weighing up a complicated stock swap with old ally and warhorse John Malone, reports the Indy, giving the nod to the Wall St Journal which broke the story yesterday. (p16)
MEDIA PAGES
Darius Sanai looks at the back-biting currently going on between upmarket men's magazines GQ and Esquire. (p8)
David Lister writes about newspapers writing stories in the best interests of the children. "Hurting children is an acknowledged, but all too real, daily side effect of journalism." (p8)
The Indy's diary pages have finally cottoned onto the fact that Lisa O'Carroll, the Daily Mail's 'forceful' TV correspondent is joining MediaGuardian.co.uk. (p8)
Interview with Noel Edmonds, a man reborn with Unique Group, his TV production company about to launch a handful of new channels. Edmonds, a victim of Peter Salmon's clearing out of BBC1, has the knives out for his old adversary: "I do now feel quite vindicated appointing someone like that to do that job was a grave error. He is a very ordinary man who made BBC1 into a very ordinary channel." Meow. (p9)
David Lister urges the beeb to keep Later with Jools Holland: "To fiddle with Later would be a bad mistake." (p10)

webTitle: Blair prepares for crucial conference speech

fields.headline: Blair prepares for crucial conference speech
fields.trailText: The prime minister was today preparing for the toughest speech of his political career. Tony Blair is under pressure to use his keynote speech to the Labour party conference to offer concessions on the contentious issues of pensions and fuel.
fields.body:
The prime minister was today preparing for the toughest speech of his political career. Tony Blair is under pressure to use his keynote speech to the Labour party conference to offer concessions on the contentious issues of pensions and fuel.

But he is expected to offer no quick fixes - and to promise delegates in Brighton a fightback to defeat the Tories at the next election.

The prime minister was expected to mirror comments from the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, that the cabinet could have seemed too high-handed and bureaucratic in its response to recent events.

It will be the clearest admission by Mr Blair of the way his party has come to be seen by voters as arrogant and out of touch.

Mr Blair will attempt to turn the Tories' opinion poll success - that has seen them rush into an 8% lead - to his advantage, warning delegates there was now a real fight on for the future of Britain.

Labour sources say the prime minister insists it is a fight he welcomes, and one he regards as over the future of investment in public services such as schools and hospitals.

Mr Blair faces pressure to address the issues of pensions and fuel in his speech - but he is not expected to offer any quick fixes. He is expected to echo yesterday's message of the chancellor, Gordon Brown, that ministers are delivering on the issues that really matter and will heed publicly expressed concerns during the Budget process.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, said today that the prime minister would use his speech to conference to emphasise that Britain's economic fundamentals were sound. "Tony Blair will be focusing on the fundamentals," Mr Cook said. "He will be pointing out that as a result of sound management of the economy, we now have £16,000m to invest in health, education, transport, providing a better future for Britain.

"The Conservatives have said they will cut that spending. I am quite confident that when the people come to make that choice, the choice between investment in the future or cuts in central public spending, their choice will be for the Labour party that made that investment possible."

On fuel prices, Mr Cook said that the chancellor had made it clear that he would be addressing the issue in the pre-budget report in six weeks' time. "I'm quite sure that the prime minister will make it clear that yes, of course we listen to the people. We understand the concerns, the difficulties of people out there. But we also know - and the people know - that the economic fundamentals are better.

"The lowest unemployment for a generation, the lowest inflation for a generation, and the opportunity for the biggest investment ever seen in our public services."

As to whether Europe should follow the lead of the United States and release its oil reserves to help drive down the price of fuel, Mr Cook said: "We will continue to keep that under review. It's a very difficult and a very tough decision because, after all, our oil reserves are there for a time of shortage."

The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, acknowledged that Mr Blair's speech would be one of the most critical he has ever made. Mr Byers said he expected the Labour leader to address directly the controversy over fuel prices. "I think he will reflect, obviously, on events of the last few weeks and I think he will need to take head-on the whole issue of the price of petrol and address people's concerns directly," Mr Byers said.

"The lowest unemployment for a generation, the lowest inflation for a generation, and the opportunity for the biggest investment ever seen in our public services." As to whether Europe should follow the lead of the United States and release its oil reserves to help drive down the price of fuel, Mr Cook said: "We will continue to keep that under review. It's a very difficult and a very tough decision because, after all, our oil reserves are there for a time of shortage." The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, acknowledged that Mr Blair's speech would be one of the most critical he has ever made. Mr Byers said he expected the Labour leader to address directly the controversy over fuel prices. "I think he will reflect, obviously, on events of the last few weeks and I think he will need to take head-on the whole issue of the price of petrol and address people's concerns directly," Mr Byers said.

fields.headline: TEAMTalk.com hires Cheetham Bell chief
fields.trailText: TEAMTalk.com has appointed Katrina Michel, a partner and head of planning and strategy at Cheetham Bell, as non-executive director. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Sports information business TEAMTalk.com has appointed Katrina Michel, a partner and head of planning and strategy at Manchester advertising agency Cheetham Bell, as non-executive director.

Michel, 44, has previously worked for several London ad agencies including Ogilvy & Mather, where she was head of planning.

"Katrina brings substantial marketing and strategic planning experience to TEAMTalk. Her appointment completes the board, giving us a broad range of talent and experience on which to build the business," said TEAMTalk chief executive Bill Wilson.

fields.headline: Videonet launches ADSL service in London
fields.trailText: Broadband provider Videonet today launches its ADSL-based video-on-demand service HomeChoice in the London region. Jessica Hodgson reports.
fields.body:
Broadband provider Videonet today launches its ADSL-based video-on-demand service HomeChoice in the London region.

Homechoice, which will be priced at £6 per month with a £40 one-off installation fee, promises to give access to 800 films, over 1,000 music videos, ITN news programmes and a raft of sports programming on demand via telephone lines.

The company has signed a number of high-profile content deals with studios including Warner Brothers, giving it access to programmes including BBC and Channel 4 shows, including The Sopranos, Friends and ER.

HomeChoice also offers banking and shopping services and fast internet access for a flat rate monthly fee of £20.

Videonet claims it is able to offer the ADSL service in most London postcodes. But Serafino Abate, a telecoms analyst at Ovum, pointed out that BT - from whom Videonet leases its service - says it can only offer ADSL to around 35% of the population.

Mr Abate said: "If the wholesaler [BT] can't offer ADSL throughout the country then I can't see how the retailer can offer it to most of the capital."

He also warned that providers like Videonet, which is paying more to BT for the lease of its local loop than the cost to the consumer, faces a major financial risk if it is not able to deliver the service to its subscribers. "It's very challenging for them and there's a high risk because they are not in control of the technology."

fields.headline: Emap in music website tie-up with HMV
fields.trailText: Emap Digital has unveiled a partnership with HMV as part of its plans to launch eight retail-oriented music websites, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Emap Digital has unveiled a partnership with HMV as part of its plans to launch eight retail-oriented music websites.

The first site, Q4music.com, is to launch on November 1, followed by Mojo4music.com, and sites for Smash Hits, Select, Kerrang, Mixmag, Kiss and the Box. Around 20% of site content will be taken from the magazines themselves and the newly recruited online editorial teams will develop the rest.

In all, Emap plans to spend around £3.5m this year on its music sites, with much of the marketing channelled through the magazines, which claim a collective share of 40% of the UK music mag market.

The idea is to launch the sites as buyers' guides integrating HMV's product datebase with site content. "We think there is definitely an opportunity in the market for a proper fusion of editorial and commerce," said Jerry Perkins, managing director of Emap Digital Music Project and former managing director of Emap's music magazines.

Mr Perkins said the tie-up meant that Emap could combine the database with content so that users would be just one click away from buying a related product. "We can do this as long as we maintain integrity and every time we mention a product make sure that it's available to buy," he added.

Paul Du Noyer, former editor of Q and Mojo magazines, is the editorial director of the music project.

fields.headline: Danish pasting
fields.standfirst:
As the euro campaign shows, Denmark's voters love to give their leaders a good kicking
Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: It is a truth universally acknowledged among eurocrats in Brussels that Denmark has the weirdest politics in Europe.
fields.body:
It is a truth universally acknowledged among eurocrats in Brussels that Denmark has the weirdest politics in Europe.

The people of Denmark, the second smallest EU member state, look increasingly likely to defy their government, almost all the major parties and their news media by voting to reject the euro in their referendum on Thursday. The antis were leading by 10% at the weekend. Such an outcome would not only deliver a huge blow to the credibility of monetary union but also represent another victory for Danish bloody-mindedness.

Governing in Denmark is a bit of a nightmare at the best of times.This, after all, may be the only country in Europe where the house-and-car-owners' party could usually hold the balance of power despite never attracting more than 4% of the vote.

The Centre Democrats, as they are now known, are for once not in this administration. Their leader, Mimi Jakobsen, miscalculated by pulling out of the ruling centre-left coalition just before the last election. She wrongly assumed they were going to lose and therefore prepared to throw in her party's lot in with the opposition centre-rightists.

Without the Centre Democrats the prime minister, Poul Nyrup Rasmussen, a dour and downbeat former trade union social democrat economist, has an even more unstable majority. He formed an administration on the basis of one vote - that of one Joannes Eidesgaard, an independent who won a seat in the Faroe Islands by fewer than a hundred votes.

Mr Eidesgaard's victory came on the basis of a pledge that he would make the gov ernment pay for tunnels to connect the islands. He hasn't got them yet but the Faroes are now campaigning for independence, provided Denmark continues subsidising the islands.

This is a country where the Progress party once proclaimed its defence policy was to disband the armed forces and leave a message on the government's answering machine saying "We surrender" - and swept the country.

Progress, whose leader Mogens Glistrup once waved his tax return on television to show how he paid no tax, started as a protest party and has moved steadily rightwards ever since.

It comes as something of a surprise in a liberal Scandinavian country to hear fervent references to Danish national identity. It is here that the rightwing People's party once staged a demonstration on the land border to repel Teutonic invaders. Only here could leakages from German pig farms into the waterways of Schleswig-Holstein become an election issue, because of their source rather than their content.

At a televised debate during the 1998 election I heard a sweet-looking, grandmotherly old lady ask the party leaders how they would guarantee if she went into hospital for an operation that she would only be given pure Danish blood. Instead of dismissing her as a silly, racist old bat, each answered with due gravity.

It is on this that part of the current referendum campaign turns. There is not only a calculation that Denmark might do better to wait and see whether the euro picks up or not, but great scepti cism about the argument of supporters of monetary union that the country would gain more influence by being inside the euro-zone.

Danes modestly enjoy being the centre of attention every time they hold a referendum on Europe - currently about once every two or three years - but they know just how big their country really is. The krone is already shadowing the deutschmark, so it is affected by the euro whether Denmark joins or not. There's still a raw nerve about how the Germans overran their country in a day in 1940. In such circumstances the assertion of independence is important.

As is the country's anti-politician culture. They know they've been lied to in the past and they're not taking anything on trust. In 1972, when Denmark voted to join the Common Market, Danes were warned prices would rise if they stayed out. Then they rose anyway. In 1980 they were told there would never be a single currency; in 1992, that EU integration would go no further.

Now Rasmussen is at it again. To win re-election two years ago he offered a guarantee on early-retirement pensions, only to rescind it after the election. Now the politicians are guaranteeing the value of pensions if Denmark joins the currency until mid-century - long after all of them will have retired. Unsurprisingly this causes some voter scepticism.

But what gives the EU its peculiar potency in Denmark is the constitution, the Grundlog, article 20 of which effectively gives the population the right of consultation over every foreign agreement the country makes. Although the current referendum is the result of a promise made to Danes at the time of the referendum on the Maastricht treaty that they would be consulted if the government wanted to join the euro, the habit of voting regularly on Europe is now ingrained.

"It's like continually scratching a scab," said Uffe Ellemann-Jensen, the former foreign minister. "Personally, I am getting a little tired of voters."

webTitle: Danes edging towards euro in countdown to the vote

fields.headline: Danes edging towards euro in countdown to the vote
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Denmark's referendum campaign on whether to adopt the single European currency was shaping up for a photo finish last night after the latest opinion polls showed the gap between the two sides narrowing.
fields.body:
Denmark's referendum campaign on whether to adopt the single European currency was shaping up for a photo finish last night after the latest opinion polls showed the gap between the two sides narrowing.

With Danes due to vote on Thursday, a poll for the newspaper Politiken indicated that 45% of Danes were in favour of monetary union while 43% were not. Another poll, conducted by Gallup for the daily Berlingske Tidende, found that 46% were against joining the common currency, with 42% in favour. And a Megafon poll for the daily Boersen gave the No camp 51% against 40% for those in favour.

Overall, however, yesterday's polls continued to show growing support for the euro, to the point where the difference between the two camps appears to be within the statistical margin of error.

Analysts said that the government-backed Yes campaign had overcome fears about the threat to Denmark's cradle-to-grave welfare provision, should the country join the single currency. Marianne Jelved, the minister for economic affairs, warned, however, that the outcome could not be taken for granted.

The campaign's arguments have been hard to understand, partly because the krone is already pegged to the euro, giving the Danish central bank only nominal independence.

Supporters say that joining the eurozone would increase Denmark's sovereignty by enhancing its influence, including a seat on the European Central Bank. Rejection, they say, would lead to 20,000 jobs being lost during the next two years.

Opponents - far-right and far-left parties in parliament and grassroot organisations - claim the economy is strong enough to stand on its own. Like British eurosceptics, they warn of a loss of sovereignty and of being overtaken by a European super-state.

EU governments are playing down the significance of the vote, pointing to the country's recurrent bouts of euroscepticism.

fields.headline: EU hint eases oil pressure
fields.standfirst:
Euro woes continue as world leaders gather under fierce spotlight
Special report: the IMF and World Bank in Prague
Special report: the petrol war
Special report: the European Commission
fields.trailText: Oil prices struggled to remain above $30 a barrel yesterday as the European Union hinted that it was prepared to follow the lead of the United States in releasing crude from its strategic reserve
fields.body:
Oil prices struggled to remain above $30 a barrel yesterday as the European Union hinted that it was prepared to follow the lead of the United States in releasing crude from its strategic reserve

With EU finance ministers to discuss on Friday the possible use of their reserves, oil prices fell below $30 a barrel at one stage in London yesterday as dealers anticipated action by rich western countries and the Opec oil cartel to increase the supply of fuel.

G7 officials in Prague on the eve of the World Bank/IMF summit said they were happy with the reaction of the commodities markets, which left some analysts predicting a price of $25 a barrel before the end of the year.

The fall in oil was in contrast to the cautious mood in the foreign exchange markets, where the euro drifted slightly lower once it became clear that the G7 industrial countries were not going to repeat Friday's intervention.

Fears that the Danish referendum on Thursday might lead to renewed downward pressure on the single currency pushed the rate against the dollar back to where it was sitting before central banks and finance ministries spent around $7bn in their surprise move last week.

In the absence of new action by the G7 yesterday, it was left to Jean-Claude Trichet, the governor of the Bank of France, to prevent the euro falling against the dollar to below 87 cents, when he said that the decline had gone too far. The euro closed at $0.872 in London after starting the day half a cent higher, but was still well above its record low of just under $0.845 last week.

James Wolfensohn, president of the World Bank, yesterday became the latest global leader to warn of the dangers of high oil prices.

He said poor countries were facing a double blow of higher energy costs and lower commodity prices, particularly for cocoa and coffee.

The west's leading think-tank, the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, said yesterday that oil prices of $30 a barrel this year and $33 a barrel next would shave 0.4 of a percentage point off global growth.

In the markets yesterday, Brent crude futures followed Friday's $1.50 fall by dropping a further $1.35 to $29.90 in morning trading.

Oil futures were also lower in New York, where the decision by the Clinton administration to draw down the reserve, coupled with hopes that G7 pressure will lead to further supply increases from Opec, offset fears that a tough winter would leave the US short of fuel.

The release from the US strategic petroleum reserve was announced by the energy secretary, Bill Richardson, after the markets closed on Friday, but prices had already fallen from 10-year peaks, $34.98 on Brent and $37.80 on American Nymex crude, over the week as markets anticipated the initiative.

Some traders said the impact of the release, the first since the 1990-1991 Gulf crisis, could be increased because it would coincide with the Opec producers' latest output increase of 800,000 barrels a day, which will start reaching the markets on October 1.

Under the release, oil from the reserve would effectively be lent to oil companies, which would replace it at a later date.

The European commission spokesman Gilles Gantelet said that discussions were under way among EU partners about the possible use of strategic oil reserves to combat high prices.

He said, however, that "for the moment, there is no intention at a European level to use the reserves".

webTitle: It's good to talk for Bush

fields.headline: It's good to talk for Bush
fields.standfirst: The sudden jump in opinion poll ratings for George W Bush following talkshow appearances shows he's in tune with the confessional mindset of the electorate, says Julian Borger in Washington
fields.trailText: The sudden jump in opinion poll ratings for George W Bush following talkshow appearances shows he's in tune with the confessional mindset of the electorate, says Julian Borger in Washington.
fields.body:
If ever mathematical proof was needed of Oprah Winfrey's importance to the nation, it was on obvious display this week. George W Bush jumped in the space of a few days from a 10-point deficit in the opinion polls to a 1% lead, and the only thing anyone could remember him doing was kissing the country's favourite chat-show hostess.

That may be a slight over-simplification. He appeared on another talkshow wearing a dark shirt which matched the one being worn by the host, Regis Philbin. People thought that was fun too, but they really liked the kiss. It seemed to have the same sort of tonic effect on Bush's political standing as Vice-President Al Gore's prolonged on-stage snog with his wife Tipper, at last month's party convention.

If anyone still doubted that the Oprah effect was truly in play in these elections, they only had to check out the breakdown of the polling figures. The greatest leap in Bush's support was among women, who make up the overwhelming majority of Oprah and Regis audiences, and who have proved to be an elusive electorate for republicans in general.

The television analysts said Bush won his poll surge just by looking relaxed and leaning forward, looking keen and engaged. But the kiss planted on the talkshow queen's cheek might have been the clincher. When Al Gore appeared on the Oprah show a few days earlier, he had offered his hand rather than his lips, earning a rebuke from his hostess. And the vice-president had sat back in his armchair and thrown his head back when he laughed, looking aloof.

The fact that the Oprah effect has thus been demonstrated under near-laboratory conditions (not much else was going on that might have spoiled the experiment) is likely to have a significant effect on future campaigns. The Oprah show, with its 7m viewers, is likely to become as important a stop along the way to the presidency as the presidential debates. There are likely to be Oprah trainers hired alongside the debate coaches, and they will specialise in body language - how to sit and how to kiss.

They will also teach the delicate art of confession, which has become an almost ritual need for a society steeped in the protocols of the talkshow and the soap opera. The confession must be offered at some apparent personal cost. It must draw a tear or at least a glassy eye.

Bush scored here. His eyes turned shiny after talking about his wife's difficult pregnancy, and stayed shiny through the ensuing commercial break. Gore, by remaining dry-eyed while talking about Tipper's struggle with depression, thus failed to fulfil the audience's expectations and we must conclude he suffered at the polls as a consequence.

But a confession is a double-edged dagger. A candidate will not wish to imply a lasting weakness. The fault he confesses must be something which he or she has overcome and which has only served to make him or her stronger. In Hollywood it is known as the narrative "arc". It is built into most of the characters in film or television dramas because it provides a satisfying mix of challenge and redemption.

Now, the electorate is expecting the same biographical curvature from the country's presidents as well. Bush scored particularly well here. He tells the well-used story of how he broke his long and deep relationship with alcohol the day after his 40th birthday in the wake of a raucous night out with friends - just about that time he found God.

Gore suffers because he lacks this sort of an arc. His progression from senator's son to congressman to senator to vice-president has been tediously linear. Straight lines do not play well in the movies, and in the Age of Oprah they make for bad politics too.

There are likely to be Oprah trainers hired alongside the debate coaches, and they will specialise in body language - how to sit and how to kiss. They will also teach the delicate art of confession, which has become an almost ritual need for a society steeped in the protocols of the talkshow and the soap opera. The confession must be offered at some apparent personal cost. It must draw a tear or at least a glassy eye. Bush scored here. His eyes turned shiny after talking about his wife's difficult pregnancy, and stayed shiny through the ensuing commercial break. Gore, by remaining dry-eyed while talking about Tipper's struggle with depression, thus failed to fulfil the audience's expectations and we must conclude he suffered at the polls as a consequence. But a confession is a double-edged dagger. A candidate will not wish to imply a lasting weakness. The fault he confesses must be something which he or she has overcome and which has only served to make him or her stronger. In Hollywood it is known as the narrative "arc". It is built into most of the characters in film or television dramas because it provides a satisfying mix of challenge and redemption. Now, the electorate is expecting the same biographical curvature from the country's presidents as well. Bush scored particularly well here. He tells the well-used story of how he broke his long and deep relationship with alcohol the day after his 40th birthday in the wake of a raucous night out with friends - just about that time he found God. Gore suffers because he lacks this sort of an arc. His progression from senator's son to congressman to senator to vice-president has been tediously linear. Straight lines do not play well in the movies, and in the Age of Oprah they make for bad politics too.

fields.headline: Monumental hassles in Berlin
fields.standfirst: The wrangles over a Holocaust memorial in the German capital persist, but in an odd way they mean the project is finally moving ahead, says John Hooper in Berlin
fields.trailText: The wrangles over a Holocaust memorial in the German capital persist, but in an odd way they mean the project is finally moving ahead, says John Hooper in Berlin.
fields.body:
It's back. What must be the world's most contentious monument is once again giving rise to controversy. The latest dispute to attach itself to Berlin's still unbuilt Holocaust memorial concerns the cost.

Last week, Günter Nooke, a Christian Democrat member of parliament and trustee of the foundation responsible for the scheme, voiced fears it could eat up more than the DM50m budgeted. He said the chairman of the trustees, Wolfgang Thierse, a leading member of the rival Social Democrats, knew of the impending cost excesses, but had chosen to mete out the truth to the public in instalments.

At the weekend, in an interview with the news magazine Focus, the architect Peter Eisenmann denied the project was set to bust its budget. He had never overrun on cost, he said, and was not about to start.

His monument, to be built by the Brandenburg Gate, is to consist of 2,700 pillars, giving the impression of a vast graveyard in the heart of Berlin. It will occupy a site the size of four soccer pitches.

Fears over the finances have been growing since July when it was agreed that an information centre attached to the monument should be built underground, directly beneath it. The committee overseeing the scheme insisted this would save money because there would be no need to buy more land in the centre of Berlin.

But some media commentators estimated the cost could be 50% higher. And liberal MP Werner Hoyer, a member of the parliamentary budget committee, argued that the changes to the project made it impossible to cost.

Though few people who have not visited Berlin are aware of the fact, this is a water city. It stands on a river, the Spree, and in the midst of a web of lakes and connecting waterways. Mr Hoyer said that the city's waterlogged soil would almost certainly mean that the underground structure would need reinforcing.

If he turns out to be right, then it could also mean further delay to a project that has so far been 11 years in the making. Work is not now due to begin until late next year. It started in November 1989 when a journalist, Lea Rosh, set up a private lobby group to press for a national monument to commemorate the Holocaust.

Four years later, the then Chancellor Helmut Kohl gave his blessing to the scheme and in 1994 a first architectural competition was held to choose the design for a monument that was to have opened two years later.

Ever since, however, the idea's promoters have find themselves been wading towards their goal through a morass of aesthetic sensibilities, feelings of national guilt and pride, fears that the monument could become a target for the neo-Nazi right and most recently, Holocaust fatigue.

The original competition produced not one, but two, winning designs. The government, the promoters and the city of Berlin all agreed on one of them, but it was then vetoed by Mr Kohl. The date for the inauguration was scrapped and in 1997 the first of three public discussions on the monument was held.

They were followed by a further architectural competition which, this time, produced four designs for consideration. One was the Field of Remembrance, which Mr Eisenmann had created in partnership with the sculptor Peter Serra. A lot of critics found their work too bland, but it won the support of Mr Kohl, though not of Berlin's Christian Democrat mayor Eberhard Diepgen.

After repeated delays and modifications to the Eisenmann-Serra design, the decision on whether to adopt it was put before parliament. By then, the information centre had been added.

Last year, their project was finally endorsed by parliament. Controversy over Berlin's Holocaust memorial is scarcely new then. But what is new about the latest exchanges, and it is arguably an encouraging development, is that they are ultimately about practicalities.

What is at issue now is not whether this or that conception measures up to the scale of Germany's national guilt, but whether the complex is in danger of subsiding or flooding and if so, whether that could mean the German taxpayer having to stump up more cash. In the context of the tortured history of this whole affair, it represents something like progress.

fields.headline: Una llave latina para la Casa Blanca
fields.standfirst: No candidate can get to the White House without the vote of the US's enormous Hispanic community.
fields.trailText: No candidate can get to the White House without the vote of the US's enormous Hispanic community.
fields.body:
La campaña de las elecciones presidenciales en Estados Unidos tiene acento latino. El candidato republicano George W. Bush habla en castellano para pedir el voto hispano. El candidato demócrata, Al Gore, visita las comunidades latinas para acceder a la Casa Blanca.

La minoría hispana en Estados Unidos tiene en sus manos un gran poder de decisión. Son treinta millones de ciudadanos y representan el diez por ciento de la población. Están concentrados en estados clave: California, Texas, Nueva York y Florida. Es imposible ganar las elecciones presidenciales sin ganar en California. Y es imposible ganar en California sin conseguir, al menos, un tercio del voto latino. El voto de la minoría hispana en Estados Unidos puede decidir entre 25 y 30 escaños de la Cámara de Representantes.

Cree usted que la comunidad hispana en Estados Unidos tiene cada vez más influencia?

María Martínez (17 años): Sí, porque en cinco años será la mayoría entre las minorías. Y su crecimiento demográfico es muy acele- rado. La gente reivindica ahora sus raíces hispanas. Donde yo vivo, en Washington Heights, casi todos son dominicanos, puertorriqueños y cubanos. En la calle, en los bancos, "las aplicaciones" oficiales están todas en español y en inglés. En las cuadras cuelgan sus banderas de sus países y las fiestas que organizan son muy populares.

Robert Stevens (18 años): Sí, es como una moda, y quizá un poco exagerado. Dicen que en Nueva York uno de cada cinco ciudadanos habla español en casa. Hay cadenas de televisión y radio en español, y tienen mucha audiencia.

Ingrid Matías (19 años): Sí, es cada vez más influyente. Los artistas latinos ayudan a dar a conocer que existe una comunidad latina y que está aquí para quedarse. Y muchos jóvenes trabajamos para mejorar el nivel de educación de la comunidad hispana y de otras minorías, como la afroamericana.

A qué candidato a presidente votaría usted? Por qué? Qué le pediría a favor de la comunidad hispana?

María: A Al Gore porque promete mejorar el sistema sanitario. No ofrece nada específico para la comunidad hispana pero los políticos del partido demócrata tienen más contactos con los hispanos y las minorías. Y yo prefiero que no prometan nada si no van a cumplirlo. Yo pediría más ayudas económicas para los barrios latinos.

Robert: No lo sé, no soy muy "aficionado" a la política.

Ingrid: A Al Gore. Pediría más ayudas económicas para los jóvenes latinos, para que vayan a la universidad. Al Gore visitó hace un año la escuela de Brooklyn donde estoy colaborando, El Puente High School.

En casa, en la escuela, con los amigos, en la calle, en qué idioma habla?

María: En español y en inglés. Yo nací en Estados Unidos y mi madre es de la República Dominicana. También hablo spanglish, que es una mezcla de inglés y español. Pero procuro no hacerlo porque destruye el castellano. A veces es divertido, pues hay personas que dicen "vacu nar la carpeta" en vez de pasar el aspirador por la alfombra, o "comprar groserías" para comprar comestibles, o "llamar para atrás" para devolver una llamada.

Robert: En inglés. Tengo algunos amigos hispanos pero hablo con ellos en inglés. Entiendo también un poco el español. Quizás tendré que estudiar español algún día, pues cada vez hay más trabajos que piden inglés y español.

Ingrid: Con los amigos latinos hablo el spanglish. Con mis padres el español. Yo nací en la República Dominicana. El spanglish lo hablamos sobre todo cuando nos reunimos los jóvenes, para "chatear".

Cree que Estados Unidos acabará convirtiéndose en un país bilingüe?

María: Sí. Y el castellano debería ser lengua obligatoria en algunos estados como Nueva York, California, Texas, Florida o Nueva Jersey. La mayoría de personas en estos estados habla español.

Robert: Muchas personas en Estados Unidos temen que el español domine el inglés. Y les molesta que la gente hable español. Sin duda harán resistencia. No sé si me gusta la idea de un país bilingüe.

Ingrid: En veinte años puede ser bilingüe. Las diferentes comunidades latinoamericanas en Estados Unidos estamos muy unidas. Pero no sería justo reconocer sólo el español. Estados Unidos debería ser un país multilingüe.

El castellano y la cultura latinoamericana han sobrevivido 150 años en Estados Unidos. Por qué cree usted que es así?

María: Porque sigue llegando gente. Durante decenios los hispanos enseñaban a sus hijos sólo en inglés, para que su acceso al trabajo fuera más fácil. Y escondían sus raíces latinas porque tenían complejo de inferioridad. Ahora ya no es así y la asimilación de la cultura anglosajona es paralela a la reafirmación de la cultura hispana.

Ingrid: Los latinos siempre dicen que regresarán a sus países pero se quedan aquí. Y hacen un esfuerzo para mantener su cultura y su lengua vivas entre la juventud, porque se sienten orgullosos de sus países y de ser latinos.

Glosario/Glossary

una bandera a flag

clave key (adjective)

cumplir to carry out

una cuadra a block

un escaño a seat in parliament

ganar to win

las raíces roots

orgulloso de proud of

· In many Latin American countries the "t?" form is considered impolite, and "usted" is the way to address people, whatever their age or relationship to you.

· Phrases in inverted commas are Spanglish, a dialect resulting from mixing Spanish and English, spoken increasingly by young people.

· Robert's words have been translated from English to Spanish.

fields.headline: Books about courage
fields.trailText: "That chicken had guts," remarked a child as he left the cinema after watching the film Chicken Run. Gutsy, inspirational fictional characters abound - some subtler than others.
fields.body:
"That chicken had guts," remarked a child as he left the cinema after watching the film Chicken Run. Guts are important to children, whether they're taking their first unaccompanied bus ride, or facing a bully in the playground. Gutsy, inspirational fictional characters abound - some subtler than others.

Because of Winn-Dixie (Walker, £7.99), by Kate DiCamillo, ambles through an important period for Opal, recently moved to Florida with her fond but preoccupied preacher father. She adopts an ugly but engaging stray dog who befriends anybody and everybody, thereby effecting introductions for Opal. The responsibility she feels for Winn-Dixie contrasts with her absent mother's irresponsibility. Her father's reticence on the subject masks his undoubted pain, a sadness which Opal helps him admit. Episodic and gently meandering, this snapshot of small-town life is touching and affecting.

While Opal patiently teases out the disparate strands of her life, Sophie, in Sharon Creech's The Wanderer (Macmillan, £10.99) wrestles with hers. Straddling action adventure and rights-of-passage, this novel uncovers several wardrobes-ful of skeletons. Sophie could simply continue to ignore the half-facts with which she has grown up, but a trans-Atlantic sailing trip shakes everybody up, literally and metaphorically. Vivid writing, with powerful emotional undertow.

The sea provides the backdrop to Nigel Hinton's hard-hitting novella, Ship of Ghosts (Barrington Stoke, £3.99) . Mick opts for a seafaring life, during which he meets a man who apparently tells him everything about the adored father he has never met. Disillusionment is all the more crushing when he eventually realises that the stories are false. Events take a terrible turn, and Mick is left haunted. Economical and pacey, this is compelling reading.

Any reader of Sarah Withrow's Bat (Bloomsbury, £4.99) might argue for a substitution of "weird" for "gutsy" when describing the central, quasi-eponymous character, Lucy, utterly convinced that she is a bat. She persuades Terence that there is something to her claim, and the two develop a friendship that says as much for his guts as hers. In his head he knows that she is wrong, but his heart tells him that he must support her. Suspend any disbelief and rest assured that readers won't easily forget this extraordinary story.

Dear Olly (Collins, £9.99), Michael Morpurgo's latest novel, evokes no such dislocation. He has mastered the art of telling sensational stories with lyrical simplicity, here using musical form as the structural framework. Matt's decision to go to Africa to make desperate children laugh is classic Morpurgo - flying in the face of sense and expectation, but utterly laudable. The gutsy migration of swallows - which shows Nature triumphantly flouting any sense of practicality - provides a bridge between suburban Britain and war-torn Africa, until tragedy brings Matt home. Gut-wrenching and beautifully told.

Tough Stuff (Allen & Unwin, £4.99) offers true stories about children with guts. Grouping them under such headings as Rescuers, Rebels, Battlers and Ferals, this is no literary classic but it merits wide exposure. The reader ricochets between breathless admiration and silent awe, proving my point that guts come in all shapes, sizes and decibel levels. They keep minds and pages turning.

webTitle: Parents are too pushy, says head

fields.headline: Parents are too pushy, says head
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Parents who sent their children for unnecessary private tuition were doing more harm than good, a teachers' conference was told yesterday.
fields.body:
Parents who sent their children for unnecessary private tuition were doing more harm than good, a teachers' conference was told yesterday.

The hothouse approach, which often began with children as young as six, could shake a child's self-confidence.

Instead of enjoying academic success, the child felt that he or she was struggling to reach the standards required.

George Marsh, headmaster of Dulwich College preparatory school in south London, claimed obsession with exams was "killing the fun" of school. Speaking at the conference in Bristol of the Incorporated Association of Preparatory Schools, of which he is chairman, Mr Marsh said: "Tweenagers - children aged between 11 and 13 - are being forced to grow up too soon.

"They are bombarded with media led, sometimes parent led, hysteria to grow up too soon. They need our protection."

He added: "There is a need for children to have a life and enjoy it."

He claimed that fear of not getting children into highly competitive, over-subscribed schools pushed parents towards enrolling their children for extra classes.

Other heads at the conference echoed Mr Marsh's sentiments. Nigel Johnson, of Brandeston Hall in Suffolk, said: "You should look at a whole child - you must remember there is a thing called family."

Sue Thomas, of Laxton junior school near Peterborough, said that a lot of extra tuition was a waste of time, if not harmful.

David Westcombe, of Rose Hill school in Tunbridge Wells, Kent, said: "Parents want to get every advantage possible but don't see the downside. And this is not just the case in independent schools - all parents are like this."

"They are bombarded with media led, sometimes parent led, hysteria to grow up too soon. They need our protection." He added: "There is a need for children to have a life and enjoy it." He claimed that fear of not getting children into highly competitive, over-subscribed schools pushed parents towards enrolling their children for extra classes. Other heads at the conference echoed Mr Marsh's sentiments. Nigel Johnson, of Brandeston Hall in Suffolk, said: "You should look at a whole child - you must remember there is a thing called family." Sue Thomas, of Laxton junior school near Peterborough, said that a lot of extra tuition was a waste of time, if not harmful. David Westcombe, of Rose Hill school in Tunbridge Wells, Kent, said: "Parents want to get every advantage possible but don't see the downside. And this is not just the case in independent schools - all parents are like this."

webTitle: Take pay cut to earn year off, teachers told

fields.headline: Take pay cut to earn year off, teachers told
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Teachers are to be told to accept pay cuts of 20% for five years if they want to take a sabbatical, under proposals put by the government to the pay review body.
fields.body:
Teachers are to be told to accept pay cuts of 20% for five years if they want to take a sabbatical, under proposals put by the government to the pay review body.

The "pay for yourself" sabbatical plan has been put forward by David Blunkett, the education secretary, according to the government's submission to the pay review board.

Under the plan an experienced teacher would take a £5,000 a year pay cut for four years to get the fifth year off. An experienced head earning £40,000 a year would have to lose £8,000 a year for four years to get the fifth year off.

Teacher unions last night reacted furiously to the proposals, which they see as a betrayal of a promise Mr Blunkett made two years ago.

His original green paper on teachers' pay promised exciting opportunities for "study leave and sabbaticals" so that "experienced and excellent teachers should have opportunities to undertake development or research work and enhance their performance". A government consultation document showed that 95% of professionals were keen on the idea.

The government's submission says: "The secretary of state is considering whether to introduce a pilot scheme for sabbaticals in England.

"One element may be to provide sabbatical opportunities based on four years pay spread over five years, i.e. teachers receiving 80% of salary over five years, which would provide the opportunity for teachers to have the fifth year as a sabbatical period."

The scheme has been running in Ontario, Canada, where teachers agree to a cut in salary and can do anything with their sabbatical, including taking jobs elsewhere.

The government's submission envisages that the scheme would be open to qualified teachers in nursery, primary, secondary and special schools. Headteachers, deputy heads and assistant heads would also be eligible.

Teachers would have to notify employers of what research work they intend to undertake and write a short report when they return to work.

The government would protect teachers and heads' pension rights during the five years they take a salary cut and those taking the sabbatical would also keep all their sick pay and maternity leave rights.

The government's submission gives an example of a teacher on £25,000 a year. They would receive £20,000 for five years, including the sabbatical, but their employer would pay their pension contributions on their £25,000 salary. Teachers would continue to pay their pension contributions on their reduced £20,000 pay, with the difference being met by a central fund.

The submission says: "The review body is requested to examine and make recommendations concerning pay arrangements for teachers for any pilot for "four over five" sabbaticals."

But Peter Smith, general secretary of the Association of Teachers and Lecturers, said last night: "This proposal is like a Whitehall version of loony tunes. I do not see why teachers who are struggling to pay their mortgages and meet their grocery bills should now have to pay for their own sabbaticals to improve their teaching ability.

"This idea would be quite fair if they were being asked to take a 20 % pay cut so they could take a year off to go round the world. It is not if they are expected to get leave for an approved project and then have to prepare a report for their school. This was a good idea that has been ruined by Whitehall bureaucrats."

A spokesman for David Blunkett last night defended the scheme which he said was being put to the review body.

"It would be phenomenally expensive to give teachers a year's paid leave. We see this as new flexibility for teachers.

"It is not compulsory and we are prepared to consult with the unions about the scheme. A pilot is the only way to see if it can be introduced nationally."

webTitle: Internet know-how: prospect for a degree

fields.headline: Internet know-how
fields.standfirst: Prospect for a degree
fields.trailText: Prospect for a degree
fields.body:
Some students might regard a male-female ratio of 70:30 at their college as an opportunity, but not those at Churchill College, Cambridge. "Lots of unsociable engineers and CompScis," complains one unidentified contributor.

Whingeing aside, Cambridge's alternative prospectus (only readable in PDF format at www.cusu.cam.ac.uk/publications/altpro/) is one of the best two. Rivalled only by Oxford's effort at www.ousu.org/pubs/ap, it's bigger than the average prospectus - chiefly because prospective students have the option of choosing a college as well as a course.

Colleges, despite some claims to the contrary, differ greatly, and although reformers have occasionally proposed abolishing their independent admissions systems, I wouldn't bank on it happening within the next decade. As Laura Spence knows, however, you can't count on being accepted by Oxbridge.

Unfortunately, the alternative prospectus seems to be a dying genre at most UK universities, possibly because so many students now have part-time jobs.

But impressive exceptions include: University of East Anglia, Exeter and Durham.

Alternatively, the student writers may be pitching their articles to Sir Richard Branson, who is looking for new contributors for the Virgin Alternative Guide to British Universities. They will be too young to remember the doomed Branson attempt to seduce the student market during his university years.

Details of the Virgin guide and a ratings service are on Redmole. The possibility of block voting leaves some of these placings open to suspicion. Loughborough, incidentally, comes top and Hull bottom.

Virgin's paperback rival, Push, is not yet seriously threatened by Unofficial-guides.com, a web-only guide that relies heavily on students' contributions. The soberer Niss and, of course, Ucas link to universities' official sites.

UEA's directory of student union links (www.stu.uea.ac.uk/info/uksu.html ) is chiefly worthwhile for its insight into student media.

Some of the better newspapers cover campus events comprehensively and evoke the university's atmosphere better than the official prospectuses do.

fields.headline: Undercover kids
fields.standfirst: First Edition/C4
fields.trailText: Twelve-year-old Aisling McCabe had a day off school this week. She wasn't sick. Instead, she was doing vital work trying to help catch shopkeepers illegally selling harmful goods to children.
fields.body:
Twelve-year-old Aisling McCabe had a day off school this week. She wasn't sick. Instead, she was doing vital work trying to help catch shopkeepers illegally selling harmful goods to children.

She is one of hundreds of young people recruited to help trading standards officers - the people responsible for enforcing the rules restricting the sale of such things as cigarettes, alcohol and gas lighter refills. The government supports the idea. Just this month it published new targets encouraging the undercover scheme against shopkeepers who "flout the laws" on under-age sales.

Is it safe as an undercover agent?

"I felt scared at first," says Aisling, "but I got used to it. We visited 18 shops and on the way to each one I was told what to ask for and reminded not to look at the officer coming in with me."

There are strict rules protecting children out on such patrols. They are never alone. Officers go into the shops with them so that later they can be a witness. Children are not expected to give evidence in court. And before the trading standards people pounce, there is time for the child to leave the shop. Also, the visits take place well away from the child's area.

According to Aisling, the only problem she had was being told off by a shopkeeper when she asked for cigarettes: "that was horrible, but it was good too - at least she wasn't prepared to let me have them."

Is it fair to "entrap" shop-keepers?

It isn't entrapment, say trading standards officers. It is always a follow-up to local information campaigns during which shop-owners are warned that they may be receiving such visits. Also, the children are not allowed to lie. If challenged, they must give their true age.

The only way to prosecute people breaking these trading laws is to catch them red-handed. A survey published last October showed that in areas ranging from the London borough of Bromley, to Wolverhampton and the Isle of White, children bought restricted goods in six out of 10 shops.

Have children been doing this investigative work for a long time?

Yes, for many years in some areas. But the big increase has been since 1991, when the law was tightened to stop sales of cigarettes to people actually under 16. Before that the law covered sales to those "apparently" under 16. Now it is the responsibility of the shop owner to apply a "No proof of age, no sale" policy with restricted items. To help them, some councils, such as Essex, are distributing proof of age cards to students.

What penalties do shop-keepers face if they break the rules?

The maximum fine is £2,000. Usually the penalty for a first offence is about £200-£300. What hurts is the bad publicity shops receive in local newspapers when prosecuted.

Often the shop-owners know the rules, but it is their staff, sometimes not much older than the customers themselves, who fail to apply them. Not that this is a defence.

Is the policy of using young people effective as a deterrent?

Yes. In Liverpool the trading standards have been working with children on undercover operations since 1988 and have seen illegal sales fall dramatically. At the start, they occurred on 85% of visits, but now on just 5%. However, not all local authorities have enough officers to mount these operations.

Do these investigations really help protect young people?

It is essential to keep these items away from children, so anything that makes them harder to buy is worthwhile. Sniffing glue or lighter gas can be lethal, and the nicotine in cigarettes is more addictive than cocaine and heroin. Of course, while the children working with trading standards are not allowed to wear make-up or lie, there is nothing to stop others disguising their ages.

What do the children working undercover get out of this work?

"I feel strongly about it," says Aisling. "Children a bit older than me are getting into smoking and it can kill. It was exciting going undercover and the officers bought me sweets and magazines in every shop."

Further information:

If you are interested in helping maintain trading standards you can contact them through the local authority or council.

The charity, Quit, runs a helpline for people wanting to stop smoking - 16% of its 500,000 annual calls come from young people, tel: 0800 002200.

Quit's "Break Free" trainers also offer courses and presentations for schools. Contact: 020 7388 5775.

Curriculum areas: key stages 3 and 4 PSHE

webTitle: If you ask me... about quitting school for work

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: Midway through A-levels, two of my son's friends decided to leave and start work. My son is impressed by their new wealth and confidence. He now seems to think school is a waste of time. He always wanted to go to university. How can I encourage him to at least finish his A-levels?
fields.trailText: Midway through A-levels, two of my son's friends decided to leave and start work. He now seems to think school is a waste of time. He always wanted to go to university. How can I encourage him to at least finish his A-levels?
fields.body:
Dr Kevin Conway, Greenhead College, Huddersfield, says:

I would sit down and say to someone in that position, "Look, you have two and a half terms to go, which is no length of time, and you would be throwing away the first whole year of work." The total national percentage of people who end up at 18 with three A-levels - even just at grade E, never mind anything else - is only 25-30%. To throw that away is to throw away something which really opens gates for young people, irrespective of whether they go to university or into some other professional training.

He is 17 - so another year is nothing within the context of living until he is 70. It is clearly shown in research that by the time they reach 28, people with a degree are well ahead of their peer group in both pay and job satisfaction. This is a lot to throw away for what is essentially eight months -a very short-term gain. Stick with it.

Ingrid Sutherland, Advisory Centre for Education, says:

Generally 16-year-olds will vote with their feet, and it is difficult to force them to do anything they don't want to do. I suggest you investigate if there are any underlying causes for his disaffection. Obviously there is the influence of his friends, but there could be other reasons. A-levels require a lot of independent work; perhaps he is panicking about the transition into a different way of studying. There might be a hidden cause - a relationship problem or a clash with a teacher.

In terms of parental action, it is difficult with teenagers. They could suggest that he speaks to his course co-ordinator or a careers adviser, or even a teacher he gets on well with. I would not suggest speaking directly to the school without their son's permission, but they could perhaps have a meeting including their son, about how they could all work together to help.

Has he other friends who are continuing their A-levels who he could talk to, to give the other side of the story? Is there a family friend who is in touch with youth culture who their son would listen to? Above all, they should keep open the lines of communication. There is always the possibility of returning to take his A-levels at a later stage if he does drop out.

Sheryl Waters, head of policy and research, Parentline Plus (helpline 0808 800 2222), says:

The important thing is to be able to acknowledge how he is feeling, and that you can understand why he is feeling like that; why he would want to earn money like his friends. When the parents have acknowledged that, they can put the other side to him. They can point out that he has the capacity to secure a more creative or high-powered job.

Don't approach this subject in concrete terms - use words like might and may, so that he doesn't feel he is being lectured. This needs to be done as a conversation, with the son being encouraged to put his side. Ask him why he is feeling like this. Ultimately the parents must say that whatever he decides, they will support him - but that they feel it would be a huge waste of potential not to finish his A-levels. Perhaps, depending on the family's financial situation, they could say that if, at times, his friends are going to a concert or whatever and he can't afford to, they would try their best to help him.

When they have this conversation, they must make sure not to be interrupted, and don't make it too long. And they must make sure he is aware that they are genuinely concerned and not trying to dictate.

Rachel Cashman, NUS vice-president, Welfare, says:

It is easy to understand why your son would want to follow the path of his friends and start earning a wage of his own. There are plenty of things people of his age can be doing, and like anything else, they cost money.

If you want him to stay on to complete his A-levels and continue into higher education, it is worth pointing out the considerable benefits of university and a degree. Students who graduated this year are earning on average £18,330 a year and the number of graduate vacancies has increased by 15%. Graduates, on average, earn £410,000 more than non-graduates over a working life.

There is, though, a great deal more to university than just a degree. Many people remember their student days fondly, be it for the social side or the countless opportunities that came their way.

Next week's problem:

All the best local schools are church schools and they are also closest to home. My partner and I are not religious, although our youngest son seems very interested in God. The thing is, I neither want to go to Church nor be a hypocrite. So do I sacrifice my child's education for my principles?

fields.headline: Raising the gold standard
fields.standfirst: Sydney's Olympics give technology, as well as sport, its day.
fields.trailText: Sydney's Olympics give technology, as well as sport, its day.
fields.body:
The Sydney Olympic games do not just represent the pinnacle of sporting achievement; they are also a showcase for cutting-edge science and technology. When the modern Olympics commenced in Athens in 1896, the results were not recorded in detail. The stopwatch and camera were first used at the 1932 Olympics in Los Angeles. With so little to choose between performances today, many are increasingly looking to technology to give them the edge. A 1% improvement can make the difference between success and failure and there is now almost no aspect of performance where science does not play a prominent role.

Training

All top athletes are constantly monitored to ensure they can produce their peak performances on the critical occasion. Blood tests are routinely performed to check that the optimum levels of amino acids are present, cardiographs are used to monitor heart rates to allow athletes to train to their optimum aerobic potential and new training techniques have been devised by sports scientists that both prevent injury and reduce the recovery time between workouts.

Technology

These days, technology doesn't just have the capacity to enhance performance, it can also change the way sports are played. Even swimming, one of the most natural of events, has been affected. Pools are now designed to minimise wave interference and to provide greater grip for kick turns off the wall at each end. The freestyle stroke has also changed from the conventional straight-arm action to a more efficient "S" motion that enables swimmers to move towards water that has not already been pushed backwards by the initial phase of the stroke, thereby reducing drag and increasing buoyancy. Technology is also being used to set limits on performance. Distances in the javelin were increasing by such large amounts in the 1980s, there were fears that throwers might become a danger to spectators and other athletes; the weight distribution of the javelin has now been redesigned to shorten flight times and distance and to put greater emphasis on the skill and technique of the thrower.

Clothing

One of the most obvious signs of technological advances has been the changes in clothing. Every sport now has its own footwear; among the latest running shoes for track and field athletes at Sydney are z-spikes and hover shoes. Marathon runners are after the perfect singlet that will allow them to lose sweat most efficiently, while sprinters wear all-in-one aerodynamic space suits. These don't just cut drag; they can also suppress muscle vibration and save energy. The pool has also seen clothing changes; the all-in-one suit is now common and one company has produced a suit that replicates the teeth-like features of a shark's skin in the belief this may help a swimmer to move faster.
fields.bodyText: The Sydney Olympic games do not just represent the pinnacle of sporting achievement; they are also a showcase for cutting-edge science and technology. When the modern Olympics commenced in Athens in 1896, the results were not recorded in detail. The stopwatch and camera were first used at the 1932 Olympics in Los Angeles. With so little to choose between performances today, many are increasingly looking to technology to give them the edge. A 1% improvement can make the difference between success and failure and there is now almost no aspect of performance where science does not play a prominent role. Training All top athletes are constantly monitored to ensure they can produce their peak performances on the critical occasion. Blood tests are routinely performed to check that the optimum levels of amino acids are present, cardiographs are used to monitor heart rates to allow athletes to train to their optimum aerobic potential and new training techniques have been devised by sports scientists that both prevent injury and reduce the recovery time between workouts. Technology These days, technology doesn't just have the capacity to enhance performance, it can also change the way sports are played. Even swimming, one of the most natural of events, has been affected. Pools are now designed to minimise wave interference and to provide greater grip for kick turns off the wall at each end. The freestyle stroke has also changed from the conventional straight-arm action to a more efficient "S" motion that enables swimmers to move towards water that has not already been pushed backwards by the initial phase of the stroke, thereby reducing drag and increasing buoyancy. Technology is also being used to set limits on performance. Distances in the javelin were increasing by such large amounts in the 1980s, there were fears that throwers might become a danger to spectators and other athletes; the weight distribution of the javelin has now been redesigned to shorten flight times and distance and to put greater emphasis on the skill and technique of the thrower. webTitle: So you want to learn about... licensees

fields.headline: So you want to learn about...
fields.standfirst: Licensees
fields.trailText: Licensees
fields.body:
When you're ready landlord. What?

Prithee, a jug of your foaming finest. £*$@ off.

What's up, mine host? I detest all this Falstaffian alehouse crap.

Oh, all right. A pint of lager. That's better.

But I thought cheery banter was the fun of running a pub. Did you?

That's why I'm thinking of giving it a go. You're welcome, mate.

Why so sceptical? Because it's seven days a week, 12 hours a day - except Sunday.

What do licensees do? Run any of the 60,000 pubs in the UK, small and large, traditional and themed, most serving food of some description.

Busy life. Not half. Apart from serving, we're keeping accounts, controlling stock, buying in drink, food and other goods, and recruiting, training and supervising the staff. Many licensees do the cooking themselves and are responsible for the health and safety of staff and customers and deal with any security issues.

Are there different sorts of licensee? Yeah: managers, tenants or freetraders. Managers are salaried employees of a pub's owners. Tenants run pubs leased to them by the owners. Freetraders own the pubs they run and are independent.

What skills does the job need? It is essential to get on well with all kinds of people, to be outgoing with good conversational and listening skills.

Oh real... Oy! Don't interrupt. Licensees must be able to deal with any trouble in the pub and have good management skills for training and motivating staff. Numeracy and business skills are essential for cash-handling, accounts, stock control, buying, pricing etc. Licensees must be able to learn and follow the legal requirements of their business concerning licensing, food and health and safety.

Any academic requirements? No. Personal qualities are more important. Previous business experience is desirable and some bar work experience is helpful. Traditionally it has been seen as a job for couples, but singletons are increasingly running pubs. You have to be 18 to serve behind a bar, but 25 is often seen as a realistic lower age limit for a licensee.

Other qualifications? Sure. Relevant ones include NVQs 1 and 2 in catering and hospitality; On-licensed premises supervisory management, level 3 and 4 and the British Institute of Innkeeping (BII) certificate of induction. There's even a degree in licensed retail management at the University of Wolverhampton.

What about training? Some employers train their managers and many pub owners provide training for potential tenants. There are modern apprenticeship opportunities. Tenants or freetraders can do five-day courses run by colleges and training companies for the BII qualifying examination. The Hospitality Training Foundation offers some one-day courses that are suitable for licensees. Graduates of relevant HND/degree courses may be able to do fast-track training courses run by the bigger companies.

 British Institute of Innkeeping Telephone: 01276 684449 www.bii.org

 Hospitality Training Foundation (HFF) Telephone: 020-8579 2400 www.htf.org.uk

 Brewers and Licensed Retailers Association Telephone: 020-7486 4831 www.bla.co.uk

 Leisure Careers U.K. (operated by BII) www.barzone.co.uk

 learndirect 0800 100900 may be able to give further information and advice on courses.

fields.headline: Courses starting with e
fields.standfirst: E-business programmes are thriving, but not at the expense of traditional ones, says  Lee Elliot Major
fields.trailText: E-business programmes are thriving, but not at the expense of traditional ones, says Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
This year sees a number of academic business schools developing e-business programmes, signalling that e-commerce has already established itself as a central component of postgraduate business degrees. The new breed of Masters of Business Administration students are just as likely to be taught the latest thinking on e-strategies, e-marketing and e-technology as the more traditional business and project management skills during their courses.

The rise of the dot.com entrepreneur initially appeared to pose a threat to MBAs. Here were businesses apparently defying all the laws of the financial markets, expanding on the back of one big idea, amid limitless hype and investor confidence. Who needed a two-year business degree when you could move immediately into the fast stream and become a paper millionaire overnight?

There have even been concerns that increasing numbers of business students would begin baling out of MBA courses as the new-economy companies sought out managers. But as yet there is no hard evidence that this has happened - either in Europe or North America. So far, there is no evidence to suggest that the new economy is leading MBA students into temptation. Dropout rates reported from UK schools are low.

Business school leaders in fact argue that MBA programmes are becoming more important for new businesses in short supply of executive talent. The humbling of the dot.com business world has seen many old business values reasserted among internet companies. The talk now is of merging old and new economy, with the best long-term strategies based on good ideas but also on sound business planning. And MBAs are now adapting to the new blend of skills being demanded.

Last year an MBA student from London Business School won the Association of Business Schools Award for the creation of the world's biggest ski destination website, iglu.com.

Jonathan Slack, the chief executive of the ABS, says: "There are going to be exceptions to every rule, but most successful entrepreneurs benefit from business training." He says that business schools offer a range of e-commerce programmes, some short, tightly focused courses, others broader modules. Continuous efforts are made to keep things up to date.

One of Europe's first MBA programmes specialising in electronic business has been created by City University Business School. The course is not aimed specifically at technology experts, but aimed at anyone needing to understand and exploit the new information technologies. It includes modules on electronic business, new media in marketing and two courses on e-commerce. City's is one of the business schools in the UK designated by the government as an IT centre for excellence.

Recent successful MBA projects in e-commerce have included students sponsored in parallel by Sun Microsystems and Abbey National.

A new MA in marketing with electronic commerce, meanwhile, has been launched at the University of Portsmouth Business School. One of the first programmes of its kind in the UK, the course seeks to combine two subject areas that have grown significantly in recent years and are expected to develop dramatically in the coming years. It is aimed at marketing personnel who want to develop an understanding of the key technical capabilities of e-commerce and formalise their marketing qualifications.

Web-based marketing is also growing in popularity at the Manchester Business School. A team of graduates recently developed strategic ideas for web-based marketing company Top Jobs on the net. The company has now become a leading internet job supplier.

Leeds University has teamed up with the world's third largest software company to create a new MBA in information management. And the London Business School has launched a series of e-business programmes, focusing on e-strategies, e-service, e-marketing and e-technology. The launch of the internet service, e-business@london.edu, is designed to help organisations understand the challenges of the new economy.

"E-commerce is currently the only identifiable sector of the world economy experiencing exponential growth of over 100% per year," says the association's latest bulletin. "UK business schools are leading the development of a wide range of relevant research and programme development to enable students and practising managers to update their knowledge and skills and strategies in the vitally important area of e-commerce."

webTitle: There's a new craze in colleges - foreign languages

fields.headline: Let's parlez-vous
fields.standfirst: There's a new craze in colleges - foreign languages
fields.trailText: There's a new craze in colleges - foreign languages
fields.body:
Further education colleges across the country are discovering a sudden new enthusiasm for learning foreign languages among their students and local communities. Where, until recently, youngsters in schools dropped subjects such as French and German at the earliest opportunity, colleges and universities are finding they are coming back to evening or part-time day classes to study a wide range of languages -from French and German to Urdu and Japanese.

At the recent European Awards for Languages ceremony at the French Embassy, further education colleges took the lion's share of the 15 prizes and Kingston College in south-west London, walked off with the top Mary Glasgow prize for innovation in language teaching.

"I was amazed at the quality of the entries," said Dr Lid King, the awards organiser. "There is so much enthusiasm out there, even though there is little money and a national shortage of qualified language teachers."

The projects covered no fewer than 17 foreign languages - showing colleges can offer a much wider range of courses than schools. Courses varied from those for mums and tots to distance courses for rural areas.

Aberdeen College has brought Spanish courses to the rural communities of the Highlands, while North Devon College in Barnstaple has 400 students of all ages studying languages as disparate as Swedish, Chinese and Arabic.

The international panel of judges, led by Leeds professor Brian Page, said they were impressed by the innovative and flexible methods of teaching and learning developed by the colleges.

In Bradford, the college has linked the learning of Asian mother tongues to competence in English and other European languages. In Sandwell in the west Midlands, the college language service has tailored its courses to the needs of local firms and is able to offer a translation, interpreting and training service in every European language, and others on demand.

"As a direct result firms in the region have improved their business relationships and thus their competitiveness, especially for those trading abroad. This has contributed to the economic regeneration of the west midlands as a whole," the judges said.

But the star of the show was Kingston College, a traditional mainstream college, which won the oscar for a scheme linking geography and languages, vocational and academic students, in a joint environmental project with a college in Berlin. The students all learned German in order to study and make a presentation in the German capital, comparing an urban regeneration site in Berlin with Spitalfields in London, and then hosted the Germans on a return visit. The college is now extending the project by video-conferencing, bringing in trainee teachers at Brunel University and GCSE students at Grey Court secondary school in nearby Richmond.

Sarah Hankin, head of languages, said the project was effective in motivating students to learn languages.

"It also has the benefit of raising cultural and international awareness and student self-confidence. It can be extended to many other vocational areas. We hope the government will take up the recommendation of the recent Nuffield inquiry report on languages and make languages a compulsory element of vocational courses."
