fields.headline: On good form
fields.trailText: Completing your UCAS form
fields.body:
The need to complete the Ucas form clearly and accurately may sound obvious but it's amazing how many critical errors are made that can affect chances of getting offers from chosen universities. At the outset the overall advice is to practise on endless photocopies and then, when filling in the actual form, follow the instructions carefully, even if this does mean wading through the less-than-thrilling 38-page "How To Apply" booklet! The reason for this? When Ucas get your form they will copy it and send it to all six of your choices, so any mistakes will be magnified sixfold and sneered at in six institutes of higher education!

So what are the basics? Clear black ballpoint pen or type is the first. Do not separate the two halves of the form and don't use glue, paper-clips or staples anywhere - no extra sheets are allowed. This year there is a plea not to use correction fluid if you make mistakes so when it comes to your real Ucas form make sure you know exactly what you are going to write and carefully copy from your final photocopy. Remember that any of these errors can result in your form being delayed and your chances harmed.

You should not have too much trouble with the first two sections; after all you know who you are and where you live. But do you know your date of birth? Nearly 10% of all applicants reckon it's the year in which they are applying! Complete this "further details" section carefully as it also includes questions about who will assess you for tuition fees or how you will pay for your course.

The next section concerns the courses and the universities you have chosen. These should appear in Ucas Directory order, not in your preference order. You'll need either the paper or CD-rom version of the Directory (also on the Ucas website) to complete the codes for this section accurately.

It is worth getting the photocopies out again for section 7. This is where you list all the qualifications you have completed, pass or fail, and those that you have not yet completed, the ones you are studying now. It is vitally important to get the details of your exam centre and the abbreviations for the awarding bodies 100% accurate as problems can arise around results time next year if there are mistakes or omissions.

Finally, apart from the personal statement dealt with elsewhere, don't forget to complete the final two sections - if you don't answer yes or no to the criminal convictions question or if you forget to read and sign the declaration then your form will not be processed by Ucas. That just leaves the payment (£15; cheques, credit, debit cards all OK) and then you are ready to pass your form to that very lovely person you've been smiling at a lot, who's going to write your reference!

webTitle: Finding the best course at university

fields.headline: Where next?
fields.standfirst: John Beckett has lots of advice on how to find the best course at university for you and how to make your application stand out
fields.trailText: John Beckett has lots of advice on how to find the best course at university for you and how to make your application stand out
fields.body:
It's that time of the year again - that "Oh no, I've got to get my future plans sorted out in the next 10 minutes!" time, when prospectuses, rough drafts of personal statements and the like start flying about careers rooms around the country, in an ever-increasing frenzy as the autumn term progresses.

Recent discussions about a six-term year with exams in April, results in July and a post-qualifications applications system for higher education remain in the realms of fantasy.

Now is the time to get your act together (no more phoning a friend or asking the audience), do the research you should have done last term and get that higher education application sent off as soon as possible. Even though it's 12 months before you'll start (maybe 24 if you are planning a gap year) Ucas forms must be completed soon.

If you are an Oxbridge candidate or a potential medic, vet or dentist then the deadline is fast approaching - October 15. For everyone else the deadline is later - December 15 - but schools and colleges will have their own deadlines much earlier than this and in any case it pays to get your form in early. If it is with Ucas in October there's a good chance you will have heard from most of your choices by the end of this year and this is likely to provide good motivation for the rest of the academic year's studies.

What are the main issues you need to address? Your choice of course and university matters most, after you've analysed exactly why you want to go in the first place.

The majority of the evidence available suggests that a successful higher education experience is a positive thing in a variety of respects, not the least of which are the personal ones of independence, freedom, responsibility and making new friends. Many will think about career prospects, whether it be in terms of status, salary, job satisfaction or a mixture of the three. Here there is no doubt that a degree, whilst not guaranteeing anything, is going to help in the job market and gives an enormous advantage over a non-graduate. Recent reports suggest that the average starting salary for a graduate is up 4% to £18,330 this year, with the best paid jobs in legal services.

Many professions are all graduate entry, others are becoming so. For some you will need a specific vocational degree, for others a degree in any discipline will suffice. Around 40-50% of all graduate employers are not concerned with your degree subject. They focus on other qualities you will have gained from your time at university. These include communication skills, problem-solving and decision-making skills, self-confidence, adaptability and flexibility and the ability to work under pressure.

How do you choose what to study when all your brain will come up with is a blank whenever you think about it? For some, probably the minority, this is a straightforward issue. One of your A-levels interests you and you want to take it to a higher level. Others may have a particular career in mind and need to follow a specific degree - medicine for doctors, pharmacy for pharmacists, golf course management for golf course managers etc.

For the rest it isn't such an easy decision - but it is worth taking some time to get right. Your choice does not have to be related to a career; rather it should be something you'll really enjoy studying otherwise you'll drop out of uni sooner rather than later. This means reading and research - both time-consuming but essential if you are to make a sensible choice.

Exploring the possibilities will open your mind to the options of taking a joint degree (two subjects of equal weight) or a combined or modular degree (where the subject combinations are even broader). There are also many new subjects available at degree level that are not possible at A-level. A cautionary note - don't mix up your subject choices too broadly (for example three physics plus three English probably equals six rejections).

There are now over 300 different institutions in the Ucas system and choosing six between Aberdeen and Ystrad Mynach (there are no Zs yet!) can be a big task. Decide on your criteria. Are you going to stay at home? If you are planning to go away, how far do want to go? New university or old/traditional? Campus or town/city centre?

Checking required grades with your predicted grades is part of all this so find out both - neither are state secrets! Whilst all these are important and are bound to exercise your mind, perhaps the most crucial issue is course content. If this isn't right when you start it does not matter how happy you are with your location, you'll struggle very quickly. Finance (or lack of it) will also play a major role in your decision, especially if you do decide to study away from home. Stories of massive debts on graduation are not total fiction - in the short and medium term money is likely to be tight, but in the long term the financial and other advantages of higher education definitely outweigh the disadvantages.

It's not too late to come up with an informed and well-thought-out application even if you are squeezing nine months' research into nine days. Use the time fully and take advice from those you respect. This could be the first stage towards the best years of your life.

The end of paper

Ucas are now encouraging students to apply via the electronic application system - EAS. This year 37,000 did so and the number is expected to double for the 2001 round and eventually overtake paper applications. It is a quick way of filling in your Ucas form on computer - the programme corrects mistakes automatically and avoids the use of dozens of practice forms. The personal statement can be cut and pasted on and print preview allows you to see your final form the way the universities will see it. fields.bodyText: It's that time of the year again - that "Oh no, I've got to get my future plans sorted out in the next 10 minutes!" time, when prospectuses, rough drafts of personal statements and the like start flying about careers rooms around the country, in an ever-increasing frenzy as the autumn term progresses. Recent discussions about a six-term year with exams in April, results in July and a post-qualifications applications system for higher education remain in the realms of fantasy. Now is the time to get your act together (no more phoning a friend or asking the audience), do the research you should have done last term and get that higher education application sent off as soon as possible. Even though it's 12 months before you'll start (maybe 24 if you are planning a gap year) Ucas forms must be completed soon. If you are an Oxbridge candidate or a potential medic, vet or dentist then the deadline is fast approaching - October 15. For everyone else the deadline is later - December 15 - but schools and colleges will have their own deadlines much earlier than this and in any case it pays to get your form in early. If it is with Ucas in October there's a good chance you will have heard from most of your choices by the end of this year and this is likely to provide good motivation for the rest of the academic year's studies. What are the main issues you need to address? Your choice of course and university matters most, after you've analysed exactly why you want to go in the first place. The majority of the evidence available suggests that a successful higher education experience is a positive thing in a variety of respects, not the least of which are the personal ones of independence, freedom, responsibility and making new friends. Many will think about career prospects, whether it be in terms of status, salary, job satisfaction or a mixture of the three. Here there is no doubt that a degree, whilst not guaranteeing anything, is going to help in the job market and gives an enormous advantage over a non-graduate. Recent reports suggest that the average starting salary for a graduate is up 4% to £18,330 this year, with the best paid jobs in legal services. Many professions are all graduate entry, others are becoming so. For some you will need a specific vocational degree, for others a degree in any discipline will suffice. Around 40-50% of all graduate employers are not concerned with your degree subject. They focus on other qualities you will have gained from your time at university. These include communication skills, problem-solving and decision-making skills, self-confidence, adaptability and flexibility and the ability to work under pressure. One of your A-levels interests you and you want to take it to a higher level. Others may have a particular career in mind and need to follow a specific degree - medicine for doctors, pharmacy for pharmacists, golf course management for golf course managers etc. For the rest it isn't such an easy decision - but it is worth taking some time to get right. Your choice does not have to be related to a career; rather it should be something you'll really enjoy studying otherwise you'll drop out of uni sooner rather than later. This means reading and research - both time-consuming but essential if you are to make a sensible choice. fields.headline: I'm fab, take me!
fields.standfirst: Now's the time to convince your chosen university that you are a keen and well-rounded student ... but how?
fields.trailText: Now's the time to convince your chosen university that you are a keen and well-rounded student ... but how?
fields.body:
If there is one thing designed to create more grief than anything else over the next month or so, apart from a lack of gold medals in Sydney, then it is the construction around the land of thousands of sparkling, interesting and imaginative personal statements. It is the applicants' opportunity to tell the university "this is me and this is why you should make me an offer".

Although there is increasing evidence that admissions tutors and selectors do not always read these statements, it is dangerous not to make a strong effort at producing a good one - it could help to persuade an admissions officer to offer you a place.

Unfortunately, the space in which you have to sell yourself is not enormous - about two-thirds of a side of A4 - and you are not allowed to use extra sheets. Also, the whole Ucas form is photoreduced to half size, so your words must be clear and legible. Many will word process their statement and scan or print the final draft directly on to the form - you should get around 500 words if you choose this method. Good-size handwriting is fine but may only allow 300 words, depending on your personal style. Aside from the process, what about content? What actually makes an earth-shattering impression? There is no right or wrong way nor a set format, but there are certain topics that must be present.

The first thing an admissions tutor will look for is your reason for choosing the courses you have listed. Why are you interested in the subject? This is especially important if you are applying for a vocational course or one where there's likely to be heavy competition for places. Stating that you've followed the career of George Clooney ever since he was in ER or that you are looking forward to the new series of Casualty is unlikely to win you a place at medical school. In the same way, explaining a deep interest in psychology based on events in Big Brother may not have the desired effect of an unconditional offer.

Whatever your choice, you need to show that you've researched the course thoroughly and know what you are letting yourself in for. If it is a new discipline then make sure you know about the content of the degree and show an enthusiasm for learning about the subject.

The best way of showing that you are a well-motivated student is to talk positively about your current studies at advanced level even if they are not directly related to your degree choice. Referring to particular modules or topics you have enjoyed or found stimulating is a good way of doing this. If you have attended special lectures, university visits or been on a summer school, write about them.

You should include a section about what makes you tick outside your studies. Selectors are looking for evidence that you are ready for university life and that does not just mean staring at books and sitting in lecture theatres. Social, sports and leisure activities have their place here as well as any relevant work experience if you are applying for a vocational degree. And if you are planning a gap year, then include a positive sentence about what you hope to do.

It may take several rough drafts but if it flows and makes you sound a keen and interesting student then you'll have done yourself justice. Be positive and only bend the truth as far as you would be able to justify in an interview. Finally, do make sure the grammar and spelling have been checked before committing your words of wisdom to the dreaded Ucas form!

webTitle: Hostel which demands swotting from residents

fields.headline: House trained
fields.standfirst: John Crace  visits a hostel which demands swotting from residents
fields.trailText: John Crace visits a hostel which demands swotting from residents
fields.body:
It's been a tough few weeks for Labour, and most MPs will be in need of the few days R&R at this week's party conference in Brighton and will welcome the opportunity to highlight some of the success stories from their time in office.

The Brighton & Hove Foyer, which opened in March 1998 and which offers accommodation and training for up to 50 insecurely housed or sofa-surfing 16- to 25-year-olds, is unquestionably one such success, but if Malcolm Wicks, the minister for lifelong learning, anticipated he was in line for his very own Olympian lap of honour when he arranged to visit the facility last Sunday, he was in for something of a shock.

"There's a saying that the Queen thinks the world smells of fresh paint," says Ron Daly, deputy manager of the Foyer, "and I think that the same thing often applies to ministers. Time and again we see old ideas recycled and reinvented as new initiatives, when what's required is for government to see the reality of what's happening at ground level and to coordinate its policies accordingly. Many of our clients feel they have been badly let down by successive governments over the years and, to be honest, I think they're right to feel that way."

The reality for many of the residents of the Foyer is that they have support needs which should have been picked up at a much earlier age at home and throughout their school years.

"You can talk all you like about the need for education and training for those who have left or dropped out of school with few, if any, qualifications," Daly continues, "but some young people need to be taught the basics of keeping themselves and their accommodation clean and tidy before they can even contemplate moving on to more formal learning."

The Brighton & Hove Foyer is owned and run by the Sanctuary Housing Association and is one of a growing number of organisations to have identified that the key to dealing with youth homelessness is to integrate education, training and job-seeking into the routine of residential accommodation.

What it is not is direct access accommodation. "You can't just turn up here and get a bed," says Daly. "Everyone referred to us is invited to an induction day, and those who like what they see come for an interview. Only about half of those are offered places."

Potential residents are normally referred to the Foyer through youth advice and support services, but assessment is made both on the willingness of the client to adhere to the rules and ethos of the organisation - "we always get complaints that no overnight visitors are allowed" - and on the risk that an individual may present to others in the building.

"We always look to give people a second chance and we have been stung in the past," admits Daly. "A statutory authority failed to mention that a 20-year-old it was referring was due in court for knife offences and he threatened some other residents."

Andrea and Jason are typical residents. Andrea found herself homeless after splitting up with her boyfriend, while Jason left home after an argument with his parents; they both have a frontiness that masquerades as self-confidence, but their eyes betray their vulnerability. These are youngsters who need all the help they can get, and at the Foyer they by and large get it, though it's not always the sort of help they might have had in mind.

"We have to be fairly brutal at times," Daly smiles. "Many kids with no GCSEs come in here expecting to get a job earning £15,000. I have to tell them that it just ain't going to happen and we try to work out a compromise between what they would like to do and what they are able to do. We also like to keep tabs on what everyone is up to, though it usually turns out that those who moan the most are those who are doing the least."

The Foyer's regime isn't everyone's idea of fun, but for all the gripes, most residents knuckle down to the benign dictatorship and live out the credo of investing in their own futures. Andrea has just started a health care NVQ at Brighton College of Technology and hopes to get a job in tourism and Jason is learning to be an outdoor pursuits instructor.

webTitle: Oxford wants more FE students, but won't relax entry

fields.headline: Top grades only, please
fields.standfirst: Oxford wants more further education students, but won't relax entry
fields.trailText: Oxford wants more further education students, but won't relax entry
fields.body:
Oxford university will review its marketing and recruitment to attract more applicants from further education colleges, but it won't dilute its rigorous academic entry criteria.

Candidates will still have to get three grade As at A-levels, it was made clear to college principals attending a conference on admissions to the university from the sector.

For the foreseeable future, Oxford won't be accepting other qualifications as substitutes for three As to achieve the minimum 30-point tariff.

Summer schools at Oxford run exclusively for further education students were among a package of proposals to stimulate more interest in the sector and remove widespread prejudice there against the university.

These also included sabbatical terms spent by further education tutors at the university, closer links between dons and further education tutors, and much more contact between Oxford students and prospective applicants from the sector.

Clarity and openness were hallmarks of what both sides unanimously agreed was a frank, illuminating and encouraging exercise.

"I think they were listening very very carefully to what we have to say," said Sue Dutton, deputy chair of the Association of Colleges.

Mansfield College, which hosted the one-day event, is spearheading a consortium of seven Oxford colleges which share the common aim of targeting the further education sector to stimulate more applications from it.

Mansfield's principal, Professor David Marquand, reiterated what he made clear in Guardian Further last week, that for too long the numbers of further education students trying for Oxford had been far too low.

Last year 459 candidates from the sector applied to Oxford. There were 4,373 applications from state schools and 3,426 from independent schools.

Of the further education applicants 30% got in compared with a 38% overall success rate. Only 4% of "mature" applicants - aged over 21 - were successful. The further education sector caters for huge numbers of students in this age group.

The possibility of increasing the numbers of mature undergraduate students at Oxford will be the focus of a project at Harris Manchester College, one of the consortium of seven. Harris Manchester bills itself as the only university college in the country which solely admits mature students to study full-time for a first degree.

Perhaps the most useful part of the day for the principals and managers from general further education and sixth-form colleges was an explanation of the Oxford admissions procedure by Edwin Peel, law and admissions tutor at Keble College.

He said the trickiest task facing admissions tutors was choosing between candidates who generally had exclusively A* and A GCSE scores and were predicted to get three As at A-level. He said candidates' personal statement and referees' assessments were scrutinised very carefully. And despite the mystique surrounding the Oxford interview, it was largely focused on the subject the candidate wanted to study. A number of mock interviews with students were staged to illustrate the point.

Offers will remain three grade As in the form of A2s, not the new AS qualification, which, under the new Curriculum 2000, students will achieve in the first year of a typical two-year A-level course.

"We are an academic university. We think that three As at A2 is the academic benchmark for assessing candidates," he said. "We will certainly take into account other qualifications."

Ann Limb, principal of Cambridge Regional College, said afterwards: "It was great, fantastic."

She had no problems with the academic entry requirement.

"Further education realises that Oxford represents excellence and we want our students associated with that excellence."

webTitle: The new heads of the learning and skills councils

fields.headline: So what's fresh?
fields.standfirst: The leaders of the brave new learning world have been chosen ... but hang on, didn't many of them run the old show, asks  Nick Tester
fields.trailText: The leaders of the brave new learning world have been chosen ... but hang on, didn't many of them run the old show, asks Nick Tester
fields.body:
Baked beans manufacturers Heinz used to boast that they had 57 varieties of products on their shelves. The government cannot claim the same for the 47 learning and skills councils, having just announced the appointments of all bar two of the top jobs to run the new outfits.

That's possibly because so many of the executive directors, who will earn £52-58,000, have been taken from the same, some would argue, sullied stables that have faced consistent criticism.

These are the officially discredited Training and Enterprise Councils, who have passed their sell-by date, alongside the local education authorities, which, we are constantly told, never do things right.

Let's not forget that the dramatic under-performance of the TECs was responsible for triggering a ministerial review 18 months ago. This eventually led to a bill, and later an Act that, with a flurry of consultative documents, led to wholesale reform of the organisation and funding of the post-16 sector.

Apart from a handful of further education college principals and a career civil servant, the majority of the new learning and skills council bosses have been taken from the same familiar cans.

Naturally Baroness Blackstone, the education and employment minister who sanctioned the appointments, says she is confident that the people, selected "from a high quality field" of applicants, will bring a "business-like approach" to the work of the councils.

But she and her DfEE officials - anxious to propel further education away from its immutable Cinderella tag - appear to have gone shopping at the local corner shop for their wares, disregarding the possibility of getting a greater choice of talented candidates by looking further afield. Why, for instance, do the legions of senior bureaucrats, currently counting down their days at the Further Education Funding Council - another animal due for extinction - appear to have been ignored?

Then there are the inevitable claims of patronage, of New Labour cronies, of late-night calls and the incredible fencing in the dark.

One newly appointed executive director commented: "It was very late in the evening when the phone rang. I was otherwise engaged, shall we say. But blow sex and all that, I answered the call, and the conversation went pretty well. This new job could be the climax of my professional life.

"It will be far easier to try to implement government policy than to run an institution constantly under attack from criticism and cynicism."

Another recalls his interview, when he suddenly realised he shared with his interrogators a mutual ignorance about what was wanted. The newly appointed executive director admits: "Neither myself or the interview panel had a clue about what was expected. I ventured something about how about making it up as we go along which, at least, is in the best, or worst, traditions of further education. I got the job, of course."

David Gibson, chief executive of the Association of Colleges, said he was not fazed by these appointments. He thought it "far better" to have 47 arms of government than 72 or so TECs, who had top-sliced funding and had charged whatever they wished to do training.

"The learning and skills councils have to present themselves as new organisations, offering a new culture of learning. I don't think that the people picked to run the councils will be biased towards private, work-based training."

However, it appears to be a revised TEC world and the Association of Colleges warns it will monitor the emerging landscape in order to safeguard the interests of colleges.

"I have yet to see a learning and skills council strategic plan," Gibson says. "The Association of Colleges looks forward to helping in this process and is already doing so. But we are determined colleges will not be left on a wing, as they were when swiftly forced to flee the local authority nest eight years ago."

A DfEE spokesman described as "nonsense" the notion that TECs were suddenly in the ascendancy. "Only 17 of the 45 appointments that have been made are former TEC leaders and they were selected in an open competition that attracted people from a very wide variety of backgrounds.

"But it is not surprising that people from TEC backgrounds have secured the new jobs because they have the skills and experience to take things forward," the spokesman added.

However, Chris Waterman, general secretary of the Society for Education Officers, is less sure. He is concerned, too, that if local education authorities are eventually abolished, as some commentators are proposing, then the TEC-biased learning and skills council world will take over.

That said, Waterman wants to offer an olive branch. "The Society for Education Officers is keen to work with the new executives to ensure the seamless provision of 16-plus education and training for all young people," he declared.

Why, for instance, do the legions of senior bureaucrats, currently counting down their days at the Further Education Funding Council - another animal due for extinction - appear to have been ignored? Then there are the inevitable claims of patronage, of New Labour cronies, of late-night calls and the incredible fencing in the dark. One newly appointed executive director commented: "It was very late in the evening when the phone rang. I was otherwise engaged, shall we say. But blow sex and all that, I answered the call, and the conversation went pretty well. This new job could be the climax of my professional life. "It will be far easier to try to implement government policy than to run an institution constantly under attack from criticism and cynicism." Another recalls his interview, when he suddenly realised he shared with his interrogators a mutual ignorance about what was wanted. The newly appointed executive director admits: "Neither myself or the interview panel had a clue about what was expected. I ventured something about how about making it up as we go along which, at least, is in the best, or worst, traditions of further education. I got the job, of course." David Gibson, chief executive of the Association of Colleges, said he was not fazed by these appointments. He thought it "far better" to have 47 arms of government than 72 or so TECs, who had top-sliced funding and had charged whatever they wished to do training. "The learning and skills councils have to present themselves as new organisations, offering a new culture of learning. I don't think that the people picked to run the councils will be biased towards private, work-based training." However, it appears to be a revised TEC world and the Association of Colleges warns it will monitor the emerging landscape in order to safeguard the interests of colleges. "I have yet to see a learning and skills council strategic plan," Gibson says. "The Association of Colleges looks forward to helping in this process and is already doing so. But we are determined colleges will not be left on a wing, as they were when swiftly forced to flee the local authority nest eight years ago." A DfEE spokesman described as "nonsense" the notion that TECs were suddenly in the ascendancy. "Only 17 of the 45 appointments that have been made are former TEC leaders and they were selected in an open competition that attracted people from a very wide variety of backgrounds. "But it is not surprising that people from TEC backgrounds have secured the new jobs because they have the skills and experience to take things forward," the spokesman added. However, Chris Waterman, general secretary of the Society for Education Officers, is less sure. He is concerned, too, that if local education authorities are eventually abolished, as some commentators are proposing, then the TEC-biased learning and skills council world will take over. That said, Waterman wants to offer an olive branch. "The Society for Education Officers is keen to work with the new executives to ensure the seamless provision of 16-plus education and training for all young people," he declared.

webTitle: Rostrum: training should get the respect it deserves

fields.headline: Gold, not silver
fields.standfirst: Britain still sees training as second best, says  Michael Sanderson
fields.trailText: Britain still sees training as second best, says Michael Sanderson
fields.body:
Probably the first economic migrants to visit Britain were the Romans - and a very good job they did when they arrived here, bringing much needed engineering skills with them.

They gave us good roads, town planning and a much needed public sanitation system. The Romans were, in truth, the first visitors to fill what we today call the skills gap.

So as interesting as Barbara Roche's views are on solving our current skills gap by allowing more highly skilled economic migrants in to Britain, they also prove, in the words of an old newspaperman, there is nothing new under the sun.

And, while Mrs Roche's views are a contribution to the skills gap debate, they are obviously not the solution. As so often has been the case in the past, only we, the British people, government, industry and educationalists, can solve the persistent conundrum: "Why do our main competitors in Germany, France and America all train their people better than we do?"

David Blunkett is the latest education secretary to try to improve our post-16 vocational training and he will outline his detailed plans in full at the Labour Party Conference in Brighton this week.

We greatly welcome his commitment to attacking the inadequacies of vocational training for school-leavers. For too long Britain has focused its educational resources on the academic elite who have gone on to gain the glittering prizes at our world-renowned universities.

Now we have an Education Secretary who has climbed to the top via the Gas Board and long hours of evening study at further education colleges, and who wants to do something for all those young people who regard Oxford merely as the town where Inspector Morse drives around in an old Jaguar.

Our colleagues in the Confederation of British Industry and the British Chambers of Commerce condemned Mr Blunkett's proposed overhaul of apprenticeships as "seriously flawed". I believe that is too strong. The Education Secretary should score 10 out of 10 for effort and determination, but perhaps only 7 out of 10 for content.

The Confederation of British Industry and British Chambers of Commerce complain that his £6bn plan for 100,000 apprenticeships for 16- and 17-year-olds is too prescriptive, especially the fixed minimum time-serving and specifying where the training should take place, particularly in local further education colleges. They want flexibility in training. They do not want Whitehall telling them how long or where they should train their employees.

Coming from an engineering background, where five-year apprenticeships used to be the norm, I do not have such a problem with prescribed minimum time-serving. My industry is now down to three-year apprenticeships, which I believe is about correct, but I can see why the service sector believes that even that may be too long for training in such areas as office skills.

My main area of concern in what Mr Blunkett is proposing is the quality of applicants that will benefit from the new scheme when it is fully up and running. The Guardian reported last month, in an unsourced story, that he will offer apprenticeships to over 100,000 16- and 17-year-olds who drop out of work or school.

I was pleased to see in recent interview that Mr Blunkett was careful to avoid such exaggerated claims. But even such claims from his advisers and spin doctors send out the wrong message. This policy is not directly about tackling poverty and social exclusion. It should not be viewed or used as some form or extension of New Deal. It is not even primarily about taking young people off the unemployment register.

It is about giving school-leavers proper qualifications and training and providing a proper vocational ladder of qualifications that stands equal to the existing academic ladder of qualifications.

It means that the brightest and best of our 16-year-olds can choose to take up an engineering apprenticeship rather than stay on at school, because that is the regular choice offered by their careers master. Why shouldn't a bright youngster choose to leave and learn to build world-beating McLaren Formula One cars in Woking rather than staying on into the sixth form?

For far too long Britain's brightest and best have regarded trade as a dirty word. We welcome David Blunkett's efforts to end that elitist view.

 Dr Michael Sanderson is chief executive of the Engineering Manufacturing Training Authority.

webTitle: Fees and the working class student

fields.headline: Inequality street
fields.standfirst: The full impact of fees on attempts to open up universities to working-class students will soon be revealed.
fields.trailText: The full impact of fees on attempts to open up universities to working-class students will soon be revealed
fields.body:
Universities saw a drop in students enrolled from the country's poorest neighbourhoods after the government introduced tuition fees two years ago, as official figures due to be published early next month confirm.

Despite its vows to widen access into higher education, the first year of the Labour government in fact saw 2,000 fewer student enrolments from less privileged backgrounds, a group already representing a tiny minority of the student population as a whole.

The statistics, obtained by the Guardian, come from the second batch of performance indicators for academic institutions published by the higher education funding councils. Published for the first time last year, the indicators record intakes of students from poor backgrounds and state schools, and compare them with the average intakes for universities with similar entry requirements and degree subjects. The latest statistics are particularly interesting because they focus on the 1998-99 academic year, which marked the end of free higher education, when the government introduced means-tested tuition fees for students and scrapped maintenance grants.

Fees had a dramatic impact on the number of students over 21 entering UK universities. In 1997-98, 100,300 mature freshers started full-time undergraduate courses. In 1998-9 mature entrants numbered 90,585 - a staggering 10% fall. Even more worrying for government ministers, the proportion of mature students with no previous academic experience and from poor districts fell from 15% to 14% over the two years.

While the number of mature students doing part-time courses increased by 5,000 to 218,000 in 1998-99, there was still an overall drop in mature entrants to universities.

The new fees regime saw little change to the make-up of young full time undergraduate entrants. The number of under-21s beginning degrees remained at 216,000 in 1998-99. And the proportion of these students from lower social classes and poor neighbourhoods stayed at 25% and 12% respectively. Combining the figures for all types of student, the statistics reveal a drop of at least 2,000 entrants from poor backgrounds.

A more promising sign for education ministers is that the proportion of young, full-time, first degree entrants from state schools went up from 82% in 1997-98 to 85% in 1998-99. But officials say that this increase is due entirely to a change of classification in the latest statistics, with some specialist colleges now included as state-funded institutions.

The figures show that one in six students are predicted to drop out of degree courses, a similar figure to that published last year.

These sector-wide figures mask huge differences in the make-up of student intakes for individual institutions. At Oxford 48% of students enrolled in its colleges in 1998-99 were from state schools, slightly up on the previous year. Durham University also saw its state-school intake rise slightly, to 63%, in 1998-99. Nottingham University, meanwhile, registers 72% state-school intake. Fewer than than 3% of students drop out of degrees in these institutions.

At the opposite end of the spectrum is the University of Central Lancashire, with 96% of its intake from state schools in 1998-99, but with just over a quarter of students dropping out. Other former polytechnics with large intakes of students from poor backgrounds see one in three students fail to complete degrees.

Already these figures have disgruntled officials in the new universities. They show that the former polytechnics are doing the bulk of work to attract poorer students into higher education. Yet the government is to focus a significant proportion of the £151m for widening access over three years on improving the number of disadvantaged students applying to "leading" universities in particular. "We want to encourage those who are capable to apply to the best universities they can manage," said one official. Another said that only "high demand" universities would qualify for these funds, and this group would include the Oxbridge institutions.

The government points out that two-thirds of students getting three grade As at A-level are from state schools, but state-school leavers with three As comprise only about half of applicants to Oxford.

The "Laura Spence" money will match funds raised by the universities and be used to recruit more admissions staff, send ambassadors to schools and colleges, and run more summer schools for young people and their teachers.

Staff in new universities are accusing the government of double standards. "We continue to increase the number of students recruited from working-class neighbourhoods," said Mike Milne-Picken, head of planning at Central Lancashire. "Research money is concentrated on the best performers, so why shouldn't widening access grants be allocated to those institutions best able to deliver?"

Others find offensive the presumption among ministers and officials that students with high A-level grades should automatically aspire to go to Oxbridge. "Government pronouncements assume aspirations and values that are out of keeping with those of many students," said Caroline Armstrong James from the University of Westminster. "People might aspire to something completely different from a traditional Oxbridge degree. You can't hope to raise aspirations if you deride their values. You will only alienate and upset students."

Even one of the funding council's advisers on access, Tim O'Shea, master of Birkbeck College, is uncomfortable with the emphasis being placed on elite institutions. "The top priority for the government should be to attract more mature students across the whole sector," he said, "not focus on transferring a few students with high A-level grades from one university to another."

webTitle: Furthermore: when students cheer you up

fields.headline: Hello there, Miss.
fields.standfirst: Janet Jones squirms with pleasure at a bit of attention from her students
fields.trailText: Janet Jones squirms with pleasure at a bit of attention from her students
fields.body:
This is going to be embarrassing. It was written in the relative privacy of August - a time when I am not going to have to look anybody in the eye tomorrow who is thinking "how could you?" so loudly and clearly that it might as well be emblazoned above them in the sky in fireworks.

I have just returned home from a trip round our local supermarket. I was able to take this trip at a sensible speed as term is over. I took time to stare. I filled the car with petrol first. A student was filling his car with petrol at the same time and he waved and smiled and shouted my name and the college's name across the forecourt at me. I waved and smiled and shouted too. It was a cheerful moment.

I went inside the kiosk to pay for my petrol and another student greeted me from behind the till. It was another cheerful moment.

I left the garage and headed for the car park. Sure enough another student had finished her shopping and was driving away. Another cheerful moment.

I got into the supermarket and started to wheel round. The first student I met told me about his plans to do animation next year and introduced me to his five-year-old. The next student I met told me her two-month-old baby was fine and at home with its grandmother and she would be coming back to college in September. The next student wished me a happy holiday ...

You get the picture. Nothing embarrassing about that. The embarrassing bit is how pleased I was. Am I getting sentimental? Sad, as you might say? Like the regular in the corner of the pub who everybody says hello to and nobody talks to? A bit like a dog in fact. "Hello there, Miss." "Good girl, Miss." "All right, Miss." And I wag my tail like the good Miss I am.

All those cheerful moments are, to put them another way, wags of my doggy tail. Am I so pleased because I have been forgiven for months and months of harping on about punctuality and punctuation? Am I so pleased because I have been acknowledged as a person in my own right and not just another supermarket shopper? Am I so pleased because I attach myself, dog-like, to every student and am delighted when one of the hands that feeds me looks out from the real world and recognises me?

I don't quite roll over on my back, but I do like having my ears scratched. The biggest buzz I ever had - so far - was when my one-time student was on my television screen. And he did not even know I was watching, otherwise, I liked to think, he would have given me a pat on the back and a titbit.

The programme was about groundbreaking medical advances on a groundbreaking medical scheme in a hospital with an international reputation. My one-time student was working as a doctor alongside the consultant running the scheme. I was so pleased I nearly wagged my tail off.

I had to speak to myself as the doctor did not know I was there: "Down girl, down!" and drop myself my own crumb of approval from the table of his achievement.

webTitle: Why the Samaritans are in nursery schools

fields.headline: You've got to laugh
fields.standfirst: What on earth are the Samaritans doing in our nursery schools?  Merope Mills finds out
fields.trailText: What on earth are the Samaritans doing in our nursery schools? Merope Mills finds out
fields.body:
Sandwiched in between arithmetic classes and scheduled somewhere alongside basic spelling, children in Denmark and Lithuania will soon have a surprising addition to their kindergarten curriculum. Befrienders International, the UK-based umbrella group for the Samaritan movement, is using the two countries as a starting point for a new life-skills programme in suicide- prevention. Reaching Young Europe starts its second stage next month and will look at how children as young as six should cope with bereavement, bullying, disappointment and loneliness.

For years, well-meaning educational organisations have espoused the benefits of starting young. We encourage children to talk, walk and read as soon as they demonstrate the capabilities to do so. But there is something faintly disturbing - or at the very least saddening - about starting suicide prevention at such a young age. Suicide remains a taboo topic in young classrooms. To some, the idea of breaking that silence equates to calling time on an age of innocence.

Befrienders, of course, is not so pessimistic. Chris Bale, director of the organisation, is keen to point out that theirs is a constructive process. "This a life skills project. As a suicide-prevention agency the most common thing we hear from people is: 'I don't know what to do,' which is really just another way of saying they don't have enough ways of coping. Maybe quietly spilling their story to a Befriender or Samaritan will help them, but how many shades of hell have they gone through to get to that stage?"

"People have been working on coping skills with 10-year-olds for some time," Bale says. "We wanted to go for something far, far earlier."

Where they are is in two countries with two of the highest suicide rates in the world, though this is one of the few characteristics Denmark and Lithuania share. The two locations were also chosen because of their contrasting educational systems: Denmark's classrooms are well-resourced and de-centralised from government, whereas Lithuania is the reverse, underfunded and with little independence. "The intention," says Bale, "is to see how it works in both systems." Were it to be a success, the programme would be rolled out to the UK and the rest of Europe which, argues Bale, would be sure to benefit whatever their suicide rates.

"We're trying to help children identify their emotions. We show them pictures and tell them stories. There's no mention of suicide anywhere but it isn't all a bundle of laughs. One of the children in the story gets bullied, another is from a single-parent family. These are all very real things and we talk about how the children should respond. Making children more aware of these feelings helps them look at ways of dealing with problems and asking for help," he says.

Bale argues that challenging such childhood inhibitions is an intricate part of the scheme. "We really try and stress - particularly to the boys - that it is a sign of strength to ask for help, so that if they do need to call a helpline like ours they're not coming in at the 11th hour." The fact that such a project might curtail drug use in children has also been a key incentive for the cooperation of the Lithuanian government.

Nevertheless, these are expectations that have little empirical evidence behind them. Bale's language is peppered with what he "hopes" the exercise will achieve: "It's a long-term and ambitious programme, but the human benefits could be enormous." He cites that the first stage showed a marked improvement in the children's social skills, empathy and assertiveness. Yet whether these advances will be transferable into adulthood, or whether they will make any lasting improvements to a child's mental health, is still debatable.

"There's no doubt that there's a developmental course of mental health difficulty where depression and some personality disorders can be traced back to childhood bereavement or loss," says Julia Fabricius, director of the Anna Freud Centre. "But what I wouldn't be so sure about is what they're planning to do about it. Just putting some nice people in schools to talk to children about emotions won't necessarily be that useful."

Fabricius is happy to concede that "mental health in children is an important issue and worth starting early". Her recommendation is for Reaching Young Europe to mimic the work of The Place To Be charity and, rather than having blanket targets across all children in a particular class or school, selecting schools in "deprived areas where there's a lot of poverty. These are things that are bound up with poor mental health in children."

However, Jennifer Smith, an educational psychologist who regularly works in the classroom, applauds the idea of an all-inclusive programme. Her concern is whether six-year-olds would be willing to open up to the project facilitators. "At this age children are more likely to share things that concern them with somebody they know, like their class teacher."

Yet Bale is anxious to point out the originality of the Reaching Young Europe project. "What makes us quite different from other attempts is that we're not just trying to help a child to help itself but also trying to sensitise him or her to when other people have problems, and how listening to your friend helps your friend."

He remains all too aware of the potential flaws of such an ambitious scheme. "It's very difficult for us to know that these skills which they learn in early childhood are actually going to help when they're an adult. In reality, we can only do that if we have something like a 25-year monitoring programme. But I think we just have to accept that, in the same way we accept that education of a young child helps them for the rest of their life, the same thing should work here, and that the long-term benefits really could be enormous."

But there is something faintly disturbing - or at the very least saddening - about starting suicide prevention at such a young age. Suicide remains a taboo topic in young classrooms. To some, the idea of breaking that silence equates to calling time on an age of innocence. Befrienders, of course, is not so pessimistic. Chris Bale, director of the organisation, is keen to point out that theirs is a constructive process. "This a life skills project. As a suicide-prevention agency the most common thing we hear from people is: 'I don't know what to do,' which is really just another way of saying they don't have enough ways of coping. Maybe quietly spilling their story to a Befriender or Samaritan will help them, but how many shades of hell have they gone through to get to that stage?" "People have been working on coping skills with 10-year-olds for some time," Bale says. "We wanted to go for something far, far earlier." Where they are is in two countries with two of the highest suicide rates in the world, though this is one of the few characteristics Denmark and Lithuania share. The two locations were also chosen because of their contrasting educational systems: Denmark's classrooms are well-resourced and de-centralised from government, whereas Lithuania is the reverse, underfunded and with little independence. "The intention," says Bale, "is to see how it works in both systems." Were it to be a success, the programme would be rolled out to the UK and the rest of Europe which, argues Bale, would be sure to benefit whatever their suicide rates. "We're trying to help children identify their emotions. We show them pictures and tell them stories. There's no mention of suicide anywhere but it isn't all a bundle of laughs. One of the children in the story gets bullied, another is from a single-parent family. These are all very real things and we talk about how the children should respond. Making children more aware of these feelings helps them look at ways of dealing with problems and asking for help," he says. Bale argues that challenging such childhood inhibitions is an intricate part of the scheme. "We really try and stress - particularly to the boys - that it is a sign of strength to ask for help, so that if they do need to call a helpline like ours they're not coming in at the 11th hour." The fact that such a project might curtail drug use in children has also been a key incentive for the cooperation of the Lithuanian government. Nevertheless, these are expectations that have little empirical evidence behind them. Bale's language is peppered with what he "hopes" the exercise will achieve: "It's a long-term and ambitious programme, but the human benefits could be enormous." He cites that the first stage showed a marked improvement in the children's social skills, empathy and assertiveness. Yet whether these advances will be transferable into adulthood, or whether they will make any lasting improvements to a child's mental health, is still debatable. "There's no doubt that there's a developmental course of mental health difficulty where depression and some personality disorders can be traced back to childhood bereavement or loss," says Julia Fabricius, director of the Anna Freud Centre. "But what I wouldn't be so sure about is what they're planning to do about it. Just putting some nice people in schools to talk to children about emotions won't necessarily be that useful." Fabricius is happy to concede that "mental health in children is an important issue and worth starting early". Her recommendation is for Reaching Young Europe to mimic the work of The Place To Be charity and, rather than having blanket targets across all children in a particular class or school, selecting schools in "deprived areas where there's a lot of poverty. These are things that are bound up with poor mental health in children." However, Jennifer Smith, an educational psychologist who regularly works in the classroom, applauds the idea of an all-inclusive programme. Her concern is whether six-year-olds would be willing to open up to the project facilitators. "At this age children are more likely to share things that concern them with somebody they know, like their class teacher." Yet Bale is anxious to point out the originality of the Reaching Young Europe project. "What makes us quite different from other attempts is that we're not just trying to help a child to help itself but also trying to sensitise him or her to when other people have problems, and how listening to your friend helps your friend." He remains all too aware of the potential flaws of such an ambitious scheme. "It's very difficult for us to know that these skills which they learn in early childhood are actually going to help when they're an adult. In reality, we can only do that if we have something like a 25-year monitoring programme. But I think we just have to accept that, in the same way we accept that education of a young child helps them for the rest of their life, the same thing should work here, and that the long-term benefits really could be enormous."

fields.headline: Invasion of Timor
fields.standfirst: The world's youngest state is about to get its first university - but not without a little help  and  hindrance from western academics
fields.trailText: The world's youngest state is about to get its first university - but not without a little help and hindrance from western academics
fields.body:
A national university for the newly independent territory of East Timor could be open for business as early as next month, according to the man most widely expected to become the first elected leader of the world's youngest state.

The guerrilla-turned-statesman Xanana Gusmão, until last September a political prisoner in the Indonesian capital and now one of the key players in the effort to rebuild East Timor, said the as yet unnamed institution would be operating "only in minimal conditions", with at least another three years needed to constitute its curricula, teaching resources and overall structure.

The transitional government cabinet in Dili, which comprises four East Timorese and four international ministers, has agreed to submit a plan to transfer budgetary funds to support the opening of the University of East Timor on a provisional basis next month. An earlier plan for Jesuit educators to establish a private university in the largely Roman Catholic territory has been placed on hold.

Filomeo Jacob, the cabinet minister responsible for social affairs, has said the university will need to admit up to 4,500 students in its first intake. His government has appealed to international donors to assist with up to $2m in startup costs.

Its language of instruction - a contentious issue among educators working on the half-island - will probably be Portuguese, although English and Indonesian are also being considered.

During the decades of Indonesian occupation of the one-time Portuguese colony, which lasted from 1975 until last year, the Portuguese language was banned in public life, with the result being that a majority of today's young Timorese are more fluent in the Indonesian tongue.

"We have so many priorities in education right now," Gusmão said, "and the first ones have had to be for the schools."

Gusmão was in the South Pacific visiting Timorese postgraduates at New Zealand's Massey University. Those Timorese postgraduates not currently studying in New Zealand are at universities either in Australia or Japan - the latter enjoying longstanding educational links with Portugal - with another 4,000 enrolled at Indonesian campuses on Java, their attendance dating back to be fore last September's politically inspired mayhem in East Timor.

Much of the half-island's already frail infrastructure was destroyed late last year after more than 80% of the island's 850,000 inhabitants used a historic referendum to choose independence from Indonesia. The plebiscite sparked weeks of violent unrest with hundreds, possibly thousands, of locals killed by militia forces loyal to Jakarta. Tracts of the capital, Dili, were razed by roaming gangs of street toughs.

For administrative purposes, including education, the fledgling nation is now being run by the United Nations, ahead of local elections to be held by 2002.

Western well-wishers, however, rather than military belligerents from nearby Indonesia, could yet prove to be the biggest future obstacle to the successful establishment of the university, said Gusmão, mentioning the widely publicised case of Jarat Chopra, a lecturer in international law at Brown University in Rhode Island in the US, who abruptly quit Dili just four months into a two-year stint with the territory's UN administrators.

Before his departure, Chopra accused the UN bureaucrats of putting the territory's future second to their own careers in a way that bordered "on criminal negligence".

In the three months since then, said Gusmão, "we have tried - with some success, I believe - to persuade the UN that they must involve everyone in their work." But it isn't just the UN that has had to change, he added. "It's visiting academics, too."

With their rich-world viewpoints and training, foreign scholars continued to be a mixed blessing for materially impoverished East Timor, he said. "They would do better not to come to us with a high sense of international standards, which are very good so far as they go, but don't really fit in with the reality of what is happening in East Timor. We can all probably work better if we work together, not from the sky down but from the ground up.

"I'm not saying that they're not very important to us - they are," he continued. "But some academics, we've come to feel, are not always coming to us with a sufficient grasp of our reality, and that is becoming more of a problem for us, and the nation we are creating."

fields.headline: Call waiting
fields.standfirst: Row over student phone numbers leaves Blunkett's ears ringing
fields.trailText: Row over student phone numbers leaves Blunkett's ears ringing
fields.body:
A drive by David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, to monitor graduate job prospects has been stopped in its tracks by the rebellion of university administrators refusing to divulge the contact details of their students.

Universities with a good track record of getting their students into employment stand to be rewarded with extra funding - but the government does not believe the figures collected by the institutions themselves are reliable enough. Blunkett proposed a national survey.

Civil servants have requested the home telephone numbers and addresses of students so Mori can carry out a pilot survey of graduate jobs, as part of government efforts to scrutinise the performance of universities. But a host of universities, including Cambridge, Oxford, Manchester and Sussex, say that giving up the information would contravene the Data Protection Act, and be unfair to students and parents.

"We have refused to give out information that would identify a student," said Michael Brooks, computing officer at Oxford University, as a flurry of email messages rejected the request from the Higher Education Funding Council for England.

"The latest changes to the Data Protection Act give even more protection to the individual." Another official blasted: "The funding council will have to do a lot better than this. Universities do not hold student data merely as agents for the council."

The head of planning at the University of Central Lancashire, Mike Milne-Picken, added: "Whatever the good intentions, this step will be seen as the unwelcome thin end of a wedge by institutions, students and their families alike."

An impasse became likely when Blunkett last year asked the funding council to develop a new wave of performance indicators for universities, aimed at tracking the job prospects of graduates from different institutions. The council got a year to produce the figures, but it was given an extension by the minister. Institutions with good employment records may in future get extra grants.

Funding-council officials, however, are worried that existing surveys of graduates, undertaken by universities themselves, are unreliable. It was decided that Mori should instead carry out a survey for all the country's graduates. But this could only be carried out if universities handed over the home contact details of students. Most contacts are for the homes of the parents of students.

The email request triggered a fierce reaction from institutions last month, with the discussion quickly escalating into a row over the legalities of the issue. University officials were told that legal advice for the funding council concluded that "there is no legal merit in the University of Cambridge's arguments whatsoever". In particular the solicitors argued that institutions were preventing the council from doing its job.

But Dennis Barrington-Light, head of student records and statistics at Cambridge, countered with news of initial advice from the government's assistant data protection commissioner. This indicated that the pilot scheme should only be operated with the consent of the students concerned.

Owen Richards, Sussex University's academic registrar, argued that irrespective of this, institutions had a moral duty to keep the records under wraps: "Leave aside the legalities. It is blindingly obvious that what is proposed places higher education institutions in an unacceptable ethical position." Another official pointed out that some students have requested that their address and telephone number should not be revealed to anyone for their personal safety. "I expect the police and MI5 are empowered to extract it, but am not sure that the council can argue the defence of the nation on this one," he said.

But Blunkett's push may finally be scuppered when ministers realise that their own addresses and telephone numbers will have to be divulged too. Blunkett's son, for example, recently studied at Liverpool University. Others in the pipeline include the sons of Jack Straw and Tony Blair.

There is also the small matter of Prince William, who starts at St Andrew's next year. Will Buckingham Palace take kindly to a call in four years' time to confirm whether the heir to the throne has secured a job?

webTitle: When parents and pupils get angry, they may go straight to a solicitor

fields.headline: Sir, meet my lawyer
fields.standfirst: These days, when parents and pupils get angry, they go straight to a solicitor
fields.trailText: These days, when parents and pupils get angry, they go straight to a solicitor.
fields.body:
Not so long ago, education was one of the sleepiest branches of the law. "From 1907 until 1989 - that's 82 years - there were only 20 cases that could be genuinely claimed as dealing with education," says John Friel, a leading barrister in the field.

Now everyone is having a pop at schools and local authorities, and hiring lawyers to juice up their claims: burnt-out teachers; former pupils who feel their schools failed them; parents who believe their child's special needs are not being met; parents of bullied children; even parents whose child simply didn't get into their school of choice. And, increasingly, those parents not actually going so far as the High Court are trundling along to appeals with a brief or solicitor in tow in the hope that legal muscle will scare a good result for them.

League tables, Ofsted inspections and a sharpening of everyone's sense of being consumers and not mute recipients have changed the landscape.

The number of appeals by parents against primary and secondary schools that did not admit their children rose from 77,000 in 1997-98 to 85,900 the following year. The figure for the latest school year is expected to show another leap to 95,000.

At the same time, lawyers have found much to play with among the endless flow of legislation. Every new statute creates work for the legal profession, and since 1979, education acts have appeared at the rate of almost one a year. Latterly the acts have given education secretaries of state huge scope for issuing subsequent statutory instruments - orders and regulations filling in details. Of the 4,000 to 5,000 statutory instruments published annually by government, up to 200 concern education.

In response to this burgeoning legislation, the Education Law Association (Elas) was set up 10 years ago to provide guidance to its membership of lawyers and educational managers. For a few years it remained an obscure body, but now it receives five inquiries a day from parents.

"Ten years ago you would have been hard put to find a lawyer who specialised in education," says Richard Clutterbuck, of Luton University, who produces the journal Education Law Monitor. Now, you can hardly move for them. Next month, London will host two conferences for them: one, chaired by Clutterbuck, is the Law Society's education law conference; the other focuses on special educational needs.

And as the education "consumers" become more reliant on legal muscle, so, too, do the education "providers". Education matters would once have been a minor part of a municipal lawyer's duties; not any more. Jack Rabinowicz, partner at Teacher Stern Selby, a London firm, says: "Local authorities now have a nominated lawyer in their legal department who's their education specialist."

The action they face from parents comes in three categories: special needs, admissions and exclusions.

The 1994 Code of Practice for special educational needs, which insisted that parents should be consulted, jolted them into starting to challenge decisions, says Clutterbuck.

Since then there had been an incremental broadening of the definition of need, he says. The Court of Appeal earlier this year ruled that a tetraplegic child needed physiotherapy to get education. Unlike health services, which are rationed, educational services cannot be. Education authorities have used every procedural device to minimise numbers of children officially "statemented" for special provision and more parents have sought to challenge them.

The proportion of special needs tribunal hearings - where parents appeal against decisions - to which parents are bringing lawyers is steadily rising. In 1997/98 only one in 10 parents was legally represented at the 1,200 or so cases heard each year. Last year it was one in five.

Then, less than two months ago, a landmark House of Lords ruling upped the ante still further. Pamela Phelps, 26, was awarded £45,650 damages for the west London borough of Hillingdon's failure to diagnose her dyslexia. This decision has had a predictable consequence: a deluge of calls to solicitors.

Schools' admissions decisions where, typically, parents can't get children into their preferred secondaries because they are already full, have been more difficult to overturn since the 1998 Schools Standards and Framework act, but that hasn't stopped parents bringing lawyers in. It's cheaper to hire a lawyer than move house, says Clutterbuck, and "it salves their conscience. Parents want to feel they've done their best for their child and if that means getting lawyers to fight appeals, they'll do it."

Similarly, parents are increasingly seeking judicial review when their appeals about excluded children are turned down. Conversely, when heads readmit a child excluded for bullying, parents of the victims are starting to seek judicial review.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, regrets that the presence of unstable kids, some reinstated after exclusion, has driven more teachers, including those who have been injured, to seek advice from their union lawyers about litigation. The landmark case came when a teacher, Hazel Spence-Young, won £85,000 for a neck injury sustained in an assault by a pupil.

John Friel rejects the notion that lawyers have been flooding into education as the pinch on legal aid has shrunk other activity. Some of his colleagues have pursued the speciality after fighting for their own children's needs. "There are probably no more than 50 barristers with regular litigation experience in education."

But what about 20 years ago? Probably none, he admits.

 For a list of education solicitors in England and Wales, contact Elas on: 01303 211570.

webTitle: Grapevine where schools share good ideas

fields.headline: A green and pleasant land
fields.standfirst: Grapevine where schools share good ideas
fields.trailText: St Paulinus C of E Primary School in Crayford, Kent
fields.body:
The seasons are all changing,

All because of us.

Don't you think it's time,

that we all made a fuss?

So rap the children from St Paulinus C of E Primary School in Crayford, Kent, who last week received the Millennium Marque from the Tidy Britain Group for their environmental work - the only school to be so honoured.

The school is blessed with a little wooded area, and until about seven years ago this was just used as a short-cut to get to the playing field. A group of parents cleared away the rubbish from this overgrown and neglected corner of the grounds and marked out a proper pathway. That was the beginning of a sustainability project that has gone from strength to strength.

On entering the school there is a wall covered with certificates - from Bexley in Bloom through to the prestigious Eco-Schools Award, evidence of the school's commitment towards green issues.

The grounds are not huge, but with the well-planned layout they give the impression that a small child could wander for hours round ponds and through wooded secret gardens, or just sit and watch the birds and butterflies. Every aspect of the school is reviewed by the pupils for its environmental impact in order to identify targets for action and improvement.

A plan is then drawn up involving the children, teachers, parents and local community, which is constantly monitored and evaluated. Different groups have responsibility for particular tasks: in the bird garden, where feeders of every shape and size are hung, the children in year six are responsible for watering the flowers, but the reception class fills the birdbath. This year reception have planted a hazel walk and bower, which, by the time they leave the school, will have grown into another established feature of the grounds.

Projects are designed with this aim in mind, and the children have a sense of shared ownership in the school. Many still visit after they have left, wanting not just to check on how their own work has matured, but to see what the new kids have been up to. They also often initiate sustainability projects in their secondary schools.

Environmental issues are integrated into the national curriculum, touching every subject. A regular science class feature is pond dipping - taking a jar of pond water and examining it and learning about the contents. The butterfly garden is planted and cared for by the children. On the wall are the descriptions and models of the different butterflies so that they can be easily identified.

The pupils have carried out projects on waste recycling and have a policy of using both sides of the paper; the saving of energy is another high priority, with projects to design posters to remind each other to switch off the lights.
