webTitle: In schooling, is small  always beautiful?

fields.headline: Dream on
fields.standfirst: Tired of tests and targets, disaffection and decay? Then join us, say the devotees of 'small schools'. But is small always beautiful?  Dave Hill  examines alternative education
fields.trailText: Tired of tests and targets, disaffection and decay? Then join us, say the devotees of 'small schools'. But is small always beautiful? Dave Hill examines alternative education
fields.body:
Somewhere out there, far from the teeming corridors of the state system, deaf to politicians' talk of "excellence" and "performance", there is an education promised land. True, it exists mainly in the dreams of anxious parents, but what a pleasant place it is. There is freedom of expression, yet chairs never arc through classroom airspace. Knowledge is treasured, yet young minds are not oppressed by achievement targets, and neither are teachers. Schools are communities rather than institutions, and every child is seen as a special individual rather than just another inmate in some government-controlled academy of stress.

This Saturday in central London, at the second annual Alternatives in Education Fair, a diverse group of educators, campaigners and parents will gather in the shared conviction that such a promised land not only exists, but that all children should be delivered there. The two best-known alternative education philosophies will be represented: Steiner-Waldorf, whose fellowship encompasses 26 schools and 45 kindergartens in Britain and Ireland, and the followers of Dr Maria Montessori. Also providing a presence will be Summerhill, the Suffolk secondary whose policy of making lessons voluntary recently survived a nasty brush with Ofsted.

Those are the big names, but a growing number of smaller operators will also be espousing their own distinctive ways of making learning in some way more spiritual, less prescriptive, less impersonal - "holistic" is a favoured term. If there is a common theme, it is that small is beautiful. The charity Human Scale Education (HSE), which represents alternative schools and organises the fair, campaigns for small classes, smaller schools, and large schools to be "restructured into smaller units".

The wish to create "learning experiences that will develop in young people the attitudes, skills and knowledge to shape a fairer world" is, of course, wholly admirable. But what are such schools actually like? The principles informing them can also trigger suspicions, not only among traditionalists who smell zealots and cranks. Liberal parents sympathetic to "alternative" ideals may also have their doubts. Is it necessarily true that virtue follows smallness? Can smallness also lead to small-mindedness, a suspicion of diversity and of majority ways? What exactly are some alternative schools an alternative to?

The possible answers to the last question demonstrate the dangers of generalisation. Many one-off alternative schools demonstrate an intellectual position in action, just as the Steiners and Montessoris do. For example, the Educare Small School, a primary in Kingston-upon-Thames, is described by its co-founder Liz Steinthal as "a reflection of my philosophy of teaching." A maximum of 50 pupils, whose parents pay £910 per term, follow the national curriculum, but also do lots of art, drama and meditation. "It allows children to learn how to be still and silent," Steinthal explains, "and how to recognise what is going on inside them instead of just what's going on around them."

By contrast, the founding impulse behind the Abinger Hammer Village School, a primary near Dorking, was simply to avoid closure. It was due to be shut by the local authority in 1982, but local residents raised funds and have kept it going. The school is now financed by a trust and vigorous fundraising efforts, and attendance is free. There is no over-arching ideology, just a straightforward conviction that a village school is essential to village life. That said, trustees' secretary Shirley Corke is clear about its values: "We like the idea of it being an unschooly school. It's not that we don't teach them anything! I sometimes help out by giving a French lesson, which gets them used to all the funny noises! But I'm not keen on children sitting down all day, struggling with too much reading and writing."

The school has just one teacher and only a dozen pupils. The oldest is the sole member of year four and as such stands unchallenged as head girl. Hammond is pleased that working with such tiny numbers means she can deliver tailored learning , and thinks the modest numbers are a positive advantage in terms of social skills. "They're like a large family. The big ones look after the little ones, and it all helps with sensitivity and communication."

The failure of mainstream schools to be sensitive towards pupils with certain special needs lies behind some of the more specialist schools under the "alternative" umbrella. Far removed from Abinger Hammer, Home School of Stoke Newington in north London began life nine years ago as one boy and his mum - teacher Catherine Allen, now Home School's principal. She was certain her boy would flounder in a conventional secondary. Dyslexic, dreamy and, his mother says, "unconsciously setting himself up as a victim," he'd already struggled at primary school, and had been baffled by basic rules. "He couldn't understand why he had to ask if he could go to the toilet," Allen recalls. "He thought that was mad."

Her son's sense of disconnection was underlined for him by the contrast between himself and his twin sister. Where she was tuned-in and confident, he was "busy off with the birds". So while her daughter moved up smoothly into secondary schooling, Allen gave up her career and began teaching her son at home. "Educationally, that was fine," she says. "But where were the mates?" After a couple of years she placed an ad in the local paper. Her son described the day he was first joined by two additional pupils as the best one of his life.

Most lessons take place in two rooms of Allen's terraced house. There is lots of artwork, plenty of books, computers, a piano, some old-fashioned school desks and a warm atmosphere. Fees are £2,700 per term. The school has nine teachers, most part-time, and 10 pupils - all boys, though girls are welcome. Most suffer from dyslexia, though the school also takes children who are school phobic or have been bullied.

A sympathetic inspector described Home School's pupils as "mainstream refugees". Allen thinks that's about right: they aren't children who'd qualify for a special needs statement, yet a normal secondary school simply can't give them what they need. And maybe the description could bear a broader application. The growing interest in alternative and home schooling suggests that more children and parents are seeking refuge from an education culture increasingly dominated by a tests-and-targets ethos and the spectre of disaffection and decay.

Do the alternatives have the answer? HSE coordinator Fiona Carnie emphasises that her organisation wants to see the most innovative values of the alternative movement backed with public money and practised at the heart of the state system. "All children need to have a nurturing, caring school environment," she says. To which we all say, amen.

 Alternatives in Education Fair: Saturday, Sept 30, Conway Hall, Red Lion Square, London, for details, call HSE on 01275 332516.

fields.headline: How much!
fields.standfirst: They're boarding schools, they're for ordinary kids, and they're free (well, almost).  Phil Revell discovers British state education's best-kept secret
fields.trailText: They're boarding schools, they're for ordinary kids, and they're free (well, almost). Phil Revell discovers British state education's best-kept secret
fields.body:
In a recent circular, Eton warns prospective parents to prepare for fees of £60,000 by the year 2020. Many parents find the current fees quite high enough, and opt for less prestigious boarding schools, but even these are unlikely to leave much change out of £15,000 a year once "extras" are taken into account. Not surprisingly, independent schools are seeing their boarding numbers drop as families count the cost and opt for day schooling.

But thousands of parents still grit their teeth and write the cheque. Some feel they have little choice. A report by the Henley Centre identified the kind of parents who, while never boarders themselves, are considering boarding for their children. These "Double Income in a Hurry" families are trying to give their children some degree of constancy in what is often a whirlwind family life.

But there is an alternative. Adams in Shropshire is a 350-year-old school with a strong academic record. It was founded by Lord Mayor of London Sir Thomas Adams in 1650. Farmers' sons would arrive on horseback on a Monday and leave on Fridays to return to the plough. Boarding fees at Adams are just over £5,000 per year. A family could send four children to the school for the cost of one place at Eton. Not surprisingly, the boarding house is full and there is a waiting list. The surprise comes with the type of school. Adams is a state school, a comprehensive.

"Most people don't know about us, they've never heard of the system," says Gillian Brierley, who manages boarding at the school. "There's a reaction of, 'Why are you so cheap? Is it because you're second-rate?' To which the answer is no, we are a state school, but the results are excellent."

There are 36 state boarding schools in England offering 4,000 places. Fees range from £1,450 to £2,200 a term and the schools cover the whole range of state provision, from boys' grammar schools to city comprehensives. The largest is Wymondham in Norfolk with 500 boarders, but the majority, like Adams, have relatively small boarding houses.

The local education authority meets tuition costs as they would for any other child at the school. Fees cover accommodation, food and other expenses. In the 1960s there were nearly 200 such schools, but many were allowed to wither away.

Today Adams has 54 boarders. Brierley believes the changing employment climate is creating more demand for the kind of settled schooling that boarders benefit from. "There's an awful lot of movement of parents, especially now that most mothers are working as well. A lot work full-time and send their child here for weekly boarding. People are just much more mobile than they used to be."

Geoffrey and Kristine are different. They had no option but to send their three daughters to boarding school. The Taylors live on Bryher, the smallest of the Isles of Scilly, where there is no school at all. "There are a lot of tidal problems even in good weather," says Geoff Taylor. "Sometimes you can't get off the island." The family's three girls go to Adams.

"It's only in the last five or six years that people discovered state boarding as an option," says Geoff. "On Scilly, kids aren't streetwise. They needed to have somewhere that offered both a secure environment and an opportunity to experience a degree of freedom, to make the transition." The family are certainly not worried about the education their daughters received. The two elder girls did well; Rosamund, currently head girl at Adams, is applying to Oxford this year. "It's very different from being at home," she says. "But in a good way; I've gained more independence. Boarding is a good half-way step between home and university." Relationships with other pupils at the school are good. "I've got friends from the boarding house and friends from college," says Rosamund. Teachers report that boarders get on well with the day pupils, with sleepovers in the boarding house a popular option.

Just why state boarding should be the best-kept secret in UK education is a mystery. Wymondham's head, Victoria Musgrave, says that the Department for Education and Employment has to be constantly reminded of the school's existence. A DfEE information booklet does exist but it isn't heavily promoted.

Inevitably, given the fees charged, the boarders in these schools tend to be middle-class. Heads in the "comprehensive" boarding schools claim a balanced intake, but at least one Midlands head believes that Stourbridge's Old Swinford School cannot justifiably claim to be a comprehensive school.

"It selects by parental income," she says. It's noticeable that schools with larger boarding houses like Old Swinford and Wymondham achieve much higher GCSE results than some of the smaller boarding establishments attached to schools with a more comprehensive intake. But Wymondham's Victoria Musgrave argues that the results are down to a school culture that values endeavour.

"They really worked their socks off for those results," she says. In the past, some boarding-school places were filled by social services departments that would select young people who needed to live apart from their family. That is now much less common, but many heads would love to be able to offer places regardless of income. Some can offer places funded by charitable foundations, but there is no state funding mechanism to cover boarding costs, even for parents like the Taylors who have little alternative.

The last administration's assisted places schemes didn't apply to state school boarding, much to some heads' disgust. And current initiatives, led by millionaire Peter Lampl, offer inner-city children a chance of a quality education in a different environment; but they have also ignored the state boarding sector.

"This is a real alternative to independent schooling," says Chris Potter, head at Old Swinford. "If there were state scholarships, that would be tremendous, we would be inundated."

 For information about state boarding schools: www.stabis.org.uk For copies of the DfEE booklet, telephone: 020-7925 5555.

fields.standfirst: Ian Wylie  reports on this year's ABS winners and the benefits to them and industry as a whole
fields.trailText: Ian Wylie reports on this year's ABS winners and the benefits to them and industry as a whole
fields.body:
There are no summer snaps to show or holiday romances to report, but when Kate Hunter returns to college today she has something a little more significant to share with her friends and lecturers.

Yesterday at a ceremony at the offices of The Guardian and Observer newspapers, the 21-year old, who is studying business management with psychology at Gloucestershire Business School, Cheltenham and Gloucester College, picked up her prize as winner of the undergraduate section in this year's Association of Business Schools (ABS) Awards.

The ABS Awards Scheme, which is sponsored by Clerical Medical and supported by The Guardian and The Observer, aims to promote the study of business and management at undergraduate and postgraduate levels by recognising both the calibre and development of students, giving them an opportunity to demonstrate their newly-acquired business skills.

The undergraduate prize is designed to show the benefits of work placement. In fact, Kate's 48-week placement at Worcester Acute Hospitals NHS Trust proved so successful that she was retained after her placement ended - as a paid employee - until the beginning of the new college term.

Kate's time at the trust involved handling a wide variety of projects within different areas of Worcester Royal Infirmary. Following her return to college, this new post will become a full-time position.

Kate also held positions within the training and development department - she acted as a work experience co-ordinator, responsible for the induction of around 30 new staff every month - in the internal communications section, where she helped with the staff newsletter, as well as working on an important clinical governance initiative.

"The development and training I received was amazing. I've really enjoyed myself this year and got a lot out of it in terms of professional development."

Kate worked on the hospital wards as well as in the offices and found it tough but essential experience for gaining an understanding of healthcare. "Getting your hands dirty gives you a real sense of what hospitals are all about."

Kate says she found she had to be adaptable and flexible, but was able to draw on much that she had learned in college. She is now keen to work in personnel and professional development once she graduates.

The winner of the postgraduate section, Patrick Dempsey, impressed judges with a report on how he set up Severnshed restaurant and bar in Bristol with two business partners, while studying for an MBA and working as a planner for the Post Office. Patrick, who completed his MBA at the University of Bath School of Management, won financial backing from environmental bank Triodos to refurbish a 19th century harbourside building designed by Isambard Kingdon Brunel.

The ABS is the national representative body of 100 major business and management education providers in the UK. ABS members employ more than 7,000 academic staff and contribute to the education of some 250,000 students each year.

In recent years, there has been a huge rise in demand from employers for people who hold business and management-related qualifications. One sixth of all undergraduates in the UK are now taking business or business-related courses.

Business schools in the UK have a long and successful track record in providing this kind of education. MBA programmes, for example can help broaden skills and encourage a "holistic" approach to business, leaving participants better prepared for entrepreneurial roles - either with existing employers or in setting up their own businesses.

Award winners

Undergraduate section:

First prize: Katherine Hunter (Gloucestershire Business School)

Second prize: Peter Li (Derbyshire Business School)

Joint third prize: Gillian Lavety (Paisley University), Lynn McCluggage (Paisley University)

Postgraduate section:

First prize: Patrick Dempsey (University of Bath School of Management)

Second prize: Julie Nerney (University of North London Business School )

Business/Society section:

First prize: Alex Nicholls and Charlotte Opal (Said Business School, Oxford University)

webTitle: Iceman is defrosted for gene tests

fields.headline: Iceman is defrosted for gene tests
fields.standfirst: New techniques may link copper age shepherd to present-day relatives
fields.trailText: More than five millennia after being entombed in an Alpine glacier, Oetzi the iceman was defrosted yesterday so scientists could try to extract his last secret: why he died.
fields.body:
More than five millennia after being entombed in an Alpine glacier, Oetzi the iceman was defrosted yesterday so scientists could try to extract his last secret: why he died.

DNA samples and tooth enamel were scraped from the mummified body which has been hailed as one of the most significant archaeological discoveries of the 20th century.

His home for the past two years, a £1m refrigerator in Bolzano, northern Italy, was warmed up from its usual - 6C (21F) for two hours.

Samples from his left knee, intestine and mouth could shed light on neolithic migration patterns, diet, disease and burial customs. Researchers hope to establish where he spent his childhood.

Discovered on a glacier at an altitude of 3,000m (10,000ft) by hikers in 1991, the body was so well preserved it was mistaken for a modern-day mountaineer killed in an avalanche.

Aged about 45, weighing six stone and 5ft 5in tall, the shepherd from the copper age was the oldest and best preserved mummy ever found.

The goatskin leggings, grass cape, copper-headed axe and arrows found nearby have provided a historical treasure trove.

Yesterday's lifting of restrictions so that tissue samples could be taken is expected to fill the gaps in the reconstructed life story of Oetzi, named after a local valley.

"Our inquiry will focus on the circumstances of his death," said Franco Tagliaro, of the University of Rome. "We will examine the disposition of blood at the moment of death and, in particular, we will study signs of lesions found on the mummy, to establish with certainty if they were present before or after death."

Despite the pinpointing of age, occupation, medical ailments (arthritis and diarrhoea) and even last meal (goat and plum), Oetzi's death has remained a mystery.

Jim Dickson, professor of archaeobotany at the University of Glasgow, concluded after a five-year study that he was probably caught in a storm, crawled into a hollow and froze to death on the border of modern day Italy and Switzerland.

Italian and British neurologists will compare his DNA with modern inhabitants of Italy's Alto Adige region to see if they are his descendants.

The corpse has been defrosted several times before but the samples have never been subjected to such sophisticated techniques.

webTitle: Footballing son is latest Gadafy to drop in on London

fields.headline: Footballing son is latest Gadafy to drop in on London
fields.trailText: Britain has granted an entry visa to the 26-year-old son of Muammar Gadafy, in a move that shows how much relations have thawed with Libya since sanctions were suspended last year. Next week a British trade mission heads there looking for business.
fields.body:
Britain has granted an entry visa to the 26-year-old son of Muammar Gadafy, in a move that shows how much relations have thawed with Libya since sanctions were suspended last year. Next week a British trade mission heads there looking for business.

Saadi Gadafy, Libya's footballer of the year, will be the fourth family member to visit Britain within a few months.

A Foreign Office spokesman said Saadi held no position in the Libyan government and would be making a private visit for medical treatment. This is what his visa application says; he has an injured knee. But Libyan opposition sources say he has long wanted to attend a British football match, and healthcare may take second place to that.

In any case, the knee injury is likely to prove only a temporary setback. Since becoming president of the Libyan Football Federation as well as captain of the main Tripoli team and the national squad, Saadi has enjoyed great success.

During his captaincy of Tripoli's al-Ahli team, the rival squad from Benghazi - also called al-Ahli (National) - has suffered defeats on and off the field.

Benghazi is seen as a centre of opposition to the rule of Colonel Gadafy, and the only outlets for this opposition are the mosques and stadiums.

At a match in Tripoli this summer, al-Ahli Benghazi had a 1-0 lead by half time but in the second half the referee helpfully imposed two penalties against it and allowed al-Ahli Tripoli an offside goal.

Benghazi's players walked off but Saadi's guards ordered them back. Tripoli won 3-1. On July 20, Benghazi played against the team from al-Baydah - Saadi's mother's home town. So outraged were Benghazi fans at one penalty that they invaded the pitch and the game was abandoned.

Returning home, the fans set fire to the local branch of the Libyan Football Federation. On August 28 the "people's leadership" in Benghazi dissolved the club, and four days later the club's headquarters were demolished and more than 50 fans arrested.

Recognising, perhaps, that his efforts might have overstepped the mark, Saadi resigned from the federation. But it pleaded that without him it would be unable to go on. On September 5 Saadi was reinstated by his father.

Other Gadafy family visitors to London include the colonel's daughter, Aisha, 23, and her half-brother Mohammed, 29, credited with a degree in nuclear engineering.

They spent a few days at the Dorchester Hotel in July but left hastily after Aisha made a pro-IRA speech at Speakers' Corner. The colonel's second wife, Safiya, has also visited, as has the wife of Abdullah al-Senoussi, the head of Libyan intelligence.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Filipinos flee army assault
More than 36,000 villagers have fled their homes to escape a military assault on a gang holding 17 hostages on the island of Jolo in the southern Philippines, officials said yesterday. The defence secretary, Orlando Mercado, said two of the rebels were killed yesterday. According to the authorities 105 gang members have died in 10 days of fighting. Only one soldier has been killed, they claim. Unconfirmed reports speak of growing civilian casualties.
AP, Jolo

Filipinos flee army assault
More than 36,000 villagers have fled their homes to escape a military assault on a gang holding 17 hostages on the island of Jolo in the southern Philippines, officials said yesterday. The defence secretary, Orlando Mercado, said two of the rebels were killed yesterday. According to the authorities 105 gang members have died in 10 days of fighting. Only one soldier has been killed, they claim. Unconfirmed reports speak of growing civilian casualties.
AP, Jolo


Villagers fight to be rescued
Hungry mobs in villages cut off by water attacked relief teams and troops on boats yesterday in eastern India, where monsoon flooding has left at least 208 people dead and 165 missing. "People were fighting ... to make sure they got a place in the rescue boats," an army official said. Trains carrying aid were looted. In the state of West Bengal as many as 800,000 houses have been flooded.
Reuters, Calcutta


Pirates target Harry Potter
China has brought forward the launch of the first three Harry Potter books by a week to combat bootleg publishers, the People's Literature Publishing House said yesterday. Officials said 600,000 copies of the books, by Briton JK Rowling, are now due on the shelves on October 6.
Reuters, Beijing


Bounty hunters kill Hanoi mice
Citizens of Hanoi have killed about 1.7m mice this year as part of an official drive to control rodent numbers, the Vietnam News reported yesterday. The state pays about 200 dong (1p) for every tail handed in.
Reuters, Hanoi

fields.headline: Milosevic may force runoff
fields.standfirst:
President's aides vow he will fight on as opposition declares victory : Milosevic may force election runoff
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Slobodan Milosevic, struggling to retain his grip on the Yugoslav presidency, sought yesterday to force a second round runoff in the face of a deafening chorus of domestic and international calls for him to relinquish power.
fields.body:
Slobodan Milosevic, struggling to retain his grip on the Yugoslav presidency, sought yesterday to force a second round runoff in the face of a deafening chorus of domestic and international calls for him to relinquish power.

All unofficial polls - except for those carried out by Mr Milosevic's Socialist party and some of its allies - put him more than 20% behind his main challenger, Vojislav Kostunica, who has managed to unite a fractured opposition. Mr Milosevic, cornered, is now fighting for time.

Mr Kostunica, 56, a law professor, claimed victory in Sunday's ballot and demanded that the state election commission release the official count: "This is a peoples' victory," he declared. "We will defend our victory by peaceful means and we will protest for as long as it takes."

As the commission delayed the announcement of the results, both sides issued widely conflicting unofficial results. The Democratic Opposition of Serbia claimed that with the votes counted at 60% of polling stations, Mr Kostunica was leading on 55.31%, against to Mr Milosevic's 34.19%.

But Gorica Gajevic, the general secretary of Mr Milosevic's Socialist party, said that with 37 % of the ballots counted, the president was ahead, on 45 % to Mr Kostunica's 40%."This result gives us optimism that we can win in the first round," he added.

There was no word from Mr Milosevic himself, and fears persisted that the authorities would resort to violence to retain their grip on power.

Western countries piled the pressure on the Yugoslav leader to accept defeat. Germany, Britain, Italy, France and the European Union all declared that Mr Milosevic had lost in Sunday's vote. The US said it doubted Mr Milosevic could make any "credible claim of victory".

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, said: "Today Milosevic is a beaten, broken-backed president. My message to him today is, be honest with your people. Get out of the way and let Serbia get out of the prison you have turned it into."

The fightback began yesterday afternoon at a press conference for domestic consumption, in which Mr Gajevic insisted that Mr Milosevic had taken the first round of the election but that the margin was small, so he would fight a second round in a fortnight to give him absolute victory.

But even former Milosevic allies such as the ultranationalist Radical party agree that he has lost. Analysts said Mr Milosevic's camp was divided between those advising him to declare an outright victory and those saying he should play for time. Even a runoff would represent a loss of face.

Milos Aligridoc, a member of the opposition said yesterday: "[A runoff] would mean absolute humiliation for him and he is not a man who likes to be humiliated ."

Belgrade was calm yesterday but pressure is beginning to mount against the business people involved with the rul ing party, who have long controlled the wealthy shopping streets and the black market in cigarettes, petrol and whisky.

The opposition was out on the streets of Belgrade again last night, celebrating victory. Everywhere people are discussing Mr Milosevic's fate.

"I go for the Ceaucescu option myself,"said one housewife. "Although, I think he will be killed by someone inside his own circle who wants to become a hero of the Serbian people."

The state election commission was locked out of its office in the federal parliament building yesterday, as it has been since Sunday night, effectively suspending the official count. Mirko Popovic, a member of the commission, said that technically they could be called in time to announce the official result on Thursday.

Result according to pro- and anti-Milosevic camps

Main opposition bloc

Milosevic 34%

Kostunica 55%

Serbian Radical party

Milosevic 37.9%

Kostunica 53.5%

Socialist party

Milosevic 45%

Kostunica 40%

Yugoslav Left party

Milosevic 56.3%

Kostunica 31.4%

webTitle: Brown concedes the cash but not the principle in bid to quell pensions revolt

fields.headline: Brown concedes the cash but not the principle in bid to quell pensions revolt
fields.standfirst:
Refusal to bow to fuel protesters but more help for the elderly on way
Chancellor refused to restore link between pensions and earnings as demanded by the unions.
But he confirmed that the minimum income guarantee will go up next April from £78 to £90, aimed at the four million poorest pensioners.
And in 2003 a pension credit is to be introduced, targeted at four million middle income people on modest occupational pensions or with limited savings.
Before 2003 'transitional help' for pensioners. But he refused to spell out exactly who would get this or how much they could expect.
Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown last night left the Labour conference hanging on a knife-edge after signalling costly concessions on pensions without spelling them out clearly enough to put an immediate end to tomorrow's threatened union revolt.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown last night left the Labour conference hanging on a knife-edge after signalling costly concessions on pensions without spelling them out clearly enough to put an immediate end to tomorrow's threatened union revolt.

Senior ministers were confident of winning over the unions as the word went round that Tony Blair had ensured his chancellor would do enough to buy off "grey power" anger. But - on a day when the conference defeated the leadership twice, on pollution and train safety - first reactions were confused.

"We will have to get through the smoke and mirrors. But if this is a large and genuine in crease in the basic rate then that will go a long way to satisfying the party," said John Edmonds, leader of the GMB union. "I want to see words on paper," said Unison's Rodney Bickerstaffe.

The chancellor's intellectually and emotionally powerful appeal for support from the party faithful in Brighton won him a rare five-minute standing ovation - led bythe prime minister - for his commitment to rectify years of economic short-termism and Tory neglect of public investment.

Mr Blair will ram home the theme today when he admits that the government has "taken a knock" in recent weeks, but one that will give it the chance to fight back, explain its achievements - and contrast it with William Hague's £16bn programme of spending cuts.

However, Mr Brown's dogged refusal yesterday to say exactly how much extra money he will find for the elderly next spring, and in 2002, to appease widespread pensioner anger left union chiefs in confusion.

Arm-twisting by ministers was under way in Brighton last night to resolve the crisis in time to avert tomorrow's vote on the conference floor.

With protesters button-holing MPs outside the conference, the pensions minister, Jeff Rooker, was heckled as he defended the official position on the conference fringe. Rank-and-file delegates piled on the pressure by voting to ensure that a "contemporary issues" debate - Blairspeak for an emergency debate - on pensions will definitely take place tomorrow.

The big unions, and Jack Jones's pensioners lobby, want the historic link between basic state pensions and average earnings restored. Mr Brown again refused yesterday - on the grounds that he wants to concentrate extra funds on the poorest of Britain's 11m pensioners. That has proved politically costly. So without conceding the principle Brown aides later gave nods and winks to the effect that the Treasury will raise the basic state pension dramatically next April, and in 2002.

Inflation-linking will ensure that it will rise by at least £2 a week for single pensioners, £3 for couples. Mr Brown will be under pressure in election year to more than double it to £5 and £8. The minimum income guarantee, directed at the 4m poorest pensioners, will rise from £78 to £90a week, Mr Brown confirmed.

Yesterday's concession will come as part of the so-called transitional arrangements, designed to tide over 4m middle-income pensioners until new cash credits to help those with modest savings or small private pensions - £10 to £15 a week - come on stream in 2003.

Unfortunately for the clarity of his message, Mr Brown's words suggested otherwise. Warning that "it cannot be that the wealthiest get exactly the same as the neediest," he said: "A flat increase will not do enough to help pensioners on modest incomes and do nothing to diminish growing inequalities, but instead rein force them." He added - repeatedly - "we will build upon the basic state pension", an important point of principle to opponents of means-testing.

Labour strategists are desperate to get union leaders such as Bill Morris of the TGWU, Mr Edmonds and Mr Bickerstaffe back on side before Mr Blair goes to the podium this afternoon to persuade his election troops that the government's annus horribilis - and the Tories' 8% poll lead - are a temporary blip.

The chancellor flew back from the IMF/World Bank conference in Prague to put flesh on earlier government concessions to pensioners made since his complicated Budget package in March failed politically.

But, as with his megaphone dealings with the fuel protesters, Mr Brown is still refusing to be bounced into premature statements on taxes and benefits ahead of his mid-November pre-Budget report, almost exactly when the protesters' 60-day deadline for resumed blockades runs out.

fields.headline: Police shoot dead ex-mercenary
fields.standfirst: Army deserter refused to surrender after threatening officer with air rifle
fields.trailText: Police are tracing the last, bizarre movements of an army deserter and former mercenary in Bosnia, who was shot dead after confronting police marksmen with a camouflaged air rifle in the grounds of a secure psychiatric hospital.
fields.body:
Police are tracing the last, bizarre movements of an army deserter and former mercenary in Bosnia, who was shot dead after confronting police marksmen with a camouflaged air rifle in the grounds of a secure psychiatric hospital.

The police complaints authority launched an investigation into the tragedy yesterday after the man had briefly held up a police station late on Sunday night and then demanded to see a woman hospital worker.

He was named yesterday as Kirk Davies, 30, who was jailed three years ago for attacking his father. The court heard that Davies had hero-worshipped his father until discovering that he was an ex-army lorry driver rather than the SAS veteran of Cambodia he had pretended to be.

Davies appeared suddenly at Selby police station in West Yorkshire on Sunday evening, dressed entirely in black and with a gun draped in camouflage netting which he aimed at the duty sergeant.

Police said yesterday that he ran off without firing the gun, but turned up an hour later at Newton Lodge secure hospital in Wakefield, 20 miles away, still brandishing the weapon. He asked for the woman, who works in another hospital nearby, which he appeared to be making for when police arrived.

Assistant Chief Constable Andy Brown said Davies was challenged but refused to surrender the gun and was followed to a patch of woodland where he was challenged again and then shot. He did not fire at police and the gun was found to be an air rifle when paramedics moved in to take him to Pinderfields hospital, Wakefield, where he died soon after midnight.

Mr Brown said: "These are tragic circumstances and we have been in contact with Mr Davies's family and we offer our sympathy and condolences to them."

Detectives have found no link between Davies and Newton Lodge, which houses a number of seriously disturbed patients, and believe that he mistook the building for the hospital where the unnamed woman works. He threatened terrified staff with his gun after they insisted that he had got the wrong hospital.

Neighbours in Selby and the nearby village of Burn, where Davies had shared a council house with a girlfriend and her two-year-old son, said he had been unpredictable and a victim of "black moods" apparently connected to atrocities seen in the Balkans. Police were called regularly to domestic disputes at the house in St Leonard's Avenue, Selby, according to local residents, and Davies made regular references to his work as a sniper for the Croatians.

He joined the Duke of Wellington's Regiment at 19, but deserted out of boredom, in spite of seeing action briefly in Northern Ireland. He then served as a mercenary sniper in Bosnia, allegedly killing 46 Serbian soldiers, according to his defence barrister at the 1997 trial for assaulting his father.

Robert Collins, representing Davies at the appeal court in York, said that the young deserter had been "involved in the very worst of the fighting and atrocities, seeing sights which no one would even wish to think about".

He told Recorder Aidan Marron QC: "He can still see the faces of the Serbs he killed, and is now terrified of battles, having seen so many people dead."

Davies's sentence was reduced from nine months' jail to probation. After hearing that his nightmares had been compounded by bitter disillusion with his father's lies, Recorder Marron told him: "There is a need to address your problem and we wish you well."

After the incident, Davies was moody and withdrawn according to Selby newsagent John Watson, 60, who listened to his stories of the Balkans as Davies drifted through a succession of local jobs as nightclub doorman, labourer and security guard.

Mr Watson said Davies had once taken an overdose of painkillers and added: "He suffered from what seemed like blackouts when he didn't appear to know what he was doing."

Ian Murray, landlord of the Wheatsheaf in Burn, said that Davies had been quiet, but a member of the pub's pool team with his own cue called Excalibur. He said: "He was a very competitive lad and he always liked to win but he never gave the impression of being a Rambo type."

fields.headline: Down but not out
fields.standfirst:
All eyes are on Milosevic after poll defeat

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Serbs may still be officially in the dark about the identity of their next president but western leaders professed no shadow of a doubt yesterday. Slobodan Milosevic was electoral dead meat, they all agreed; his principal opponent, Vojislav Kostunica, had won an incontrovertible first-round mandate in Sunday's poll.
fields.body:
Serbs may still be officially in the dark about the identity of their next president but western leaders professed no shadow of a doubt yesterday. Slobodan Milosevic was electoral dead meat, they all agreed; his principal opponent, Vojislav Kostunica, had won an incontrovertible first-round mandate in Sunday's poll. "All the reliable evidence suggests the people voted Milosevic out by a massive majority," declared foreign secretary Robin Cook from his Brighton observation post. The EU and the US said Mr Milosevic, despite fraudulent practice, had plainly, undoubtedly lost, and others like Gerhard Schröder expressed a similar, almost desperate certainty. The German chancellor even went so far as to speak for Russia's Vladimir Putin, who (if recent Moscow Times investigations are to be believed) is himself expert in electoral skulduggery. "We agreed... Yugoslavia has decided in favour of democratic change," Mr Schröder said after talks in Moscow. But Mr Putin kept mum while Russia's foreign minister spoke ominously of a poll free of "major violations".

Montenegro's pro-western leadership also fiercely welcomed the Serbian opposition's "absolute victory", chiming in harmoniously with the Kostunica camp's own analysis. They claimed their candidate had taken around 55% of the vote on a high turnout and that his winning margin was too great for even the ruling party to fiddle. The president's supporters, in stubborn contrast, claimed their man was ahead in the count but conceded that a second-round run-off may be necessary. Under this scenario, Mr Milosevic would have a little less than two weeks, until October 8, to intimidate, bribe, manipulate and coerce his way back into a "winning" position.

Two things seem clear despite this confusing war of words. One is that Mr Kostunica, by any normal measure, has indeed won a signal, remarkable victory on which he should be congratulated. Serbs finally turned their backs in large numbers on Mr Milosevic's decade-old tactic of dividing the nation into patriots and traitors. But it is also clear that nobody, perhaps not even Mr Milosevic himself, has any firm idea what he will do now - yet whatever he decides is likely to spell trouble. Yesterday's concerted attempt to talk him into history, to choreograph his swansong from afar, is hot air filling a vacuum where a western policy should be. Mr Milosevic is down but, unfortunately, he cannot yet be counted out.

fields.headline: Barnstorming Brown
fields.standfirst:
But he still hasn't come clean on pensions

Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown needed to deliver a barnstorming speech and yesterday he did just that. After two weeks as the lightning rod for public anger over the price of fuel, the size of pensions and revived interest in the Bernie Ecclestone affair, he had to win back the affection of his party if he was to restore his standing with the public.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown needed to deliver a barnstorming speech and yesterday he did just that. After two weeks as the lightning rod for public anger over the price of fuel, the size of pensions and revived interest in the Bernie Ecclestone affair, he had to win back the affection of his party if he was to restore his standing with the public. He succeeded with a rhetorical dash that had delegates in Brighton on their feet so long, the chancellor seemed to squirm with shy pleasure. When he was joined on stage by his wife, Sarah, the moment had an almost presidential smack of acclamation.

Mr Brown won his ovation with more than an artful mix of crowd-pleasing dips into Labour history and canny quotation from the revered John Smith. He struck a chord because he dared make the large case for Labour - and to stand firm in the face of urgent demands for help from hauliers, pensioners and others. He did not use his speech to throw a bone to those groups (though in fact there was a fairly juicy one for pensioners, subtly hidden away). Instead he sought to show a conviction that defied popular pressure. If it wasn't such a touchy point to make about this ambitious chancellor, you might say the speech was a calculated display of leadership.

The core message was the centre left argument for public investment, paid for by taxation. That may sound basic, but after the last fortnight Labour needed to go back to basics. The task this week - and this applies to the prime minister who speaks this afternoon - is to remake the argument for the fundamental purpose of government. Mr Brown did that, by pointing to New Labour's record of economic stability and improving public services. "These things did not just happen," he boomed. "A Labour government made them happen." He looked forward to "a great national debate" between this Labour approach, and the Tories' preference for privatisation and lower taxes. To highlight the difference, he ruled out future across-the-board tax cuts - promising targeted reductions instead. Labour is making its stand: spending on services, not lower taxes.

That done, Mr Brown could then approach the two loudest demands - from hauliers and pensioners. The former got little more than a promise to look at their situation, and word that the IMF had just called on the oil producers to increase supply and lower prices. That was interpreted as firmness inside the hall, but may well be read as arrogance and intransigence outside it.

Pensions was always going to be a more tricky business: unlike hauliers, the elderly are a core Labour constituency. Mr Brown's speech did not bow to them either, preferring to explain why the true progressive did not want to increase the basic pension but rather to concentrate help on the poorest. In terms of pure policy, that approach is surely right - and Mr Brown was applauded when he said so. But as a matter of real politics, the basic pension has become too great a pressure point for the government. Recognising that, the chancellor's aides later briefed that the "transitional measures" trailed in the speech will increase the state benefit for all. The result was confusion among the audience and, crucially, among the trade unions who have threatened to inflict a conference defeat on the issue. Mr Brown ended up treading on his own story - his fear of being accused of a U-turn denying him credit for what could be a vote-catching boost for the elderly. It was a blunder of communications which tarnished an otherwise formidable performance. The PM can afford no such mistake today.

fields.headline: Mark my words...
fields.standfirst:
Embattled Tony Blair's conference speech today is being billed as the most important of his career. But does old-fashioned oratory still work in the TV age? Actually, yes, says Jonathan Freedland

Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Embattled Tony Blair's conference speech today is being billed as the most important of his career. But does old-fashioned oratory still work in the TV age? Actually, yes, says Jonathan Freedland
fields.body:
The golden hour will come just after 2.15 this afternoon. That's the moment the tens of thousands of delegates, journalists and assorted hangers-on gathered in Brighton are waiting for. Once it's passed, the energy will suck out of the Brighton Centre like air from a birthday balloon. In a party conference, the leader's speech is all.

Tony Blair knows that. That's why he will have spent last night doing yet another read-through, and why he will probably wield the editorial pencil a few more times this morning. He will have rehearsed his delivery, trying out the key lines for Alastair Campbell's approval - just as he does in the Rory Bremner send-up.

In fact, Campbell and others will have been toiling on this speech for months. On the other side of summer the brainboxes of Downing Street, led by the head of the policy unit, David Miliband, would have been asked for "input" on the substance of the address, submitting chunks on education, health, tax. Throughout the process, Gordon Brown and Peter Mandelson, along with Campbell, will have kept a close eye on the core message. All the while, No 10's hired wordsmiths, including Campbell himself, will have been striving to turn those memos and political instructions into ear-friendly prose.

Every element is treated with deadly seriousness - including the gags. John O'Farrell, the satirist and Guardian columnist, was drafted in to write Blair's jokes. He, along with the others, will have heard the dreaded word "rewrite" a dozen times in the past two weeks - as the team edited the text to take account first of Mo Mowlam's departure, then the Dome debacle, then the fuel crisis and now demands for higher pensions.

But why all this trouble over a mere address? Surely Downing Street knows the conventional wisdom is that the political speech is dead? After all, a subtle part of the New Labour revolution was a shift away from the thundering oratory of the party's past - exemplified by the likes of Tony Benn, Michael Foot and Neil Kinnock - and towards the softer, more telegenic style of Tony Blair. Podium-banging and tub-thumping went out with clause four.

The evidence for the death of the speech seems persuasive enough. The great barnstormers are either dead or dying, unreplaced by their successors in the Commons or elsewhere. TV is said to have killed off the public meeting, where rhetoric found its most natural home. The new generation of leaders have cultivated a kind of anti-oratory - typified by Charles Kennedy - in which the stirring passage is deliberately replaced by the relaxed, chatty aside which prompts barely a ripple in the hall but plays well on television. As if to illustrate the shift, much of today's news is made far away from the podium. Who remembers the great public speech which ignited the fuel protest movement? There wasn't one. Or think of one of Blair's most memorable phrases: "I'm a pretty straight kind of guy." He said that in a TV interview.

Despite all that, the Labour party - both leaders and followers - seem to think that today's speech matters. The funny thing is, they're right. For, regardless of fashion, political speeches can still turn fate around. Not perhaps in the romantic, Shakespearean sense - in which a single oration by a Mark Antony can persuade a nation to change course - but a few words, chosen well or ill, can still reshape the political landscape.

The Blairites have a favourite example, one from which they've drawn much comfort in recent days. In the US their fellow apostle of the Third Way, Al Gore, was also languishing in the polls behind a conservative promising lower taxes and a shrunken state. Gore, too, had to do something to haul himself and his party out of the hole. The solution was a speech - his acceptance address at last month's Democratic convention in Los Angeles. Gore won plaudits for his energy, his concentration on substance and his uncharacteristic (if deliberate) non-woodenness, including a semi-pornographic snog with his wife Tipper. The result was a an extraordinary double-digit surge in the ratings. Not that Blair needs too many lessons from America on the enduring power of the speech. Comfy though he may be on the sofas of David Frost and Richard & Judy, Blair knows all too well how a set-piece address can make all the difference. For one thing, he laid the foundations of New Labour with his first leader's speech to the Labour conference in Blackpool in 1994. He told activists then that a modern party needed "a modern constitution" - code for the rewriting of clause four, the emblematic battle which defined Blair in opposition. A year later Blair used the leader's speech to trail another dramatic shift, not just for Labour but the entire nation. He presaged both the landslide of 1997 and the Cool Britannia phenomenon when he spoke of his ambition to make Britain "a young country again."

Indeed, for all of its famous felicity with the techniques of modern political combat - websites, rapid rebuttal, pagers and the rest - the evolution of the entire New Labour project can be traced through a series of landmark low-tech speeches. Besides Blair's own efforts, John Prescott's 1993 plea for Labour delegates to move to a system of one member, one vote still stands out as a key moment in the birth of the new regime. No matter that it read in print like a corrupted computer file; the spirit was what mattered, not the syntax. The modernisation of New Labour took a stride forward, and Prescott solidified his status as the reformers' indispensable ambassador to the party.

Earlier still, the very first step towards the transformation of Labour came in a speech from the conference platform. In 1985 Neil Kinnock stunned a Bournemouth audience by rounding on the Militant-infiltrated local authority in Liverpool. "You end in the grotesque chaos of a Labour council," Kinnock raged, "a Labour council - hiring taxis to scuttle round a city handing out redundancy notices to its own workers!" The target of his ire, Derek Hatton, was sitting just a few yards away, leaping to his feet to denounce Kinnock as a "liar, liar". The whole scene was played over and over on the TV news. The episode told the nation that Labour wanted to change, that the days of left-wing extremism were coming to an end. David Owen has spoken of Kinnock's Bournemouth turn as the precise moment when he knew his own Social Democratic dream would fail; Labour was clearly coming back to claim the centre ground it had once abandoned. All that in a single speech.

The explanation for Kinnock's success 15 years ago is not too complex. For that address contained one of the core ingredients of any good speech: confrontation. Margaret Thatcher had played the same trick just three years earlier, when she used her conference turn to round on critics who had demanded a U-turn in policy. "You turn if you want to she said," she boomed famously. "The lady's not for turning."

Nor is such aggressive speech-making confined to politics. Earl Spencer sent shock-waves through Westminster Abbey and beyond when he turned on the royal family during his funeral oration for his sister Diana in 1997. Speaking for Diana's "blood family", he promised to let the souls of Diana's sons sing - unmistakably damning the stifling grip of the stuffy Windsors. Which is not to say that the decisive speech always works wonders for the speaker. On the contrary, careers can be broken as well as made by the unpredictable alchemy of orator, audience and text. Spencer's own fall from grace was speeded by a public perception that he had failed abjectly to live up to his rhetoric. Michael Portillo made himself a national hate figure when he dragged the SAS into party politics with his Who Dares Wins address to the Conservative conference of 1995. His rant against the meddlers of Brussels and his bellicose revelling in British military prowess brought delighted squeals in the hall, but made him a poster boy for Tory extremism. He paid the price in the sheer national delight that greeted his ejection from the House of Commons two years later.

His former Cabinet ally Peter Lilley also learned of the lethal power of an ill-judged talk. As the Tories' deputy leader in 1999, he chose to mark the 20th anniversary of Margaret Thatcher's arrival in Downing Street with a lecture apparently recanting the old Thatcherite faith in the free market's ability to deliver public services. The backlash from the Conservative true believers was so intense that Lilley had to pay with his job - removed as William Hague's number two and booted out of the shadow cabinet.

Speeches have turned nearly as sour for Tony Blair. When he looks back on the annus horribilis that 2000 has been for Labour, a particularly bitter memory will be the slow hand-clap he received from the Women's Institute. He gave a speech that they deemed too political and they booed him for it. Or he may cast his mind back even further, to the roots of the current trouble, by recalling his address to last year's Labour conference, when he declared war on the "forces of conservatism". A right-wing press which had previously given a free pass to Blair decided that New Labour's honeymoon was over: from that day onwards something of the old left-right struggle returned to our national life.

So speeches can still be decisive, for good or ill. They don't work the way myth said they once did: hostile audiences are rarely won over with a few poetic sentences. Nor are there many of the great phrase-makers of yore - Kennedy and his "new frontier", Churchill and his "iron curtain". Still, it is possible to train oneself into good oratory. Bill Clinton is rated as perhaps the best communicator on the planet, but when, as a little-known state governor, he delivered a keynote address to the 1988 Democratic convention, he rambled and stuttered so badly that delegates cheered when he finally left the stage.

But if a speaker convinces the people in the hall and, crucially, impresses the journalists present, then the climate of opinion can change. If every commentator tonight and tomorrow says Blair did well, then he will have done well: it will soon settle into the collective cortex that the PM has reasserted his grip. And that message will reach millions more than the select group of activists and addicts who will actually watch today's speech.

That's the moment the tens of thousands of delegates, journalists and assorted hangers-on gathered in Brighton are waiting for. That's why he will have spent last night doing yet another read-through, and why he will probably wield the editorial pencil a few more times this morning. He will have rehearsed his delivery, trying out the key lines for Alastair Campbell's approval - just as he does in the Rory Bremner send-up. In fact, Campbell and others will have been toiling on this speech for months. On the other side of summer the brainboxes of Downing Street, led by the head of the policy unit, David Miliband, would have been asked for "input" on the substance of the address, submitting chunks on education, health, tax. Throughout the process, Gordon Brown and Peter Mandelson, along with Campbell, will have kept a close eye on the core message. All the while, No 10's hired wordsmiths, including Campbell himself, will have been striving to turn those memos and political instructions into ear-friendly prose. Every element is treated with deadly seriousness - including the gags. John O'Farrell, the satirist and Guardian columnist, was drafted in to write Blair's jokes. webTitle: Financial inquiry into scientist in missing embryo scandal

fields.headline: Financial inquiry into scientist in missing embryo scandal
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: The investigation into missing embryos at two fertility clinics took a new twist last night when one of the hospitals involved confirmed that it was looking into possible financial irregularities in connection with the scientist at the centre of the scandal.
fields.body:
The investigation into missing embryos at two fertility clinics took a new twist last night when one of the hospitals involved confirmed that it was looking into possible financial irregularities in connection with the scientist at the centre of the scandal.

The investigation is said to be focusing on whether Paul Fielding, an embryologist who worked for both North Hamp shire Hospitals NHS Trust in Basingstoke and the privately run Hampshire Clinic, submitted claims for IVF treatment he never actually carried out. This might explain why discrepancies have emerged between patient records and stored embryos.

As 39 women treated at the hospitals where frozen embryos have gone missing were offered free DNA tests to prove their babies are their own, Mr Fielding's employer, the NHS trust, confirmed that its inquiry had widened to examine "any question of financial irregularities" in relation to his work involving the recording and storage of embryos.

Until his suspension Mr Fielding had held the position at the NHS trust for about 10 years. He was contracted out to work for the private Hampshire Clinic until two months ago, when it appointed its own embryologist.

Last night Mr Fielding's home in Whitchurch was deserted and neighbours said they had not seen him or his wifeand two young sons since the scandal broke on Thursday.

A Hampshire Clinic spokeswoman, Carole Friend, said they had been unable to contact Mr Fielding and were keen to speak to him.

Strict guidelines laid down by the Human Fertility and Embryology Authority mean that only a named embryologist can freeze and store em bryos and keep records of these operations. Seeing patients and harvesting eggs cis only carried out by a medical specialist.

Ms Friend added: "It looks like we are dealing with a case of poor record-keeping. It seems to be issues more about carelessness, not completing processes and never freezing embryos when he said he did."

She confirmed that the clinic would consider offering free treatment to women whose fertility treatment has been suspended because of errors in their patient records relating to their stored embryos. In addition, DNA tests are being offered, although she claimed there was "categorically no possibility" women had been given the wrong embryos.

The fact that some patients undergoing IVF treatment are distressed is of particular concern because it has a high failure rate and patients are advised to avoid stress.

The two clinics are also bracing themselves for potential group legal action from patients whose embryos may have been lost or whose treatment has been disrupted.

The situation came to light three weeks ago when staff were unable to find the frozen embryos of a patient due to undergo IVF treatment. As a result an audit was carried out at the assisted conception units at both the hospital and the clinic and it was found that nine containers were missing and other records appeared inconsistent.

Last night Emma Holt, a specialist in clinical negligence with the Manchester law firm Pannone and Partners said couples whose embryos went missing may be able to bring a case for the loss of a chance of conceiving in respect of that embryo and the ordeal of having to repeat IVF treatment.

webTitle: Ambition and opportunism undermine opposition's common purpose

fields.headline: Ambition and opportunism undermine opposition's common purpose
fields.standfirst:
Ambition and opportunism undermine opposition's common purpose

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: If the opposition to President Milosevic took a gamble in confronting him in Sunday's election, it faces an even   more daunting task in the next few days. While the prospect of victory is real, it can be chilling and the embattled dictator will try hard to scare his opponents or buy off their leaders.
fields.body:
If the opposition to President Milosevic took a gamble in confronting him in Sunday's election, it faces an even more daunting task in the next few days. While the prospect of victory is real, it can be chilling and the embattled dictator will try hard to scare his opponents or buy off their leaders.

He may well be testing them to see if he can get away with claiming a first round victory, or whether he has to concede a second round.

Opposition leaders were at least standing firm yesterday. "There will be no bargaining," Zoran Djindjic, the leader of the Democratic party, said. "Milosevic should better avoid tormenting the people since he would be wiped out in the runoff." The opposition challenger, Vojislav Kostunica, broke from Mr Djindjic's party in the early 1990s so the two men have a history of disagreement.

More question marks hang over the two parties whose candidates will be eliminated if there is a second round. Vojislav Seselj's ultra-nationalist Radical party is still officially part of Mr Milosevic's ruling coalition, even though it fielded a separate candidate on Sunday. Before the first round Mr Seselj also repeatedly said his party would vote against Mr Milosevic in any second round.

But Mr Seselj is a notorious opportunist as well as being fiercely ambitious. He was widely considered to have won the last presidential elections in Serbia but was defrauded of the result - whether through blackmail, death threats or the offer of a lucrative post is unknown. Now he is in a strong bargaining position with both Mr Milosevic and the opposition even though his party may have won less than 5% of the vote.

Equally intriguing will be the conduct of the Serbian Renewal party, which used to be the strongest opposition group. Its vain and volatile leader, Vuk Draskovic, refused to join the 18-party coalition of Mr Kostunica, gravely weakening Mr Draskovic's already fragile authority and making him appear unprincipled.

Mr Draskovic was formerly a deputy prime minister in Mr Milosevic's government and commands little trust among many liberal Serbs. He seemed yesterday to be trying to recoup his position within the opposition ranks by congratulating Mr Kostunica from his beach home in Montenegro where he has been in self-imposed exile after assassination attempts. "I'd like to express my hope that Mr Milosevic will recognise the election and the will of the people," he added.

He even expressed regret that his party had not joined the Democratic Opposition of Serbia bloc, which launched Mr Kostunica's can didacy in July. "The results are a consequence of an ill-advised decision by the party leadership, including myself, to run in the elections on our own," he said.

Ideologically, the opposition contains a mixture of political ideas, from monarchists, conservatives and nationalists to social democrats and liberals. The only common factor is a desire to see Mr Milosevic removed from power.

webTitle: We will seize terrorist assets, says Mandelson

fields.headline: We will seize terrorist assets, says Mandelson
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Paramilitary godfathers are to have their assets confiscated as part of a new drive to crack down on Northern Ireland's "mafia-like virus", Peter Mandelson, Northern Ireland secretary, announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Paramilitary godfathers are to have their assets confiscated as part of a new drive to crack down on Northern Ireland's "mafia-like virus", Peter Mandelson, Northern Ireland secretary, announced yesterday.

Bank accounts, cars and property will be seized by a new confiscations agency to prevent the flow of millions of pounds into the coffers of dissident paramilitaries.

The new agency, which will mirror the work of a similar body set up recently on mainland Britain, will focus on the burgeoning loyalist drugs trade and the £460m cross-border fuel smuggling run by republicans.

Mr Mandelson, who has been alarmed by the rise of "gangsterism" in Northern Ireland despite the Good Friday agreement, said yesterday: "We must do more to attack the racketeering, the smuggling and the drugs dealing that is feeding and financing the rump of paramilitarism that stands between Northern Ireland and the decent society we are striving to create ... No longer will the paramilitaries be able to salt away the profits from their ill-gotten gains."

A cross-border body will also be set up to improve cooperation between the British and Irish governments in tackling paramilitary fund-raising. In a speech to the Labour party conference in Brighton, Mr Mandelson said that the Northern Ireland security minister, Adam Ingram, would "work together with our Irish counterparts to rid Northern Ireland of this mafia-like virus".

The new confiscation agency is to be modelled on the Criminal Assets Bureau set up in the Irish republic in the wake of the murder of the journalist Veronica Guerin by one of Dublin's gangland leaders. It will focus on "front" businesses which paramilitaries use to launder money.

All paramilitary groups, including those on ceasefire, continue to raise millions of pounds. But ministers are particularly concerned by the fund-raising activities of dissident loyalist and republican groups which are determined to destroy the peace process.

They include the Real IRA, the Loyalist Volunteer Force, and the Adair wing of the Ulster Defence Association. Loyalists are making millions out of the drugs trade, while republicans are making millions out of smuggling fuel across the Irish border.

Mr Mandelson warned the dissident paramilitaries he was determined they would not disrupt the peace process.

The Northern Ireland secretary told the province's mainstream political leaders that dissidents would only be beaten if a new police service was introduced which could attract both Catholics and Protestants.

In a blunt message to unionists, who have rejected Chris Patten's police reforms report, Mr Mandelson insisted he would implement its recommendations in full.

His remarks came after the Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, warned that the government must introduce the Patten report in full. "The people who voted for the Good Friday agreement must have their mandates fulfilled in terms of the implementation of [Patten], as opposed to it being usurped and subverted by a British government because of difficulties in unionism."

The West Belfast MP was speaking at Stormont at the launch of a 34-page Sinn Fein document, which outlined ways in which the government had watered down the Patten recommendations in the new policing bill.

However, the Ulster Unionists reiterated their determination to oppose the Patten report. Sir Reg Empey, the UUP enterprise minister, said: "People cannot understand how you contemplate reducing the number of police officers in a situation where you do not have the peace and stability against which the Patten proposals were drawn up."

Meanwhile, police in Northern Ireland were still investigating the death of a leading loyalist paramilitary after earlier fears that he had fallen victim to the feud in the Shankill Road area of Belfast.

John White, chairman of the Ulster Defence Association, close to the Ulster Defence Association, played down suggestions Stevie McKeag, 29, was the fourth victim in the month-long loyalist vendetta.

The postmortem examination on McKeag, a former member of the UDA, sister to the Ulster Freedom Fighters, was inconclusive. One report suggested that he had suffered bruising to his face while another indicated he had suffered a drugs overdose.

McKeag was cleared in 1994 of murdering Sean Hughes, 40, a Catholic father of three. Two UDA gunmen shot him dead in west Belfast.

The trial judge said he was unhappy with identification evidence. A lawyer said during a bail hearing that police believed he was "a very active terrorist" in the UFF.

McKeag had played little active role in the UDA since suffering serious injuries in a motorcyle crash two years ago.

Mr White said: "No one else was involved in his death. He has been taking painkillers since his motorbike accident and it appears he was drinking at the same time."

McKeag was cleared in 1994 of murdering Sean Hughes, 40, a Catholic father of three. Two UDA gunmen shot him dead in west Belfast. The trial judge said he was unhappy with identification evidence. A lawyer said during a bail hearing that police believed he was "a very active terrorist" in the UFF. McKeag had played little active role in the UDA since suffering serious injuries in a motorcyle crash two years ago. Mr White said: "No one else was involved in his death. He has been taking painkillers since his motorbike accident and it appears he was drinking at the same time."

fields.headline: Voters' logic baffles faithful
fields.standfirst:
Party mood
Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Has the past fortnight been Labour's Black Wednesday, or an aberrant moment by a fickle electorate? The true split at this conference is not over pensions or book serialisations, but between the short term blippers and what Trevor Phillips dubbed this week as the cremation tendency.
fields.body:
Has the past fortnight been Labour's Black Wednesday, or an aberrant moment by a fickle electorate? The true split at this conference is not over pensions or book serialisations, but between the short term blippers and what Trevor Phillips dubbed this week as the cremation tendency.

Delegates and MPs appear dazed as to how their massive poll lead for the past three years could have evaporated so quickly. It is the issue perplexing the fringe and haunting discussion in the bars.

Speaking at a Labour Renewal Fringe meeting, Matthew Taylor, the director of the Institute of Public Policy Research shocked an audience last night by saying: "If a company loses market share as fast as Labour has over the past fortnight, it is time to ask some very searching questions."

He added: "We have to look at the worst case scenario and face the fact that we may be in the middle of our equivalent of Black Wednesday. If so, we will have to go through some cathartic changes in our style, message and the way we communicate."

The worst case scenario, he admitted, was the most plausible interpretation for what has been happening.

"For over a year, it has been impossible to find anyone in pubs or taxis who actually likes the New Labour project and it explains the unprecedented gap between our opin ion poll leads and our performance in real elections.

"The electorate think we are authoritarian, controlling and unlistening. They think too many at the top of New Labour don't like each other and we don't behave as a team".

Others such as Diana Jeudah, the National Executive member, said that the poll turn-around did not chime with what she found on the door steps in her town of Whitby.

David Blunkett, the education secretary, speaking at Progress was typically frank and ruminated on why the government had been "temporarily derailed". He asked: "Why are people so angry with us ?"

He counselled that the party needed to remember it was dealing with different people with different concerns , many of them contradictory.

He explained: "They don't want high direct taxation but they don't want high indirect taxation. They want high quality public services, but they want someone else to pay for them. They want a stable economy, but they are not sure they want to pay the bill. Sometimes people don't actually mean what they say."

He offered no flip solution simply saying: "One thing is absolutely certain is the electorate don't respect and won't vote for a government which changes its stance by the day".

However, another minister said that he was so worried that the case a delay in the election until the 2002 was strong. He said he was lobbying Downing Street to give more time for the extra money to work through on local schools and hospitals. Fiona MacTaggart, the Labour MP for Slough, also warned the party was getting its image wrong. She criticised Alistair Darling's handling of pensions. He had, she said, "appeared very clever and rather cross, instead of someone who is listening".

Many delegates, at all levels, angrily blame ministers and their advisers for compounding the crisis. John Monks, the TUC general secretary drew applause when he told a fringe meeting that Tony Blair and the cabinet should learn from the discipline and maturity shown by trade unions towards the government.

He said: "There needs to be an end of the biting and back-biting. Solidarity should begin at the top."
