webTitle: Montenegrins breathe easier as strongman fades

fields.headline: Montenegrins breathe easier as strongman fades
fields.standfirst:
Boycott Tensions ease in sister state

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Relief spread through the pro-western government of Montenegro yesterday, its leaders apparently convinced that Slobodan Milosevic would have less chance of provoking violence after faring badly in Yugoslavia's elections.
fields.byline: Jonathan Steele  and Nick Wood  in Pristina
fields.body:
Relief spread through the pro-western government of Montenegro yesterday, its leaders apparently convinced that Slobodan Milosevic would have less chance of provoking violence after faring badly in Yugoslavia's elections.

Montenegro's deputy prime minister, Dragisa Burzan, said he believed that the main opposition candidate, Vojislav Kostunica, had won an outright victory in the presidential poll, and predicted that Mr Milosevic would soon be forced from power.

"I'd expect quite a quick removal of Milosevic. It cannot be more than at most a month of manoeuvring," he said in Podgorica.

Mr Burzan said the president was growing desperate as his support ebbed and claimed that the atmosphere in Mr Milosevic's inner circle was "like a funeral".

He was confident, he said, that the Yugoslav army and police would not support Mr Milosevic after seeing that he had such narrow backing.

He felt that low levels of support for Mr Milosevic also helped to cut the chances of armed intervention in Montenegro which has very mixed feelings about its federation with Serbia; together they make up Yugoslavia. "Tension is less _ I think he will be focused only on Serbia at the moment. I think he cannot now undertake anything in Montenegro."

As rumours grew of disarray among the Serbian ruling elite in Belgrade, there were reports that the Yugoslav prime minister, Momir Bulatovic, a Montenegrin and a Milosevic loyalist, had resigned.

But the main pro-Belgrade party in Montenegro dismissed the reports. "I wouldn't pay much attention to this. It's not true," Zoran Zizic, the deputy leader of the Socialist Peoples' party, said in Podgorica. He went on to accuse the Montena-Fax news agency of spreading wrong information.

Earlier, quoting a senior source in the Socialist Peoples' party, the agency had said that Mr Bulatovic had resigned after failing to meet a demand from President Milosevic to provide him with "an extra 100,000 votes".

"Having realised the election result was disastrous, Milosevic issued an ultimatum to Bulatovic to allocate another 100,000 votes through the military leadership and [army chief of staff] General Nebojsa Pavkovic," the agency said.

It quoted the party source as saying that "forged election material was to be transported to Podgorica by a military plane under General Pavkovic's orders, to be passed on to the election commission for 'verification'".

Mr Zizic called the report "media lies". He said that turnout in Montenegro, which has barely 5% of the Yugoslav electorate, was slightly below the 130,000 originally estimated, but reiterated that his party had won 90% of votes counted so far.

The Montenegrin government boycotted the vote and denounced it as an unconstitutional farce. It left pro-Belgrade parties to organise their own elections in makeshift polling stations.

Meanwhile, as the first results emerged in the province of Kosovo in Serbia, a mixture of apathy and resignation set in among Serbs there.

In spite of numerous allegations of electoral fraud, both Mr Milosevic's ruling Serbian Socialist party (SPS) and the opposition alliance of parties trying to oust him agreed he got the majority of votes.

In the divided town of Mitrovice, Mr Milosevic had claimed his party had won with 3,500 votes, compared with 800 for Mr Kostunica. In other towns the SPS claimed three-quarters of the vote.

The leader of the Serbian Democratic party in Mitrovice, Dragisa Djokovic, put the large margin down to the fact that many opposition supporters were not on the voting lists. But he admitted that many of the 100,000 Serbs in Kosovo had voted for Mr Milosevic in the hope that Yugoslav troops would one day return to the province. Kosovo's Albanian community boycotted Sunday's vote.

Mr Djokovic said: "There are a lot of reasons, one of them is people's disappointment in the international community."

For the most part, Kosovo's interest in the election results has been muted. TVs and radios in Mitrovice's cafes and shops could be heard announcing the results, but few people seemed pay attention.

Most roadside stallholders were reluctant to say who they had voted for. But one woman selling clothing said with a smile: "I have always voted for him. I don't know why, it's just a sort of tradition."

Nearby a man selling wires and batteries implied he had voted for Mr Kostunica. "People are afraid to vote for change, they think change is something terrible."

Back at the opposition's headquarters Mr Djokovic said the key to the next few days would lie in Serbia.

"Belgrade decides what happens here. Our primary concern here is to have peace and avoid any incident."

webTitle: Britain says: 'Get out of the way and set Serbia free'

fields.headline: Britain says: 'Get out of the way and set Serbia free'
fields.standfirst:
Europe Nato ready if trouble stirs

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Western leaders tried to bounce President Slobodan Milosevic from office yesterday in the wake of Yugoslavia's chaotic election.
fields.body:
Western leaders tried to bounce President Slobodan Milosevic from office yesterday in the wake of Yugoslavia's chaotic election.

Even though not a single ballot result had been announced, west European countries insisted that the Belgrade leader had lost overwhelmingly and should admit defeat.

Foreign ministries throughout Europe and the US talked to eachother throughout Sunday night and agreed to act in concert. They organised a strong coalition for what they see as one of the best chances yet to oust him from office after an election turnout that exceeded their expectations.

They moved quickly to try to exploit the disarray by claiming he had lost overwhelmingly and should stand down.

The west has little sway over Mr Milosevic but it can influence public opinion in Serbia by discrediting any attempt by the president to hang on.

Germany's chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, also met the Russian president, Vladimir Putin - the one leader who may have some influence over Mr Milosevic. He urged Mr Putin to encourage Mr Milosevic to give way.

Mr Schröder, speaking at a press conference with Mr Putin in Moscow, said: "We agreed _ that it looks as though Serbia and Yugoslavia have decided in favour of democratic change." Mr Putin did not dissent.

Although the west European governments know that Mr Milosevic will not capitulate easily, given that he faces the prospect of trial at the Hague for war crimes, they will do everything possible to undermine him in the hope that the Serbian population will finallyinsist that he goes.

Nato is building up its forces in the region. British defence and diplomatic sources said this was in case Mr Milosevic tried to divert attention by creating trouble in Kosovo or Montenegro, but a conflagration was not expected.

The sources insisted Nato would not go to war over Montenegro.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, said: "Today Milosevic is a beaten, broken-backed president. The margin of defeat appears too great to fix through electoral fraud. My message to him today is to be honest with your people, do not cheat them. Get out of the way and let Serbia out of the prison into which you have turned it."

The White House national security adviser, PJ Crowley, said it would be hard for Mr Milosevic to make a "credible claim of victory" because of strong opposition support and reported voting irregularities.

Mr Crowley said: "They haven't announced any election results at this point but the reliable information coming out of Yugoslavia suggests that the opposition has done very well."

In Brussels, the EU insisted that Mr Milosevic could not declare himself the winner. "It is clear that any attempt by Milosevic to declare himself the victor would be fraudulent," the EU said in a joint statement released by France, which holds the rotating presidency.

The statement said the high turnout showed that the people of Serbia wanted change.

"They wanted to speak up, regardless of intimidation, manoeuvring, pressure and all sorts of manipulation by the Belgrade regime leading up to this ballot," said the statement.

Javier Solana, the EU's foreign policy supremo, and Nato secretary-general during last year's Kosovo war, said Yugoslavia had to respect the will of its people.

"The people of Serbia have delivered an overwhelming vote for change. The turnout is remarkable by any standards. The clearly expressed will of the voters must now be translated into reality. The people of Serbia deserve nothing less," he said.

Before the presidential and parliamentary elections on Sunday, the EU had pleaded with the Serbian people to turn out and vote to remove Mr Milosevic. Last week it repeated its promise to lift sanctions and offered reconstruction aid and help the country out of its international isolation. Nato made no comment yesterday, insisting that the election was a political, not a military matter.

The party of the Western-backed Bosnian Serb prime minister, Milorad Dodik, saluted what it said was electoral defeat for Mr Milosevic.

"The defeat of Slobodan Milosevic is the defeat of the forces of the past, the defeat of the politics of conflict and isolation," the Party of Independent Social Democrats said.

The Croatian president, Stipe Mesic, predicted that Mr Milosevic would do anything to stay in power in Yugoslavia, no matter how much blood had to be shed.

"Remaining in power is the only guarantee for him to stay alive, not politically but literally alive," Mr Mesic said in a state radio interview

The British shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, said Serbs were tired of Mr Milosevic's "gross misrule".

Mr Maude said: "He must now step down. Whatever the election results, Kosovo's Albanians are clear that they do not wish to be governed from Belgrade. The international community now needs to take urgent steps to address this."

fields.headline: At this price?  Inflexion
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Six months have passed since net incubators fell so spectacularly out of fashion. Indeed, the concept remains so unhip that companies such as Inflexion describe themselves as "pan-European technology investors".
fields.body:
Six months have passed since net incubators fell so spectacularly out of fashion. Indeed, the concept remains so unhip that companies such as Inflexion describe themselves as "pan-European technology investors".

Inflexion is one of those vehicles that caught the market at the precipice - floating at 100p on April 10, rallying momentarily to 106p then dropping all the way to 61p over the next three months.

The price has recovered somewhat and the management, lead by joint chief executives John Hartz and Simon Turner, have clearly been working hard at identifying decent investments, picking up young assets at knock-down prices.

Inflexion drew a few sideways glances recently when it emerged that it had a small stake in Arc International, the successful mobile chip specialist. Yesterday, in its seventh deal to date, Inflexion announced a £3m investment in ANT, which professes to be a specialist in embedded communication appliance software.

The incubator is putting its money in alongside a Beeson Gregory investment fund to complete a £5m funding round in what Mr Hartz describes as a company whose core products "are a key element of the technology and communications revolution".

In short, ANT makes pieces of software such as a "frugal" web browser and "thin client" email software suited to the coming wave of mass-market internet devices.

Mr Turner describes this as a typical Inflexion investment - an established business where the potential revenues are clear and the technology is proven.

He says the company has so far invested around half the £36m it raised at flotation.

While shares in Inflexion spiked up to 94p on news of the Arc investment, the price has drifted back over the past month to 82.5p. But, given that Inflexion floated on a less than exorbitant valuation of 1.6 times book value, the shares seem an excellent, though slightly high-risk play on a one- to three-year view.

webTitle: Knives out as Delia the bitch bites back

fields.headline: Knives out as Delia the bitch bites back
fields.standfirst:
It's saucepans at nine paces after 'the Volvo of cooks' lays into her 'repulsive' TV rival

Delia's delights
Who's cooking? TV's army of chefs
fields.trailText: It's saucepans at nine paces after 'the Volvo of cooks' lays into her 'repulsive' TV rival
fields.body:
In the world of television superchefs who like to sharpen their knives in public, it was like sticking a pin in your opponent's cheese souffle. Delia Smith, the food presenter whose schoolmistress approach to the kitchen was once described by Egon Ronay as the "missionary position" of cookery, attempted to shed her clean image yesterday by speaking her mind about rival chefs Anthony Worrall Thompson and Gary Rhodes.

But the tactic backfired when Worrall Thompson responded by calling her rude, cold, scripted and lacking in personality.

Worrall Thompson, who once called Smith the Volvo of cookery - reliable but dull - and Rhodes, who said her How to Cook series on how to boil an egg was offensive and insulting, were slated by Smith in an interview in the Daily Telegraph.

Smith, who has sold 11.5m cookery books and turned down a peerage from Tony Blair, said: "Actually I hate Gary Rhodes'programmes and I think that Anthony Worrall Thompson is worse: he is dreadful, just repulsive. I think that Food and Drink, the show that he is on, is the most disgusting programme on television. I will never, ever know, as long as I live, how the BBC or the general public can tolerate it."

She said the show's former wine presenter Jilly Goolden, who once described a flavour as being "like running naked through a field of thistles", was awful. She said of the former Food and Drink presenter Michael Barry: "Yuk. He's all sweaty palms."

Smith concluded: "When we finish recording my shows, the crew and I always sit down and have a good giggle at Food and Drink. So I am not too nice, really. See how bitchy I can be?"

Worrall Thompson, 49, who has presented the Food and Drink programme for five years, responded: "It appears I can't be doing badly on Food and Drink if I get a reaction like this from the coldest woman on television."

He said he was glad that Smith, 59, who is a director of Norwich City football club, had discovered she had a personality, after always having her words scripted. "She's probably depressed because Norwich City are failing miserably and she doesn't have a very exciting life.

Bad-tempered

"Delia is a bit like Steven Redgrave in the rowing at the Olympics because she has been around for so long. I am sure she will still be with us in 10 years' time, a little greyer and wrinklier, but still giving out advice while propped up by her walking frame."

He went on: "I think her comments are marvellous. It shows there is spirit in the old duck, yet. I know she is only having a go at Gary Rhodes and myself because we are the only two chefs who have ever stood up to the Goddess of Cookery."

Worrall Thompson added: "I called her the Volvo of cooks because she is the safest chef on TV. Now it appears she has gone to the Gordon Ramsay school of charm classes."

In turn, Ramsay, the Michelin-starred chef who was once famously depicted as bad-tempered and rude to employees in a behind-the-scenes documentary, said of Worrall Thompson's comments: "The problem with celebrity chefs is that 99% of them do not have restaurants to run. I work very hard behind the scenes to run a successful restaurant which is kept full every month with advance bookings. I do not have time for politics, unlike Anthony Worrall Thompson who has set himself up for this kind of exchange by prostituting himself in offering to comment on other chefs.

"British food is a serious issue, not for this kind of joking around. Delia Smith is the only thing I buy my wife for Christmas. I have a great amount of respect for her."

Gary Rhodes was not available for comment last night but Sue Ayton, Jilly Goolden's agent, said: "Jilly has never given Delia Smith a moment's thought so she has nothing to add to this discussion."

Katie Nicholls of Bazal Productions, which makes Food and Drink for BBC2, said: "It is a shame she is saying these things about the show, but everyone is entitled to their own opinion. I am sure the millions of viewers who watch the show regularly will disagree with her."

Delia Smith, who published her first recipe in 1969 and has a fortune estimated at £24m, said in the interview: "I am not some prim Brownie pack leader - in fact I am a bit of a bitch. I like to sit down with my friends and have a really good bitch." She said she liked to sing "Stand up if you hate the scum" about the opposition at football matches.

She said: "I don't mix in cookery circles. They think I am not trendy enough, not quite the ticket. And when I do meet them, they are always saying to me, 'Delia, when are you going to go organic?'

"People have criticised me from day one. It's not a problem."

She declined yesterday to respond to Worrall Thompson's comments.

fields.headline: Milosevic can't count on army
fields.standfirst:
Serb forces Strong-arm tactics unlikely

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Slobodan Milosevic's hold on power may be crumbling. The loyalty of the police force can no longer be guaranteed and the army is unlikely to support the use of force against peaceful protesters, Belgrade observers said yesterday.
fields.body:
Slobodan Milosevic's hold on power may be crumbling. The loyalty of the police force can no longer be guaranteed and the army is unlikely to support the use of force against peaceful protesters, Belgrade observers said yesterday.

"Beating up people for a president who is finished is not good for any policeman's job prospects," said Ljubodrag Stojadikovic, a former army spokesman who resigned last year. "If Milosevic tries to use the army it will be the last act of a drowning man."

His remarks came as Milan Panic, a former Yugoslav prime minister who lost to Mr Milosevic in the last Serbian presidential elections in 1992, called on the army and police not to take part in repression. "I want to remind the army and police that their duty is not to shoot or use force against their own people," he said.

He also urged western governments immediately to recognise the opposition candidate, Vojislav Kostunica, as Yugoslavia's new president.

The 120,000 strong Serbian police force is huge by regional standards. In the winter of 1996 and 1997 it was involved in quelling three months of protests when Mr Milosevic rigged local elections.

The opposition fears there is now a real risk that Mr Milosevic's special forces, a section of the police loyal to him and used in Bosnia, Croatia and the Kosovo war, could come to see their only future as going down fighting with him.

There are estimated to be around 30,000 police in the special forces - many of them highly trained - who could be used to crush the demonstrators declaring victory for Mr Kostunica. Throughout his hold on power Mr Milosevic has successfully deployed the police and internal security as his personal protection force. They have also been used to organise unrest in Bosnia and Croatia.

It was his former head of secret police, Jovica Stanisic, who gave Belgrade prisoners the option of serving their sentence in the capital or as paramilitaries in Bosnia and Croatia (where they could loot) and who arranged for the first stocks of weapons for these wars to come from Serbian police stores.

"The only factory that is getting new workers in Serbia is the police," said Jovan Dulovic, who has specialised for 20 years in police affairs for the small independent magazine Vreme. "The special force can be in Belgrade in a few hours."

Despite threats by the top ranks of the army that they will back Mr Milosevic, the army in Serbia is obsessed with legality and the role of constitution. There is a great deal of anger that Mr Milosevic allowed them to be humiliated in the Kosovan and Bosnian wars and that their once proud reputation was dragged into the dirt in these conflicts.

Johan Stanovic, a 21-year-old taxi driver, who was injured in the Kosovo war, said: "There is no way that guys like me and the guys I was in the army with will go on to the streets for him. The army is supposed to fight wars, not beat their own people."

fields.headline: Apocalypse not now
fields.trailText: The mantra being heard across the City yesterday was speculation, speculation, speculation.
fields.body:
The mantra being heard across the City yesterday was speculation, speculation, speculation.

"The market feels good for something, the question is who, what and when," said one senior trader. With tip-hungry punters losing interest in last week's takeover favourites - Bank of Scotland , off 5p to 605p, and Royal & Sun Alliance , down 8.5p to 467.5p - a new list of runners and riders was quickly drawn up.

Heading the list was retail conglomerate Kingfisher , with Invensys , Emap , Thus and Geo Interactive Media also present.

Meanwhile, back in the world of facts and figures, the FTSE 100 closed 51.2 points higher at 6,257.1 as investors decided that, following last week's intervention in the currency and oil markets, the global economy is not after all heading for disaster.

The Techmark and FTSE 250 also posted strong gains.

Some bullish traders are predicting further gains as fund managers (who are awash with cash by historical standards) rush to invest before the close of the third quarter on Friday.

There was no doubt about the story of the day. Kingfisher ended 47.75p - equivalent to 11.23% - higher at 473p following a strange chain of events involving French retailer Pinault Printemps-Redoute and a US investment bank, said to be Schroder Salomon Smith Barney.

After a lively morning of trading, Kingfisher shares had reached 440p by 2pm after 6m units had changed hands. In the next 40 minutes of trading the stock shot up to 470p with turnover reaching a massive total of 22m units.

The initial impetus for the move came from the large US investment bank, which had agreed to sell a client 12m Kingfisher shares at 458.5p. Because it did not have enough stock on its book to cover the trade, the bank was forced to buy shares in the market to cover the position.

Unfortunately for the bank, the trade coincided with speculation that Kingfisher was about to reveal an all-share merger with Pinault, a strange tale given that the French group has no obvious overlaps with Kingfisher. Nevertheless, the rumours resulted in a scramble for stock.

Although Pinault issued a denial of the merger speculation, briefly taking the stock price all the way back to 440p, the determination of the bank to close the position amid fresh speculation (US home improvement group Home De pot was said to be ready with an offer) saw the shares close at 473p.

Meanwhile, Invensys , the controls and automation group, ended the day as the best performing FTSE 100 stock as rumours of a takeover gathered momentum.

There was nothing new in the talk. The usual names were being mentioned from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the buyout specialist that yesterday bought the non-core oper ations of chemicals group Laporte , up 85.25p to 508.75p, to US groups Tyco and GE. There were even suggestions that German firm Siemens or even Swedish group ABB could be interested.

Analysts at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson added fuel to the fire when in a note to clients they said Invensys could not continue trading at such a severe discount without one of the aforementioned companies taking a shot. Dresdner reckons Invensys is worth 295p on a sum-of-the-parts valuation. The stock closed at 151.75p, after rising 15.5p over the session, with 43.8m units changing hands.

Elsewhere, dealers were begging to chatter excitedly about Emap, up 22p to 972p, the company behind lad magazine FHM. The gossips reckon the company has got a lucrative link-up, which will be enough to keep it on the FTSE 100. Telecoms group Thus picked up 9p to 132p due to talk of an offer.

Video compression specialist Geo Interactive advanced 95p to £12, with retail punters excited by a report in the Israeli business press. According to that story, the group is once again close to a deal with Ericsson.

fields.headline: European optimism
fields.trailText: September has not been the best month for the European equity markets. In London, the blue chip FTSE 100 index has fallen more than 550 points as investors took fright at the oil price, the euro and a string of profit warnings from across the Atlantic.
fields.body:
September has not been the best month for the European equity markets. In London, the blue chip FTSE 100 index has fallen more than 550 points as investors took fright at the oil price, the euro and a string of profit warnings from across the Atlantic.

But, according to investment bank Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, auguries are improving. Yesterday, it raised its recommended exposure to European equities on the grounds that the conditions for a fourth quarter rally are in place. These are concerted action to support the euro, the release of the US strategic petroleum reserve and a more realistic appraisal of technology stocks in the wake of the Intel profits warning. Morgan Stanley reckons the sectors to rally will be telecoms and financials.The one to avoid is pharmaceuticals. The bank says, however, next year will be a down period for European equities.

webTitle: Who's cooking?  TV's army of chefs

fields.headline: Who's cooking?  TV's army of chefs
fields.standfirst:
Knives out as Delia the bitch bites back
Delia's delights
fields.trailText: Delia Smith has been presenting cookery programmes on the BBC for 27 years. Her most recent series was How to Cook Part 2 on BBC2
fields.body:
Delia Smith

Has been presenting cookery programmes on the BBC for 27 years. Her most recent series was How to Cook Part 2 on BBC2

Trademark: Classic casseroles and souffles and lessons on the cookery basics such as how to make toast - it tastes better if left to stand before buttering.

Shots of her cats in the back garden in her most recent series have upped the cosiness factor, taking the edge off her occasional austerity.

How to Cook Part 1 had an average of 4.4m viewers and Part 2 averaged 3.9m

Gary Rhodes

His latest programme, New British Classics, was shown in November last year on BBC2.

Trademark: The spiky-haired punk fan creates modern interpretations of British classics like the Cornish pasty. He appeals to young children and pensioners alike. He has produced eight spin-off cookery books and two more are about to be published.

New British Classics, had an average audience of 3.2m.

Jamie Oliver

The Naked Chef ran in April 1999, and The Return of the Naked Chef began in April this year and ran for eight weeks.

Trademark: Young Cockney chef from the River Cafe sniffs out the best fish at the local market and teaches lads to make "pukka" recipes like wild mushroom risotto and Maltesers crushed over ice cream.

Oliver has spun off into glossy magazine spreads, books and an advertising deal with Sainsbury's

His first series averaged an audience of 2.3m. The second averaged 4m

Food and Drink

Magazine and consumer interest programme currently shown at 8.30pm on Wednesdays on BBC2.

Food and Drink gives a personality-led consumer-angle on recipes and products. Its guest chef slot provided television debuts for Gary Rhodes and Jamie Oliver.

The latest series was watched by an average audience of 3.5m.

Nigella Lawson

Nigella Lawson's Bites has been running since August on Channel 4

Trademark: Glamorous, intelligent, working mother makes homemade fish and chips and elaborate ice cream and lets children lick the bowl.

The series is based on her book How To Eat. She makes traditional English food with extra cream for thirtysomething women who yearn for effortless domestic bliss.

The fifth and last episode in the current series, which is averaging 1.9m viewers, is this week.

Ainsley Harriott

His new series, Ainsley's Gourmet Express, is showing on Wednesday nights on BBC1

Trademark: Contemporary recipes from around the world, presented with his characteristic guttural laugh.

Harriott recently took over hosting BBC2's daytime staple Ready Steady Cook. His own, more laidback programme specialises in African and Asian food produced in record time. In it he is followed to local delis, restaurants and kitchens in search of produce and recipes.

No viewing figures yet for Gourmet Express but Ready Steady Cook averages at least 2m.

webTitle: Safety rules aimed at firm chiefs

fields.headline: Safety rules aimed at firm chiefs
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Health and safety laws covering work and transport are to be introduced for the first time in quarter of a century, the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, announced at the Labour party conference yesterday.
fields.body:
Health and safety laws covering work and transport are to be introduced for the first time in quarter of a century, the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, announced at the Labour party conference yesterday.

The shake-up will see directors and companies being held legally responsible for accidents in the workplace and prison sentences being imposed for the majority of health and safety offences - instead of the minority.

Corporate manslaughter could be brought in and fines are expected to be linked to a company's turnover or company directors' bonuses.

The legislation, which will not be introduced before next spring, was heralded by Mr Prescott as he said lives were being lost in industries such as construction through sheer bad working practice.

"Company directors whose negligence costs lives must not be allowed to hide behind workers and get away with it scot-free," he told delegates.

Each year, 400 people die in the workplace, with 1m injured, 29,000 seriously, at a cost to the taxpayer of £18bn.

In addition, some 350 die each year in transport accidents - with 31 killed last year in the Paddington rail crash. The new legislation will also cover transport safety, and is expected to incorporate the recommendations of Lord Cullen whose inquiry into the Paddington disaster, and the wider issue of rail regulation and safety, will report back next spring.

Mr Prescott also announced a goal to wipe out fuel poverty by 2010, and stressed that the government aimed to help the elderly and disabled by introducing half price bus fares for them all.

He attacked The Countryside Alliance, many of whom were demonstrating outside the conference centre, and drew cheers as he insisted the government had to stand firm on the fuel crisis.

fields.headline: Thumbs that say far more than words
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown sat down to a massive ovation after a dazzlingly successful speech. He had tackled the twin problems of the Ecclestone fib and the petrol crisis head on - by ignoring them. Was he contrite? No. His speech was as packed with contrition as a frog is full of toothpaste.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown sat down to a massive ovation after a dazzlingly successful speech. He had tackled the twin problems of the Ecclestone fib and the petrol crisis head on - by ignoring them. Was he contrite? No. His speech was as packed with contrition as a frog is full of toothpaste. But the Labour party has decided it adores him. The stamping and applauding and cheering continued for a ages, and became even more hysterical when his wife Sarah ran to join him on the platform. As they descended a vast, heaving mob of cameramen climbed up on each other.

The Browns saw the tottering, heaving phalynx advancing upon them. They fled backstage, and finally the cheering stopped.

The reception Mr Brown received was as demented as the prime minister will get this afternoon and possibly more so. And it can't be co-incidence that he ended with the last words John Smith said in public: "the opportunity to serve; that is all we ask." (This is politician-speak for "the chance to grab a hold of power; that is all we demand".)

Mr Blair sat on stage clapping and beaming as if his life depended on it, which it possibly does. One imagines him saying sibilantly to the chancellor afterwards, "That was jolly, jolly good, Gordon. Now I'm afraid I'm going to have to kill you..."

I myself was fascinated by the way that the chancellor now makes his points through elaborate hand gestures. If he'd picked up a piece of A4 at the start of the speech he'd have ended with an origami swan. "To build on success..." was emphasised by both hands out with thumbs up - hitchhiking on two carriageways. There's the frantic flap ("Help! I am being pursued by flesh-eating zombies") and the one where he pulls apart two fighting crabs. In another he hammers a point home by cupping Madonna's bustier, and "unemployment, the lowest for a generation" was emphasised by the hand made into a fist with the index finger pointing up. All this conveyed a passion and conviction mere words could not express. No wonder they were driven to a frenzy.

He did not get a standing ovation; instead the applause resembled the sound of empty crisp packets blowing across an playground.

By contrast, John Prescott was received with rapture. A Prescott speech resembles a bull charging an imaginary matador. It's impressive, even fearsome, but now and again the cape is whisked away and he's impaled himself on the planking. Under Labour, he said, "you'll have noticed - no water bans or hosepipe crises". That's because we've had all that rain, I wanted to shout. It's certainly a first - even this government has never before taken credit for the weather.

No, silly, of course he didn't say the last bit.

webTitle: Court threat to Prescott over tube

fields.headline: Court threat to Prescott over tube
fields.standfirst:
Special report: transport in Britain
Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone yesterday threatened legal action if John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, pressed ahead with his plans to part-privatise the London Underground, after an independent report damned them as offering poor value for money and potentially risking the safety of passengers.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone yesterday threatened legal action if John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, pressed ahead with his plans to part-privatise the London Underground, after an independent report damned them as offering poor value for money and potentially risking the safety of passengers.

London's mayor, who is due to take over the tube only after the private contracts are locked in place, said it would now be unreasonable in law for the government to carry on with its public-private partnership unless there were radical changes to the scheme.

His remarks were made as government sources said that conflict between the Treasury and Mr Prescott's Transport and Environment Department over how to finance tube modernisation were hampering attempts to achieve a workable political compromise over the issue.

Tony Blair conceded during the London mayoral election that it would be difficult to go ahead with part-privatisation of the tube if Mr Livingstone were elected, but the government now appears determined to force through the scheme.

Yesterday's report by Will Hutton, chief executive of the Industrial Society think tank, commissioned at Labour's insistence, argued that the PPP should be abandoned in favour of a bond-financed public sector option, unless tougher safeguards on safety, contract compliance and value for money are introduced.

"I would have thought to proceed now in the light of Will Hutton's complaints, unless they adapt and take on board his points, there is an opening for a judicial review of the decision," said Mr Livingstone.

"I am not opposed to partnership with the private sector on principle, but this is a rotten deal which binds London for 30 years to overgenerous contracts giving private sector monopolies intolerable powers over London's democratically-elected authorities".

The Rail Maritime and Transport union's senior tube official, Bob Crow, yesterday raised the prospect of a strike over safety on the London Underground, while Mick Rix, general secretary of the train drivers' union Aslef, said the Hutton report had blown a hole through the government's case for PPP.

"The government must now think again and start listening to the trade unions, the elected London mayor and Londoners who voted for him on a platform of a properly funded, publicly owned future for the tube."

fields.headline: Wolverhampton wandering aimlessly
fields.standfirst: Go-it-alone brewer fares badly
fields.trailText: The ale is looking increasingly flat at Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries, the maker of traditional tipples such as Banks's, Marston's and Pedigree bitter.
fields.body:
The ale is looking increasingly flat at Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries, the maker of traditional tipples such as Banks's, Marston's and Pedigree bitter.

Wolves brushed aside a takeover proposal from the private equity firm Botts & Co with surprising arrogance last month, to the irritation of many of its shareholders. At the time, the management dropped non-too-subtle hints that there would be pleasing surprises in this month's trading statement.

That statement flopped on to investors' doormats yesterday offering little comfort - the fullest flavour on offer was a less than booming 1.2% increase in like-for-like sales during August. The brewer is, at best, back on schedule with the integration of recently acquired Marston's and Mansfield, after suffering a severe bout of hiccups in the spring.

Wolves' long-term problem is that it makes ale which, while enjoyed by purists, hardly attracts the cachet of a vodka and Red Bull. The management's response has been to get bigger, in the hope that economies of scale will drive profits forward. So, through a series of takeovers, Wolves has cornered the market in running street-corner boozers in towns in the midlands and north.

Cost cutting is continuing - Wolves is likely to announce imminently that at least one, possibly two, of its four breweries is to go. It has done little with one of its few promising businesses: Pitcher & Piano, a bar chain inherited from Marston's. It is a sad fact of life that the traditional brewing industry is in a slow, long-term decline. Wolves' management has aggravated the situation by trying to do too much, too fast. Botts & Co is hardly the most credible bidder for a £470m business - it is struggling to decide whether to pay £12m for the even less glamorous Oriental Restaurants Group.

But for Wolves, a tight control on costs will be insufficient to satisfy the market's insatiable desire for growth. The best place for the company is in private hands - the question is, whether it will fall to a careful owner.

Exchange stakes

Here is an obscure fact concerning the fight for control of the London Stock Exchange: a portion of the declared 3.6% stake in the exchange held by the investment bank UBS Warburg is in fact beneficially owned by its hedge fund, UBS O'Connor.

The fund was set up in June, drawing together a sizeable group of UBS Warburg's top risk-taking traders in Chicago and London to manage money provided by the parent bank and any of the investment bank's clients who fancied a seriously professional flutter in a high-risk, high-reward world.

How or why UBS O'Connor ended up with a stake in the LSE remains a mystery, although it is assumed the hedge fund thought this particular corporate play to be a good punt. Indeed, since the LSE's demutualisation in mid-summer, the shares have moved from a low of £19 to a recent high of close to £31 - a capital gain of 63% for a well timed speculation in less than two months.

Understandably, the bank does not discuss individual trading positions. The size of its holding is unknown, but is thought to be relatively small. What is clear cut is that the hedge fund manager is holding the stake for one reason: to make money.

Sentimentality over a 200-year-old British institution will not get in the way; neither will the broader implications for UBS, one of the City's premier banks, stemming from a change of ownership of the exchange. Hedge funds only exist to provide their investors with exceptional returns on their money. Should this bother us? For all the debate over institutions becoming more socially aware in their investment choices, financial markets are overwhelmingly driven by the short-term profit motive. Making a speculative gain on the future of the exchange is perhaps just an especially cute bet. (It is also worth noting here that numerous senior staff at the exchange have taken personal punts on the future of the business by buying shares in the London Stock Exchange for themselves.)

Yet somehow the brazen nature of UBS's action feels uncomfortable. In the main, the holding in the LSE is a legacy of its past takeover of two building blocks of London's modern financial community, SG Warburg and Phillips & Drew. The bank may argue now that it is impossible to act simultaneously as a shareholder in the exchange while being one of its prime customers - and it is evident that this peculiarity has muddled quite a few stockbroking brains over recent months. It may also argue that, as a separate hedge fund operation, UBS O'Connor is given its own head, being left to pursue value wherever its dealers manage to spot it.

But whatever the chinese walls and other internal procedures at UBS, the parent bank risks being badly misunderstood when it comes to debating and eventually deciding the LSE's future.

webTitle: Rattled minister beats retreat from fringe event after rough ride from protesters

fields.headline: Rattled minister beats retreat from fringe event after rough ride from protesters
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Labour's pensions minister was booed and heckled yesterday by angry OAPs as he attempted to defend the government's refusal to restore the link between earnings and benefits.
fields.body:
Labour's pensions minister was booed and heckled yesterday by angry OAPs as he attempted to defend the government's refusal to restore the link between earnings and benefits.

At the most inflammatory fringe meeting of the Labour conference, Jeff Rooker struggled to make himself heard as pensioners drowned out his speech with cries of: "Restore the link."

Mr Rooker misjudged the mood of the 500 pensioners when he told the meeting, after a powerful speech by the veteran campaigner Barbara Castle, that he wanted to "dispel a few myths". As he reeled off statistics about pensions, saying that less people were now subjected to means tests, members of the audience shouted "give us our pensions back" and "you don't listen to us". Sweating and looking unsettled, Mr Rooker provoked the audience when he leant over to one noisy pensioner and said: "I'm worried about your health, don't have a heart attack." The pensioner replied that he had already suffered a heart attack.

Jack Jones, the veteran former transport union leader, attempted to calm the atmosphere with an appeal for quiet. But this failed to silence the protestors who continued to barrack Mr Rooker. "Will you shut up while I'm speaking please," he said.

Mr Rooker brought his speech to an abrupt end and hurried back to the safety of the main conference hall to listen to Gordon Brown's speech.

Lady Castle, who introduced the link between pensions and earnings in the 1970s, was given a rapturous reception as she entered the meeting, which was also attended by veteran Labour MP Tony Benn and the agony aunt Clare Rayner. Supported by an aide, the frail 89-year-old former cabinet minister demanded a restoration of the link to ensure that future pensioners are protected. "We are fighting for the restoration of the welfare state and the abolition of the mentality of the poor law - don't let it come back," she said.

Jack Jones was applauded as he told the meeting that this year's increase in the basic state pension of 75p had been "derisory". He said that there were billions of pounds in the National Insurance fund which could be spent on boosting pensions. "It's our money and that money should be released by way of substantial increases to the pensioners this year," he said. "We are not asking for the moon."

Mr Benn joked that he was an "apprentice pensioner" at the age of 76. Saying that pensioners' concerns have been "brushed aside" for too long, he used Gerald Kaufman's famous description of Labour's 1983 election manifesto to underline the importance of restoring the earnings link.

"The decision not to link pensions and earnings is the shortest suicide note in history," he said. "The people in this room are the people who served in the war, voted Labour and gave us all the achievements we have had."

webTitle: Country Gardens HQ withers in £111m deal

fields.headline: Country Gardens HQ withers in £111m deal
fields.trailText: Wyevale, Britain's largest garden centres group, has triumphed in its long running attempt to take over rival Country Gardens.
fields.body:
Wyevale, Britain's largest garden centres group, has triumphed in its long running attempt to take over rival Country Gardens.

In its third offer for Country, Wyevale is paying £111m or £4 a share for the company.

The deal will see the closure of the Country Gardens head office, with the loss of up to 60 jobs, along with the resignation of its board. Nicholas Marshall, chief executive of Country Gardens, said it was a "sad and upsetting time" but that he was already in talks with potential backers to build a new chain of garden centres.

"I will be starting again," he said. "I am sure it won't take very long to raise the finance and I have already had some offers."

Wyevale plans to spend up to £4m on upgrading and re-branding Country Gardens centres early next year.

The agreement announced yesterday follows months of bitter wrangling which saw Wyevale's approaches rejected three times - at 310p, 320p and 350p a share.

"The cash and shares deal underlines Wyevale's dominance in a fragmented sector and brings the total number of centres to 119 and employees to over 3,000.

Robert Hewitt, the chief executive, said the company was on the look-out for more acquisitions. "We were always prepared to have to walk away but still, in our heart of hearts, believed we would make the acquisition," he said.

Analysts said Wyevale was "paying a full price", which was illustrated by the stock's 25.5p drop in value to 485p as the markets closed last night.

Shares in Country Gardens soared 78.5p to 377.5p. Paul Kavanagh of Killick & Co stockbrokers, said: "They are paying a full price but the logic of the deal is compelling.

"Wyevale is the number one in the country but its market share is minimal. The industry is ripe for consolidation."

Country Gardens' centres, based mainly in the south east, made average sales of £1.7m last year. The new group will have a turnover of £160m.

webTitle: Unigate still losing money on pork processing

fields.headline: Unigate still losing money on pork processing
fields.trailText: Unigate yesterday blamed the swine fever outbreak for preventing its pork processing plant in North Yorkshire returning to profit. The company had hoped pig prices would have fallen by now and bolstered its under-pressure Malton site.
fields.body:
Unigate yesterday blamed the swine fever outbreak for preventing its pork processing plant in North Yorkshire returning to profit. The company had hoped pig prices would have fallen by now and bolstered its under-pressure Malton site.

But it admitted movement restrictions to contain the disease, which initially struck in Suffolk, had squeezed availability and kept prices high.

It has also temporarily closed off key export markets, including Japan and the US.

A statement hinted that the company might consider selling or closing Malton. "As indicated at the annual general meeting, the board continues to explore how Malton could participate in an overall pig meat industry restructuring," it said. John Worby, the group finance director, admitted that Malton was "having a tough time", but said he had been "reasonably optimistic" of seeing either falling pig prices or rising selling prices before the outbreak.

"We're looking forward to restrictions being lifted and some better availability. It's in everyone's interests."

The former dairy group had warned in June that pig prices needed to fall to reverse flagging fortunes which had seen full-year pork profits fall from £27m to £15.4m.

The first news of the outbreak came at the beginning of last month when 3,500 pigs had to be slaughtered at a Suffolk farm. The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food introduced movement restrictions on pigs at 155 farms - including neighbouring areas to those where cases had been discovered.

Last night, Maff said 13 infected herds had been killed, while 61 farms were still under restrictions.

webTitle: Wolves may wield axe to bolster its defences

fields.headline: Wolves may wield axe to bolster its defences
fields.standfirst: Two breweries may be closed to fend off bidder
fields.trailText: Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries is likely to close its Mansfield plant and is studying the possibility of selling its Cameron facility in Hartlepool as part of a cost-cutting drive to shore up its bid defences against the private equity firm Botts & Co.
fields.body:
Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries is likely to close its Mansfield plant and is studying the possibility of selling its Cameron facility in Hartlepool as part of a cost-cutting drive to shore up its bid defences against the private equity firm Botts & Co.

Industry sources say that an internal review, due to report in November, will come to the conclusion that Wolves cannot continue to operate all of its existing four breweries.

The company was tight-lipped on the issue yesterday as it released a trading statement showing a 1.2% increase in like-for-like pub sales during August.

Finance director Ralph Findlay would only say that the review was "complicated and sensitive", and that it would be a mistake to make a "hurried decision".

He added: "We've brewed more beer across the group this year - like-for-like, we're up 6.5%. The landscape is moving."

Wolves' Mansfield brewery, which it took over in December, is operating at just 73% of capacity. However, at the time of purchase the group undertook to trustees that it would keep the site at least partly open until the end of next year.

The Cameron brewery is running close to capacity but is producing high-volume lagers, which Wolves could buy elsewhere. The site could be sold as a going concern.

The group's other two sites, in Wolverhampton and Burton-upon-Trent, are closely associated with local brands - Banks and Pedigree - and are thought to be safe from the axe.

In its trading statement Wolves said it was back on track to deliver £32m of savings next year from its recent purchases of Mansfield and Marston's. It said retail margins had been restored, and it gave details of a new management structure, with divisional managing directors for retail operations, tenancies and brands.

However, the news did not impress Botts & Co, which has said it is willing to pay 550p a share for the business. A Botts spokesman said: "The announcement tells us nothing new. It does not hold out a promise of growth in shareholder value."

The shares jumped 13.5p to 481p, reflecting a belief that a takeover remains possible.

fields.headline: Brown's pension promise
fields.standfirst:
Refusal to bow to fuel protesters but more help for the elderly on way
Chancellor refused to restore link between pensions and earnings as demanded by the unions.
But he confirmed that the minimum income guarantee will go up next April from £78 to £90, aimed at the four million poorest pensioners.
And in 2003 a pension credit is to be introduced, targeted at four million middle income people on modest occupational pensions or with limited savings.
Before 2003 'transitional help' for pensioners. But he refused to spell out exactly who would get this or how much they could expect.
Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: The nervous mood of the Labour conference was turned around yesterday when the chancellor, Gordon Brown, pledged more help for all pensioners, a return to full employment and increased on the minimum wage.
fields.body:
The nervous mood of the Labour conference was turned around yesterday when the chancellor, Gordon Brown, pledged more help for all pensioners, a return to full employment and increased on the minimum wage.

Clearly indicating that he was unwilling to make quick concessions to the fuel protesters, he called for a national debate on the impact of cuts on fuel duty on public services, adding he would do nothing to damage planned increases in spending on health, education and transport.

The four-minute ovation for the much-criticised chancellor only ended when he brought his wife Sarah onto the stage and gave her a kiss, which did not quite match Al Gore's embrace of his wife Tipper at the Democratic convention.

Refusing to bow to the petrol protesters, Mr Brown said: "The national debate is too important to ever be decided by those who shout the loudest or push the hardest. The British way, the Labour way, is that every voice is heard.

"However difficult the decisions we have to make the country will never forgive us if we lurch from one opportunistic tax decision to another and retreat to the old short termist ways of the past."

Addressing the issue that has come to grip the conference, he said it had not been wrong to put the abolition of pensioner poverty first, but he now recognised that the government had much more to do. He said: "We will build on the basic state pension. The basic state pension is and will remain the foundation of everything we do.

"In the pre-Budget report, it will be a priority that we do more with, by 2003, a new pensioner credit that will get extra help not only to the poorest but the millions who have lost out in the rising prosperity of this country." He promised the format of the credit, by rewarding saving, would provide a bigger increase to lower and middle income pensioners than if the pension was increased in line with earnings.

Rejecting an across the board increase in the basic pension, he said a flat rate increase would not do enough to help pensioners on modest incomes and reinforce growing inequalities. The pensioner credit, he said, would "provide more cash than either an inflation rise, or an earnings link would provide".

However, prior to the introduction of the credit, he said he would publish details on transitional arrangements "to the benefits of all pensioners". Treasury sources later indicated that there would be substantial, above inflation increases in the basic pension in the three years before the new pensioners credit kicks in. Mr Brown also said that the minimum income guarantee, directed at the poorest pensioner, would rise from £78 to £90, but gave no timetable on the increase.

On oil, he said "a 300% rise in oil prices in 18 months cannot be justified and I understand the difficulties it is causing for motorists, business and consumers in Britain, as it is in every continent of the world".

The chancellor would do everything possible on the international stage to ensure oil production was increased and oil prices came down. He was speaking on a day when oil prices fell sharply partly due to the release of US oil reserves.

He promised to report on the oil issue in the pre-Budget report, but he gave little ground on a possible tax cut in fuel duties, saying the country faced a choice.

"Is our national priority today to build long term stability and invest in hospitals schools and strong public services for all? Or is it to put both stability and public services at risk by irresponsible tax promises which if implemented would cut billions from hospitals schools and our core services?"

Nevertheless, he promised targetted tax cuts again in the future and treasury sources said the chancellor did not favour any further general cuts in the basic rate of income tax but instead favoured cuts aimed at the poor.

He said:"What we rule out is blanket irresponsible tax promises that cut into £4bn extra spending, the £12bn in education and training, the £14bn in health we will not put the long term future for our public services at risk".

Mr Brown said the industry secretary, Stephen Byers, would ask the Low Pay Commission to report on a further rise in the minimum wage.

Offering a new agenda for the second term, he said: "Be cause family friendly employment is good for both employers and employees, there will be new measures for maternity pay and leave, and with the new investment, our commitment to high quality accessible and affordable child care, a national child care startegy." He promised a right to paid time off for a mother or father when their child falls sick.

He ended by quoting John Smith, the former Labour leader, saying: "All we ask is an opportunity to serve".

fields.headline: Sotheby's former chairman pays
fields.standfirst: $186m settlement of price-fixing and collusion claims
fields.trailText: Sotheby's former chairman, Alfred Taubman, has agreed to pay $186m (£130m) out of his own pocket to help the auction house settle US lawsuits with shareholders and customers over a continuing price-fixing scandal.
fields.body:
Sotheby's former chairman, Alfred Taubman, has agreed to pay $186m (£130m) out of his own pocket to help the auction house settle US lawsuits with shareholders and customers over a continuing price-fixing scandal.

Mr Taubman, the controlling shareholder, quit as chairman in February when the allegations surfaced. Sotheby's is accused of colluding with rival auctioneer Christie's to keep commission rates high.

In a settlement with former customers, Sotheby's has agreed to stump up $256m, of which it will pay $50m cash and $50m in discount vouchers. Mr Taubman will provide the rest. Sotheby's has also agreed to distribute $40m of stock to angry shareholders, with another $30m of cash from Mr Taubman.

Mr Taubman is one of America's richest businessmen. He made millions from shopping malls before becoming chairman of Sotheby's, which he has controlled since 1983.

"I endorse and am contributing to these settlements to facilitate the resolution of all matters and to minimise the impact on Sotheby's, a company I care about deeply," he said.

Mr Taubman has control of the auctioneer through a large holding of B shares - which carry 10 times the votes of ordinary A shares. It is unclear whether he will sell to finance the settlements.

Christie's, which is co-defendant in the US lawsuits, has agreed to pay similar sums to shareholders and former customers. Some lawsuits, which refer to transactions outside the US, remain outstanding.

After a period of intense competition in the 1980s, Sotheby's and Christie's both raised their commission levels on sales in the early 1990s.

They then both introduced similar sliding scales, charging commissions of between 2% and 10%. The US department of justice is investigating whether collusion took place. Sotheby's said it was in "serious negotiations" with the department and believed a mutually acceptable resolution would soon be reached.

An investigation by Britain's office of fair trading was passed on to the European commission, which is still looking into the matter.

webTitle: Murder case farmer loses court plea for legal aid

fields.headline: Murder case farmer loses court plea for legal aid
fields.standfirst:
Tony Martin's new legal team may sue former solicitors over fund to pay for trial

Free Tony Martin campaign
Special report: The Tony Martin case
fields.trailText: Farmer Tony Martin, who was jailed for life in April for murdering a teenage burglar, was yesterday told that he would not receive legal aid to fund his appeal against the conviction.
fields.body:
Farmer Tony Martin, who was jailed for life in April for murdering a teenage burglar, was yesterday told that he would not receive legal aid to fund his appeal against the conviction.

The ruling means that Martin, 55, could be forced to sell his Norfolk farm to fund his legal fight.

During a preliminary appeal court hearing Martin's new legal team said it wanted vital papers from the solicitors whom Martin had instructed for the original trial at Norwich crown court but has since sacked.

And outside court it emerged that the new team is contemplating civil action against the previous solicitors in connection with money which had been held in a trust fund for Martin's case.

Martin's new solicitor, James Saunders, said after the hearing: "We're determined that Tony Martin's case will be properly prepared for the court of appeal. We're hoping to find some money to finance that.

"If no one helps him he will have to sell the very thing that provides him with his purpose in life - his farm. In order to be free, to get back to his previous life, he will have to destroy his previous life."

A court can rule that a person has sufficient wealth to fund an appeal. The value of Martin's assets is not known but he does have valuable farmland and machinery as well as his dilapidated farmhouse.

Martin's new legal team told the court it was hampered because the farmer's previous solicitors, Leicestershire-based M&S Solicitors Ltd, had not handed over papers which could help in the appeal.

It is thought that one of the arguments the new team could put forward is that medical issues could have had an impact on Martin's state of mind. The farmer's new lawyers want to find out if this was discussed with Martin and if any steps were taken to draw up a report on his psychiatric state.

Another bone of contention between the old and new legal teams is a trust fund set up to help Martin's fight.

The various problems mean that the appeal, which had been expected to be heard this autumn, might not take place until the start of next year.

Nick Makin, of M&S Solicitors, said that his firm was hanging on to the case papers until costs due from the legal aid authorities were paid.

He said he was not aware of any action in relation to the trust fund - the firm was happy to transfer the funds in accordance with the trustees' instructions.

webTitle: Redstone avoids BT's local loop obstacles

fields.headline: Redstone avoids BT's local loop obstacles
fields.trailText: Redstone Telecom deftly avoided controversy yesterday when it announced its plans to exploit the breaking of British Telecom's grip on the local telephone network next year.
fields.body:
Redstone Telecom deftly avoided controversy yesterday when it announced its plans to exploit the breaking of British Telecom's grip on the local telephone network next year.

Redstone, which provides services to small and medium size businesses, said it had applied for access to 1,250 BT exchanges.

The company has, however, opted to install its equipment outside the exchanges, avoiding BT's complaints about lack of space in its 6,000 exchanges and security issues which have led some rivals to accuse it of muddying the process.

"There is a way round all this," said Bob Cushing, Redstone's group marketing and business development director. "Most companies have applied for physical space within BT exchanges and do not realise how difficult that is. We were not expecting this process to be anything other than complicated."

Both BT and regulator Oftel have come under intense criticism for their handling of the break-up of the local phone network, known as "unbundling the local loop".

The issue has become highly charged because it is seen as inextricable from the widespread adoption of broadband services. Competition is expected to accelerate the installation of DSL technology which upgrades the copper wires to high speed internet access and broadcast links.

Some companies including US groups WorldCom and Global Crossing have abandoned plans to offer high-speed internet services amid claims that BT was blocking access to the most lucrative exchanges.

"DSL fundamentally changes our business," Mr Cushing said. "We are able to offer services such as high-quality video conferencing which are currently well beyond small companies. For us it builds the margin and relationship with customers."

webTitle: No vote on move for elected Lords

fields.headline: No vote on move for elected Lords
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Labour party conference 2000
Special report: Lords reform
fields.trailText: Supporters of a largely elected second chamber were forced to retreat last night in the face of heavy opposition from conference delegates.
fields.body:
Supporters of a largely elected second chamber were forced to retreat last night in the face of heavy opposition from conference delegates.

The Campaign for a Democratic Upper House decided not to press for a conference floor vote on its proposal that at least half the second chamber should be subject to democratic election. The campaign said it had decided to withdraw in the face of a likely defeat.

"History is on our side. A democratically elected upper house is inevitable. The question is how quickly it comes," said Damien Welfare, the campaign's co-ordinator.

He pointed out that Lady Jay, leader of the House of Lords, had said in a BBC interview that the largest option for an elected element of 35%, proposed by the Wakeham commission, would be the most sensible.

Mr Welfare commented: "This is substantially higher than the small elected element mentioned by government spokesmen before the party conference."

He went on: "Public opinion backs a largely elected upper house. An ICM poll last week showed that 78% of the electorate support it. We are confident that democracy will win in the end."

However, the leader of the Commons, Margaret Beckett, told delegates: "Those who argue that election gives legitimacy must accept that two elected houses either have, or ultimately will, claim equal or even greater legitimacy. That would be a profound and dramatic change both in our party's policy and in our country's constitution."

She warned that a two-chamber parliament could end up being perpetually at war.

The outcome of the vote will be a relief to ministers. However, all sides condemned the organisation of yesterday's debate, which was disjointed and spread over two days.

webTitle: Virgin Mobile seeks £115m to widen sales base

fields.headline: Virgin Mobile seeks £115m to widen sales base
fields.trailText: Virgin Mobile yesterday announced plans to raise £115m through a syndicated loan, its first injection of outside finance since the service began last November.
fields.body:
Virgin Mobile yesterday announced plans to raise £115m through a syndicated loan, its first injection of outside finance since the service began last November.

The cash will in part support the group's first independent distribution deals with a number of retailers, including supermarket chains Sainsbury's and Iceland.

The loan is being syndicated through JP Morgan and was aided by the presence of Deutsche Telekom, which owns Virgin's partner in the business, One2One.

Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Group and One2One put £50m each into the business when it was formed last year.

A spokesman for Virgin Mobile said the distribution deals were in line with intentions announced last November. The network has still not secured distribution through Britain's largest independent retailer, Carphone Warehouse, with which Sir Richard had a public spat last year.

The spokesman said: "Virgin Mobile has been the fastest growing start-up seen in Britain and the funding will support our expansion as we move toward third-party distribution.

"By waiting we have been able to prove that we have a successful business and a successful brand which has meant we could negotiate distribution deals on our own terms."

The company is converting many of its Our Price music stores into Virgin Mobile shops after a deal to dispose of the chain fell through last year. Around 30 have so far been given the new fascia with 100 scheduled for conversion by the end of October.

The company claims to have signed up 400,000 customers.

Virgin Mobile has already established partners in Europe and Asia and has turned its attention to the US, where it is holding discussions with US networks AT&T, Voicestream and Sprint in the hope of setting up a joint venture modelled on the British business.

Virgin Mobile has opened an office in San Francisco and appointed former McKinsey consultant John Tantum to run the US operation.

Singapore Telecom has injected $450m and Virgin $50m into an Asian venture.

fields.headline: Robocop meets Corporal Jones in Brighton
fields.trailText: On Sunday I helped organise a successful counter-conference to New Labour's annual gathering in Brighton. It was addressed by the writers Susan George and George Monbiot, MPs Alan Simpson, Tony Benn and Jeremy Corbyn, plus campaigners like Mark Thomas and Rob Newman. The event sold out of the 1,200 places available.

London

Peter.Burke@logobrand.com

Every day the Benefits Agency imposes silly tests on the disabled and, without any reference to GPs or medical notes, deprives genuine benefit claimants of their rights, safe in the knowledge that the Disability Rights Commission is powerless to take action.

Means tested supplements could be made available for those MPs who suffered hardship brought about by such a change.

SJ Mack
Birmingham

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Britain's trade deficit widened from £2.4bn to a record £3bn in July as import growth forged ahead at the fastest pace since the late 1980s boom.
fields.body:
Trade deficit reaches record

Britain's trade deficit widened from £2.4bn to a record £3bn in July as import growth forged ahead at the fastest pace since the late 1980s boom.

Strong domestic demand sucked in imports worth £18.2bn while exports totalled £15.2bn, according to data published yesterday by the office for national statistics.

Despite sterling's strength against the euro, Britain recorded a relatively small deficit with the EU of £300m, up from £200m in June. But this was swamped by a record deficit of £2.7bn with non-EU countries, £600m up on June.

Motorola acts on its own

Symbian yesterday insisted that the Psion-led consortium to make software for next-generation mobile phones and portable computers was on track despite Motorola's deal to make a set with someone else.

Motorola said it was developing a "smartphone" with Palm of the US, the world's largest maker of palmtop computers.

"Motorola remains committed as a shareholder, active participant and licensee of Symbian," the company said. Symbian's other members include Ericsson, Nokia and Matsushita.

CGNU sells US interests

CGNU is to sell its interest in its US general insurance operations to White Mountains Insurance for £1.42bn and may use the proceeds to make acquisitions of fund management operations.

Retained businesses consist of Pilot, a Canadian general insurance company, the group's US life insurance operations and a European-listed investment.

CGNU chief executive Bob Scott said: "Whilst the group will be incurring a significant loss, we have achieved a clean-cut exit from the difficult operating environment of the US property and casualty market."

Tessa warning for banks

Banks and building societies were yesterday told by a watchdog to stop penalising savers with tax-exempt special savings accounts (Tessas) who wish to move their money elsewhere.

The banking code standards board, which monitors whether institutions are obeying the industry's code of practice, recommended that penalties for transferring Tessa money to another account provider be removed.

fields.headline: Paper chase
fields.trailText: We are bored by Andrew Neil's rants in which he takes no blame for the Scotsman's circulation decline during almost four years in charge, but I was disappointed that you allowed room for his xenophobic outpourings (Bring them all on, September 25). We are funded by a Swedish company, Bonnier. They are one of Europe's largest media companies and his own, Press Holdings, is a mere regional minnow. Neil seems to think that their Scandinavian roots mean they know nothing about operating in the UK. Long may he remain in blissful ignorance but to describe us as "Nordic pygmies" borders on the racist.

fields.headline: The route to rail safety
fields.trailText: Jeremy Hardy  is wrong to say that some rail companies don't want to install automatic train protection because of the cost. The train protection and warning system (TPWS), which is currently being fitted to track and trains, will mitigate the effects of 70% of signals passed at danger by the time it is fully installed by the scheduled date of end-2003.
fields.body:
 Jeremy Hardy (Pass at red, September 25) is wrong to say that some rail companies don't want to install automatic train protection because of the cost. The train protection and warning system (TPWS), which is currently being fitted to track and trains, will mitigate the effects of 70% of signals passed at danger by the time it is fully installed by the scheduled date of end-2003. And if current trends continue, it will be a large proportion of a small number (the number of incidents in July 2000 - latest figures - was half that of July 1999).

We cannot fit additional further automatic train protection (ATP) yet, for these reasons: European law requires that any new system should be "interoperable" (capable of being used on any EU railway without modification). Neither of the systems currently installed in Britain is likely to comply. The European Train Control System has been developed to meet that requirement and is currently being tested at various levels of sophistication. When it is ready, we shall install it in Britain. It will prevent trains passing red signals. Until then, the best option is to use our existing systems of ATP and install TPWS, as Sir David Davies recommended in his report in February.

Ian MacKellar
Association of Train Operating Companies
Ian.MacKellar.atoc@ems.rail.co.uk

Jeremy Hardy describes TPWS, now being installed, as "crappy, dangerous technology". TPWS, unlike the more sophisticated ATP, is available now. It would have prevented accidents like Ladbroke Grove by stopping the slower of the two trains.

The best is always the enemy of the good and the really reprehensible action would be to postpone installation of TPWS (the best available technology) for an even better version not yet in production.

Lord Bradshaw

fields.headline: Cowboys in a bank raid
fields.trailText: You recommend using a post-dated cheque as protection against cowboys. I discovered this summer that Lloyds TSB (and, I suspect, most other banks) deduct a cheque from the account as soon as it is presented regardless of the date on the cheque.
fields.body:
 You recommend (Shoot first policy to deal with cowboys, Jobs & Money, September 23) using a post-dated cheque as protection against cowboys. I discovered this summer that Lloyds TSB (and, I suspect, most other banks) deduct a cheque from the account as soon as it is presented regardless of the date on the cheque.

If you cannot trust the salesman to wait until the date on a cheque before presenting it (and usually you can't) then post-dating a cheque is pointless. Recently a post-dated cheque of mine was presented and paid early. When I complained to the call-centre which pretends to be my branch I was told that I had no grounds for complaint as they no longer paid attention to the date on a cheque when processing it.

Carl Darby
Huntingdon,
Cambs
CarlDarbyX@aol.com

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText:
Eight foot wire mesh fences protect Tonytown's borders, keeping pensioners, gamekeepers, hauliers and other populist purveyors of Poujadist protests in the outside world. Entry to the mini-state is through airport-style security checks at border points operated by Group 4.
Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.body:
 Eight foot wire mesh fences protect Tonytown's borders, keeping pensioners, gamekeepers, hauliers and other populist purveyors of Poujadist protests in the outside world. Entry to the mini-state is through airport-style security checks at border points operated by Group 4. Construction minister Nick Raynsford, turning up with government red box in left hand, discovered rank wins no privileges. The guards ran a check after refusing to believe he was the N Raynsford of HMG when he hopped off a bus rather than out of the back of a car. His lead-lined red box rendered the X-ray ma chine useless, the guards arguing he must open it so they could check all it contained was confidential papers. A compromise saw him required to sign a disclaimer promising to pay to rebuild the conference complex if he had smuggled in a bomb.

 Even Blair's babe, Leo, needs a passport in Tonytown and a photo security card is pinned to his romper suit after the premier decided to take him to the seaside. So will Nelson Mandela when he speaks on Thursday. Security chiefs, fearing an international incident, popped into Politico's bookshop at the conference to buy a tome on the former South African president. They cut out a picture to stick on his pass.

 A particularly warm Tonytown welcome is extended to deputy PM John Prescott, cutting quite a dash in his new Friar Tuck haircut. Leaving Millbank last week, he told staff: "See you next week in Blackpool."

 BBC staff have been issued with a guide telling them Greg Dyke will pay no more than £5 for breakfast, £6 for lunch, £10 for dinner, £20 for kipping on a friend's floor and £39.88 for a B&B. A helpful section also told them what to pack in their suitcases: "Pens, pencils."

 More tales emerge from Brighton races. Home Office minister Mike O'Brien, responsible for the racing industry, showed he is uniquely qualified for the job. Handed a free £2 bet, he needed help to fill in the slip. Yes. He lost.

 Standing at the Hilton Metropole's carvery, Alastair Campbell looked for a chef. "Pick up the knife," suggested a fellow diner, "you've stuck enough in people's backs." Not very Tonytown.
