fields.headline: More ideas for our manifesto
fields.trailText: I read with great interest your "radical and realistic programme for the next government" (Guardian manifesto, September 25) and was pleased to see many suggestions I too would like to see implemented.
fields.body:
 I read with great interest your "radical and realistic programme for the next government" (Guardian manifesto, September 25) and was pleased to see many suggestions I too would like to see implemented. A community re-investment act, expansion of the surestart scheme, reduction of inequalities in health provision, an overhaul of the Equal Pay Act, continued constitutional reform of local and national government and a new strategy to reduce inequalities.

But... how could you ignore the issue of racism and asylum? And what about housing and homelessness? One brief mention about improving housing! And the only reference to homelessness is about farmers made homeless by the IRA in Northern Ireland?

Putting these issues at the centre of a manifesto and challenging the negative perceptions that permeate the debates on asylum and homelessness - now that would have been truly radical!

Toby Blume
National Homeless Alliance
toby@home-all.org.uk

You don't want Trident replaced, so why advocate wait ing until it is dangerously obsolete? If you think we don't need nuclear weapons in the future (and Trident is our only remaining nuclear weapon), why are they useful now? Wouldn't it be more logical, and useful in giving a shove to global nuclear disarmament, if you advised getting rid of Trident at once?

Harry Davis
Thames Ditton,
Surrey

 We were delighted to see free entry to national museums feature so prominently in your manifesto. You are right to focus on VAT as the main obstacle to achieving this important goal. At present we have the absurd situation whereby museums that charge for admission are regarded as businesses and can recover their VAT, whereas free museums cannot. There is therefore a positive incentive for museums to charge.

Sir Nicholas Goodison
Chairman,
National Art Collections Fund

You declare that the "career civil service" should be replaced with a generic public service which should be "permanent and professional". Perhaps your writers could enlighten us as to how such a body is different from the present civil service.

You also propose introducing "a new cadre of chief executives" into government. I am surprised to see the Guardian advocating such slavish imitation of private companies, when the objective is surely to promote an ethos of effective and responsible public service.

David Frazer
Richmond,
Surrey
DavidFrazer9@netscape.net

Your manifesto fails to mention gay rights even once. No commitment to repeal Section 28, to equalise the age of consent, to repeal sex crimes which apply only to (consenting) gay men, to give equal status to gay relationships in terms of tax, pensions, inheritance and parenting, just to mention a few. In a 40-page manifesto, the human rights of a segment of the electorate are completely ignored.

Efisio Mele and Peter Washer
London
peterwasher@barclays.net

Your manifesto section on health is welcome. Poverty causes ill health. Inequalities make an unhealthier society. Tackling both is essential in order to promote health for all. We also need to combat the anti-health forces. For example, your main section rightly shows the dangers of unregulated water and privatised tube services (Peter Preston, Will Hutton, September 25). Health will not be achieved by stealth. Public health is not safe in private hands.

John Nicholson
Chief executive,
UK Public Health Association
john@ukpha.org.uk

Excuse me? "Policies that absorb women and others into society"? I thought "society" was what we all belonged to, not an elite club. And "why not put a man in charge to maybe do better"... Sir Peter Kemp's language betrays his implicit conviction that "women and others" need to have something clever done to them, by competent males, to make them absorbable into that part of society that counts: presumably the rich, white and male part.

Hilary Keay
Telford
HilaryKeay@aol.com

I was disappointed to see no mention of investment in cleaner coal technology as well as renewables. The government does not subsidise the coal industry by £100m a year, as the manifesto suggests. There is a subsidy package waiting for approval by the EC which would offer some help over the next two years that might at maximum give the UK coal industry £100m in total. No subsidy has yet been paid and as delays increase, the likelihood of the whole £100m being paid gets smaller as the ECSC treaty runs out in June 2002.

Part of the rationale of asking for a subsidy for the UK industry is that other governments in the EU do subsidise their coal industries. UK coal is by far the cheapest in the EU and it makes no sense to close mines in the UK when much more expensive capacity is kept open elsewhere.

Roger Kojan
Yorkshire Coal Task Force
RKojan@wakefield.gov.uk

Some years ago I read a jokey summary of the political attitudes of people who read particular newspapers. It said that the Guardian is read by people "who think they ought to run the country". Perhaps it is not a joke after all.

Terry Vincent
Woking,
Surrey
terryvincent@email.com

Perhaps your writers could enlighten us as to how such a body is different from the present civil service. You also propose introducing "a new cadre of chief executives" into government. I am surprised to see the Guardian advocating such slavish imitation of private companies, when the objective is surely to promote an ethos of effective and responsible public service. David Frazer Richmond, Surrey DavidFrazer9@netscape.net Your manifesto fails to mention gay rights even once. No commitment to repeal Section 28, to equalise the age of consent, to repeal sex crimes which apply only to (consenting) gay men, to give equal status to gay relationships in terms of tax, pensions, inheritance and parenting, just to mention a few. In a 40-page manifesto, the human rights of a segment of the electorate are completely ignored. Efisio Mele and Peter Washer London peterwasher@barclays.net Your manifesto section on health is welcome. Poverty causes ill health. Inequalities make an unhealthier society. Tackling both is essential in order to promote health for all. We also need to combat the anti-health forces. For example, your main section rightly shows the dangers of unregulated water and privatised tube services (Peter Preston, Will Hutton, September 25). Health will not be achieved by stealth. Public health is not safe in private hands. John Nicholson Chief executive, UK Public Health Association john@ukpha.org.uk Excuse me? "Policies that absorb women and others into society"? I thought "society" was what we all belonged to, not an elite club. And "why not put a man in charge to maybe do better"... Sir Peter Kemp's language betrays his implicit conviction that "women and others" need to have something clever done to them, by competent males, to make them absorbable into that part of society that counts: presumably the rich, white and male part. Hilary Keay Telford HilaryKeay@aol.com I was disappointed to see no mention of investment in cleaner coal technology as well as renewables. The government does not subsidise the coal industry by £100m a year, as the manifesto suggests. There is a subsidy package waiting for approval by the EC which would offer some help over the next two years that might at maximum give the UK coal industry £100m in total. No subsidy has yet been paid and as delays increase, the likelihood of the whole £100m being paid gets smaller as the ECSC treaty runs out in June 2002. Part of the rationale of asking for a subsidy for the UK industry is that other governments in the EU do subsidise their coal industries. UK coal is by far the cheapest in the EU and it makes no sense to close mines in the UK when much more expensive capacity is kept open elsewhere. Roger Kojan Yorkshire Coal Task Force RKojan@wakefield.gov.uk Some years ago I read a jokey summary of the political attitudes of people who read particular newspapers. It said that the Guardian is read by people "who think they ought to run the country". Perhaps it is not a joke after all. Terry Vincent Woking, Surrey terryvincent@email.com

fields.headline: Delia's delights
fields.standfirst:
Her fellow TV chefs aren't among them

Knives out as Delia the bitch bites back
Who's cooking? TV's army of chefs
fields.trailText: The oven gloves are off and the temperature has already reached regulo 8 as Britain's TV chefs exchange insults with all the dedication of athletes pitching for Olympic gold. In the heats, Anthony Worrall-Thompson of BBC2's Food and Drink programme described Delia Smith - whose frying pan sometimes seems to have a halo around it - as the Volvo of cooking (ie reliable but dull).
fields.body:
The oven gloves are off and the temperature has already reached regulo 8 as Britain's TV chefs exchange insults with all the dedication of athletes pitching for Olympic gold. In the heats, Anthony Worrall-Thompson of BBC2's Food and Drink programme described Delia Smith - whose frying pan sometimes seems to have a halo around it - as the Volvo of cooking (ie reliable but dull). Meanwhile, Gary Rhodes, the only chef who can beat eggs with his headset, described her How to Cook series as an insult to viewers because it told them how to boil eggs.

These remarks have been marinating angrily inside St Delia for months until, by some form of spontaneous combustion, they suddenly set her on fire this week. She said: "I hate Gary Rhodes's programmes and I think that Anthony Worrall-Thompson is worse: he is dreadful, just repulsive." She described the show's former wine buff, Jilly Goolden, as "awful". She also revealed that she liked shouting: "Stand up if you hate the scum", a remark that might until this week have been thought to refer to taking the waste from the top of clarified butter: but, no, it is a taunt that the former saint shouts from the terraces about Ipswich Town, a rival football team to her beloved Norwich.

As spats go that between the best selling cookery writer and her male rivals has a lot more going for it - at least in terms of therapeutic value - than the repressed feelings harboured by the prime minister and the chancellor about each other. Maybe they should do a Delia and get it all off their chests in public. Meanwhile, there is one way to end the feud. Lock the chefs into the premises vacated by the Big Brother team, and don't let them out until the public has judged the winner of a competition for a recipe that none of them has yet proved capable of making: an old English dish made from the heart, liver and kidneys of a deer, given to servants while their masters dined on the prime cuts. 'Umble pie.

webTitle: Jay's bid for country credibility backfires

fields.headline: Jay's bid for country credibility backfires
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Lady Jay yesterday claimed she was in touch with the countryside as she had a "little cottage" she visited most weekends.
fields.body:
Lady Jay yesterday claimed she was in touch with the countryside as she had a "little cottage" she visited most weekends.

Labour's leader in the Lords was accused by the Tories of being "arrogant and snooty" after an attempt to prove she understood rural problems, including fuel prices, backfired.

Lady Jay told BBC TV's conference programme that the government opposed protests but was sympathetic to the plight of country dwellers.

And the peer, who has cottages in Oxfordshire and Cork, said she knew of the problems through her weekend breaks.

Her comments, as Countryside Alliance demonstrated in Brighton, followed a fierce attack on the "contorted faces" of the protesters by the deputy prime minister John Prescott, who has also insisted that he knows rural Britain.

"John Prescott made a very vivid reference to how, as a small child he was taken to the Lake District and how this opened his eyes to the beauties and importance of the countryside," she said. "We've all had those experiences. I have a little cottage in the country that I enjoy enormously. I'm not anti countryside, but I am anti vested interests."

Lady Jay sparked a row this year when she said she went to a "pretty standard" school. In fact, her alma mater, Blackheath high school, was not part of the state system.

The Oxfordshire cottage that Lady Jay, who was born in south-east London, visits most frequently was inherited by her husband from his parents.

Tim Collins, Tory MP for rural Westmorland and Lonsdale, said Lady Jay's remarks "show she is determined to keep her title as the most arrogant and snooty member of the government".

A Countryside Alliance spokesman said: "The countryside is the workplace for hundreds of thousands of people. It's a lot more than a weekend retreat for politicians."

webTitle: Sci seeks a date with destiny

fields.headline: Sci seeks a date with destiny
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: The company responsible for computer games such as Carmageddon for PlayStation and Thunderbird for Gameboy is getting romantic.
fields.body:
The company responsible for computer games such as Carmageddon for PlayStation and Thunderbird for Gameboy is getting romantic.

Sci Entertainment Group, the London-based computer games publisher, yesterday announced that it is going to become a matchmaker by starting a service called findablinddate.com.

The company is diversifying to take advantage of the increasing number of mobile phone users.

"What we want to do is to use the technology available to give people an entertainment experience," said Rob Murphy, finance director of Sci.

The service is the most recent product to be created by the groups mobile media division.

Findablinddate.com will match romantics with their perfect partners by profiling the personal details that the user enters into the system and letting people know when a match turns up.

The user can then choose with whom to arrange a blind date. The service can also connect secret admirers with a "Who fancies who?" feature.

"Findablinddate.com is about fun and communication and will have a huge entertainment appeal," said Mark Knutton, Sci's mobile media chief operating officer.

The service, targeted at people aged between 16 and 30, will be able to connect 30m mobile phone users in Britain by Wap, email or the internet 24 hours a day.

fields.headline: Falconer admits mistakes on dome
fields.standfirst:
Guardian debate 'Real concerns' over expenditure
Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Lord Falconer, the beleaguered dome minister, expressed the government's strongest admission of penitence yet over the controversial structure yesterday - but refused to apologise and insisted he would not be resigning.
fields.body:
Lord Falconer, the beleaguered dome minister, expressed the government's strongest admission of penitence yet over the controversial structure yesterday - but refused to apologise and insisted he would not be resigning.

In a Guardian debate entitled Has Labour forgotten its roots?, the QC and close friend of the prime minister admitted the government had "made mistakes" in building the attraction and confessed: "I accept it hasn't been the success that people wanted."

Speaking after a new report suggested accountants cast doubt on the Millennium Dome's viability three years ago, he continued: "I also accept that there have been real concerns about the way it [the decision to build it] was reached in the first place and whether the money was handled in the right way"

But he insisted: "We did it with the best possible motives and we did it in a way which has brought jobs and regeneration."

The minister's muted confession - which he later insisted did not mean he would be resigning - was backed up by the culture minister Chris Smith, who, questioned about what he would have changed in the past five years with the benefit of hindsight, admitted: "We almost certainly would have made a different decision about the dome."

Yesterday, the spectre of the dome returned to haunt the party after the Today programme claimed that accountancy firm Deloitte and Touche had warned the Millennium Commission its target of 12m visitors would be difficult to achieve and recommended a lower target of 8m.

Yesterday the Millennium Commission was quick to deny the claims, with a spokesman insisting Deloitte and Touche had advised them the 12m target was "achievable", while 8m was a "worst-case scenario".

After the debate, Lord Falconer said he had no information about the reports.

But, at the debate, the outspoken backbencher, Robert Marshall-Andrews, brought the subject to the fore when he suggested the dome typified the government's "arrogance" since decisions about its funding were made by an "unelected, unaccountable committee."

He added: "As long as these kind of mechanics exist people will believe the political process is being treated with contempt."

The MP for Medway suggested that the reason for the government's unpopularity was not its refusal to cut fuel taxes, and not even in its stance on pensions, but its "contempt for democracy and the corruption of politics." He attacked the prime minister for only attending 4% of Commons votes.

The contentious issue of the London mayor Ken Livingstone was also brought up at the debate, when one delegate suggested he should be readmitted into the party despite standing against Frank Dobson, Labour's candidate.

Mr Smith said it was probable "in due course", but reminded delegates: "This is someone who has stood against and defeated a Labour party candidate and that is not something to be dismissed lightly."

But Alan Simpson, MP for Nottingham South, insisted: "If we can vote Paddy Ashdown into the cabinet, we can have Ken Livingstone in the party."

webTitle: Good day bad day in Brighton

fields.headline: Good day bad day in Brighton
fields.trailText: Good day undoubtedly for iron chancellor Gordon Brown. He must have been flushed with pride after getting a four-minute standing ovation from delegates. But perhaps schemers among Labour's ranks may have detected another reason for his happiness. Peter Mandelson's "graveyard" speech warming up conference yesterday morning was received with lukewarm enthusiasm with barely a bottom stirring from its seat.
fields.body:
Yesterday

Good day

Good day undoubtedly for iron chancellor Gordon Brown. He must have been flushed with pride after getting a four-minute standing ovation from delegates. But perhaps schemers among Labour's ranks may have detected another reason for his happiness. Peter Mandelson's "graveyard" speech warming up conference yesterday morning was received with lukewarm enthusiasm with barely a bottom stirring from its seat.

Bad day

Another one for the pensioners. Barbara Windsor, actor and screen barmaid of the Queen Vic pub in EastEnders, was due to address pensioners at a rally yesterday lunchtime. But the soap superstar was forced to cancel citing "work commitments" for her lack of attendance. One disgruntled observer noted: "It was all a bit of a carry on."

Quote of the day

Rodney Bickerstaffe, the general secretary of the public services union Unison:

"Pensioners don't want to see the letters DNR (Do Not Resuscitate) on the end of their hospital beds, and we don't want to see DNR on the bottom of the basic state pension."

Delegate of the day

Godfrey Xuereb, 38, a dietician and deputy international secretary of the Malta Labour party.

"Gordon Brown showed that he's still the best person to run the economy and he also showed a lighter side which he's not normally known for, joking about William Hague's 14 pints and being very humorous about Michael Portillo.

The standing ovation he got showed that his speech definitely overshadowed the events of last week - and that the grassroots here haven't really bothered about Rawnsley's book.

John Prescott's speech was very encouraging and I went to a very good lunchtime fringe meeting with Alan Milburn. I thought he was very courageous because he only spoke for a couple of minutes and then threw open the room to questions. He was favourably received and it was completely packed with hardly any standing room."

Decision of the day

The government signalled it will try again to repeal section 28, which prevents promotion of homosexuality.

Local government minister Hilary Armstrong described the issue at Labour's conference as "unfinished business.

"Let's not forget it's the Tories who try to stigmatise the entire gay community.

"They used the unelected House of Lords to frustrate our determination to repeal section 28 and to build a society which is more tolerant," she said.

Today

11.00am: Britain in the world debate with Robin Cook, Geoff Hoon and Clare Short

2.30pm : Tony Blair makes his leader's speech

7.30pm : The left is on parade at the Tribune rally

NEC ballot results.

webTitle: Waiter 'intended to take kidnapped schoolboy home'

fields.headline: Waiter 'intended to take kidnapped schoolboy home'
fields.trailText: A waiter accused of falsely imprisoning a schoolboy and blackmailing his parents yesterday told a jury he had intended to take the boy home.
fields.body:
A waiter accused of falsely imprisoning a schoolboy and blackmailing his parents yesterday told a jury he had intended to take the boy home.

Malaysian Vui-Kiong Wong, 30, of no fixed address, who denies false imprisonment and blackmail, told Norwich crown court he had not been involved in kidnapping the unidentified 14-year-old in November 1999.

The youngster was lured into a car by three men outside the King's school, Ely, Cambridgeshire, then held for three days in Barking, Essex, the court heard. His kidnappers demanded £250,000 then £100,000 from his parents, who live in Cambridgeshire, during a series of telephone calls, and talked of Triads.

Police found the youngster unharmed with Wong and three other men in a car in Barking. They also found a 56lb weight, rope and plastic cable, the court heard.

But Wong said he was not in volved in snatching the boy and only discovered that he was being held when he visited a friend in Barking. He said he intended to take the boy home.

Wong told police: "They were going to tie the boy up with the weight on his foot so that he could not run away." Wong admitted that a month earlier the group had "jokingly" talked of snatching the boy.

Three other Malaysian men - Chon-Kiong Hong, 29, of no fixed address, Vui-Tshung Thien, 23, of Barking, and his brother, Vui-Kiun Thien, 29, of no fixed address - have admitted false imprisonment and blackmail. The trial continues.

fields.headline: Missing student survives jungle adventure
fields.standfirst: British teenager emerges after a three-week battle with waterfalls and whirlpools during solo trek through Bolivian wilderness
fields.trailText: A British student who disappeared in Bolivia for more than three weeks during a solo jungle trek escaped with his life after being thrown over a waterfall, sucked into a whirlpool and trapped on a cliff ledge until his rations ran out.
fields.body:
A British student who disappeared in Bolivia for more than three weeks during a solo jungle trek escaped with his life after being thrown over a waterfall, sucked into a whirlpool and trapped on a cliff ledge until his rations ran out.

Luke Dance was yesterday recovering in hospital in the capital La Paz. Last night his father, Michael, 48, who was reunited with his son at the British embassy, told of a catalogue of misfortune which saw the Loughborough University student lose two stone and suffer leg injuries.

Problems for the 19-year-old, from Crawley, West Sussex, began soon after he started a solo trek in the Yungas, a region of lush sub-tropical valleys in Bolivia which is known for its spectacular trekking.

"He ended up on the wrong path and lost his footing in the mud," his father explained. "The weight of his backpack took him over the side and he fell into a river - about a 12ft drop. He could not climb out as it was too steep. He ended up falling over a 15ft waterfall.

"He was drawn into a whirlpool where he was trapped for a while. His backpack saved him because it was full of air."

Upon finding dry land, Mr Dance realised he could no longer continue as he faced a further 30ft waterfall, his father said.

"He built a camp and made some equipment to try to signal to passers-by on the road. He was there for just over two weeks. In the end he was no nearer to getting help - and his food had run out.

"He decided he would have to shed excessive weight to get over the falls - which he did. He went through several waterfalls and rapids for two days before he could get out of the water and make his way to the nearest village."

Mr Dance's mother, Lynn Coleman, 45, last night said she had spoken to her son from their home and was relieved to hear that he was safe and sound.

"He sounded like he just wanted to come home to his family and get back to university this weekend," she said.

"He's a little bit battered and bruised, he told me he slipped off the track and fell down a mountainside. He said he couldn't manage to climb back up and it just took him that long to find his way back to civilisation."

Concern for Mr Dance first arose when he failed to meet up with friends from the East Midlands Universities Officer Training Corps in Lima, the Peruvian capital, after his trek. He had been due to fly back to Britain with them on September 15.

Mr Dance, who plans to join the Royal Engineers on graduation in 2002, had contacted his family from an internet cafe in La Paz on August 29, two days before leaving his friends and setting off on his trek.

He told his father he intended to travel alone for the last leg of his eight-week trip.

His father, a manager with the gas company BOC, flew to Bolivia with 500 posters of his missing son on Saturday while a website appeal was set up from Britain.

Mr Dance, a management science student, had already felt a number of adrenaline rushes on his Latin American travels - bungee jumping 1,200ft from a hot air balloon, white-water rafting and climbing a 18,000ft mountain.

Foreign Office advice to those travelling in Bolivia is to "be vigilant at all times".

"Recent incidents in La Paz have reflected a trend towards aggressive crimes against foreigners," it said.

"Visitors travelling alone overland are especially vulnerable and are advised to be extremely vigilant."

He went through several waterfalls and rapids for two days before he could get out of the water and make his way to the nearest village." Mr Dance's mother, Lynn Coleman, 45, last night said she had spoken to her son from their home and was relieved to hear that he was safe and sound. "He sounded like he just wanted to come home to his family and get back to university this weekend," she said. "He's a little bit battered and bruised, he told me he slipped off the track and fell down a mountainside. He said he couldn't manage to climb back up and it just took him that long to find his way back to civilisation." Concern for Mr Dance first arose when he failed to meet up with friends from the East Midlands Universities Officer Training Corps in Lima, the Peruvian capital, after his trek. He had been due to fly back to Britain with them on September 15. Mr Dance, who plans to join the Royal Engineers on graduation in 2002, had contacted his family from an internet cafe in La Paz on August 29, two days before leaving his friends and setting off on his trek. He told his father he intended to travel alone for the last leg of his eight-week trip. His father, a manager with the gas company BOC, flew to Bolivia with 500 posters of his missing son on Saturday while a website appeal was set up from Britain. Mr Dance, a management science student, had already felt a number of adrenaline rushes on his Latin American travels - bungee jumping 1,200ft from a hot air balloon, white-water rafting and climbing a 18,000ft mountain. Foreign Office advice to those travelling in Bolivia is to "be vigilant at all times". "Recent incidents in La Paz have reflected a trend towards aggressive crimes against foreigners," it said. "Visitors travelling alone overland are especially vulnerable and are advised to be extremely vigilant."

webTitle: Nappies cause infertility claim stirs controversy

fields.headline: Nappies cause infertility claim stirs controversy
fields.trailText: Plastic-lined disposable nappies may be to blame for the worrying drop in male sperm counts and the increase in testicular cancer in young men, according to research published today.
fields.body:
Plastic-lined disposable nappies may be to blame for the worrying drop in male sperm counts and the increase in testicular cancer in young men, according to research published today.

A team of scientists in Germany found that disposable nappies prevented the natural cooling mechanism in the testes of male babies and toddlers from functioning properly.

They argued, in a paper in the journal Archives of Disease in Childhood, that the rise in temperature of the testes could damage the development of sperm in the long term and possibly make cancer more likely.

The study was immediately attacked by nappy manufacturers. Peter Stephenson, director general of the Absorbent Hygiene Products Manufacturers Association, said: "We believe the study is scientifically flawed and unsound. The conclusions are irresponsible, inappropriate and unreliable."

Some studies of male fertility suggested that it began to fall before the second world war, when disposable nappies had not been invented, he said. The paper would cause "unnecessary alarm for parents".

The authors of the disputed paper, Wolfgang Sippell and colleagues from the department of paediatrics at the University of Kiel, pointed out that previous studies had shown a decline in the quality of human sperm.

Environmental changes, such as increased use of hormone-disrupting chemicals, have been blamed, but heating of the scrotum, through tight-fitting underwear, sedentary jobs and the effects of saunas have also been implicated.

The German researchers used tiny temperature monitors located within 48 babies' and toddlers nappies to assess whether the disposable, plastic-lined variety which are now in common use affected temperature more than traditional cotton nappies. The children ranged in age from five premature babies to a boy of four and a half years old.

The children wore disposable nappies for one period of 24 hours and cotton nappies for a second day and night. The monitors recorded their scrotal temperature, which has been shown to be reasonably similar to testicular temperature, every 30 seconds.

When they wore the disposable nappies, scrotal temperatures were significantly higher - up to 1C higher than in cotton nappies - with the highest temperatures recorded in the youngest babies.

Rectal temperatures were, as would be expected, higher than scrotal temperatures, but in 13 babies, there was no difference - which meant, said the authors, that the normal testicular cooling mechanism had failed completely.

They said that more work was needed to prove or disprove their hypothesis. Disposable nappies were introduced 25 years ago.

They suggested studying the fertility of men in west Germany whose parents had access to them, and those in east Germany, whose parents did not.

Harvey Marcovitch, editor of the journal, defended publication of the study against the critics in the nappy industry. "The authors are not claiming this is the cause of infertility but that it might be one of the causes."

webTitle: Swedish firm deals blow to British-backed dam project

fields.headline: Swedish firm deals blow to British-backed dam project
fields.trailText: An international Swedish construction firm which was one of the leading partners in the controversial project to build the Ilisu dam in eastern Turkey has pulled out of the scheme in order to protect its environmental reputation.
fields.body:
An international Swedish construction firm which was one of the leading partners in the controversial project to build the Ilisu dam in eastern Turkey has pulled out of the scheme in order to protect its environmental reputation.

The decision by Skanska, which had a 24% stake in the project, is a body blow to the seven-company consortium led by the British firm Balfour Beatty, which has a 31% stake. All of the companies had asked for the export credit guarantee agencies of their countries to fund their part of the work.

The project has become the focus of a global campaign by environmental and human rights groups, who claim that up to 25,000 Kurds would see their homes disappear below the dam's reservoir and that it would potentially cut the flow of the river Tigris into Syria and Iraq.

Officially, the government has yet to decide whether to continue to back the project with taxpayers' money but Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, and Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, are both against its construction on ethical grounds.

The prime minister, Tony Blair, overruled their objec tions and has said that the government "was minded to back the project".

Yesterday the news that Skanska had pulled out was revealed at the Labour party conference in Brighton in a leak that was intended to embarrass Mr Blair in showing that a company with a worldwide reputation for respecting the environment had pulled out of a project that he still appears to favour.

The Department of Trade and Industry would only say yesterday that no decision had been made on the dam and that "Balfour Beatty has assured us their application for £200m credit remains live".

Thor Krussel, a spokesman for Skanska, said he was contractually obliged not to speak to the press about the Ilisu dam. However, he pointed to a recent updating of the company's environmental statement by the firm's president and chief executive Claes Bjork, which says: "Caring about people and the environment must permeate all of our work.

"Skanska will abstain from participating in construction projects when in our judgment a project will result in serious risks to the environment or to society at large."

Balfour Beatty confirmed that Skanska had pulled out of the consortium but said the decision was down to contractual disagreements and not the environment.

Environmental pressure groups, which have been campaigning against the dam, were delighted at the news. Tony Juniper from Friends of the Earth said: "A company with a good environmental record like Skanska, which wants to retain it, clearly cannot afford to go near a project like Ilisu.

"Balfour Beatty on the other hand with such schemes as the Pergau dam, in Malaysia, and the Cardiff Bay barrage, in Wales, has got nothing to defend and is going ahead."

Nick Hilyard, from the environmental think tank Corner House, said "This is excellent news, it will be a big factor in the scheme's demise."

He added that the Swedish pullout coincided with news from Turkey that the country's existing dam schemes on the Euphrates river in the same region were in serious trouble.

The water level was so low because of drought that the dams were virtually unable to produce electricity - although they were supposed to provide one fifth of the nation's supply. Reports said that even with normal rains it will take four to five years for the dams to reach normal capacity.

webTitle: After the party comes the real challenge: the public

fields.headline: After the party comes the real challenge: the public
fields.standfirst:
Brown has soothed and wooed a traumatised conference
Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: The Labour party spent most of yesterday talking to itself. This isn't usually an advisable activity for a political party. The collective celebration of triumph is always disastrous, as may well be shown at Bournemouth next week, when the Conservatives nourish each other's passing delusions of grandeur regardless of the world outside.
fields.body:
The Labour party spent most of yesterday talking to itself. This isn't usually an advisable activity for a political party. The collective celebration of triumph is always disastrous, as may well be shown at Bournemouth next week, when the Conservatives nourish each other's passing delusions of grandeur regardless of the world outside. But for Labour in Brighton, it was a necessary exercise. The party has suffered an unimaginable shock. It was in trauma. It doesn't know what happened. It needed reassurance that the world isn't about to come to an end.

Its bewilderment is justified. I haven't spoken to a single soul who really claims to understand why public opinion stands where it seems to at this moment. That goes for Tory as well as Labour people whose job it is to know. The job is harder because the switch in the polls, though fast and wide, does not seem to be deep. It's difficult for anyone to believe that the voters have made a settled decision to jettison the Labour government. No sea-change is apparent, only a sudden redirection of the swirling shallows. Yet this doesn't diminish the fear, never far below the surface of old Labour psyches, that the tide may turn against them.

The leadership's response yesterday was unambiguous. It steadied the ship by insisting it would not change direction. It summoned the party to keep its nerve, reminding it of why it came to power in the first place. Called on to repent of its famous arrogance, it made no apology for anything it had done. The reassurance it offered was to lead and not to bend. The recent fashion has been to present it with the choice between listening and leading: is this a focus group or a principle that I see before me? Its answer to the party was surprisingly categoric. It will listen, but is quite determined not to become as fickle or frenetic as the public in the world outside.

After all, it is the governing party. Ministers are still doing big things that transcend the froth and gossip that unwary newspaper readers might imagine to be the alpha and omega of the government's existence. They're about more than spin and headlines. That was the message. By mid-afternoon it had proved to be the correct strategic choice. Trauma had absorbed its therapy, and vanished.

The first message came, as if to emphasise its novelty, from Peter Mandelson. The man commonly cast as the ace of spinners, the source of all bitching, made a serious speech about Northern Ireland. At first the response was tepid. Mr Mandelson has never been a favourite at even the most laundered of New Labour conferences. But slowly they warmed to him. Here was a minister presiding over important business, laying into the forces of bigotry who would overturn it, delivering something the Tories could never do. Though there was no danger of a standing ovation, the extended applause signalled the looming of reassurance.

Next up was John Prescott. Again the story was all about delivery, beginning with the delivery of a speech containing more sentences that parsed than Mr Prescott has ever given. Within his impossibly spacious brief, there was nothing the deputy prime minister wasn't delivering, and he reeled off lists of achievement that most of the party had long forgotten - if, indeed, they had ever been fully aware of them. Mr Prescott was listening - but mainly to the massive applause he got for a rededication to the fight against fox-hunting. The Countryside Alliance, the petrol blockaders and all other forces of conservatism were told not to mess with a Labour government. You could hear relief settling over a lot of rattled people.

Yet these ministers were but the prelude. Gordon Brown arrived from Prague, with a speed that shows how things have changed in a quarter of a century. In 1976, Denis Healey abandoned the International Monetary Fund to come and treat in desperation with the Labour party. This year, Mr Brown favours the Labour party with a mere 12 hours before returning to the IMF. He didn't waste his moment. His speech registered a disdain for the party's petty tribulations which the party was only too delighted to hear.

Instead of rounding on him for his inflexibility, it gave deep-throated cheers for the association he was offering the rank and file with his grand long-termist project. He was at his most seigneurial, vowing to listen, but implying there was no conceivable contradiction between this performance and the unflinching pursuit of his objectives. The best way he could serve "the hard-working people of Britain" (aka Labour voters), he said, was by sticking to the strategy he had laid down for the years and not the weeks.

Mr Brown pleased the conference enormously. He talked it into a spirit of almost total reassurance. With resonant declarations about the commitment to raising pensions, who could deny that he continued to speak reliably for the soul of the party? It is also notable how uncontrived his speeches seem. Compared with all the rough drafts, fine rewrites, minute calibrations and neurotic all-night knitting that has gone into every leader's conference speech from Thatcher to Blair, this one seemed hewn out of stone that its maker did not need to search far to find. The party's day of talking to itself had done the job.

This does not, however, entirely solve the problem. The party is necessary, but it is not sufficient. Playing from strength, insisting on strategy, asserting authority, this was undoubtedly the right response to the crisis of ap parent fickleness. But the dangers remain. The shallows do still swirl. The public no longer gives governments the benefit of much doubt. It's prepared to punish errors that hurt it, like the petrol blockade, or blunders that scandalise it, like the dome, with a severity unmitigated by larger allegiances that in different times could be relied on to raise the threshold of toleration.

Labour happens to be governing at a time when the electorate's cynicism has much increased. The party may not have promised too many unwise specifics in 1997, but it unleashed an enormous promise of the spirit. It was cautious in particular, but ecstatic in general. It therefore made millions of people who were not part of yesterday's conversation believe great things would happen. Since many of these have not yet happened, the public's impatience, goaded by the personal rivalries and cabinet divisions they seem to see before them, races towards swift, if temporary, conclusions.

Gordon Brown exuded disdain for such pettinesses. He's interested in higher things. He carried the party aloft, to recall its social mission as well as its exceptional economic record. The party listened, and steadied itself. But today there will be another speech, which needs to be addressed to a different audience. Brown is the party man, but Blair is the national man. His, I think, is much the greater challenge.

webTitle: Analysis: The world needs Iraq's oil

fields.headline: Saddam's trump card
fields.standfirst:
The world needs Iraq's oil as never before - and the Iraqi president seems certain to exact whatever concessions he can for it
Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: There is nothing like an oil crisis to spread feelings of empowerment around the Middle East. Last week even Palestinians - whose only oil comes from olives - were suggesting that here was a weapon their friends could use to further the struggle with Israel.
fields.body:
There is nothing like an oil crisis to spread feelings of empowerment around the Middle East. Last week even Palestinians - whose only oil comes from olives - were suggesting that here was a weapon their friends could use to further the struggle with Israel.

Suddenly everyone in the region is aware of how much the world depends on them. The Middle East holds two-thirds of the world's proven oil reserves and, at current rates of production, it will last for 87 years, compared with 14 years for North American oil and eight years for European. And our dependence on the Middle East is increasing. The US Department of Energy predicts that 10 years from now the region will be called upon to produce about 30% more oil.

Given the political uncertainties in the region, the risks are obvious. Among the Middle Eastern producers, Saudi Arabia is way ahead of the rest, providing 12% of the world's oil and holding more than a quarter of the known reserves. It is the only country capable of influencing prices single-handed, by turning the taps on and off - or it was until recently.

In return for exercising this power responsibly, the west guarantees Saudi Arabia's security and doesn't complain too loudly about its record on human rights.

But now this arrangement faces a challenge from Iraq. Following the recent Opec production increases, Iraqi production - currently just over 3m barrels a day - exceeds the world's readily available spare capacity. If supplies from Iraq were interrupted, by accident or design, havoc would ensue.

On its own, that makes Iraq no different from other producers of similar size - Iran, Norway and Venezuela, for example - though it's worth noting that Iraq is one of the six largest suppliers to the United States. But in combination with Iraq's pariah status and the unpredictability of Saddam Hussein, it is potentially devastating.

"Five years ago, the Iraqi president, in his most fantastic dreams, never thought he would find himself in the position he is in today," says Jareer Elass of the Washington-based Oil Navigator consultancy. "Tight oil markets, a world weary of sanctions, and an American presidential election - there's no way Saddam is going to let this pass."

Chance has delivered Saddam a powerful weapon, and it is easy to see how he might use it: to end sanctions (on Iraq's terms), roll back the no-fly zones, and get out of paying several hundred billion dollars in Gulf war compensation. "The Iraqis are trying to bargain with the UN and oil companies to keep oil production going in exchange for a pledge to remove sanctions," a Kuwaiti official said last week.

But Iraq may be in less of a mood for bargaining than for testing UN-imposed restrictions to destruction in the belief that a world desperate for Iraqi oil, and suffering from sanctions fatigue, will be powerless to resist.

The re-opening of Baghdad airport and the arrival of the first Russian and French flights is one crack that Iraq hopes to widen while the oil crisis lasts. "Once we have regular civilian flights from Moscow, Amman and Paris, sanctions will be at an end," an Iraqi spokesman said.

There are several other chinks. Earlier this month an Iraqi military plane infringed Saudi airspace for the first time in more than a decade, and there have been Iraqi incursions into the demilitarised sea zone off Kuwait.

The success or otherwise of Saddam's strategy will depend on whether he can convince the world that he really would turn off the taps if it came to the crunch. Western analysts generally dismiss the idea on the grounds that he would be punishing himself by cutting off his only significant source of income.

But it might not be so costly for Saddam. The high oil prices of the last few months, plus recent production increases, have given him a cash windfall. Estimates vary, but it could be enough to see Iraq through several weeks - possibly even a couple of months - of zero oil revenue.

A second factor to bear in mind is that Iraq stands to lose less from cutting off its oil than other producers. The regime receives only half the total revenue from its oil production; the UN deducts the rest to pay compensation to Gulf war victims, feed Kurdish areas of Iraq, and to meet administration costs of the oil-for-food programme.

If Iraq did decide to cut off supplies, the time of maximum impact would probably be at the end of October - just before the US presidential election. But there are problems with that. Under the current phase of the oil-for-food programme, Iraq is contracted to supply oil until December 4. Saddam might not be unduly worried by the legalities, but he does have to consider his long-term business relationships with the oil companies.

It would be easier to turn off the taps in December, but by then the impact might be less because increased Opec production would have begun to replenish stockpiles.

In either case, Iraq would need a plausible reason and, even if it found one, would risk losing the goodwill which it has carefully built up with countries such as France over the past 10 years.

Psychologically, the oil weapon is very similar to a nuclear bomb because it tends to harm the user as well as the victim: its effectiveness lies in threatening to use it but not actually doing so.

That requires subtle and precisely calculated tactics, which may be beyond Saddam's capability. The risks are certainly high and he may eventually back off. But, given the region's dominance of the oil markets, he will probably not be the last person to try.

Among the Middle Eastern producers, Saudi Arabia is way ahead of the rest, providing 12% of the world's oil and holding more than a quarter of the known reserves. It is the only country capable of influencing prices single-handed, by turning the taps on and off - or it was until recently. In return for exercising this power responsibly, the west guarantees Saudi Arabia's security and doesn't complain too loudly about its record on human rights. But now this arrangement faces a challenge from Iraq. Following the recent Opec production increases, Iraqi production - currently just over 3m barrels a day - exceeds the world's readily available spare capacity. If supplies from Iraq were interrupted, by accident or design, havoc would ensue. On its own, that makes Iraq no different from other producers of similar size - Iran, Norway and Venezuela, for example - though it's worth noting that Iraq is one of the six largest suppliers to the United States. But in combination with Iraq's pariah status and the unpredictability of Saddam Hussein, it is potentially devastating. "Five years ago, the Iraqi president, in his most fantastic dreams, never thought he would find himself in the position he is in today," says Jareer Elass of the Washington-based Oil Navigator consultancy. "Tight oil markets, a world weary of sanctions, and an American presidential election - there's no way Saddam is going to let this pass." Chance has delivered Saddam a powerful weapon, and it is easy to see how he might use it: to end sanctions (on Iraq's terms), roll back the no-fly zones, and get out of paying several hundred billion dollars in Gulf war compensation. "The Iraqis are trying to bargain with the UN and oil companies to keep oil production going in exchange for a pledge to remove sanctions," a Kuwaiti official said last week. But Iraq may be in less of a mood for bargaining than for testing UN-imposed restrictions to destruction in the belief that a world desperate for Iraqi oil, and suffering from sanctions fatigue, will be powerless to resist. The re-opening of Baghdad airport and the arrival of the first Russian and French flights is one crack that Iraq hopes to widen while the oil crisis lasts. "Once we have regular civilian flights from Moscow, Amman and Paris, sanctions will be at an end," an Iraqi spokesman said. There are several other chinks. Earlier this month an Iraqi military plane infringed Saudi airspace for the first time in more than a decade, and there have been Iraqi incursions into the demilitarised sea zone off Kuwait. The success or otherwise of Saddam's strategy will depend on whether he can convince the world that he really would turn off the taps if it came to the crunch. Western analysts generally dismiss the idea on the grounds that he would be punishing himself by cutting off his only significant source of income. But it might not be so costly for Saddam. The high oil prices of the last few months, plus recent production increases, have given him a cash windfall. Estimates vary, but it could be enough to see Iraq through several weeks - possibly even a couple of months - of zero oil revenue. A second factor to bear in mind is that Iraq stands to lose less from cutting off its oil than other producers. The regime receives only half the total revenue from its oil production; the UN deducts the rest to pay compensation to Gulf war victims, feed Kurdish areas of Iraq, and to meet administration costs of the oil-for-food programme. If Iraq did decide to cut off supplies, the time of maximum impact would probably be at the end of October - just before the US presidential election. But there are problems with that. Under the current phase of the oil-for-food programme, Iraq is contracted to supply oil until December 4. Saddam might not be unduly worried by the legalities, but he does have to consider his long-term business relationships with the oil companies. It would be easier to turn off the taps in December, but by then the impact might be less because increased Opec production would have begun to replenish stockpiles. In either case, Iraq would need a plausible reason and, even if it found one, would risk losing the goodwill which it has carefully built up with countries such as France over the past 10 years. Psychologically, the oil weapon is very similar to a nuclear bomb because it tends to harm the user as well as the victim: its effectiveness lies in threatening to use it but not actually doing so. That requires subtle and precisely calculated tactics, which may be beyond Saddam's capability. The risks are certainly high and he may eventually back off. But, given the region's dominance of the oil markets, he will probably not be the last person to try. analysis@theguardian.com

webTitle: Loophole could let gay couples have own babies, says scientist

fields.headline: Loophole could let gay couples have own babies, says scientist
fields.trailText: An obscure recommendation in a government report could pave the way for gay and lesbian couples legally to conceive children together, it has been claimed.
fields.body:
An obscure recommendation in a government report could pave the way for gay and lesbian couples legally to conceive children together, it has been claimed.

Calum MacKellar, an Edinburgh-based biochemist and ethicist, argues that the recent Donaldson report on human cloning and embryonic cell research opened up a legal loophole allowing same-sex conception, and that science could soon catch up with it.

But an authority in the field said yesterday that the research breakthroughs needed to allow gay or lesbian couples to become biological parents of children were too far away for the government to think about changing the law.

The Donaldson report will form the basis for any changes to the law. One of its little noticed recommendations is that the technology involved in Dolly the sheep style animal cloning should be used to help women with defective eggs to become pregnant.

Under this system, gene-carrying chromosomes would be removed from the nucleus of a woman's defective egg and placed inside a donor egg which had had its genetic material removed. Sperm from the woman's partner would be used to fertilise the egg.

Since this is not cloning, it has attracted little controversy. But Dr MacKellar claims it could be interpreted as allowing the creation of "male eggs", where the chromosomes from sperm are used instead of genetic material from a woman's egg. A second man's sperm would then fertilise the egg.

But Azim Surani, of the Institute of Cancer and Developmental Biology in Cambridge, said nature had placed a barrier in the way of two fathers or two mothers conceiving children together which for the foreseeable future looked insurmountable.

"If you try to make an embryo with two paternal sets of genes, these embryos will die very shortly after birth," said Professor Surani. "You cannot get a viable offspring under any circumstances if you only have a paternal contribution. You really do require a contribution from the mother."

A spokesman for the Department of Health said: "If at some point in the future this becomes a practical possibility, the expert group may want to further consider the issues which may be raised."

webTitle: Midas iTouch  Profits rise wrongfoots critics

fields.headline: Midas iTouch  Profits rise wrongfoots critics
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Wireless internet group iTouch defied the cynics yesterday with a 56% increase in revenues in the second quarter of the year, writes David Teather .
fields.body:
Wireless internet group iTouch defied the cynics yesterday with a 56% increase in revenues in the second quarter of the year .

The business, which is controlled by Tony O'Reilly's Independent News & Media, provides content and services to mobile phone customers through short messaging and Wap.

Group revenues were a shade under £1.3m, with pre-tax losses for the period widening to £1.8m. The company said the rate of revenue growth was likely to continue in the second half of the year.

ITouch shares climbed more than 5% to 67.5p, al though they are still trading below their 70p offer price when the company was floated last month.

Chairman Ivan Fallon, above, said growth had been strongest in the corporate sector, with new clients including BAT and BMW. The fastest growing part of the business is short messaging services, which showed a 150% rise in revenues. ITouch opened its Wap portal in Britain in June, with the most popular sites so far proving to be real-time share prices, news, market indicators, currencies and sport.

ITouch is also established in Ireland, South Africa, Australia, New Zealand and Israel.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Browning Version | Silverado | This Year's Love | A Chinese Ghost Story ll
fields.body:
The Browning Version

(Anthony Asquith, 1951)

11.15am, Carlton Cinema

Michael Redgrave's dignified performance as a petty-tyrant teacher coming to terms with a failed life steers close to the sentimental, particularly in his unlikely final speech to assembly. But this understated screen version of Terence Rattigan's play earns a good B-plus. Jean Kent plays Redgrave's unfaithful wife.

Silverado

(Lawrence Kasdan, 1985)

8pm, FilmFour

The western had come to a halt by the mid-80s, but this spurred a fresh canter. A sort of Magnificent Four - Kevins Kline and Costner, Danny Glover, Scott Glenn - take on bad sheriff of Silverado, Brian Dennehy and his deputies. It's a traditional plot, but exuberantly done, and not half as serious as Kasdan's Wyatt Earp. Less obvious western types such as Jeff Goldblum, Rosanna Arquette and John Cleese provide quirky touches, while Linda Hunt is tough and touching as the bar owner.

This Year's Love

(David Kane, 1998)

10pm, Sky Premier

Kane's engaging comedy covers a year in the love lives of a semi-bohemian Camden Town set, something like a gentler Withnail And I. It opens with the wedding of Danny (Douglas Henshall) and Hannah (Catherine McCormack), but the marriage fails even before they reach the honey moon. She takes up with the erratic, vulnerable Ian Hart; Danny with pub rocker Kathy Burke. Womaniser Dougray Scott and wealthy Jennifer Ehle also cross their paths. An affectionate study of thirtysomethings getting by.

A Chinese Ghost Story ll

(Ching Siu-Tung, 1990)

1.20am, FilmFour

Melding the supernatural with political satire, romance and wild wire Fu action. Cheung finds himself in jail, mistaken for his bearded cellmate. He finally escapes, only to find that with a full beard he now really does resemble him.

fields.headline: My world went mad
fields.standfirst: She missed two episodes of Frasier, but almost got to have tea with Colonel Gadafy. Rebecca Marling Barrie on what happened when her husband was jailed for alleged spying in Liberia
fields.trailText: She missed two episodes of Frasier, but almost got to have tea with Colonel Gadafy. Rebecca Marling Barrie on what happened when her husband was jailed for alleged spying in Liberia
fields.body:
Before my husband was imprisoned in Liberia prison for espionage last month, my knowledge of West Africa was limited to a Blue Peter summer special (circa 1974) when the team went off to the Ivory Coast. I remember it looked beautiful and the team kept saying they were exhilarated. I am now more familiar with African politics and know the names (and some of the telephone numbers) of the area's leaders.

David is a television producer- director. He spent most of last year making a series for Channel 4 about the hairdressing chain, Vidal Sassoon. Early this summer, tired of bobs and shampoo, he accepted a job to make a film about Liberia and its government. He was thrilled to have the chance to go to Africa and tell a big international story.

We spoke several times after he arrived. He told me that filming was difficult and access to President Charles Taylor was being denied, although he had agreed to be interviewed. I began to feel really uncomfortable and my two small boys and I started to count the "sleeps" left before David would be home.

Then I got the call. It was about 9.30pm on Friday August 18. On television, Friends had just finished. I never got to see Frasier. David said his room had been searched and his tapes had been seized but he was OK. There was nothing to worry about. He was on schedule to leave on Sunday and would be home by Monday. But there was something in his voice that I didn't recognise at first. Fear.

Next day, at lunchtime, David's executive producer called to tell me that my husband had been arrested and had spent the night in a police cell. This couldn't be happening. The idea that the sweetest, most innocent man in the world, whose only brush with the law was being drunk in charge of a moped as a student, could be banged up in a Liberian cell was beyond belief.

I rang round friends and family. My father-in-law came round and occupied the boys while I tried to get more information. I called a friend of ours, Roy Ackerman, a South African-born television executive who said he would call his uncle, who knew Nelson Mandela. It sounded like a long shot. Friends started to turn up at the house and a campaign committee formed in my kitchen. We started to lobby the Foreign Office, the United Nations and the World Bank. But by the end of the first day, I knew little other than David was still being detained. I felt utterly powerless.

Somehow, I slept for about five hours. At 6am, I called the production company that had hired David and screamed at the executive producer, whom I had woken. We had a very animated conversation. He was tense and tired and told me to stop "crapping on his head"; he didn't have any more news. At 7am, the Liberian story was the third item on the Radio 4 news. My husband was named. I unplugged the radio and television, preferring news from the ground. At 9am, my sister took my boys to Legoland. I hadn't told them anything. I wanted to keep them in their happy summer-of-fun bubble.

Then my world went mad. I received a call from the Foreign Office telling me that next day David would be charged with espionage and sent to prison.

By lunchtime on Sunday, reality had taken on a whole new look. Nelson Mandela had telephoned President Taylor and asked for the four to be released. This was unbelievable - but there was more to come. Jesse Jackson, the US special African envoy, went live on CNN to plead for David's release. There I was, chain-smoking in the garden of my north London house, and there was Jackson, one of the most influential politicians on the planet, talking on what is arguably the most politically influential television channel on the planet, about my husband and the wellbeing of his family.

Shortly after his appearance on CNN, I was asked by Jackson's office if I would like to give the special envoy a statement or ask any questions. I had five minutes to think about it. We scratched our heads. "What about getting him to sort out your resident's parking?" my father-in-law suggested. Once the nervous laughter died, we dictated a few lines about David, his innocence and his credibility as a film-maker.

I received another call from the Foreign Office, this time asking me to dictate a message that the European consul in Liberia would be able to pass to David. I told him I was strong and fighting, I told him the boys were fine and in Legoland.

The next day, things deteriorated. "The Liberian Four", as the media had named them, were charged and sent to prison. There was talk of a trial in November. I was reassured that the four men were together, separated from other prisoners and in good spirits. The prison was "really clean, for Africa".

Tim Gardam, the director of programmes at Channel 4, called me. In television mythology, this man is a god and people like me don't get to talk to him, let alone shout expletives at him. He was sympathetic and deeply upset. But I still shouted at him: "He's my love, he's my life, you've got to get him home."

My house had turned into a 24- hour drop-in centre for concerned friends and family who comforted, humoured and organised a running buffet of mixed delicacies - pork pies, doughnuts and caviar, all the things people know I love. I couldn't swallow any of it. But boy, could I smoke.

During a late night think-in, our friend Roy came up with the name George Weah - a Manchester City footballer and, apparently, the most famous Liberian in the world. It took me a while to get the power of the footie thing. The influence Beckham would have on Tony Blair, Roy assured me, was not a good comparison.

Then came the Colonel Gadafy connection. A friend in the US had spoken to former president Jimmy Carter who suggested, bizarrely, that I fly to Libya and meet the colonel. Gadafy is apparently close to Taylor and happy to help out in difficult international situations. He would appreciate a personal visit from a wife, I was told. But how could I leave my children?

Wednesday was grim. I got a call saying David had been beaten up. I cracked. I was sick. More calls were made to Mandela and Jackson. A few hours later, Gardam called to say that David hadn't been beaten up. He had been psychologically abused. We agreed to meet the following day.

I took Roy, my sister and my father-in-law with me. We had a brief, but vivid, meeting at Channel 4 and then went to the Foreign Office where our moods were soon lifted. We met James Watt, the head of the consular division. Things, he assured us, were happening. The chairman of Channel 4 had written to Taylor apologising for any action the crew might have taken to cause offence, and undertook not to continue with the film. The four men had also apologised to the Liberian government. The British ambassador to the Ivory Coast was in Monrovia, holding meetings with the Liberian justice minister.

By Friday, mercifully, the combination of apology, international pressure and diplomacy secured the men's release - so I never got to take tea with Gadafy in his tent. The men were flown from Monrovia to the Ivory Coast. David rang me at about 9.30pm - the most welcome phone call I have ever received. But it also threw another episode of Frasier down the tubes.

fields.headline: Answer me
fields.standfirst: Getting personal with... Dermot O'Leary
fields.trailText: Getting personal with... Dermot O'Leary
fields.body:
Full Name:
Sean Dermot Fintan O'Leary

Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why?
My mum used to call me Sean Dermot if I misbehaved.

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why?
Yes, to see Poltergeist III. It wasn't worth it.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts?
Sad, sad, sad, and celibate. Need rescuing now.

What was the last illegal thing you did?
That's for me and my ex-girlfriend to know, you to find out.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did?
I gave a Big Issue seller £5.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with?
Jamie Glazebrook, producer of Light Lunch. Committed, and pays well too.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with?
MH. Nasty, selfish, and self-obsessed.

Has a critic ever made you cry?
Jacques Peretti, reviewing Dog Belearic after the first episode. With his intelligence, he should know that a new series improves during its run.

What would you advertise without a fee?
Guinness - a social and moral element to everyone's lives, and good for pregnant women.

What would you never advertise?
Nescafe.

What wakes you up screaming at four in the morning?
My sister's cats and foxes at the end of the garden.

What takes you to a "happy place"?
Cars and trains.

Dermot O'Leary presents the Barfly Sessions, tomorrow night, 12.40am, Channel 4.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Living By Design | The Sixties
fields.body:
At first Thomas Crapper's invention of the flushing water closet seemed to herald the beginning of a new age, built around new levels of personal and public hygiene. Unfortunately, few considered clearly the disposal of the consequent waste, and we ended up transferring vast amounts of pollution. In Living By Design (3.45pm, Radio 4), James Dyson describes new ways of recycling the 33 gallons we each consign daily to the local sewage system.

Julian Pettifer winds up his survey of The Sixties (9.0pm, Radio 2) with a sombre account of the contrast between the love-not-war spirit of Woodstock and the traumas of the wider world. Race riots scarred 127 US cities, thousands died in the Biafran war, the US lost its 10,000th plane over Vietnam, Robert Kennedy was gunned down, French students tore up Parisian pavements, Russians invaded Czechoslovakia, and Northern Ireland exploded. It really wasn't quite the cosy period of popular myth.

fields.headline: Help yourself
fields.trailText: Louis Theroux's Weird Weekends
fields.body:
Self-fulfilment isn't an easy thing to come by. You work hard. You have a nearest and dearest who loves you and with whom you have a nice home. You go to pleasant restaurants and drink fine wine with your pleasant friends. You have no terminal health problems, no danger lurking in your DNA, no mad relatives locked in attics. You should be happy. You're not.

At least you're not as happy as you should be, someone in your position, and the reason is as mysterious to you as a self-assessment tax return form. You think about walking in front of buses, spitting at people at parties and crushing up 21 paracetamol with your Jamie Oliver-esque pestle and mortar and dissolving them in a bottle of Chablis. You could continue as you are in your nice life, trying not to notice how unfulfilled you are, or you could take the Chablis and liver failure route (quick) or you could get a couple of badly drawn tattoos, drink cider and wish your life away watching Trisha (slow). Or you could do something completely different. You could seek self-fulfilment in Las Vegas.

It sounds like a last-ditch attempt, but shouting "I am fantastic!" several times in a moving vehicle is the first step to achieving everything you want to, being who you want to be. The first in a new series of Louis Theroux's Weird Weekends (BBC2) saw the cheeky, geeky one in Las Vegas seeking out self-fulfilment with the help of hypnotists. It was a joy.

First off was Dennis Lowry, director of the American Academy of Hypnosis. His powers were so awesome, he had managed to hypnotise a caterpillar to lie along his upper lip. (Either that or he had a very bad moustache, the kind normally sported by men who ask children in the park if they want to see some puppies.) Dennis told Louis that the mind is a powerful thing which, if it's harnessed in the correct way, can work miracles. To prove his point, Dennis hypnotised an arthritic dog.

The credentials of Ross, an advocate of the "speed seduction" technique, were more suspect. He had bought an $800 quilt tree for his cat's Christmas. Incredibly, he wasn't gay. Even more incredibly, he was actually successful with women, thanks to his technique which involved going up to women in coffee houses and at supermarkets and asking them what their favourite constellation was. Ross doesn't go to bars, because women go to such places to reject men and get free drinks (but surely not in that order).

Louis was less successful when he tried Ross's MO. "Compliment, introduction, question," Ross sighed, as women ignored Louis on the street. Despite his "I am confident" mantra, Louis looked like the last schoolboy to get picked up at the school gate. You can understand why a lady called Sydney eventually took pity on him and gave him her mobile phone number.

Last on Louis' list for hypnotic help with self-improvement was the doyen of such things, Marshall Sylver. He had very odd hair, which might have been a fleet of caterpillars, all entranced to lie perfectly still atop his head. Marshall had made millions hypnotising people. Not, as you might think, with the "When you wake up, you will give me all your money" approach, but by helping them believe in themselves. He could even make people into millionaires with the power of positive thinking. Louis was too sceptical to be made a millionaire. He had no "mustard seed of faith".

In Marshall's world, you don't say "No problem", you say "No challenge!" If you're diagnosed with cancer, you feel "awesome". His associates quote Yoda and his buzzwords are Passion, Power, Profit. He speaks in capital letters and exclamation marks. It was hard not to dislike Marshall. Especially when he hypnotised a woman, then stood on her. She would have woken up and found footprints on her back but been unable to explain them. Hardly the actions of a nice man.

In his wonderfully understated, deceptively dippy way, Louis exposed these ridiculous men and their practices, summing up poetically: "Would I rather have the truth or a lie that gave me hope? I'd rather have the truth."

As Dennis, Ross and Marshall participated in their own character assassinations - victims with no one to blame but themselves - the gentle genius of Louis Theroux was illuminated. His gift is the gentle ribbing. Extra sensation, don't you know.

fields.headline: Putting her oar in
fields.standfirst: Her husband may be a national hero but Ann Redgrave isn't happy.  Louisa Young  knows why
fields.trailText: Her husband may be a national hero but Ann Redgrave isn't happy. Louisa Young knows why
fields.body:
Behind every great man, they say, is a good woman - a wonderful, patient, sick-to-her-back-teeth woman. I feel for Dr Ann Redgrave, I really do. The whole country is falling about with pride at her husband's exploits and she, a former Olympic rower, is still working, seeing to the family, sorting out all the domestic stuff that never stops, however many Olympic Golds your man has won.

This weekend, she made her feelings clear, telling the press: "I don't think either of us know what the future holds. Hopefully, not a boat." But in saying "Enough already, can we have a family life now or what?" she has been instantly cast as a selfish spoilsport. Can't she understand that national sporting pride is more important than one family's family life? For goodness sake, woman, where's your patriotism?

This national pride bit is an extra burden but many women will recognise the syndrome. He has Something Terribly Important which he has to do on a regular basis and which is not negotiable. Usually it's to do with sport. Sometimes it involves him participating (Redgrave has been training eight hours a day, seven days a week, for half his life) but often enough it is simply watching. Redgrave himself, who had previously invited the world to shoot him if they caught him looking at a boat, is now quoted as saying: "You can assume nothing. It's been made very clear that it's the wife or the boat. The choice has got to be made."

It is a simple question of priorities and what drives so many women mad is the non-negotiability of it. For 99.9% of mothers, seeing that the children have everything they need is number one priority, 24 hours a day. (Yes, even if they're at work. Do we interrupt a meeting if a child breaks a leg? Yes, we do.) After that, for most women comes their partner. It's part of the make-up: why would we want to be with a man we didn't want to make sure was OK?

When sorting out family duties, these two are automatic priorities, whether or not we admit it. Half the time we wouldn't even mention it. Redgrave may say "never assume" but it is assumed. A lot of men (I can't believe I'm saying this, it's so obvious) assume one thing for the woman and another for them. On a non-Olympic everyday domestic level, many believe, for example, that their Tuesday night training or Saturday afternoon spectating is as important as getting the food into the house, keeping the bedding clean or fixing a broken tap. And maybe it is, for keeping happy is important - but it goes both ways.

Here is a sample conversation.

"Could you call the plumber while I try to get the children into bed?"

"I can't, I'm late for training."

"Yes, but the ceiling in the kitchen has fallen in."

"Well, it'll still be fallen in when I get back."

The sneaky thing about this is that the woman becomes cast as the nag. He, the innocent man, who slogs all week and who deserves his bit of relaxation, is being Got At by this harridan who wants to spoil his fun. "She was never going to stop me from doing what I wanted to do," Redgrave said on another occasion. I bet she never wanted to. I bet she just wanted to see him sometimes.

Meanwhile, in an ordinary family, when the woman says: "I want to go to t'ai chi on Tuesday night" he says: "Tuesday night? That's my training night."

"OK," she says. "Friday?"

"Friday night?" he says.

"No," she says. "Friday nights."

"What, every Friday night?"

"Yes." Silence. "I don't think I can be back from work by then."

"Leave a little early," she suggests.

"Can't," he says. "I already leave early for training on a Tuesday."

Yes, she thinks, and have done every Tuesday for the past 10 years. How about my turn?

Nonsense, says my daughter's godfather. Women have far more flexibility in how they use their time. Men just go to work all day and come home knackered. Women are usually in charge of family arrangements: they have far more opportunity to get things done how they want.

Of course nothing great is achieved without sacrifice. And it's desperate to issue an ultimatum. It isn't usually to do with gold medals, but anyway, how many gold medals does one man need? As a weepy ex-husband once said to me: "I may be an award-winning journalist, but I'm not an award-winning father."
