webTitle: A giant leap in confidence from Lupfer

fields.headline: A giant leap in confidence from Lupfer
fields.trailText: Markus Lupfer presented his fourth catwalk show yesterday, with a collection for spring and summer that has secured the approbation of buyers and press alike.
fields.body:
Markus Lupfer presented his fourth catwalk show yesterday, with a collection for spring and summer that has secured the approbation of buyers and press alike.

The London fashion week venue was unusual, a former church turned sports hall on a trading estate in west London, but it was packed to the rafters with the cream of the fashion crowd, and they did not leave disappointed.

Building on the success of last season, his collection had the usual Lupfer trademarks, supple leathers and bold graphics, but the overriding difference was a giant leap in confidence.

With a tight colour palette of black, cream, green, lilac and blue, he tipped his shallow brimmed trilby in a Mod direction once again.

Masculine leather jackets (with all important shoved-up sleeves) were worn with micro minis and mid-calf colourful boots.

The key print was Prince of Wales check on a cream base with red or blue.

The check was blown up for some bias cut silk dresses with draping cowl necks and floaty sleeves, and used in miniature on high button prim shirts matched with A-line skirts.

In true Lupfer style the check was then juxtaposed with differently weighted fabrics. A check blouse was worn with a pastel blue leather skirt that had ribbons of leather hanging from the waistband; and check trousers were worn with a light black lace top swathed in black and white feathers.

There was even a tribute to cowgirl - a check skirt studded with rhinestones.

Lupfer kept the emphasis on the hips, a trend already in evidence on many other catwalks this season. Bands of smocking adorned the backs of jackets and the bottoms of blouses, cinching them at hip level. Chunky leather belts wrapped skirts which themselves often featured a dropped peplum (waistband), again drawing attention to the hips.

Lupfer followed up last season's photo prints with a series of dresses and separates featuring a flock of birds taking off from water - herons or was it ducks? We could not decide, but my guess is that ducks are too downmarket for the fashion crowd. Then again ... maybe we are getting used to slumming it.

fields.headline: 'Precious time was passing us by'
fields.standfirst: Officers dismissed radar warning of Exocet attack on HMS Sheffield
fields.trailText: David Forster's story
fields.body:
David Forster's story

"As I was the long-distance air surveyor, I operated 1022 radar which covered 258 miles down to 18 miles radius from the ship. I was sitting at my display when a contact appeared at 180 miles. So I waited for the next sweep - and there it was again. I logged it into the computer and reported it as I'd done so many times before.

But this time [an officer] said there was nothing there. The next sweep of my radar came and there it was, now at 160 miles. I reported it again. But the same thing happened. Precious time was passing us by, we did not alert the fleet. We did nothing.

The next sweep of my radar, it was at 130 miles, so I reported it again. This time [the officer] became annoyed and told me 'You're chasing rabbits'. My mate now reported a contact at 120 miles and closing. I changed my display down to watch it closer. The contact was now at 80 miles and closing.

The radar swept again but this time there were two contacts. The second contact was only on our display for two sweeps when it disappeared under radar coverage. This indicated that we were dealing with an Exocet missile designed to skim above the waves. My mate and I reported the double contact and the fact that one had suddenly disappeared. [An officer] told us that we were 'riding a bike'.

Slowly the machines in the ops room began ticking away with the information that Sheffield had been hit. We were shocked with disbelief. An officer came up to us and began handing round sweets.

I should have stood up and shouted, 'There is a fucking contact, there's something coming in, believe me - alert the fleet'. I'll always punish myself in my conscience for not having done that. But you're trained to obey the chain of command regardless. It had been drummed into me."

Mark Booth's story

"I was sitting next to David. We were literally shoulder to shoulder. I knew him very well at the time. He was a very good radar operator.

He nudged me when the first contact came in. We already knew from a contact in Chile that the Argentinian aircraft had launched, so we were expecting something.

David was the very first person to see them. I saw them as clearly as he did. It is quite a disturbing thing to see an enemy aircraft approaching your ship. He was very nervous and could not speak, so I transmitted his message to the air picture supervisor. We definitely said that they were clear contacts.

What he says about the other contacts is correct. The screen giving the identification goes on to everybody's screen in the ops room. There was nothing more David could have done at all."

fields.headline: Legendary Sobers bats for auction
fields.trailText: The cricket bat with which Garry Sobers hit six sixes in an over is expected to fetch up to £45,000 at auction in Australia next month.
fields.body:
The cricket bat with which Garry Sobers hit six sixes in an over is expected to fetch up to £45,000 at auction in Australia next month.

The short-handle Slazenger was used by Sir Garry to make cricketing history on August 31, 1968, when he was playing for Nottinghamshire against Glamorgan at Swansea.

The bat, from Sir Garry's personal collection, is being sold at Christie's in Melbourne on October 4. It will be exhibited in London until then.

Also on offer will be the Gradidge bat with which he made the then world record test score of 365 not out against Pakistan in 1958. It is set to fetch up to £40,000, while a prototype "scooped" bat which he designed himself for hitting lofted boundary shots and low defensive drives could make £16,000.

Sir Garry, who was born in Barbados in 1936, was knighted in 1975 for his services to West Indies cricket.

webTitle: Chirac scandal drags in fashion king's name

fields.headline: Chirac scandal drags in fashion king's name
fields.standfirst: Urgent inquiry announced into corruption claims on tape held by ex-minister
fields.trailText: France's political elite was reeling yesterday after the highly damaging allegations of kickbacks centred on the president, Jacques Chirac, spread to embroil a former Socialist finance minister and dragged in the name of the celebratedfashion designer, Karl Lagerfeld.
fields.body:
France's political elite was reeling yesterday after the highly damaging allegations of kickbacks centred on the president, Jacques Chirac, spread to embroil a former Socialist finance minister and dragged in the name of the celebratedfashion designer, Karl Lagerfeld.

Dominique Strauss-Kahn, a leading ministerial light until forced by graft allegations to resign from Lionel Jospin's cabinet last year, admitted that for nearly two years he had been sitting on potentially devastating corruption evidence against Mr Chirac.

The disgraced former finance minister confirmed he had been given a now-infamous videotape last April in which Jean-Claude Méry, a property developer and senior official in Mr Chirac's RPR party, directly implicated the president in a vast covert fundraising operation.

Méry recorded the tape before dying of cancer last year. His lawyer gave the cassette to Mr Strauss-Kahn - apparently in the hope that as finance minister he would arrange a massive tax break for another of the lawyer's clients, the couturier Karl Lagerfeld.

Amid mounting suspicion in RPR ranks that the Socialist party was responsible for the release of the tape to French media last week, an embattled President Chirac immediately called for an investigation into "the possible involvement of Mr Strauss-Kahn in this very serious matter".

After a morning crisis meeting the prime minister, Mr Jospin, promised to hold a swift inquiry and said the finance ministry would hand over all relevant documents to magistrates later in the day. Mr Jospin is anxious to prevent any further fallout on his ruling coalition.

Mr Strauss-Kahn, a lawyer by training and a close friend of the prime minister, admitted he had received the original of the tape from Méry's counsel, Alain Belot, but denied he had ever watched it and claimed he did not even know where it was.

"I knew Belot as a tax lawyer and because he had worked with the parliament's tax committee," Mr Strauss-Kahn told Le Monde. "He gave me a tape and said: 'Have a look at that, it's interesting.' He said it was about illicit RPR fundraising at Paris town hall, but he never told me the president was implicated."

The former Socialist minister, already under investigation for alleged false accounting at his law firm, could now face charges of obstructing justice for having withheld the tape - especially as Mr Belot is reported to have told police that Mr Strauss-Kahn asked him last week not to reveal the fact that he had the tape.

Before his fall from grace, Mr Strauss-Kahn had been hotly tipped as the Socialist party's candidate for Paris mayor in next year's municipal election. The tape, detailing allegations of institutionalised RPR corruption at Paris town hall, would have been a powerful electoral asset.

Mr Lagerfeld's fashion house declined all comment on the story, but according to French media the couturier was indeed the subject of a big tax investigation and faced a £30m demand last year after it emerged he had not paid any tax in France for six years.

One paper said that he eventually paid just £5m, though there is no evidence that any special favour was granted by the authorities.

Mr Strauss-Kahn rejected all allegations of wrongdoing. He told French radio that he denied "all political connections that people are trying to make, as well as any connections with any tax dossier" involving Mr Lagerfeld.

The extraordinary tale of widespread corruption in high places began to emerge last week when Le Monde printed, in two consecutive issues over some six pages, the transcript of Méry's tape, which the businessman recorded in 1996 "in case anything happens to me".

He claimed that he was in charge of a many-tentacled system whereby construction companies paid big bribes to win maintenance, heating and other contracts for city-owned housing blocks while Mr Chirac was mayor of Paris.

The vast majority of the money, he said, went to Mr Chirac's RPR.

The allegations from beyond the grave, which dropped like a bombshell in Paris and were furiously denied by Mr Chirac, were the latest in a string of corruption accusations levelled against the president pertaining to the period from 1977 to 1995 when he was mayor.

webTitle: French poll sounds alarm to political elite

fields.headline: French poll sounds alarm to political elite
fields.trailText: A record abstention rate in a referendum on shortening the presidential term has sent a strong signal to the political establishment that it is out of touch with people's concerns, analysts said yesterday.
fields.body:
A record abstention rate in a referendum on shortening the presidential term has sent a strong signal to the political establishment that it is out of touch with people's concerns, analysts said yesterday.

Almost 70% of the French electorate failed to vote in Sunday's referendum on whether to cut the head of state's time in office from seven to five years, aligning it with the parliamentary term and with most of Europe.

The change was approved by 73% of those who bothered to vote, but it was the abstention rate - the highest in the nine referendums held during the fifth republic - that grabbed the headlines.

"A little Yes, but a big slapdown," was the verdict of Le Parisien, while Libération and France Soir referred to "the vote strike" and the conservative Le Figaro called the poll "a huge political and symbolic failure".

Most commentators agreed on the value of the reform. The presidential mandate was out of synch with parliament's five-year term, leading to paralysing "cohabitations" between presidents and prime ministers of different political persuasions that block real institutional change.

"Today, it's clear that the path towards reform of our institutions is open," said Dominique Chagnollaud, a constitutional law professor. "No matter who is elected president in 2002, he will not be able to avoid far-reaching institutional reform."

But many criticised the method President Jacques Chirac chose to ratify the reform. France's constitution can be changed by a special joint congress of the upper and lower houses of parliament, and putting such an arcane issue to the people was, analysts said, inappropriate.

But the main reason for the indifference was that most French people are more concerned by practical issues such as soaring petrol prices, their heavy tax burden, and the current corruption saga tainting many in the political class.

fields.headline: Sharks kill two off Australia
fields.trailText: A 17-year-old surfer was killed by a shark yesterday, in the second fatal attack within 36 hours on the south coast of Australia.
fields.body:
A 17-year-old surfer was killed by a shark yesterday, in the second fatal attack within 36 hours on the south coast of Australia.

A shark was reportedly seen circling three surfers before picking off the teenager at Black Point, near Elliston, 280 miles west of Adelaide. Police confirmed that the unnamed surfer's board was later washed up on the shore, but his body had yet to be recovered.

On Sunday morning, 25-year-old New Zealand tourist Cameron Bayes was hauled from his surfboard and killed by a four-metre great white shark at Cactus Beach, 140 miles west of yesterday's attack. Bayes had been on his honeymoon.

South Australia shark expert Rodney Fox said that the timing of the two attacks was coincidental. "It is pretty horrifying to have two deaths in two days, but I don't believe that a shark that has eaten somebody would swim 230km," he told ABC news.

Divers with sonar devices designed to repel shark attacks were deployed in Sydney harbour last week when Olympic triathletes took to the water. While there are frequent sightings of sharks around the bay, there has not been a fatal attack in the harbour since 1963.

According to shark statisticians, there were nine fatal shark attacks off the Australian coast in the 10 years leading up to the latest deaths.

The great white shark is an endangered species in Australia. But despite a decline in numbers of the great white, demonised by the Jaws films, there has been an increase in shark attacks during the last two decades.

Experts blame the rise on the fact that more people are taking up water pursuits such as surfing and scuba diving, and point out that, in Australia, more people still die from bee stings than from shark attacks.

webTitle: Laporte offloads £810m worth of offshoots to US buyer

fields.headline: Laporte offloads £810m worth of offshoots to US buyer
fields.trailText: Chemicals group Laporte is to reformulate itself into a specialist maker of organic materials, by selling its pigments, additives, electronics and water technology businesses for £810m to the US private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.
fields.body:
Chemicals group Laporte is to reformulate itself into a specialist maker of organic materials, by selling its pigments, additives, electronics and water technology businesses for £810m to the US private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

The businesses changing hands include operations which make chemicals for separating the stripes in toothpaste, keeping Coca-Cola fizzy and adding colour to US dollar bills. The clear-out halves the size of the group, disposing of 20 sites in 15 countries employing 3,000 people.

Laporte's chief executive, Jim Leng, said that the group's disappointing recent share price meant it had been unable to make acquisitions to grow the businesses: "All the things we're selling are great businesses but they will want acquisitions. If you can't use your equity to make acquisitions, you can't support them."

He wants to concentrate on manufacturing speciality organics - in particular, supplying bespoke chemicals for pharmaceuticals companies to use in new drugs.

The deal completes Mr Leng's slimming down of Laporte. When he arrived in 1985, the group was highly diversified, having bought 114 businesses in ten years. Mr Leng, 54, intends to take a backseat role later this year. He will replace non-executive chairman George Duncan, who is retiring, and the group will appoint a new chief executive.

Laporte will return £200m to shareholders after the transaction. The shares, which reached 850p two years ago, jumped 75.25p to 500p.

The group intends to add to but more speciality organics operations. Mr Leng said: "Conservatively, we could spend a quarter of a billion pounds."

Analysts said the clear-out makes Laporte vulnerable to a takeover. Peter Clark of SBC Warburg said that Clariant, Dow Chemical, Lonza and Degussa were potential bidders.

Talks with Swiss group Clariant, which offered 800p a share, collapsed last year.

fields.headline: Angrey TV firms unplug Delhi
fields.trailText: Cable operators in India last night blacked out TV screens in almost 1m homes in protest at a new broadcasting law which holds them directly responsible for showing adult programmes, and for screening advertisements for beer and cigarettes.
fields.body:
Cable operators in India last night blacked out TV screens in almost 1m homes in protest at a new broadcasting law which holds them directly responsible for showing adult programmes, and for screening advertisements for beer and cigarettes.

The operators say it is "ridiculous" to blame them for the contents of India's mostly mediocre 70 TV channels and claim it is the broadcasters who should be the target of government legislation.

The strike, which is set to go on for three days, has so far only affected Delhi, completely wiping out coverage of the Olympics and all state-run channels.

"So far we have only hit Delhi. But unless the government wakes up soon and does something about the law the strike will spread to Bombay and across the country," Vikki Chowdhry, of the Cable TV Operators United Front said last night. "We are not responsible for what is on TV. The government must scrap this lopsided legislation."

There was confusion in gov ernment circles as to what, exactly, would fall foul of the new cable network act. By western standards, Indian TV is remarkably chaste with no full frontal nudity and not much kissing. The country's most risque channel is Fashion TV, which shows models gliding down the catwalk, while Indian actresses are required to do nothing more suggestive in Hindi movies than to gyrate in the obligatory wet sari scene.

Under the new legislation cable operators will receive a warning if they are deemed to be transmitting obscene material. They then face arrest if they repeat the offence. Delhi's police chief Dr K K Paul, yesterday claimed that certain operators were flouting the rules by transmitting pornography in the early hours of the morning. "If they are as clean as they say they are, then why are they going ahead with the strike?" he asked.

The law which came into effect two weeks ago has attracted the wrath of India's tobacco advertisers who say they spend only 1% of funds on TV ads. The industry claims that such adverts are shown at times when children are unlikely to be watching. The law's only immediate casualty appears to be adverts for Kingfisher, one of India's most popular beers, which have now been pulled.

India's broadcasting minister, Arun Jaitley, has defended the new act, which comes amid wider moves to liberalise Indian TV, including a decision two months ago allowing foreign companies to broadcast to India via cable for the first time.

"We are a liberal society. We will ban cable operators only in the rarest of rare cases. Power to ban any channel is only with central government," Mr Jaitley insisted.

But under the new, more stringent rules shows deemed to be adult, previously only broadcast between 11pm and6am, have been banned completely. "All programmes will now have to be in conformity with the code prescribing norms of decency, morality and national security," a government spokesman said. An estimated 50m Indians own TV sets, with another 100m believed to have access to television.
fields.bodyText: Cable operators in India last night blacked out TV screens in almost 1m homes in protest at a new broadcasting law which holds them directly responsible for showing adult programmes, and for screening advertisements for beer and cigarettes. The operators say it is "ridiculous" to blame them for the contents of India's mostly mediocre 70 TV channels and claim it is the broadcasters who should be the target of government legislation. The strike, which is set to go on for three days, has so far only affected Delhi, completely wiping out coverage of the Olympics and all state-run channels. "So far we have only hit Delhi. But unless the government wakes up soon and does something about the law the strike will spread to Bombay and across the country," Vikki Chowdhry, of the Cable TV Operators United Front said last night. "We are not responsible for what is on TV. The government must scrap this lopsided legislation." There was confusion in gov ernment circles as to what, exactly, would fall foul of the new cable network act. By western standards, Indian TV is remarkably chaste with no full frontal nudity and not much kissing. The country's most risque channel is Fashion TV, which shows models gliding down the catwalk, while Indian actresses are required to do nothing more suggestive in Hindi movies than to gyrate in the obligatory wet sari scene. Under the new legislation cable operators will receive a warning if they are deemed to be transmitting obscene material. They then face arrest if they repeat the offence. Delhi's police chief Dr K K Paul, yesterday claimed that certain operators were flouting the rules by transmitting pornography in the early hours of the morning. "If they are as clean as they say they are, then why are they going ahead with the strike?" he asked. The law which came into effect two weeks ago has attracted the wrath of India's tobacco advertisers who say they spend only 1% of funds on TV ads. The industry claims that such adverts are shown at times when children are unlikely to be watching. The law's only immediate casualty appears to be adverts for Kingfisher, one of India's most popular beers, which have now been pulled. India's broadcasting minister, Arun Jaitley, has defended the new act, which comes amid wider moves to liberalise Indian TV, including a decision two months ago allowing foreign companies to broadcast to India via cable for the first time. "We are a liberal society. We will ban cable operators only in the rarest of rare cases. Power to ban any channel is only with central government," Mr Jaitley insisted. But under the new, more stringent rules shows deemed to be adult, previously only broadcast between 11pm and6am, have been banned completely. "All programmes will now have to be in conformity with the code prescribing norms of decency, morality and national security," a government spokesman said. An estimated 50m Indians own TV sets, with another 100m believed to have access to television.

fields.headline: Maritime simulator opens on Merseyside
fields.trailText: HMS Anon, an unnamed 4,000-tonne destroyer, hurtled past Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty at 32 knots and set course to ram-raid the twin towers of the World Trade Center on Manhattan Island.
fields.body:
HMS Anon, an unnamed 4,000-tonne destroyer, hurtled past Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty at 32 knots and set course to ram-raid the twin towers of the World Trade Center on Manhattan Island.

The fog came down over New York and the captain did a stomach-churning swerve in a rolling 10ft sea to avoid a buoy. Then he slid the vessel, which had by this time metamorphosed into a 30,000-tonne container ship, deftly between a couple of other boats and made full speed backwards.

Earlier, without leaving his berth in a factory unit on a Birkenhead industrial estate, the skipper had taken the same container ship on a run down the misty Mersey (Eastham docks to port, Liverpool's twin cathedrals to starboard) and past the Pier Head. Night fell, lights twinkled and the vessel snuggled through Gladstone Lock and into Seaforth docks.

So ended the sea trials of a £1.6m maritime equivalent of a flight simulator installed by Liverpool's John Moores University next to the Cammell Laird shipyard.

It is Britain's first ship simulator with a full 360 degree field of vision, which enables learner drivers to check whether the back end of the boat is smacking into the dock when they make a tight turn.

Chief mates, master and marine pilots keen to improve their skills stand in a five-tonne replica of ship's bridge, complete with charts and radar screens, and are required to cope with all the perils of the sea: 100 knot gales, tide changes, engine failure, instrument breakdown.

"If you had wanted to, could you have rammed that other ship?" someone asked Bert Kunze, director of the Lairdside Maritime Centre where the simulator is housed. "Yes, but that's not the object of the exercise," he replied. "If I had, the image would have shaken a bit. But no bits of metal would have fallen off and we have no collision sound effects.

"The object is to allow mariners to practise their skills in a safe environment. If they run aground here, there is no harm done to the ship - and no pollution."

Twelve video projectors and computer graphics can create a variety of port land and seascapes, including Felixstowe and the ship-packed English Channel, and changing conditions are used to test the team work of crews.

"In any group, one or two people will treat it as a joke," added Mr Kunze. "But after a couple of minutes, they forget the jokes and really get into it because it feels so much like the real thing.

"Ships loom suddenly out of the fog as in real life and it's interesting to hear the comments of the students. Usually it's an expletive followed by a large helm order."

fields.headline: Walken, the mild side
fields.standfirst: He's one of Hollywood's weirdest actors. He plays psycho killers, demented gangsters and headless ghosts. And now he's got this great idea for... a cookery show.  Damon Wise reports on the double life of Christopher Walken
fields.trailText: He's one of Hollywood's weirdest actors. He plays psycho killers, demented gangsters and headless ghosts. And now he's got this great idea for... a cookery show. Damon Wise reports on the double life of Christopher Walken
fields.body:
The last time UK cinemagoers saw Christopher Walken, he was rampaging round a late 19th-century American town, wielding a sword and butchering the locals. His dialogue was minimal but effective - "GnnnnrraaaaaGGGhhh! NnnnraaAAAAaaggghhh!!!" - as he hacked his way through Tim Burton's Hammer tribute Sleepy Hollow.

Which is no surprise. Measured by his screen persona, the 57-year-old actor is anything but normal. Take the wheelchair-ridden Man With The Plan in Things To Do In Denver When You're Dead, or the psychotic mob boss Vincenzo Coccotti in True Romance. Indeed, many thought his performance as the demented Frank White in the super-violent gangster flick King Of New York was his most extreme - until last year's Wildside showed him whipping his chauffeur with his underpants while attempting to sodomise him at gunpoint.

Recently, however, Walken went even further when he came up with an idea for a TV show that was so far out, nobody would touch it. MTV said no, Bravo said no. The Comedy Channel said no. So what was so dangerous about this show? Was it America's Best-Loved Serial Killers? How To Raise The Dead? The Murder Roadshow? No, Walken simply wanted his own cookery programme.

"It was either 10 or 12 segments," he recently told the New York Observer. "I can't remember. I was going to have some sort of kitchen set-up. I wanted it to be a little like Pee-Wee's Playhouse. I love that show. And I would have maybe a showgirl, you know, with a little thing on, chopping my vegetables. Maybe some musicians. And an audience. Some people to talk to."

If this seems a little unusual, perhaps some perspective is required here. Walken's father, 97, is a German immigrant who ran a bakery in the New York suburb of Queens. Walken was considering joining the family business and often worked for his father, putting the jam in doughnuts, but a shambolic stint as a delivery boy convinced him otherwise.

Today, cooking remains one of Walken's private hobbies, and he rarely eats out. "I'm amazed people let total strangers mess around with their food," he once said. "When I cook for myself, I know what I'm getting. I use good stuff. I'm not a great chef, I don't have a repertoire, but if you buy the right things and cook them very simply it has to be good."

Since his breakthrough performance in the harrowing 1978 Vietnam drama The Deer Hunter, Walken has led something of a double life. While his screen roles become all the more bizarre, his home life seems all the more normal. Not many people know, for example, that his real name is Ronnie, and that he trained as a dancer in stage school. The name change was suggested by a Belgian songstress, who hired Walken as part of a trio of backing singers/hoofers in her nightclub act. "You know," she told him, "I don't really like 'Ronnie'. I think you're more 'Christopher'. Do you mind if I call you Christopher?" Walken said, "Call me anything you like, just don't call me late for lunch."

As a child, Walken and his brother did modelling and advertising work, and at the age of 10 he would get the subway to Manhattan with his brother and hang around the TV studios. He appeared in the background of many family TV shows, such as The Colgate Comedy Hour, and one of his fondest memories is taking part in a sketch with Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis. As a teenager, he pursued a song and dance career, and it was during a 60s production of West Side Story that he met his future wife, Georgianne. They married in 1969, and the pair have been together ever since, sharing their small farmstead a few hours outside New York City with their cats.

Indeed, it wasn't until 1977, some 30 years into his career, that Walken began to be considered a menacing movie presence, when he landed a small but memorable part as Annie Hall's death-obsessed brother Duane in Woody Allen's hit movie. Duane opened the floodgates, and nowadays, anything goes. In the last 20 years, Walken's fans have seen him causing metaphysical carnage as the angel Gabriel (Prophecy parts l and II) and disco-dancing with aliens after receiving an anal probe (Communion). Strangely, however, these people can't imagine Christopher Walken sitting at home, stroking the cats, dancing with his wife or whipping up a tasty pasta sauce.

"If I wasn't so lazy, I'll tell you what I would do," he told the NY Observer. "I saw this thing on television. This whole thing with people putting cameras in their house, for the net. I thought I'd get a couple of those cameras and put them in my kitchen and just, you know, turn it on whenever I felt like it. Maybe I would have a particular time of day I would do it, or something like that. And to make it amusing, I thought I would have a hotline - you know, a red telephone. And they could call and I could give them advice about their love life...

"You remember a programme called This Is Your Life? I thought I'd have a curtain over to one side and once in a while I'd have a mystery guest. You know, actors are always coming over to my house. Maybe Joe Pesci comes over and makes his tomato sauce. Everybody makes something, you know what I mean? Don't you think that might be amusing?"

Whatever you say, Mr Walken.

fields.headline: The best cinema scene
fields.standfirst: Scary movie
fields.trailText: Scary movie
fields.body:
A darkened cinema. After her boyfriend leaves to use the bathroom, Brenda (Regina Hall) sits alone watching Shakespeare In Love, surrounded by fellow paying customers. Munching her way through an enormous tub of popcorn, she rests her feet on top of the chair above.

"Woohoo!" she bellows. "I'm gonna have a heart attack. Oh, I am scared !"

A man in a bow tie turns to her disapprovingly.

"Excuse me."

Brenda pouts back.

"I think I paid my money like everybody else up in here."

Rummaging in her bag, she produces a video camera and begins taping the film.

"Mmm-hmm! Brad Pitt's ex-girlfriend is a freak!"

The man sitting behind her leans forward.

"Will you shut up?"

Outraged, Brenda spinsround, pointing the camera at the man.

"Oh yeah, I got you. I got you on camera. You're on candid camera now."

On-screen, Gwyneth Paltrow appears in drag.

"That ain't no man," Brenda yells. "Look right there, it's coming out."

The woman in front turns round.

"Do you mind?"

"I know you'd better get out of my face."

She holds a finger up to the woman. "Outta my face! Outta my face!" A mobile phone starts to ring. The entire audience groans in unison. Brenda searches through her bag, then retrieves her phone.

"Hello?"

See also: An American Werewolf In London, Gremlins, The Player

Don't see also: Another 48 Hours

Pointless trivia: Scary Movie and Shakespeare In Love were released through the same production company, Bob and Harvey Weinstein's Miramax.
